webTitle: Savage with a dash of flash

fields.headline: Savage with a dash of flash
fields.standfirst: Leicester's midfielder tries to rise above his name
fields.trailText: Roy Collins talks to Robbie Savage, the Leicester stalwart, as his club prepare to take on Chelsea for the FA Cup.
fields.body:
English visitors to Wrexham are accustomed to the feeling that indigenous folk in pubs and restaurants are making disparaging remarks behind their backs. But it is not something you expect when, like Robbie Savage, you are a local boy with a Welsh-speaking dad and have worn the red dragon on your chest.

When you are brought up a Savage, however, it is not just headline writers who are unable to resist every opportunity to make a connection between name and nature. And if a few dodgy tackles on the football field have convinced some fans that he is the anti-Christ, Wrexham's less successful sons like to assuage their jealousy by portraying him as a typically flash footballer.

Savage, 25, says: "It's really sad because when I go back, I see all the same friends I had at school. Yet people want to believe the worst of me and it means I don't want to go home as much. The Wrexham fans even booed me when I played at the Racecourse Ground for Crewe." His Leicester manager Martin O'Neill believes his physical appearance encourages detractors to jump to instant, erroneous conclusions - the beach-blond hair, the designer sideburns and a suntan that is as permanent as Liz Hurley's.

Even O'Neill admits a prejudice saying: "He looks like he should be surfing in California and if there is one thing that annoys me about him, it's that tan. I know he hasn't been to Barbados because we haven't played there lately, so he must have been on the sunbed. As we approach February, I like players to have that drained, pale look that I've always had at this stage of the season."

In an incestuous world like football, people form indelible value judgments about you on the flimsiest of evidence. Savage names three incidents: his part in the sending off of Justin Edinburgh in last season's Worthington Cup final which enraged Tottenham's players and fans; his challenge on Arsenal's Nwanko Kanu during this month's FA Cup tie; and his naivety in throwing down a shirt with Paolo Maldini's name on it before Wales played Italy, which led to him being sacked from, then recalled to, the national squad.

Airing the name of Savage in front of Totttenham supporters provokes the same reaction as waving an Arsenal scarf in their faces. Yet he insists he is not a dirty player and learned to tackle only after joining Leicester. Perhaps that is part of the problem as he explains: "At Crewe I played in midfield, just in front of the back four, and my job was to get the ball and give it to Danny Murphy, who could really play."

His manager, who often forgets to remove his tongue from his cheek before speaking, says that all he lacks as a footballer is ability. "He will never be able to pass a ball like Garry Parker did for us a few years back and he hasn't got electrifying pace." Neither, adds O'Neill, does he make mazy, nor even Muzzy Izzet dribbles, but "he is improving as a player and he has galvanised us a couple of times when the team were on their knees. He has become an integral part of the side."

Savage claims to have learned everything from O'Neill, even, it would seem, the timing of a punchline. Having played as wing-back in the first 14 games of last season, he was horrified when Leicester bought Andy Impey to play in his position. "I wasn't happy but I am not a quitter and I believed there was room for both of us in the side. Now I tell the gaffer Impey's the best buy he ever made."

Savage's self-deprecatory humour makes it difficult to view him as one of the game's bad boys. And though he appeared to have been born with a silver spoon in his mouth when he joined Manchester United and played alongside David Beckham, Paul Scholes and Ryan Giggs in the side that won the FA Youth Cup, it quickly rusted in his jaws.

Having played in every round of the Youth Cup, he was dropped to make way for Giggs in the final. A year later, when Alex Ferguson delivered the cruellest euphemism in football, telling Savage he was "letting him go", he added that he was certain he would make it elsewhere.

Savage's head, though, was full of confusion as he drove home to Wales and he was unable to find the words to tell his parents. "I went out with a mate to play snooker while I thought of how to tell them. But my mind must have been wandering and I crashed the car. I woke up in hospital to find mum and dad there and told them then."

Savage will be snapping at the heels of Chelsea's expensive foreigners in tomorrow's fifth-round FA Cup tie but the way he talks about them, like a star-struck fan, seems to make a myth of the flash theory.

He says: "When we played at Stamford Bridge the other week, it was George Weah's first full game and it was fantastic to be on the same pitch. Chelsea have got him and players like Marcel Desailly and I am just from a small town like Wrexham." A town, sadly, where for Savage they keep the sort of welcome usually reserved for Englishmen.

webTitle: Logical choice for a club full of surprises

fields.headline: Logical choice for a club full of surprises
fields.trailText: There is a certain logic in Glenn Hoddle becoming a Saint. That is often the way with martyrs, and this appears to be how Hoddle still sees himself a year after his comments on reincarnation and the disabled forced him out of the England job.
fields.body:
There is a certain logic in Glenn Hoddle becoming a Saint. That is often the way with martyrs, and this appears to be how Hoddle still sees himself a year after his comments on reincarnation and the disabled forced him out of the England job.

There was little doubt that he would return to football eventually but his re-emergence more than halfway through the season and with a club struggling to stay in the Premier League is as surprising as it has been sudden. It was thought he would go abroad; instead he is barely an hour from home.

Then again, Southampton always did have a knack of pulling rabbits from hats. Lawrie McMenemy did as much in 1980 when, with a crowd of reporters assuming they had been assembled in order to welcome Alan Ball, in walked Kevin Keegan.

Southampton's present circumstances are less sanguine. Having survived last season after winning only two of their first 17 matches they are again heading for trouble after six defeats in nine league games.

The board has acted now to avoid being placed in an even more difficult situation with regard to Dave Jones, their manager since the summer of 1997. Once the date for Jones's trial on 17 charges of child abuse had been set for November 27 the directors had to safeguard the interests of the club without making it appear that they were prejudging the case.

Hence Jones's 12 months' leave of absence to allow him to concentrate wholly on preparing his defence. Thus, for a second time, Hoddle has found a vacancy because the previous incumbent needed more time with his lawyers.

To survive, Southampton need to average roughly a point a match for the rest of the season. That is Hoddle's challenge and he will have little time to impose his own style and football beliefs on the players. No doubt a posse of reporters and photographers will be on hand in case Hoddle's other beliefs again intrude on the job in hand.

Yesterday Hoddle insisted that he had been misquoted over remarks which were taken to mean he believed that the disabled were being punished for sins in a previous life. At the time he said he had been "misconstrued", "misinterpreted", and "misunderstood". Either way he would be wise from now on to keep his beliefs to himself and Eileen Drewery, his faith-healing friend, away from football.

Hoddle's immediate task at the Dell, from which Southampton will hope to move to a new stadium sooner rather than later, will be to come to terms with the local icon, Matthew le Tissier, whose absence from the side this season led to supporters becoming increasingly disaffected with Jones.

As England coach, Hoddle was ambivalent where Le Tissier was concerned, picking him for a World Cup qualifier against Italy in February 1997, when a 1-0 defeat at Wembley threatened the team's chances of reaching France the following year, but ignoring the player for the tournament proper after he had scored a hat-trick in a B game against Russia.

Whatever happens, Hoddle and his assistant, John Gorman, will strive to place the emphasis on possession and good passing in an effort to get Southampton back up the table. At 41, Hoddle has time on his side. He was a success at Swindon, where he first went into management, and hardly failed with Chelsea.

Now much will depend not so much on how much he has learned from experience but the extent to which he is prepared to admit he has made mistakes; apart, that is, from not taking Drewery to the last World Cup.

webTitle: Hoddle's suspect spirit could return to haunt Saints

fields.headline: Hoddle's suspect spirit could return to haunt Saints
fields.standfirst: Jim White has a look at the wider, weirder world of sport
fields.trailText: All Southampton need to do now is invite Will Carling and James Hewitt along for the ride and they will have the complete set of modern pariahs on their books.
fields.body:
Eileen Drewery presumably told him it was going to happen, but for the rest of us the announcement that Glenn Hoddle has been put in temporary charge of Southampton came as a surprise.

It was not so much the granting of gardening leave to Dave Jones that was a shock. A manager on charges of indecency is about as damaging to a football club's image as it gets. And since Jones is not conspicuously successful at the moment, his impending trial has given the board the opportunity to try a new approach. In fact, it is not too far-fetched to suggest it is probably only the moral implications of removing a man yet to be proven guilty that prevented him from being sacked.

But to bring in Hoddle, even on a temporary brief, seems a big risk. It was only this time last year that Hoddle was in disgrace, hounded out of office because of his ill-judged remarks about the disabled. All they need to do is invite Will Carling and James Hewitt along for the ride and Southampton will have the complete set of modern pariahs on their books.

To be fair, the Southampton board might argue that despite the blip in results which preceded his departure from the England job, Hoddle's managerial record is sound. He did well at Swindon, kick-started the Chelsea revolution, and there are nostalgics who look back on the way he led England through qualification for France 98 at a time when the national team at least had tactical coherence.

But it is his reputation rather than his record that is Hoddle's achilles heel. Despite what outsiders might imagine, it is not so much his mish-mash of spiritual doctrines and misplaced enthusiasm for Mrs Drewery that count against him among players.

No, the Hoddle problem is more down-to-earth: latterly he lost the respect of his dressing room because of poor man-management. The England camp was constantly leaking stories of his aloofness, inability to articulate and insistence on blaming anyone but himself for defeats. It was revealing that not one player stood up for him publicly after his humiliation.

It is behaviour like that - rather than attributing the striker's barren run to bad feng shui in the east stand - which will quickly lose the confidence of the players. And, at the moment, the last thing a team as demoralised as Southampton can afford to lose is confidence.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Trivia may do more for your weekend laughs than 16 pints of lager.
fields.body:
Hats off to Andy Cole, Alan Shearer and Michael Owen, voted the three best players in the world in Fifa's recent poll. Well, at least they were by the Laos Under-20 coach Soutskhone Oudompet, the only one of 140 national-team coaches to vote exclusively for English players. There were other idiosyncratic choices: Bolivia's Manuel Reinaldo Bilches clearly hasn't seen Paulo Wanchope in action for a while. It also revealed the whereabouts of some forgotten characters. Willie McFaul, the former Newcastle United goalkeeper and manager, for example, is masterminding Guam's assault on the heights of world football. And Burma are the latest to grapple with the prose of the former Lincoln City manager Colin Murphy. If that doesn't make them clean up their human rights record, nothing will.

 Quoting Murphy's programme notes is usually the last resort of the desperate football diarist, but the publication of a new history of Lincoln City makes it almost topical. Brian Halford's Past Imperfect takes Murphy's words as its guiding text: "You, me, we all of us have been forced to breakfast on travesty, lunch on objection and insult, dine on inflicted pressure," the former City boss mused. Past Imperfect is a fine title, but Breakfasting On Travesty might have captured the essence of the Imps even better.

Let's hope Soutskhone Oudompet wasn't watching Sky Digital's coverage of Manchester United v Arsenal on Monday night, which offered subscribers the chance to follow one player for 15 minutes at a time. One drawback became obvious when viewers watching Roy Keane found themselves lip-reading a mouthful of obscenities when Arsenal scored. Another, which would have disappointed Soutskhone, was that Andy Cole, picked as the next player in focus, was promptly substituted. Close-up footage of the pride of Laos donning his tracksuit: another coup for the digital revolution.

The Cyprus FA is trawling the world for top-quality players qualified to represent the island. According to the French paper L'Equipe, the first two targets are Leicester City's Muzzy Izzet, whose Turkish background seems to make him a candidate, and the Watford teenager James Panayi. Look out world.

The Diary's own performance-of-the-week award goes to Jack Lester, the Grimsby Town striker who has moved to Nottingham Forest. Lester took the trouble to post a message on a Grimsby internet mailing list, which read in part: "I decided to send this message because I didn't just want to drift away without acknowledging the tremendous support I have had at Grimsby from the club, the management, the players, the other staff, the local press and radio, and of course the fans. Everyone has been an inspiration, in good times and bad."

David Beckham is a huge animal, worth around £500. But don't take our word for it, that's the view of his owner, Jessica Healey of Wedmore in Somerset, who is selling her herd of beef calves, all named after Old Trafford stars, for slaughter. Bye bye David.

webTitle: Beckham will never have the talent of Best, but he has time on his side

fields.headline: Beckham will never have the talent of Best, but he has time on his side
fields.trailText: To a large extent comparing Beckham with Best is an idle exercise. A more valid comparison lies between Best and Ryan Giggs.
fields.body:
Some footballers simply refuse to go quietly. Amid the dumbfounded silence which greeted his award of an MBE in the new year's honours list, Ian Wright might have chosen the moment to retire while he was in favour. Instead, he has landed himself in yet more trouble with referees.

Wright's gong recalls Tony Hancock's response to the Australian Bill Kerr's boast that he was an OBE - Order of the British Empire. "Bill," said Hancock, "You were ordered OUT of the British Empire!"

George Best's football career ended nearly a quarter of a century ago but the name still carries charismatic undertones. So when he declares David Beckham an overrated talent there are those prepared to take him seriously enough to debate the point.

The reality is that Best has joined the ranks of the game's barrel-preachers, a harmless enough occupation but not one noted for its profundity. Nevertheless, when he says that one of his more vaunted successors at Manchester United cannot tackle, kick with his left foot or head the ball, and does not score enough goals, the criticism is hard to ignore.

Best appeared in 361 league matches for United and scored 137 goals. So far Beckham has played in 160 Premiership games and found the net 29 times. Beckham has won three championship medals to Best's two and both appeared in a European Cup-winning side. But time is on Beckham's side.

To a large extent comparing Beckham with Best is an idle exercise, since there is little common ground to be found in the functions they have performed for their respective United teams. A more valid comparison lies between Best and Ryan Giggs.

Yet Best surely cannot be allowed to get away with the manifestly unjust accusation that Beckham cannot tackle. In fact his willingness to put himself about defensively and the regularity with which he steals possession from opponents deep in his own half has been one of the biggest improvements in his game.

True, Beckham's right foot is his principal strength, just as the principal role of the right foot of Ferenc Puskas was to stop the great Hungarian falling over. It is difficult to recall Puskas ever receiving criticism for being one-footed since his left was so lethal. The same should go for Beckham.

Cannot head the ball? How many wingers have ever been strong in the air? Best could nod in the odd goal and the diving headers of Tottenham's Cliff Jones remain vivid in the memory but neither player was a target figure.

Beckham's recent lack of goals (none in the league so far this season) has been the subject of critical comment but his main use to United is as a provider, not a finisher. The English game has seen few such accomplished crossers of the ball from the right wing since the retirement of Sir Stanley Matthews.

Matthews's football had an athletic quality which Beckham shares in part, the main difference being that the United player does not have the acceleration which enabled Stan to leave a defender behind once he was beaten. Then again, few of even Matthews's centres combined accuracy with speed in the manner of Beckham.

This is what makes him unusual. The ball is whipped in at such a pace and with such an assured sense of direction that defenders barely have time to react before Dwight Yorke, Andy Cole or Roy Keane is rising above them to meet it.

Beckham is not the outstanding individual talent that Best was and he never will be. But for an accident of birth which effectively prevented him from appearing in the latter stages of a World Cup, Best would now be ranked with Pele, Johan Cruyff and Diego Maradona.

Best, moreover, became a supreme entertainer at a time in the English game when skilful players did not receive the protection from referees that they do now. He was frequently hacked at from behind and taken instead of the ball. Best also had to slog through the sort of mid-winter mud-heaps of pitches which are seldom seen now, although such conditions did give him an edge when it came to turning opponents.

Football would welcome a George Best in any age. Certainly the modern United team, in which passing, movement and teamwork are a religion, would be able to accommodate his individualism just as it did the gifted eccentricities of Eric Cantona.

Yet Beckham is as integral a part of the United of today as was Best in the 60s and in one respect he is his equal. For just as the off-field life of George Best filled the news pages then so do the extra-mural activities of Beckham.

The loves and leavings of Best, however, made far better stories. Apart from some bizarre fashion habits, Beckham, happily married with a young son, is thoroughly conventional by comparison.

The amount of attention paid to Beckham and his pop star wife is more reflective of the media vacuum left by the death of Princess Diana than anything else.

Those who saw George Best play can excuse the misguided meanderings of a middle-aged man. But Beckham was only two when Best last appeared for United.

The reality is that Best has joined the ranks of the game's barrel-preachers, a harmless enough occupation but not one noted for its profundity. Nevertheless, when he says that one of his more vaunted successors at Manchester United cannot tackle, kick with his left foot or head the ball, and does not score enough goals, the criticism is hard to ignore. Best appeared in 361 league matches for United and scored 137 goals. So far Beckham has played in 160 Premiership games and found the net 29 times. Beckham has won three championship medals to Best's two and both appeared in a European Cup-winning side. But time is on Beckham's side. To a large extent comparing Beckham with Best is an idle exercise, since there is little common ground to be found in the functions they have performed for their respective United teams. A more valid comparison lies between Best and Ryan Giggs. Yet Best surely cannot be allowed to get away with the manifestly unjust accusation that Beckham cannot tackle. In fact his willingness to put himself about defensively and the regularity with which he steals possession from opponents deep in his own half has been one of the biggest improvements in his game. True, Beckham's right foot is his principal strength, just as the principal role of the right foot of Ferenc Puskas was to stop the great Hungarian falling over. It is difficult to recall Puskas ever receiving criticism for being one-footed since his left was so lethal. The same should go for Beckham. Cannot head the ball? How many wingers have ever been strong in the air? Best could nod in the odd goal and the diving headers of Tottenham's Cliff Jones remain vivid in the memory but neither player was a target figure. Beckham's recent lack of goals (none in the league so far this season) has been the subject of critical comment but his main use to United is as a provider, not a finisher. The English game has seen few such accomplished crossers of the ball from the right wing since the retirement of Sir Stanley Matthews. Matthews's football had an athletic quality which Beckham shares in part, the main difference being that the United player does not have the acceleration which enabled Stan to leave a defender behind once he was beaten. Then again, few of even Matthews's centres combined accuracy with speed in the manner of Beckham. This is what makes him unusual. The ball is whipped in at such a pace and with such an assured sense of direction that defenders barely have time to react before Dwight Yorke, Andy Cole or Roy Keane is rising above them to meet it. Beckham is not the outstanding individual talent that Best was and he never will be. But for an accident of birth which effectively prevented him from appearing in the latter stages of a World Cup, Best would now be ranked with Pele, Johan Cruyff and Diego Maradona. Best, moreover, became a supreme entertainer at a time in the English game when skilful players did not receive the protection from referees that they do now. He was frequently hacked at from behind and taken instead of the ball. Best also had to slog through the sort of mid-winter mud-heaps of pitches which are seldom seen now, although such conditions did give him an edge when it came to turning opponents. Football would welcome a George Best in any age. Certainly the modern United team, in which passing, movement and teamwork are a religion, would be able to accommodate his individualism just as it did the gifted eccentricities of Eric Cantona. Yet Beckham is as integral a part of the United of today as was Best in the 60s and in one respect he is his equal. For just as the off-field life of George Best filled the news pages then so do the extra-mural activities of Beckham. The loves and leavings of Best, however, made far better stories. Apart from some bizarre fashion habits, Beckham, happily married with a young son, is thoroughly conventional by comparison. The amount of attention paid to Beckham and his pop star wife is more reflective of the media vacuum left by the death of Princess Diana than anything else. Those who saw George Best play can excuse the misguided meanderings of a middle-aged man. But Beckham was only two when Best last appeared for United.

webTitle: Linesman who did not realise it was all over

fields.headline: Linesman who did not realise it was all over
fields.trailText: Football officials have long been abused for their eyesight, their knowledge of the off-side rule, and even their parents' marital status, but Sunday league linesman Peter Rhoden may well be the first match official ever to miss a decision to abandon the match.
fields.body:
Football officials have long been abused for their eyesight, their knowledge of the off-side rule, and even their parents' marital status, but Sunday league linesman Peter Rhoden may well be the first match official ever to miss a decision to abandon the match.

The 46-year-old linesman from Hartlepool did not notice that the referee had abandoned a Sunday league match - and continued to run the line for a full five minutes before he spotted that the players and officials had left the pitch.

The Kenny Ball Cup match at Seaton Carew, Co Durham, was abandoned after fierce winds and driving hail swept over the pitch, and obscured much of it.

League secretary Kip Watson said: "The game was becoming farcical as players could hardly see in front of them. They were trying to play with their backs turned to protect themselves from the hail and keep it out of their eyes."

The clash was 65 minutes old, with the Touchdown Pub trailing Wingate 3-2, when the referee called it off. Everyone trooped off - forgetting about Mr Rhoden. It was five minutes before anyone realised he was still on the field and a player was sent to find him. The embarrassed linesman will not be giving up his day job as a salesman. He insisted he thought play was held up at the far end of the pitch.

webTitle: St Mirren seek to profit from Aberdeen anguish

fields.headline: St Mirren seek to profit from Aberdeen anguish
fields.trailText: Ian Archer has a look at the SFA Cup ties played today.
fields.body:
They still talk in Berwick of the day that Rangers crossed the border and came to the English town. The tiny club still holds the distinction of producing the only seismic shock in the history of the competition the Scottish FA Cup, a 1-0 win which reverberated around the world and eventually took their manager Jock Wallace to Ibrox, where he won trebles and coached the side to the European Cup Winners' Cup.

The only trouble is that it happened 33 years ago and that was the last time that the Scottish Cup's early rounds ever tempted a self-respecting editor to shout, "Hold the Front Page!"

Unlike England, with its illustrious roll call of memorable upsets, in Scotland the little clubs are expected to know their place, tug their forelocks and get back on their team buses with a crate of lager and the biggest cheque they will ever see in their lives. This afternoon, in theory, the ritual culling will take place and the Premier League sides will be left to contest the later stages.

Apart, of course, for Aberdeen, whose terrible season continued when they received the kind of awful draw that always seems to attach itself to the afflicted. Bottom of the Premier League, they go to Paisley to meet St Mirren, lording over the First Division. An 8,600 capacity crowd awaits them at Love Street.

Sir Alex Ferguson managed both clubs before going to Manchester United, and the Saints, after several lean years, appear to be on the mend under Tom Hendrie, another unusual coach. A schoolteacher by trade, he was happy enough to saunter around the little leagues as a part-time boss with Berwick and Alloa Athletic before going full time, and he has three times already this season been named manager of the month.

He has promoted youth, including the sweeper Sergei Baltacha, the Ukrainian whose father, also called Sergei, played for Ipswich and St Johnstone, coached at St Mirren and will be in the stand today. "It's my first big cup-tie," he says, "so I will be asking him how to handle it."

Steve Paterson, once a Manchester United player, takes Inverness Caledonian Thistle to Celtic Park and, doubtless, another 60,000 crowd. Some 5,000 will be supporting the underdogs and the manager said: "We are not going there simply to make up the numbers." Neither will Julius Francis later in the day, but that is not to say that neither will end up nursing some bruises.

Hibernian, meanwhile, face a tricky task against Dunfermline. "Some of our fans have never seen Hibs win the cup," said their manager Alex McLeish. But he was rather understating the case - the last time that Hibs won the competition was in 1902.

The most competitive tie of the round could be tomorrow's meeting of St Johnstone and Rangers at Perth. The holders struggled there in the league last season. A Saints win might not be a complete shock but it would still put them on the front page, such is the peculiar way of Scottish football.

 Rangers have made an official approach to Sunderland for the Scotland winger Allan Johnston. The 26-year-old, who joined Bolton on loan this week, has been in dispute with the Wearside club this season after turning down a new contract.

The Rangers chairman David Murray has offered a nominal fee for the player, who will be out of contract in the summer.

webTitle: Referee suspended after Prenton Park fiasco

fields.headline: Referee suspended after Prenton Park fiasco
fields.trailText: One of England's leading referees Rob Harris was suspended yesterday for his part in the farcical events which unfolded towards the end of the Tranmere-Sunderland FA Cup fourth-round tie.
fields.body:
One of England's leading referees Rob Harris was suspended yesterday for his part in the farcical events which unfolded towards the end of the Tranmere-Sunderland FA Cup fourth-round tie.

Harris will not be allowed to officiate until February 29 at the earliest but the fourth official on duty at the tie, David Unsworth, despite having an allegation of technical irregularities proven against him, will face no further action.

The assistant referee Tony Green also escaped punishment, although the case against him was upheld. It was the first time that match officials had been asked to attend a Football Association commission.

Harris, in a written submission to the three-man panel of the referees' committee which met in Peterborough, accepted responsibility for the injury-time incident, when Tranmere defended a Sunderland free-kick with 11 men despite having had a player sent off. Harris has 14 days to appeal.

In mitigation he had pointed out that he had been unaware of the illegal substitution taking place as he was focusing on a confrontation on the pitch.

The commission, who met for five hours, upheld that he had less than proficiently applied the laws. They also took into account the fact that Harris had not officiated since, costing him £2,500 in fees.

Keith Cooper, the public relations officer for match officials, criticised the ruling. "We are disappointed at the length of the suspension, especially because Rob has already missed several games.

"Nowadays you see players elbowing others in the face and receiving a two-match ban, so we are most disappointed that Rob has been suspended for this length of time."

 Nottingham Forest have completed the signing of Jack Lester from Grimsby for £300,000 but are annoyed that Sheffield United's Martin Smith, who had agreed terms to move, also for £300,000, opted for Huddersfield instead.

"I am disappointed and would have to question the player's integrity," said David Platt, Forest's manager. "I agreed a deal with Sheffield United on Monday and was told by his agent on Thursday that the player had agreed everything."

 Spanish police are investigating a complaint from a TV film crew who claim they were attacked by Nicolas Anelka, his brother and a third man when they went to report on a small fire in the garage at the Real Madrid striker's house. The three are accused of damaging equipment when they tried to stop the filming. The crew also claim to have suffered minor injuries, including bruising.

fields.headline: Blatter has Germany odds-on
fields.trailText: England's campaign to host the 2006 World Cup received a blow yesterday when Sepp Blatter heaped praise on their rivals Germany.
fields.body:
England's campaign to host the 2006 World Cup received a blow yesterday when Sepp Blatter heaped praise on their rivals Germany.

The Fifa president, in Leipzig to mark the centenary of the German Football Association (DFB), said: "I would nearly have to say Germany is favourite. The DFB is the best organised football association in the world."

The remarks will be seen as evidence that Fifa is distancing itself from Africa ahead of July's vote despite Blatter's insistence that the World Cup should go to South Africa or Morocco if they can meet Fifa's demands.

But the director of England's 2006 campaign, Alec McGivan, remained bullish. "If this contest ends up as being England v Germany I'm absolutely convinced England will win," he said. "Sepp Blatter has been terribly complimentary about the English bid. He's consistently said what a high-class bid it is. When it was presented in Zurich he said it was outstanding."

 Le Havre claim they are set to sign Xavier Gravelaine from Watford, saying Graham Taylor has agreed to release the 31-year-old forward, who is under contract until May.

 West Brom's highly rated Italian midfielder Enzo Maresca, 19, yesterday flew to Turin where he is expected to sign for Juventus for around £4.5m this weekend.

 Sunderland hope to look at the former Brazil forward Bebeto in training next week. The 33-year-old is without a club after walking out on the Mexican side, Torres Nexa.

webTitle: 'Why won't you sign my bat, Alec?'

fields.headline: 'Why won't you sign my bat, Alec?'
fields.trailText: Back in November, when England were newly arrived on South African soil and finding their way here on some quite unusual wickets, there was a warm-up game against a combined Western Province/Boland XI at Newlands.
fields.body:
Back in November, when England were newly arrived on South African soil and finding their way here on some quite unusual wickets, there was a warm-up game against a combined Western Province/Boland XI at Newlands.

The Barmy Army would have been supping ale in their local pubs in England, dreaming of exploits to come in sunny South Africa. The locals were certainly not interested. Who could blame them? They were convinced that this indifferent England side would not trouble their green and gold heroes. The crowd consisted of three men, no dog and about 50 school kids. (This shrunk after the first day.)

As I stood with my eight-year-old son by the England dressing-room, we offered words of encouragement to our boys. Goughie, Tuffers and all seem pleased to find friendly faces to talk to during quite a boring game. All signed my boy's bat readily (as is the custom in these parts) and posed for pictures. All, that is, apart from a certain Chelsea-supporting wicketkeeper. "No son, he's not past his best and yes, son, he will sign your bat". The trouble was, he didn't.

We hung over the railings: "Alec will you please sign my bat?"

"Later," was the reply.

"Alec will you please sign my bat?"

"There will be a time for that later," was the follow on. I explained to my son that Mr Stewart was tired (obviously untrue) and would keep to his word and sign later (also untrue).

And so it went on for two days: firm refusal for no good reason. On the last day I had had enough. By now the other two men and most of the school kids had long since gone and I was alone, a rather forlorn 40-year-old businessman holding a bat and pen in the manner of a pre-pubescent. "Alec, will you please now sign my boy's bat: you've promised him for the last two days you'd do so and now he's had to go back to school".

Guess what? "There will be a time for that later". Later? When? After the tour? When he retires from the game? In the afterlife?

There's no point in getting angry, I thought, until out of the corner of my eye I saw the local players. As they left the pitch they pulled up chairs and sat down. The school kids lined up in front of them, bats and pens in hand, and duly got their signatures. It took about 10 minutes but the impression will last more than 10 years for me.

So now my son has his bat signed - but not by our fellow Chelsea-supporting wicketkeeper. If someone is of world class, a genius, outstanding, then I suppose one can put up with a little arrogance. I was always told 'never kick people on the way up as they'll kick you twice as hard on the way back down'. I know in which direction Mr Stewart is travelling.

Chris Anderson is an England supporter living in South Africa

fields.headline: Saints put faith in Hoddle
fields.standfirst: Switch at the Dell Jones takes 12-month leave of absence to prepare for court battle
fields.trailText: Glenn Hoddle is clearly not a man for half-measures. If his removal as England coach was astonishing for its protracted agony, his return at Southampton yesterday was amazing for its suddenness. From hell to the Dell without a whisper.
fields.body:
Glenn Hoddle is clearly not a man for half-measures. If his removal as England coach was astonishing for its protracted agony, his return at Southampton yesterday was amazing for its suddenness. From hell to the Dell without a whisper.

The circumstances of his managerial reincarnation are appropriate. Personal problems rather than results forced him out last February. And it is Dave Jones' 17 child abuse charges which have paved the way for his comeback.

His arrival on a 12-month contract came after Southampton asked Jones to step aside on full pay for a year to fight his case, which goes to court on November 27. The pressure on Jones, the board said, would "adversely affect the club". Just as in his first job at Swindon in 1991, Hoddle finds himself in a relegation battle.

He showed no signs of worry yesterday morning at a press conference rather more relaxed than the one he faced at London's Royal Lancaster hotel 11 months ago. There was no suggestion he wondered what he had reaped to sow a job like this.

"It is a challenge I am looking forward to," he said. "I've had a chance to recharge the batteries. I've got no reservations. Managing England was a superb experience. I've had opportunities to return before but it's all about timing and the timing wasn't right."

The timing here makes this a brave gamble for Hoddle, albeit a lucrative one at an estimated £250,000. Southampton are only one place and two points above the bottom three. Relegation would leave his reputation in tatters.

He will get straight to work. Training begins today, the real business at home to West Ham next Saturday. "I've seen Southampton twice this season," he said. "I've got six or seven tapes of the last few games which I will be studying, and I'll be getting used to the players and the team.

"The players are going to feel for Dave Jones and I feel for him as well. Dave is going through a very difficult time and I can understand that because I went through a difficult time too.

"But we need to maintain a steady ship. The only thing I've got to prove is that we can stay in the Premiership; that we've got the will and the quality."

Relegation is certainly unthinkable, with Southampton committed to building a new £30m stadium for which they have borrowed £17m from a German bank.

The club's chairman David Lowe has been in an impossible position for some time, unable to sack Jones, who denies the charges and has not been convicted, but under pressure to remove him and concerned at the effect Jones' problems were having on results.

He said it was unanimous decision by the board to appoint Hoddle, even though the club are left paying two managers' salaries they can ill-afford.

Rumours were rife that last Saturday's game against Everton would be Jones' swansong. But Jones insisted after a 2-0 win that he was staying unless Lowe was "a very good liar" and seemed shocked to learn on Thursday night that he had to leave. "I am discussing with my lawyers my current position," he said, "and for that reason I can at present obviously say nothing more."

The sense of shock among Southampton's players was obvious. "We all had a great time in training on Thursday and the gaffer was enjoying it as much as anyone," said the captain Jason Dodd. "Nothing at all was mentioned about this and the players are staggered."

Matt le Tissier, in particular, might be taken aback. He said he wondered "what goes on in Glenn's head" after being ommitted from Hoddle's World Cup squad despite scoring a hat-trick in a B international.

But the 31-year-old, who is injured, was supportive of his supposed enemy. "I don't bear grudges," he said. "I'm excited by his appointment because the way he likes to get a team playing is the way I like to play." Hoddle said Le Tissier still had it in him "to be one of the best players in the Premiership".

The former England coach, who has brought his trusted No2 John Gorman from Reading, sounded upset at the manner of the his removal from the national scene. "I was misquoted," he said. "I've never believed that disabled people were being punished and it's unfortunate that disabled people got upset about it."

He will be happy to hear that Tom Tomalin, disability issues officer for the Football Supporters' Association, offered at least conditional support: "He may well have learned his lesson and he has to be given a chance to prove that.

"But he has to realise that if he opens his mouth again on any controversial subjects, particularly disability, then it will be even more unforgivable than it was the last time."

Southampton's fans generally welcomed Hoddle's appointment. "It's a real coup," said Clive Foley, editor of the fanzine The Ugly Inside. "It gives us every chance of pulling the players and fans in the right direction and I can't see for the life of me how Jones can come back if Hoddle does well." For now, that issue can wait.

 Reading have named the former West Ham midfielder Martin Allen as their assistant manager to succeed John Gorman, who has joined Glenn Hoddle at Southampton.

There was no suggestion he wondered what he had reaped to sow a job like this. "It is a challenge I am looking forward to," he said. "I've had a chance to recharge the batteries. I've got no reservations. Managing England was a superb experience. I've had opportunities to return before but it's all about timing and the timing wasn't right." The timing here makes this a brave gamble for Hoddle, albeit a lucrative one at an estimated £250,000. Southampton are only one place and two points above the bottom three. Relegation would leave his reputation in tatters. He will get straight to work. Training begins today, the real business at home to West Ham next Saturday. "I've seen Southampton twice this season," he said. "I've got six or seven tapes of the last few games which I will be studying, and I'll be getting used to the players and the team. "The players are going to feel for Dave Jones and I feel for him as well. Dave is going through a very difficult time and I can understand that because I went through a difficult time too. "But we need to maintain a steady ship. The only thing I've got to prove is that we can stay in the Premiership; that we've got the will and the quality." Relegation is certainly unthinkable, with Southampton committed to building a new £30m stadium for which they have borrowed £17m from a German bank. The club's chairman David Lowe has been in an impossible position for some time, unable to sack Jones, who denies the charges and has not been convicted, but under pressure to remove him and concerned at the effect Jones' problems were having on results. He said it was unanimous decision by the board to appoint Hoddle, even though the club are left paying two managers' salaries they can ill-afford. Rumours were rife that last Saturday's game against Everton would be Jones' swansong. But Jones insisted after a 2-0 win that he was staying unless Lowe was "a very good liar" and seemed shocked to learn on Thursday night that he had to leave. "I am discussing with my lawyers my current position," he said, "and for that reason I can at present obviously say nothing more." The sense of shock among Southampton's players was obvious. "We all had a great time in training on Thursday and the gaffer was enjoying it as much as anyone," said the captain Jason Dodd. "Nothing at all was mentioned about this and the players are staggered." Matt le Tissier, in particular, might be taken aback. He said he wondered "what goes on in Glenn's head" after being ommitted from Hoddle's World Cup squad despite scoring a hat-trick in a B international. But the 31-year-old, who is injured, was supportive of his supposed enemy. "I don't bear grudges," he said. "I'm excited by his appointment because the way he likes to get a team playing is the way I like to play." Hoddle said Le Tissier still had it in him "to be one of the best players in the Premiership". The former England coach, who has brought his trusted No2 John Gorman from Reading, sounded upset at the manner of the his removal from the national scene. "I was misquoted," he said. "I've never believed that disabled people were being punished and it's unfortunate that disabled people got upset about it." He will be happy to hear that Tom Tomalin, disability issues officer for the Football Supporters' Association, offered at least conditional support: "He may well have learned his lesson and he has to be given a chance to prove that. "But he has to realise that if he opens his mouth again on any controversial subjects, particularly disability, then it will be even more unforgivable than it was the last time." Southampton's fans generally welcomed Hoddle's appointment. "It's a real coup," said Clive Foley, editor of the fanzine The Ugly Inside. "It gives us every chance of pulling the players and fans in the right direction and I can't see for the life of me how Jones can come back if Hoddle does well." For now, that issue can wait.  Reading have named the former West Ham midfielder Martin Allen as their assistant manager to succeed John Gorman, who has joined Glenn Hoddle at Southampton.

webTitle: Glenn Hoddle: Managerial highs and lows

fields.headline: Glenn Hoddle: Managerial highs and lows
fields.trailText: April 91 Replaces Ossie Ardiles as Swindon player-manager. Narrowly avoids relegation to old Third Division.
fields.body:
April 91 Replaces Ossie Ardiles as Swindon player-manager. Narrowly avoids relegation to old Third Division.

May 93 Takes Swindon into Premiership via play-offs, scoring first goal in 4-3 win over Leicester at Wembley. A month later he leaves to take over at Chelsea.

May 94 Guides Chelsea to first FA Cup final for 24 years; they are beaten 4-0 by Manchester United.

May 96 Succeeds Terry Venables as England coach after Euro 96.

October 97 England achieve 0-0 draw in Italy to qualify for World Cup finals in France.

June 98 World Cup campaign, which began in controversy with the omission of Paul Gascoigne, ends in similar fashion as England lose on penalties to Argentina after David Beckham is sent off.

September 98 England's qualifying campaign for Euro 2000 begins poorly with a 2-1 defeat in Sweden. Hoddle accused of betraying players by publishing World Cup diary.

October 98 Hoddle allegedly rows with Alan Shearer after 3-0 win in Luxembourg.

February 99 Hoddle's contract with FA terminated "by mutual consent" after public outcry at comments about disabled people. Hoddle is quoted as saying: "You and I have been physically given two hands and two legs and half-decent brains. Some people have not been born like that for a reason. The karma is working from another lifetime."

January 2000 Takes temporary charge of Southampton.

webTitle: Dave Jones: what the chairman said

fields.headline: Dave Jones: what the chairman said
fields.trailText: Statement by the club's chairman, Rupert Lowe:
fields.body:
Statement by the club's chairman, Rupert Lowe:

"On Wednesday, David Jones's trial date for 13 charges of child abuse was set for November 27, 2000. The club is dismayed at the decision to postpone the trial for 11 months and to consider the addition of four further charges.

"The board is saddened that the British judicial system appears to be unable to dispense the justice for which it has rightly been known in a swift and efficient manner.

"The board is also disappointed at the prosecuting authorities' apparent practice of drip-feeding charges into the system, and angered at the effect this perceived sloth has had on David and his family for the past half year, and which will now continue for a further 11 months. Any family man will understand the pressure put upon David over and above that associated with the position of a Premier League Manager. This pressure, and the inability of David to defend himself whilst the case remains sub-judice, will in the view of the board adversely affect the club. The allegations against David may also affect the club's commercial relationships, and should this be the case it may well be that the club will take steps to recover any loss in the event of David's acquittal.

"The setting of a firm trial date has enabled the board to review its requirements over this period. After full discussion the board has put in place measures that will allow David to concentrate fully on his defence and the clearing of his name, and at the same time allow the club to look forward to another year in top-flight football.

"We do not realistically believe both these priorities can be given the best chance of success whilst David remains in sole charge of playing and training staff management. Accordingly, the board has placed David on a 12-month leave of absence, during which he will continue to be paid, to allow him to concentrate fully on the preparation of his case and trial.

"His contract of employment is not terminated and no one should confuse this situation with that of dismissal. The board also wish to state quite clearly there is no change in their view that David is innocent until proven otherwise."

fields.headline: Gary Imlach never travels without
fields.trailText: A necessity: The phone numbers of all my credit cards and insurance. I always leave things behind in hotels. I have to ask the crew to come and inspect my room every morning to check that I haven't left anything behind. At the moment, I'm waiting for my wallet to come back from a supermarket in Austria.
fields.body:
A necessity: The phone numbers of all my credit cards and insurance. I always leave things behind in hotels. I have to ask the crew to come and inspect my room every morning to check that I haven't left anything behind. At the moment, I'm waiting for my wallet to come back from a supermarket in Austria.

A luxury: I'm all for immersing myself in the local life and trying the local delicacies but if the locals drink terrible coffee, I don't see why I should join in, so I usually take a travel kettle and a can of Carluccio's coffee.

A memento: I once, by accident, ended up with an entire set of hotel keys from every place I'd stayed in when covering the Tour de France. I was going to arrange them into a route map and stick them on to the wall as a souvenir. I also started buying boxes of chocolates with scenes of the city on the top. I've now got boxes of the things mouldering in my cupboards.

If only: I hate those hermetically-sealed hotel rooms and would love to have a device to open the window. Sometimes you feel as if you have been entombed alive. Perhaps they think that someone will take one look at the horrible decor and throw themselves out of the window. But breathing fresh air is a real luxury, particularly in America.

 Gary Imlach presents The Snowboarding World Cup on Channel 4 on Sunday mornings.

fields.headline: One-way ticket
fields.standfirst: The helicopter dropped  Steve Chamberlain at the top of Andorra. It was a long way down
fields.trailText: I'm about to jump off the top of an 8,500ft mountain. The helicopter that has just dropped five of us off is nothing more than an annoying buzzing thing deep below in the white valley.
fields.body:
I'm about to jump off the top of an 8,500ft mountain. The helicopter that has just dropped five of us off is nothing more than an annoying buzzing thing deep below in the white valley.

Behind, there is a sheer drop that I don't like to guess the height of, and in front is a snow-covered wall that descends around 400ft into a shallow bowl and then goes down beyond that for maybe 1,500ft. Already, the guide and photographer have gone and are so far down that I can't see them. Now I'm expected to follow, and it's a good thing my legs are strapped to a snowboard, otherwise they would be shaking uncontrollably. At least the view is good.

And so it should be - I'm looking at the whole of Andorra, all 280 square miles of it. Immediately below is Arcalis, a resort that is eager to attract snowboarders to its miles of off-piste opportunities among these craggy peaks. Soon you won't need to fly to get to where I am; there will be a lift to give access to hundreds of gulleys and cliffs that seem tailor-made for boarding.

But despite the board park, halfpipe, pisted runs and fast, modern chairlifts, there is a noticeable absence of crowds. As Mark Creighton, director of the ski school at Arcalis, explains, "There is a policy to keep Arcalis green, so there are no hotels here, no accommodation, just the mountain. That keeps the number of people to an acceptable level and maintains the area's natural beauty."

But back to the boarding, because that's what we're here for. I can't stay on top of the mountain for much longer, so I ease myself to the edge and lurch over.

It's a bit like jumping from a high diving board and never quite landing and, although I flail my arms a lot and don't feel totally in control, neither am I quite out of control. Gaining confidence, I actually get in a few turns, sending the classic spray of snow out in a wide arc. Although, to my embarrassment, at the very moment I am stretched to the limit of my abilities, I notice Mark gently skiing backwards in front of me and looking at the scenery as if he's sliding on a nursery slope.

Pretty soon we are back in the valley, just a handful of long, snaking tracks coming down off the peaks to show where we have been.

We are based in the small town of Arinsal, which has a real village atmosphere and hostel-type accommodation, which should appeal to most snowboarders on the lookout for a no-frills trip. Arinsal itself is a good warm-up area with its wide, high-sided slopes, and it has the best nightlife in Andorra after Soldeu.

The Surf restaurant, next to the gondola, offers one of the best barbecues around, while upstairs the club is open late and the drink is cheap and plentiful. However, being drunk in the street is actually illegal in Andorra, and, although there are no licensing hours, clubs are subject to noise limits, so that when you go to bed there is no music thumping through your head into the small hours and no screaming drunks outside your window.

From Arinsal, it's no more than an hour's drive to any of the other resorts. But it's worth hiring a car because the ski bus service leaves a lot to be desired.

The closest resort is Pal, a small place full of beautiful tree-lined runs, mainly reds, but with a few blues and greens. We had one of the best day's boarding here as well as the best food in the slope-side restaurant.

Next came Soldeu-el-Tartar - a big mountain putting a lot of investment in on new lifts and a halfpipe. Like all the resorts in Andorra, it is investing in snowboarders rather than just capitalising on the sport by fitting it around skiing and skiers.

Pas de la Casa/Grau Roig is actually two resorts joined together to form a huge 88km of pisted runs. The slopes are served by a gondola from the town of Encamp which travels half the width of the country and is reputed to be the longest in Europe.

But perhaps the biggest attraction for aching boarders is Caldea, the natural spa in the capital Andorra la Vella. For three hours, you can float in heated spring waters inside a building straight out of a science-fiction film. You can have a sauna, sit in a steam room, have your back and neck massaged by water jets, go to sleep in the relaxation room or swim outside. Oh, and look out for the pool filled with oranges - I'm still not sure what you're supposed to do in that.

At the end of the week, there was still one final chore - a big air competition at Arcalis organised by Ian Boast of UFO. Later that night, they show a video of the competition in the Surf. When my acrobatics come on, everyone sucks in their breath in sympathy and it looks like something from a late-night satellite TV show like When Stunts Go Bad. But I don't mind, I've never been on TV in a pub before. And where did I come in the competition? Last, of course.

The practicals

UFO Snowboard Club (020 83174385) runs tailor-made tours in Andorra for boarders of all abilities. Steve Chamberlain flew with Ryanair from Stanstead to Carcassone for £68 return and stayed at the Micolau (376 835 052) for £14 per person per night B&B. Heliand helicopter drops: 376 837 929.

fields.headline: Fly by wire
fields.standfirst: Ros Taylor looks for  cyber-gold in the form of cheap flights on the internet
fields.trailText: Ros Taylor looks for cyber-gold in the form of cheap flights on the internet
fields.body:
I'd better come clean right at the start. I've never found a dirt cheap flight on the web. I've saved money and I've listened enviously as people told me of their £50 returns to New York, but I've never struck cyber-gold.

There is a good reason for this - my departure dates are inflexible and I like to savour the prospect of a holiday, so it's hard to take advantage of last-minute deals. Nonetheless, you can almost always save money by going online.

Expedia
A few weeks ago, for example, Expedia was offering the cheapest flight available to Bordeaux at £188, although when KLM subsidiary Buzzaway begins to ply the route in March, it should become a lot cheaper, at around £100 return. (Buzzaway is targeting some of the less competitive destinations, notably Marseille, Helsinki, Montpellier and Jerez, as well as Paris and major German cities). Expedia's site is rather like Microsoft, the company behind it: efficient, clever and rather uninspiring. The inquiry line is helpful and the tickets arrive quickly. Also, it is about to lift its registration requirement, which will make it easier to access the site on a first visit.

Cheapflights
Cheapflights doesn't sell flights over the web - instead it can redirect you to another site that does, or give you a booking number to call. You can only search by destination, so it can take a while to track down an affordable flight at the right time. If the date doesn't matter, however, Cheapflights throws up bargains: at the time of writing, Cancun, in Mexico, is going for £129, New York for £149 and Dublin for £21.

Ebookers
Ebookers is another newcomer. While it allows you to search by date, the site returns a list of flights and prices without airport tax - and even then seats may no longer be available. That said, ebookers is well organised and easy to use. You can also bid on flights and, unlike a conventional web auction, this facility asks you to name the price you're prepared to pay. ebookers then undertakes to try to find you a suitable flight.

Travelocity
Travelocity uses Sabre, the travel agents' database, and the results are noticeably different from ebookers' own. It's certainly worth checking both.

Go and easyJet
The excellent easyJet and Go sites cover most of Europe and need no introduction - fares vary but are almost always cheaper than the major carriers.

fields.headline: Pocket books
fields.trailText: Abdul's Taxi to Kalighat | Take the Kids Travelling | Agatha Christie's England | Picasso's Paris | Russia from A to Z | Curious Chester | Great Places to Stay in Europe | Cheap Sleeps Europe
fields.body:
Abdul's Taxi to Kalighat, by Joe Roberts
(Profile Books, £15.99)

Joe and Emma and baby Llewelyn were living in a flat in Bath when the nudists downstairs moved out. The nudists' upturned heating had warmed the entire building. So with winter approaching, it was time to head for Calcutta. And where better than the Fairlawn hotel? Run by Violet and Ted Smith, the Fairlawn seemed a little bit of an England that never was.

Fawlty Towers transported to the poorest city on earth? Sort of. Except that the Smiths and their guests begin where situation comedy leaves off, and Calcutta itself, while undeniable poor, has a lot more going for it than all those documentaries about Mother Theresa would have us believe. It is a living kaleidoscope - an ever-shifting pattern of buildings and people.

Take the Kids Travelling, by Helen Truszkowski
(Cadogan, £14.99)

Friends warned the author of the previous book against taking baby Llewelyn to Calcutta. And when he developed a fever after a few days, they wished they had listened. Would the family have left Bath had they read this book? Its determination to cover all eventualities ('Children can make themselves big and thus more visible by lying on the ground in a star shape if a searching helicopter flies over') could deter the faint-hearted.

On balance, though, Truszkowski's message is summed up by her subtitle, 'Survive and enjoy'. How do you tell if a prospective hotel is as child-friendly as the brochure claims? How can you be sure you are really getting a discount? Truszkowski has the answers. Her tips for single parents are especially useful. How many have been sent home because they lack written authorisation for the trip from their child's other parent? Star shapes won't save you then, junior.

Agatha Christie's England, by Judith Hurdle
(RDR Books, £13.99)

'I prefer to travel like a local rather than like a tourist on holiday,' writes Judith Hurdle, 'and I have met such interesting people on public transportation.' It takes neither a Poirot nor a Marple to work out that the locals are our good selves, Hurdle being an English teacher from Valparaiso, Indiana.

Actually, the fact that its author is American works in this book's favour. For it means that Christie fans, while following in the footsteps of their favourite fiction, can also gain innumerable insights into English life that a native might well have overlooked (why, for instance, in order to open the door in an older railway carriage, is it necessary first to open the window?)

The action flits between London, Oxfordshire and Devon, with an extraordinary interlude in Harrogate, where Christie turned up after an unexplained 11-day disappearance in 1926. What happened to her? Perhaps nobody told her about opening the train window.

Picasso's Paris, by Ellen Williams
(The Little Bookroom, £10)

Any number of books currently work to this formula (see above), and Paris is uncommonly susceptible to such treatment. Indeed, Williams has herself produced a sister title, The Impressionists' Paris, and in this she is not alone. You know the formula. Follow in the artist's footsteps, locate some viewpoints, spot the difference, wring your hands at the ravages of time, then pop into this cafe (closed Mondays) for an authentic taste of old Montmartre.

But the publishers have certainly gone to town. This is pocket-size, hardback and clothbound, neat and weighty, with illustrations that glint like gemstones. 'Very nice objects,' as they say. And for once, I'm happy to nod in agreement.

Russia from A to Z, by Vladimir Reznichenko
(Russian Information Agency Novosti, £7.95)

A very interesting and comprehensive book on Russia. Says who? Says Boris Yeltsin, that's who. And, as a matter of fact, he's right.

It's a veritable mini-encyclopaedia, says Mr Y, presenting 'the life of our country in all its myriad varieties and dynamics'. All of them? 'As it is well known,' says the chapter on ethnic groups, 'the nationalities question is a sticky one.' The former president clearly approves of such candour. 'We are not trying to hide contemporary problems,' he says, 'because we are sure that they will be overcome as soon as the reforms that we have launched are decisively and effectively introduced at all walks of life.' Quite so.

Curious Chester, by Gordon Emery
(Gordon Emery, £11.99)

Perhaps you didn't know that 'Niyon anomhma mh monan oyin' - it means 'I wash away my sins, not my face alone' - is the only Greek inscription that is a palindrome (try spelling it backwards after three glasses of ouzo). And perhaps you didn't know that Russian men were expected to pay a beard tax in 1698 - the ones with beards, that is. But you know it now.

The Greek palindrome is carved on the oak font canopy at St Peter's church in Chester. Small wonder, then, that it crops up in this 'portrait of an English city over 2,000 years'. But a Russian beard tax? The author was talking about hearth tax and window tax and thought he might as well drop it in. And why not? This is Emery's book - self-published and in his own handwriting. So anything goes.

And thanks to good design and a sense of humour, what might have been an undisciplined mishmash turns out to be a very nice book indeed. Dozens of photographs (by Mike Penney) and any number of old prints keep it going at a cracking pace. Like the Chester-Holyhead Mail that overturned in 1827, crushing the brother of the MP for Cheshire...

Great Places to Stay in Europe
(Dorling Kindersley, £14.99)

You know the look and feel of a DK book. The weight, the shine, the sheer volume of little colour pictures, glittering like jewels and surrounded by crisp, tiny icons on an endless number of pure white pages... You know, also, what a hotel looks like - a parador, a pousada, an inn, an auberge, a farmhouse, a pub, a villa, a cottage, a B&B in a converted windmill... Pour a couple of thousand of these into that DK format and you have this bright little thing to carry around in your briefcase and thumb through when you ought to be working.

Working? Oh yes. You'll need to work fairly hard if you want to turn some of these little fantasies into reality ('charming' and 'distinctive' are words that crop up time and again, but I don't see the word 'budget' too often). Of course, if you're happy just turning the pages and dreaming... Well, dream on.

Cheap Sleeps Europe, by Katie Wood
(Ebury Press, £12.99)

The very title has been trimmed to the bone. No pictures and plenty of paper the colour of chipboard, yet it costs a mere £2 less than the plush tome described above. How's this? Well, it does have more than 10,000 entries. And as one reviewer pointed out, it could pay for itself in the first two nights.

Some of the addresses mentioned are not a million miles away from red-light districts, Wood points out. 'But we have vetted the places listed, and if there is likely to be trouble or overt displays that your parents wouldn't like, they're not in.'

Overt displays? Somehow, I don't think she's talking about dried flowers on the bedside table.

fields.headline: The ride ideas
fields.standfirst: From the best type of board to how to get big air, former world snowboarding champion  Kevin Delaney  answers the 10 most frequently asked questions
fields.trailText: From the best type of board to how to get big air, former world snowboarding champion Kevin Delaney answers the 10 most frequently asked questions.
fields.body:
1 Snowboarding looks easy, do I really need a lesson? If you take a full-day, professional lesson to start, you will avoid hours of frustration and struggle on the slopes. A full-day lesson will show you the basics of getting started, ease you into turns and polish your technique as you begin to link turns. A two-hour lesson leaves you hanging without skills to ride the mountain.

2 Am I too old/young to get started? I have had 84-year-olds come through my snowboarding camp and seen many children learn to ride, although they had never been on skis before. Go for it at age seven.

3 What is the best board for me? If you are interested in carving smooth turns with no jumping, then look into a freecarving board model with a length that falls between your nose and the top of your head.

For all mountain riding and a solid performance in a wide variety of snow conditions, go for the freeriding board style. This is perfect for your first day on the slopes, the halfpipe or ripping up fresh powder. Buy a freeride model between your chin and nose in height.

For fun, look at a freestyle board. They are light and easy turning makes them easy to spin and ride in all conditions, but they are not known for durability or ability to deliver stability at speeds.

4 What is the best way to set up my bindings?
For a freestyle set-up, position your bindings slightly wider (centre to centre) than the distance from your elbow to your fingertips. Place your front binding 10-27 degrees forward, or positive angle, and your back binding positive as well. Position your bindings so that your toes hang over the edge slightly more than your heels. Adjust the forward lean of your front binding, located on your highback, forward - to increase the response and quickness of your heelside edge. Rotate the highback of the front binding to become near parallel to the heelside edge.

5 I have trouble stopping quickly, what's wrong?
If your legs are locked straight, your board will make a bounc ing, chattering attempt at stopping. The key to quick stops is being able to manage your board's pressure in the snow. Start with equal weight on both feet, when you will be pressuring the entire board into the snow. Now, you must apply your body weight through the board and on to the snow so that the edges grip. To do this, you must be able to lower your body mass on to the biting edge evenly and progressively. The legs will be flexing, allowing the weight of the body to pressure the edge and thus grip the snow and stop.

6 I can make turns easy to my heels, but I fall when I try to get to my toes. Why?
Learning to make a heelside turn is easier because your body will rotate into the turn, if only to see where you are going.

When it comes to making good toeside turns, first of all, slow down! On a heelside traverse, shift your weight (from 50/50) more to the front foot (70/30). Simply move your hips towards the nose of the board, which will then seek the fall line and begin the first half of the turn automatically. As you get going into the turn, rotate your head, shoulders, hips and knees into the same direction as the desired turn and stay on your front foot! Your board will come around effortlessly every time if you just remember the three simple steps: slow down, shift weight to front foot, rotate into the turn.

Avoid leaning into the turn or getting on to your back foot because of fear.

7 What should I work on to get better?
Learning to carve will help you ride longer with less effort and prepare you for riding powder. Aggressive short-radius turns are the only weapon against steep slopes, moguls, trees and crowds.

Develop your carving balance by tipping your board up on edge past 45 degrees. Start riding down the fall line. Tip the board up on edge and try to maintain that edge, without sliding, across the slope and back up the hill. Practise on both edges. To link carve turns together, repeat the process to get started but roll the board over to the downhill edge when you get to 45 degrees away from the fall line. If you are sliding and you try to get on to the downhill edge, you will crash. Make sure you are carving before you go to the next turn.

For aggressive edge-biting turns with an even tempo, try to find a rhythm in your head and keep the turn shape intact. The more you practise, the more you will gain strength and control over your board when the going gets rough.

8 I can survive jumps, but how do I get good board grabs?
When you jump, you still need to maintain a good riding foundation, which includes: 50/50 weight, flexed knees and ankles, straight back, arms at your sides with one hand on either side of the board, and eyes looking in the direction of travel. Notice hand position.

First the take off. Do not throw your hands into the air on every jump. Use your arms for balance only when you need them. On take-off, jump upward with your shoulders going skyward rather than your elbows. As you fly through the air, with the proper hand position, bring your board up under your body rather then reaching down for the rail. With decent hangtime, you will have your board in your hand with no effort, and - remembering to let go - land smoothly.

9 How do I learn to spin?
I suggest working on riding "fakie", or backwards, until you are comfortable turning and stopping. The obvious progression would be to start with a 180-degree rotation and move up 180 degrees at a time. That is why you want to learn to ride backwards first.

10 What is the secret to riding a halfpipe?
The secret to getting big air is not collapsing in the transition. You need to get set in the flat bottom in an aggressive stance with all the elements of a good foundation in place. As you enter the transition of the approaching wall, start to push gently with your legs to counter the force that is trying to get your legs to bend. If you bend at the legs in the transition, you will be slowing yourself down and losing speed required to launch out of the vertical.

 Kevin Delaney presents more tips at Board-it.com, the online snowboarding guide. Details of his worldwide snowboarding camps are on www.board-it.com/delaney

fields.headline: 3 minute guide
fields.standfirst: The Passion of Bavaria
fields.trailText: The Passion of Bavaria.
fields.body:
Such passion?

Oberammergau fans have waited 10 years for this.

Is Oberammergau the happening place?

Once every decade, despite being a tiny Bavarian village 150 miles southwest of Munich.

What's the significance of its play?

In 1633, the village fell victim to the Black Death. The burghers took an oath that if it survived, they would re-enact Christ's suffering and death every 10 years.

What good would that do?

Hopefully, God would have pity on them and release their village from the epidemic.

Did it work?

No one died from the day of the vow, the village is still there, and the play has been performed every decade since.

It sounds riveting.

Cynics need not apply. There are barely enough tickets for true fans.

A sell-out?

A seat in the 4,600-strong audience calls for forward planning.

Is it staged daily?

Five times a week between May 22 and September 29, from 9am to 5.30pm, including a lunch break of three hours.

Just line up at the box office?

Contact with a tour operator to Germany would be a more sensible first step. The German Tourist Office (0171-317 0908) has a list of more than 40.

Offering Passion packages?

Fly-drive or coach holidays with accommodation and the play.

For example?

German Travel Centre (0181-429 2900) has a one-night package costing £710, including return fares, B&B, one lunch, an evening meal and a ticket to the play.

Could I stay on?

Easily. Insight Vacations' (0870 5143433) eight-day Tyrolean package, based in the village of Ehrwald, costs from £679 and includes a play ticket and all meals, but not optional visits to Bavarian castles, the Italian Dolomites, Innsbruck and Venice.

Tickets only?

Contact the Oberammergau Booking Office, Geschaftsstele Passionsspiele, Engen Pabst Str 9A, 8103 Oberammergau, Germany.

I won't be roped in for crowd scenes?

More than 2,000 villagers will already be on stage. So your school nativity talents are unlikely to be needed.
