fields.headline: Ghostbusters
fields.standfirst: Glasgow and South Dakota don't appear to have a lot in common. But, last year, the city returned a ghost dance shirt to the Lakota Sioux - the type of shirt many were wearing at the massacre at Wounded Knee.  Jean Rafferty  follows it from her home town to the Badlands and goes on the trail of the American Indian
fields.trailText: Glasgow and South Dakota don't appear to have a lot in common. But, last year, the city returned a ghost dance shirt to the Lakota Sioux - the type of shirt many were wearing at the massacre at Wounded Knee. Jean Rafferty follows it from her home town to the Badlands and goes on the trail of the American Indian.
fields.body:
The journey began in November, the month the Lakota Sioux call the Moon When the Wolves Run Together, in my home city of Glasgow. It was to take me across the ocean and half a continent away to South Dakota on the trail of the American Indian.

In 1892, Buffalo Bill Cody's Wild West Show came to Glasgow and created a sensation, as it did throughout Europe. The people of my city were wild for it, especially for the Indians and their fantastic costumes. A member of the troupe gave a Lakota Sioux ghost dance shirt to Kelvingrove art gallery and museum. I remember seeing it there as a child, along with a model of an Indian Plains family, all dressed in buckskin and beading. But in 1999 Glasgow recognised the shirt as an important piece of Sioux history and returned it to the tribe.

As the plane flies into Minneapolis, the city lights spread out below us, I am struck with the thought of the strangeness of cities. The great plains where the Indians roamed in search of buffalo are now a great forest of pale orange and yellow, miles and miles of artificial lights laid out on the land like millions of barren Christmas trees. Instead of a people at one with nature, we have become aliens on the earth, people who can't see the stars in the sky for the orange haze above our streets.

On to Rapid City and then the long drive across the prairie. The roads are so endless and so empty that you wonder how the Indians and the whites ever ran into each other. I stop at Wall, a little town on the edge of the South Dakota Badlands. It's a curious experience, one of those delights that Western capitalism throws up, a place that flourishes because a demand has been created for it way beyond any need.

In 1931, Dorothy and Ted Hustead bought the local drugstore here. It was the middle of the Depression and business was slow. One hot July day, Dorothy watched the dust rising behind the passing cars and realised the people inside them would be thirsty. She put up a sign offering free ice-water. So many people stopped that the Husteads built a virtual empire on it. Practically every souvenir or craft shop along the wooden boardwalk now belongs to their family, rather like some towns in Scotland where woollen mills with different names mysteriously offer the same woolly jumpers. Here in Wall, you can buy expensive leather-fringed jackets or cheap dreamcatcher earrings, the cheapest of them made in China, where they'll churn out anybody's culture and undercut the natives.

From this examplar of that proud marketing concept, the American Dream, you move into the Badlands, a strange, desolate place that could come out of a nightmare. Here, fantastically-shaped hills have erupted on the land like vomit from deep inside the earth. Catch the light right and you see bands of colour streaked along the surface, rich reds and purples. A few miles past the western entrance, where the land is still flat, is the Prairie Homestead. It's closed for the winter, but I peer through dusty windows into what looks like an outpost of Hell. This housed a family of the first settlers, or sodbusters.

It's built into the sod, with grass covering the roof, and you can see that the earth floor inside is cracked. Outside it's a 30-yard walk to the privy, a shack where a wooden plank with two holes is perched above God knows what horrors. Rattlesnakes could lurk anywhere on the prairie, even in the rafters of the houses. Blizzards were so blinding that sometimes the people had to use a rope tied between the house and the barn to hold on to. The Homestead Act of 1862 offered a parcel of land to every settler who could secure a claim. It drew a million people here, undoubtedly one of the marketing triumphs of all time.

After this detour, it's late by the time I reach Pierre, South Dakota's state capital, where the ghost dance shirt is held. The receptionist at my motel has heard of it, not surprisingly as she's a counsellor at Lower Brule Indian school. She says she'd like to think there's no prejudice against the Indians but there is really. It's the work ethic. They don't really have it. "We keep trying to force it on them," she says.

Next morning, I go to the South Dakota State Historical Society Museum, where director David Hartley takes me round one of the most wonderful museums I've ever been in. It shows the history of the people of South Dakota, from the Sioux creation myth to sodbusters and gold miners and right up to the present day. The Lakota believe they came from a cave deep inside the Black Hills, where they were first called the Buffalo Nation. But when they came to live on the surface of the earth, they became Ikce Wicasa, Ordinary People. This embracing of the ordinary strikes me as similar to Glaswegians' faith in the power of the workers. The parallels are even stronger with the Cheyennes, whose name for themselves is Tsetsehesestahase - We Are the People, a common Scottish football chant.

"The Lakota are more spiritual than we are," says Hartley. "To them there was no status in accumulating possessions or wealth. You gained status in giving it away." Their name for generosity, one of their four cardinal virtues (the others are courage, wisdom and fortitude) was wacatognaka, the ability to give without a pounding heart.

The exhibit cases here are filled with artefacts they gave away, often on ceremonial occasions - moccasins decorated with quillwork, an intricate Oglala beaded saddle blanket, tiny little beaded turtles given to new mothers to hold their babies' umbilical cords. Next to their lightness of spirit and the exquisite beauty of their workmanship, the soldiers' possessions are cumbersome and ugly - iron shackles, rifles, metal spurs, dark leather saddles.

Glasgow's ghost dance shirt stands in a case of its own. It's a pale tan colour with rust-brown fringing and has some holes in the side with staining around. This looks ominously like blood, though it could be ink or anything.

The ghost dance, a strange mix of Christianity and the Indians' own religion, tore through the Indian nations in 1889 and 90. It was non-violent and should have posed no threat to the white authorities, but they were afraid because the Indians were so crazed with the dance they did it for days on end, from dawn into the hours of darkness. A Paiute called Wovoka claimed he had seen the dance in a vision and that if the people performed it a Messiah would come to rescue them from the whites. If they wore special ghost dance shirts, the white man's bullets could not hurt them. Many Indians were wearing them when they died in the terrible massacre at Wounded Knee on December 29 1890.

Surprisingly, the shirts are not rare. The museum already had one of its own when the Glasgow shirt was returned.

It's dusk by the time I get down to Lake Sharpe, which offers the sportsman fishing and sailing. An Indian camp has been set up there on La Framboise Island to protest against the government's possession of the Sioux's sacred tribal lands, the Black Hills of Dakota. The tepees are deserted, but right at the end of the camp is the familiar sound of a television playing. Inside a large blue plastic marquee I find 21-year-old Richard Shangreaux, who says the Sioux are the caretakers of the earth. He's an Oglala, of the Teton nation, and he grew up in a tepee.

He has the fine face of a brave, the chiselled nose and high cheekbones. He also has an anorak. "We walk in spirituality. It's not a religion, it's a way of life," he says, taking a taco out of its plastic wrapper and munching on it. "They're scared of our spirituality. They're not scared of us physically. They've got the biggest guns in the world."

A smaller Indian joins him, 23-year-old LeGrand Wells, a Hunkpapa Sioux who was brought up in the city of Minneapolis. He says he wants to learn about the traditional ways of his people, though he's scared he might not make it through the cold winter.

They invite me into the tepee where they keep a sacred fire burning 24 hours a day. A chair with a blanket thrown over sits by the side of it. They say it's for the spirit of the fire, Yellow Horse. Inside, the tepee is cosy as a cocoon, with soft fabrics and cushions scattered everywhere. As a way of coping with the rigours of the Dakota winter it seems infinitely more attractive than the Prairie Homestead. "They did so much and worked so hard to make us forget who we are," says LeGrand. "It almost worked." Richard throws some sweetgrass into the fire. We sit in the warmth and we are all thinking of the wrongs that have been done the Indian people, as the flames and the scented grass whisper upwards to the roof poles of the tepee and through to the night outside.

How close Indian hopes are to going up in smoke is evident the next day at the Wounded Knee massacre site. The road there is through the eastern gate of the Badlands, over the White River, where 3,000 Sioux danced the Ghost Dance in the snow for days together, past cliffs and buttes all puckered up like pleating. This is the Pine Ridge reservation, with straggly little towns where many live in trailers with several cars parked outside, some working, some not. Like the people. Everyone here is on food stamps.

Beyond Kyle, the road deteriorates suddenly, becoming like a rally track. Finally, at Wounded Knee, we're back on the highway. But the Indians have clearly not mastered the white man's art of packaging their history. There is no visitor centre, no gift shop or tearoom, only a couple of stalls that have been closed up for the season. A plain metal sign tells the story of the massacre, which happened in the Moon of Popping Trees (December-January) 1890. Hundreds of Indian men, women and children were gunned down by US soldiers. Many of the women were fleeing, their babies in their arms.

As I try to decipher where everything actually happened, a car suddenly revs up and drives all of 20 yards to sit by mine. An Indian sticks his head out of the car. He says his name is Jeremy and hands me a leaflet welcoming me to the Oglala Lakota nation. Then he asks if I'm interested in arts and crafts. He pulls out a bundle of dreamcatchers and medicine wheels, ranging from $15 to $30. "I'll give you a good deal if you take more than one," he offers. I discover I have no cash left. "Can you give me a few dollars then?" he says.

Indian culture and history are for sale throughout the state of South Dakota, not necessarily by Indians, but the reservation itself is a depressing place, a reminder of how much the Indians have lost in becoming part of the American nation. In Pine Ridge itself, the main social attraction seems to be the local Texaco station, where Indians sit round chatting and eating greasy food.

Just outside Pine Ridge, on the Nebraska border, is another protest camp, Camp Justice. Last June (the Moon When the Chokecherries Are Ripe), two Indian men were found dead in a ditch 100 yards north of this mud-caked field. Their throats were slit, their faces and bodies heavily bruised, their wrists swollen after being tightly bound. No one has been brought to justice for their murder.

This is the underside of the tourist industry that brings so much money to this area in the summer. It's a black hole in the heart of South Dakota, a place where no visitor would willingly choose to go. Beyond the reservation, and into the Black Hills, things are much more comfortable and even downright touristy. Hot Springs, a spa town, and Hill City are both charming places where you buy Indian souvenirs without con fronting the misery of the Indians themselves.

Between them lie miles of beautiful parkland, not the Jane Austen rolling variety but rugged hills black with trees, and clear blue skies streaked with fantastical clouds you can understand Indian artists seeing visions in. As Wind Cave National Park gives way to Custer State Park, you see deer and wild turkeys and even a herd of little donkeys. On the Wildlife Loop road is a prairie dog town, where hundreds of these rabbit-like creatures live in the animal equivalent of a shanty town, their burrows littering the ground like hundreds of miniature rubbish dumps.

Most fascinating of all is the sight of herds of buffalo roaming free on the hills as they once roamed right across the Great Plains. Signs warn you they are unpredictable, but they seem gentle creatures, standing stolidly chewing grass or lying dead asleep. They are so close to your car you can see the dust on their flanks and the yellow burrs that have clung to their faces.

The buffalo are a reminder that what is lost can be built up again, as the Indians are trying to restore their own culture and religion. But the sacred tribal lands of the Black Hills have become sacred to the white man, too - for the money they generate. More than 2.5 million people a year visit Mount Rushmore, with its car parks and gift shops and sculptures of dead politicians. You walk up an avenue draped with state flags, its triumphalism queasily reminiscent of Nazi architecture. Then, from above the $10 million amphitheatre, you look across at the carved stone faces of Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln. And it's strangely disappointing. The achievement is remarkable, the workmanship magnificent, but you're left wondering, what does it all mean? Are these grim-faced men the whole of American history? Are they even the best of it?

Just a few miles south of Hill City is the Crazy Horse Memorial, built when Chief Henry Standing Bear of the Sioux wrote to sculptor Korczak Ziolkowski saying his people "would like the white man to know the red man has great heroes, too". Crazy Horse was a warrior and a visionary leader, who believed this world was not the real world. Through dreams he entered the real world, the world of spirits, where his horse floated and danced. Ziolkowski and his wife Ruth decided the memorial, of Crazy Horse on his stallion, would be the largest ever built, nearly 600ft high.

The work has been in progress for 50 years and is still not finished, partly because the Ziolkowski family refuse to accept government funding, partly because it is so colossal. The place is a building site, the horse's head is only sketched in. But you look up above the trees and see the stern face of the man, his hair flying out behind him in the stone wind; you see the beauty of the horse; and you think of freedom.

The practicals

Jean Rafferty organised her trip through STA travel (020 73616262), flying from Glasgow to Rapid City via Minneapolis at a cost oif £264 return plus tax. She took an add-on trip to Kalispell for £250. She stayed at the Alex Johnson Hotel in Rapid City (001 605 432 1210) and shee hired a car through Dollar Rent-a-Car (001 605 342 7071).

There is no visitor centre, no gift shop or tearoom, only a couple of stalls that have been closed up for the season. A plain metal sign tells the story of the massacre, which happened in the Moon of Popping Trees (December-January) 1890. Hundreds of Indian men, women and children were gunned down by US soldiers. Many of the women were fleeing, their babies in their arms. As I try to decipher where everything actually happened, a car suddenly revs up and drives all of 20 yards to sit by mine. An Indian sticks his head out of the car. He says his name is Jeremy and hands me a leaflet welcoming me to the Oglala Lakota nation. Then he asks if I'm interested in arts and crafts. He pulls out a bundle of dreamcatchers and medicine wheels, ranging from $15 to $30. "I'll give you a good deal if you take more than one," he offers. I discover I have no cash left. "Can you give me a few dollars then?" he says. Indian culture and history are for sale throughout the state of South Dakota, not necessarily by Indians, but the reservation itself is a depressing place, a reminder of how much the Indians have lost in becoming part of the American nation. In Pine Ridge itself, the main social attraction seems to be the local Texaco station, where Indians sit round chatting and eating greasy food. Just outside Pine Ridge, on the Nebraska border, is another protest camp, Camp Justice. Last June (the Moon When the Chokecherries Are Ripe), two Indian men were found dead in a ditch 100 yards north of this mud-caked field. Their throats were slit, their faces and bodies heavily bruised, their wrists swollen after being tightly bound. No one has been brought to justice for their murder. This is the underside of the tourist industry that brings so much money to this area in the summer. It's a black hole in the heart of South Dakota, a place where no visitor would willingly choose to go. Beyond the reservation, and into the Black Hills, things are much more comfortable and even downright touristy. Hot Springs, a spa town, and Hill City are both charming places where you buy Indian souvenirs without con fronting the misery of the Indians themselves. Between them lie miles of beautiful parkland, not the Jane Austen rolling variety but rugged hills black with trees, and clear blue skies streaked with fantastical clouds you can understand Indian artists seeing visions in. As Wind Cave National Park gives way to Custer State Park, you see deer and wild turkeys and even a herd of little donkeys. On the Wildlife Loop road is a prairie dog town, where hundreds of these rabbit-like creatures live in the animal equivalent of a shanty town, their burrows littering the ground like hundreds of miniature rubbish dumps. Most fascinating of all is the sight of herds of buffalo roaming free on the hills as they once roamed right across the Great Plains. Signs warn you they are unpredictable, but they seem gentle creatures, standing stolidly chewing grass or lying dead asleep. They are so close to your car you can see the dust on their flanks and the yellow burrs that have clung to their faces. The buffalo are a reminder that what is lost can be built up again, as the Indians are trying to restore their own culture and religion. But the sacred tribal lands of the Black Hills have become sacred to the white man, too - for the money they generate. More than 2.5 million people a year visit Mount Rushmore, with its car parks and gift shops and sculptures of dead politicians. You walk up an avenue draped with state flags, its triumphalism queasily reminiscent of Nazi architecture. Then, from above the $10 million amphitheatre, you look across at the carved stone faces of Washington, Jefferson, Roosevelt and Lincoln. And it's strangely disappointing. The achievement is remarkable, the workmanship magnificent, but you're left wondering, what does it all mean? Are these grim-faced men the whole of American history? Are they even the best of it? Just a few miles south of Hill City is the Crazy Horse Memorial, built when Chief Henry Standing Bear of the Sioux wrote to sculptor Korczak Ziolkowski saying his people "would like the white man to know the red man has great heroes, too". Crazy Horse was a warrior and a visionary leader, who believed this world was not the real world. Through dreams he entered the real world, the world of spirits, where his horse floated and danced. Ziolkowski and his wife Ruth decided the memorial, of Crazy Horse on his stallion, would be the largest ever built, nearly 600ft high. The work has been in progress for 50 years and is still not finished, partly because the Ziolkowski family refuse to accept government funding, partly because it is so colossal. The place is a building site, the horse's head is only sketched in. But you look up above the trees and see the stern face of the man, his hair flying out behind him in the stone wind; you see the beauty of the horse; and you think of freedom. The practicals Jean Rafferty organised her trip through STA travel (020 73616262), flying from Glasgow to Rapid City via Minneapolis at a cost oif £264 return plus tax. She took an add-on trip to Kalispell for £250. She stayed at the Alex Johnson Hotel in Rapid City (001 605 432 1210) and shee hired a car through Dollar Rent-a-Car (001 605 342 7071).

fields.headline: Summer of Samos
fields.standfirst: Twenty-odd years after her first visit to the birthplace of Pythagoras,  Helen Oldfield  squares the circle and rediscovers the 70s art of island-hopping
fields.trailText: Twenty-odd years after her first visit to the birthplace of Pythagoras, Helen Oldfield squares the circle and rediscovers the 70s art of island-hopping.
fields.body:
Two great romances and just about everything else of note that's gone on in Samos happened at least 2,000 years ago. Admittedly almost everywhere you go in the Mediterranean seems to have had a brief spell in the BC era when three men, two dogs and a few fast triremes ruled the known world. And you wouldn't want to underplay Samos's AD years when the island has been successively occupied by Romans, Goths, Huns, Venetians, Genoese and, for centuries, Turks, and has seen them all off.

But it was the sixth century BC that spanned Samos's glory days. Democracy had already come and gone. Polycrates - tyrant, legalised pirate and patron of arts and monumental architecture - had seized dominion over the island and the whole of the Aegean. And, at the same time, Pythagoras was working out his right-angled triangle theorem. A couple of centuries later, a Samian mathematician realised that the earth circled the sun, rather than vice versa, at least a millennium and a half before Copernicus.

Of the island's great lovers, Antony and Cleopatra, who called by in the first century BC with their pet leopard, asses' milk baths and exotic dancers, were perhaps the most sybaritic. Hera, queen of the gods, and her lover (and brother) Zeus were undoubtedly the most indefatigable: their wedding night lasted 300 years, and Hera, initially a reluctant bride, later a jealous wife, perpetually renewed her virginity by bathing in the sacred river Imvrasos. The river is still there and so is Hera's temple, once one of the wonders of the ancient world, now knee-high ruins with one solitary pillar standing.

Samos is not quite so cutesy and pretty as some of the other Greek islands. The towns have a business-like air. Samians used to be great ship-builders, now they make their living - aside from tourism - from olive oil and wine growing, including a grand cru dessert wine that is used as a communion wine in some countries (not sure if that is a recommendation). There must be quite a bit of rain some of the year, because the island is very green; there are miles of pine forest, several proper mountains and beautiful, sculpted valleys scattered with cypress trees like exclamation marks.

I first went to Samos in the 1970s as a backpacker heading for Turkey. By mistake we got off the Athens ferry at Karlovassi, the lesser of Samos's two ports and finally pitched up at Pythagorio, birthplace of the geometrician. We stayed with a couple of old ladies who rented out rooms.

Back then, there were maybe half a dozen tavernas and a kind of dairy selling Greek coffee and yogurt, and that was it. Now it is the premier resort of Samos: yachts are moored all along Polycrates's harbour; jewellery shops stand shoulder to shoulder up the high street, and there are hundreds of restaurants and bars. Purists might call it commercialised - I rather like it. In any case, in Pythagoras's day, the town allegedly had a population of 250,000, six times that of the entire island today.

The Turkish coast is only a couple of kilometres across the water from Pythagorio, but when we were first there, only one small ferry made the crossing and you were vigorously discouraged from using it - "Don't you know they have a typhoid epidemic over there." Now there are hydrofoil connections, day trips to Ephesus, regular ferries. You might hear the odd anti-Turkish jibe, but business is business. The real animosity in the spring of 1999 - at least expressed in the graffiti - was directed at Nato for its incursions in Kosovo.

Not that we heard much about that where we were stay ing in Ormos Marathokampos, a little fishing village on the south-west coast of Samos that has a couple of bakeries, a few tavernas, a harbour and a beach. It's the kind of place where you get to know people fast. Yani, who reckoned to make the "best pizzas this side of Naples" at his waterside café, had run a pizza parlour in Cleveland for 27 years before retiring to his native Samos. He spends the winter working on the land and picking up olives. Quite a modest workload compared with some.

Our landlord Costa (we were staying in a self-catering villa) also runs an olive-pressing factory. And, as for Manoli, a restaurateur along the coast, he has his own wine label, an "interest" in olives, helps his father with his charcoal burning in the hills, and is a partner in a bike- and car-rental business. When we met him, he'd just been entertaining some tax inspectors from Lesbos and - how well-organised is he? - they brought him clams and rare and very salty sardines, only found in Lesbos waters, that you eat raw.

On our first day, when good intentions of taking lots of exercise were running high, we set off on a long walk eastward along the bay from Ormos. It was as we turned inland, away from the sea breeze, that we got that first blast of hot, sweet-scented air, that in itself is a reason to visit Greece in springtime. The combined smell of massed wild flowers and oleander, a bit herby, thyme probably, sweeps over you like maple syrup - or Pyrgos honey. Along the road to Chora and Pythagorio, roadside stalls sell bags of fantastically aromatic oregano and and tins of honey from, so the label says, "thyme, coniferous trees, flowers".

Routinely, all Samos's beaches have the prefix "pure white sand" in guide books - this is not strictly or even loosely true. Quite a few are pebbly. Psili Ammos beach, two or three kilometres west of Ormos, is a beautiful exception and it is a good place to begin an exploration of the wild west end of Samos, where Mount Kerkis plunges into the sea, and rarely-used tracks lead to empty coves.

Samos is an island of motorbikes - well, they're mostly 50cc motor scooters, styled to look like motorbikes. They're for hire everywhere. Ours had "Ultimate Weapon" painted on the tank to give that Harley feeling. Zig-zagging up the hills, sun on your back, breeze in your face, magnificent scenery - it is a delightful way to travel. Which is why the walking programme came to rather a standstill, and why we didn't even contemplate climbing Mount Kerkis. This is the highest mountain on Samos, indeed in this part of the Aegean (a bit under 1,500m); a dormant volcano that looms over Ormos, handsome but slightly ominous - the kind of granite lump that might look more tempting with a snowcap.

It presented a challenge to our fellow holiday-makers: two with climbing boots, waterbottle, plus crampons and ropes probably, failed to reach the top having set off at 5am. Another couple tried the after-lunch, flips-flops and ouzo method, and failed, too. Finally an unassuming man in khaki shorts, who used to walk the Peak District, cracked it and was down again in time for a siesta.

Actually, what I missed most from the back-packing days was not lengthy treks on foot, but the island-hopping - the pleasure of being at the mercy of master seamen who, however erratic their timetabling, can charge at a 12ft quay at 20 knots, swivel and park on a sixpence. So we took a smallish jobbing ferry to Ikaria, a neighbouring island, along with a slate lorry, a jeep, a few soldiers (plenty of those in this part of the world), a couple of fellows in windcheaters and a school of backgammon players.

The island is so-named because Icarus, son of Daedalus the inventor, fell into the sea and drowned just off the south coast when the sun melted the wax on his wings. Locals can take you to the precise spot. Anyone would think it was a true story. More recently, Ikaria was a dumping ground for communists and other dissidents during the colonels' era, and it still has a reputation for being pretty (as have most of the islands).

We landed at the capital, Agios Kyrikos, a workaday little town, and walked along the cliff path to Therma, a seaside spa with numerous hot springs, once a resort popular with Greeks, especially those suffering from rheuma tism or gout. But, in decline and out of season, there was a torpid, Death in Venice vibe about the place, which a soak in a bathful of steaming hot, radioactive water did nothing to dispel. Quite the contrary. Still there were signs of something about to happen: chairs were lined up outside restaurants for a lick of paint; an earthmover shifted sand from one end of the beach to the other; hotel foyers were getting a scrubdown. I can imagine it would be a pleasant place to stay, even - or especially - if you have aching joints and sore feet.

On the far side of Ikaria, there is apparently a ravishing beach and the beginnings of one or two small resorts. I hope they won't be the Death of Therma.

The practicals

Helen Oldfield was the guest of Laskarina Holidays (0629 822203/4). Prices for two weeks at Ormos Marakampos, Samos, in self-catering accomodation from £460pp in May (inc flight) to £645 in August. Laskarina also has, for the first time this year, accomodation and hotel rooms on the north coast of Ikaria, which cost around £50-£100 less than equivalents on Samos. The ferry between Samos and Ikaria costs £6 return, more on a hydrofoil.

fields.headline: The triumph of the ordinary
fields.standfirst: Carol Shields says that she could have been 'one of those women who somehow slips out of her own life'. But instead, wife and mother of five children, she has become a hugely successful novelist, one who finds a glory, as well as the devil, in the detail
fields.trailText: Carol Shields says that she could have been 'one of those women who somehow slips out of her own life'. But instead, wife and mother of five children, she has become a hugely successful novelist, one who finds a glory, as well as the devil, in the detail
fields.body:
It was Christopher Potter - now the much-lauded publishing director of Fourth Estate but, back in 1990, a lowly commissioning editor - who "discovered" novelist Carol Shields for a British audience. Though, of course, a writer is not really "discovered". It's a bit like that silly joke: what was the highest mountain in the world before Everest was found? Carol Shields's voice is her own; she "discovered" herself. Still, it was the meticulous Potter, trawling through small Canadian, American and Australian publishers looking for writers - "I knew there were bound to be people who'd been overlooked" - who one day picked up her novel, Mary Swann, then published by a "tiny, ramshackle" firm in eastern Canada, read it and loved it.

So much so that he got hold of her remaining backlist - four novels and a book of short stories - read those, and took the decision to publish the lot.

Shields's work had already done the rounds of British publishers and been "overlooked" by everybody. Yet Potter knew instantly, from the first paragraph: "A character tells a joke about the way she dresses that tells you a lot about her, about her flaws; it tells you she can see her flaws but is unable to do anything about them. It is human and funny, and I knew here was an unusual and a major voice." But then Potter- a former maths student with an MSc in philosophy of science- who came into publishing because it was the first job he was offered, is himself quite unusual. "I never had a plan, no overarching structure" - none of what Shields has designated "ejaculatory narrative" ie linear, plot-driven, resolution-driven.

Potter didn't have any preconceived notions of good writing. "I could please myself," he says. And it just so happened that what pleased him also pleased a great many others. Mary Swann was published to great critical acclaim, with reviewers asking, "Where has this major writer been hidden?" Four years later, The Stone Diaries, the 80-year chronicle of Daisy Goodwill Flett's miserably unsatisfied middle-class life, was short-listed for the Booker, only losing when the chair of the judging panel, Lord Gowrie, put his casting vote behind Roddy Doyle. In 1995, The Stone Diaries won the Pulitzer Prize. "I could easily have been a Daisy Flett," says Carol Shields. "One of those women who erases herself, who somehow slips out of her own life. I only missed it by one generation." Shields was born in 1935, the fictional Daisy in 1905. "Still, thank god for Christopher," says Shields, who hasn't believed in god since the age of six.

There are connections, interstices, moments in a life that seem to change its entire trajectory, and some of them are obvious - getting your book published, the moment when Daisy's first husband, Harold, falls out of the bedroom window on their honeymoon night and is killed. But most of them aren't. All of Shields's writing implicitly asks the question: suppose life is as much in the minutiae as it is in the big picture. We tend to hang our lives on, or fashion them out of, the dramatic episodes - birth, death, love, hate, war - because they impress a pattern on our world. But suppose there is no pattern, or that the pattern is in the detail - most lives are lived in detail: a new recipe for soup, how to find time to take the cat to the vet - and we tend to disregard the detail, or to regard it with contempt, as though it is somehow keeping us from the real business of living. "Ordinary" has become a term of abuse, so to say that Shields chronicles "ordinary lives" will sound disparaging to some ears. Anyway, as she says, "I don't believe in ordinary or extraordinary people, unless we are all extraordinary." She is interested in biography, in how we construct the stories of our own lives and other people's - what we select, what we leave out. Why are we curious about other people, she asks. Are we curious enough about our own lives?

Shields is a feminist, and has been all her life, though she gave this sensibility a name only after reading Betty Friedan in the 70s. When she started writing, she wanted specifically to write about women, family loyalties, "people like me": subject matter that seems conservative. Even she was afraid it was dull. "I didn't think there would be an audience outside women's magazines." But her interest in structure would always mark her as unusual. Happenstance, her third novel, was the dissection of a marriage told from both points of view - first one, then the other. Mary Swann examines the life of a murdered poetess from the perspectives of four individuals, each of whom are obsessed by her. In Larry's Party, her last novel, and a book about a man, the structure mimics the convoluted workings of Larry's thought. The Stone Diaries is the biography of a woman who slowly writes herself out of her own life. And so on. It's not that she has an agenda, she says. "It's just that clearly, if you write a few books, you are going to write about the things that concern you deeply, and perhaps even more deeply than you'd like to confess to. For me, I object to the casual dismissal of women that I so often see."

Childhood is built for happiness, and yet there is almost always something ineradicably sad about it. For Shields, I think, it was her parents' silence. Though they were, she says, the best parents they were able to be, they didn't talk to their children, and for Shields - who is a wonderful listener, who seems scarcely to want to talk herself if she can listen - this must have been so lonely. Anyway, she is married to someone, Don, "43 years this summer", who loves to talk. "He likes nothing more than a table full of people, all talking."

Shields was born in Chicago 64 years ago, in the pretty suburb of Oakland. She was the third child. Her brother and sister are twins - which could have been the root of the loneliness. But no, she says, she never felt excluded. "I was everyone's little darling." Her mother, Ines, of Swedish descent and from whom she must inherit her golden hair, used to tell her that she was an accident. "She turned it into a blessing, so I never minded. But I remember reading how Nancy Friday's life was ruined by her mother telling her that same thing, and I thought, 'Oh, it all depends on how it's said.'"

Life was ordered. A prairie-style house, four rooms up, four rooms down. Church every Sunday. Family meals in the evenings, when her father would serve and carve. "I think he liked that role. Apart from that, I didn't know him very well. I don't think we ever had a real conversation." The thing about children, she says, is that they are not very interested in childhood, they take it for granted. Of course, there are things that you know as a child that stay with you always. "The way that children have of really knowing the surface of their lives. I could put my hand now on a particular square of linoleum in our kitchen and know exactly how it felt." She, too, plays that game at night, when unable to sleep, of revisiting every room of her childhood home, and then every cupboard and every drawer.

But so much is lost, she says, or goes unexamined. As a child, she relished her mother's vast family of seven siblings. "All dead now." (Her mother was the youngest. Was she, perhaps, the accident?) She accepted the fact that her father was alone in the world, that his family was a sort of blank. "All I know about my father's mother is something my mother once told me. That her name was Pearce and that she was 'Proud to be a Pearce'." What should be inferred from this? That the mother-in- law thought her not good enough to marry her son. Not that anything would ever be said. "Ours was a quiet house, reserved . . . I do not come from a storytelling family."

Details. Uncle Harry, her mother's brother, who lost a leg in the first world war and whose mother could never be told. "I've always wondered what sort of woman she was that she could not bear that news." The terrible nightmares she had when she was 10 about a child murder in a Chicago park. "It's a problem what you tell children, how much you protect them. It's how you present it, I suppose." No chance of protection here, with all the mothers talking, huddled in groups, full of whispers and anecdote. Later, Shields would turn this into a short story. "The only real violence of my childhood."

She was six when it began and nine when it ended; the surprise in that, she says, is that it seemed so very long at the time. She is famous in her family for declaring when the war ended: "Good. There will be no more news." To the child, the war was an interruption of life, not life itself. "We didn't even know where Germany was." There were no nightmares about this enemy. But then Potter- a former maths student with an MSc in philosophy of science- who came into publishing because it was the first job he was offered, is himself quite unusual. "I never had a plan, no overarching structure" - none of what Shields has designated "ejaculatory narrative" ie linear, plot-driven, resolution-driven. Potter didn't have any preconceived notions of good writing. "I could please myself," he says. And it just so happened that what pleased him also pleased a great many others. fields.headline: 'Race feud' family's agony over deaths
fields.standfirst: Friend of hanged man describes campaign of harassmentRace issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The agony of the McGowan family began in a small front room in a redbrick house in Wellington, Telford. Amidst salmon pink and faded green wallpaper, Harold McGowan, better known as Erroll, was found hanging on July 2 1999.
fields.body:
The agony of the McGowan family began in a small front room in a redbrick house in Wellington, Telford. Amidst salmon pink and faded green wallpaper, Harold McGowan, better known as Erroll, was found hanging on July 2 1999.

One end of an electric flex had been cut from a clothes iron and wrapped around his neck, and the other end tied to a doorknob. He had two lengths of rope in his van which he used for his job as a builder. Police believe his death was suicide.

Erroll's family say a vicious feud with white racists which police ignored points to something more sinister.

Erroll, 34, had been housesitting for James Ross who, talking to the press for the first time, yesterday told the Guardian that he did not believe that Erroll had taken his own life. He had asked Erroll to look after his home while he was in New York, having known Erroll since birth. Mr Ross said: "He was a happy kid. I don't think he would kill himself."

Erroll had confided in Mr Ross that he was being hassled by white youths in the months leading up to his death: "He was talking about problems with the police not doing anything about the white lads."

The chain of events since Erroll's death has seen his nephew, Jason, also found hanged and allegations that police bungled investigations into the deaths of two more black people. Mr Ross said: "It has upset me. Erroll was like my son."

Erroll would visit Mr Ross, who lives on his own, and cook for him: "He would say 'Jim, relax'. He was so considerate."

Investigation

On Mr Ross's mantelpiece sits a picture of Erroll, smiling, with his fiancee Sharon. He had moved forward their wedding after his mother, Icyline, suffered a stroke. After Erroll failed to show up for work, his sister Doreen went with police to the house. They broke down the door, and she was the first to reach her brother's body.

"Erroll was by the kitchen door, crouched. I just thought he was asleep."

West Mercia police say an inquest into Erroll's death will be held on February 28. A police spokesman stressed that a full investigation had been carried out. But the police report has gone to the coroner, not the crown prosecution service where it would go if charges were pending.

The family says that initially police tried to link Erroll to drug dealing and even suggested that he was a lottery winner who couldn't handle the pressure.

Erroll worked as a bouncer at the Charlton Arms, a hotel in Wellington, where he refused entry to a white youth who was barred by the management after a fight. The family says a catalogue of hate started then, leaving Erroll fearing for his life.

People drove past him drawing their fingers across their throats. White friends of his were asked: "Why are you hanging around with this nigger?" According to his brother Clifton, Erroll was working at the Charlton Arms when a colleague told him his girlfriend was on the phone. When he got to the phone, there was a man's voice saying "You're dead, nigger".

The family also say that a man told Erroll's niece, Sonia, that he was on a Combat 18 death list.

He rang the police at least four times, the last time a week before his death. Clifton said: "The police did nothing to advise him on how he should go about dealing with people harassing him.

"Erroll was a level-headed person. He had no reason to take his own life. He had everything to live for. He loved his three kids, he loved his family."

Erroll's nephew Jason started investigating the death as family unease grew. At 6am on New Year's Day he too was found hanging, this time from railings by a Telford roadside. Nothing about this death, say the McGowans, points to him taking his own life.

The spot where Jason McGowan was found was barely 100m from where he had been celebrating the millennium with friends and his wife Sinead.

Asked in the pub about his new year resolutions Jason, 20, said he did not need to make any as life was going so well.

At around 11.30pm he went outside to get some fresh air. His wife would not see him again.

If he committed suicide, Jason first walked 100 yards, took off his leather belt, attached it to the 5ft high railings and manoeuvred his weight so that he managed to strangle himself.

Police say they are still investigating Jason's death, but the McGowans lack any confidence in them. Their belief that Jason did not take his own life is fuelled by attacks and threats the family received.

In August Erroll's son Omar was attacked by a group, who, it is claimed, held him down, spread his fingers, and put a knife between them. On December 2 Clifton McGowan was phoned and told that unless the family called off its efforts to find out what had happened to Erroll they would get hurt.

Icyline McGowan, Jason's grandmother, has been left shattered by the deaths. Now aged 63, she is the mother of six children and grandmother to 19. She moved to Wellington from Jamaica in 1959. She said that until the harassment Erroll suffered she had experienced no racial prejudice in the area.

After the national newspaper headlines about racism in the town, Telford has started to think whether there is an undercurrent of prejudice.

Asian and black people in Telford make up 3% of the 150,000 population. Most would not give their names but said they had experienced racism in the town.

Kumran Azam, 21, owns a designer clothes shop in Telford's shopping mall. Last Saturday night he was called "Paki" during an evening out. So bad was the abuse while he was a teenager that he took up boxing to protect himself.

He recalls a terrifying incident when aged 13. A white man in a car wound down his window and grabbed his tie: "I thought he was going to drag me to my death. He called me Paki then let me go."

Racism ignored

Kumran said: "Whites don't think racism exists in Telford, they ignore it. They just don't want to know".

The reporting of racism in Telford is bad news for the new town, which is trying to win city status. It was created in 1968. There is one cinema, one theatre and a non-league football team.

Robert, an electrician, bemoans the deteriorating fabric of the town's life. He believes Telford exists for little else but work - often poorly paid - and shopping.

There is an odd sense of community in parts of the town. On the Arleston estate, where Erroll's parents live, members of the local Anti Nazi League sought signatures for a petition calling for a more rigorous police investigation. All bar one person signed. The man in his early 60s who did not want to be named said of the McGowans: "Speaking from an English point of view, do you say that they are making too much out of it? There is an office in the town for racial equality, but there's nothing for white people."

Most white people believe that Jason's death is at least suspicious.

Keith Austin the vice-chairman of Telford and Wrekin council, is also vice chairman of Telford and Shropshire racial equality council. He said: "I believe the sensationalism of reporting in some papers may have attracted the kind of people we don't want in Telford."

For West Mercia police the links being made between the deaths of the McGowans and the Stephen Lawrence case are highly uncomfortable. In a new statement yesterday the force attempted to rebut charges they had not taken the investigation seriously. "We have carried out inquiries into far right groups who were referred to by family and friends of Erroll McGowan. The results of those inquiries indicate that no such group is active in the Telford area.

"We have investigated allegations of past harassment on Erroll McGowan. Six people were interviewed in connection and a file presented to the crown prosecution service. They decided there was insufficient evidence to charge any individuals with racial harassment or in connection with Erroll's death."

A review by a West Midlands detective superintendent into the investigation into Erroll's death had taken place in July 1999 and lasted 10 days. An internal investigation of the handling of both cases is now being undertaken by a Det Supt Mel Shore. West Mercia said close liaison with family members had been a "top priority".

But Clifton McGowan said last night: "It was more a PR exercise to make them look good. They didn't actually tell us anything. They were treating us worse than five-year-old children. I wish now we had recorded some of these conversations."

A spokesman for the anti-fascist magazine Searchlight said Shropshire had high levels of racism, but one of the lowest levels of fascist activity in England.

Icyline McGowan added: "I see what's happening and I am hurt. I would like really the truth to be known, because I believe they didn't do what the police said they did."
fields.bodyText: The agony of the McGowan family began in a small front room in a redbrick house in Wellington, Telford. Amidst salmon pink and faded green wallpaper, Harold McGowan, better known as Erroll, was found hanging on July 2 1999. One end of an electric flex had been cut from a clothes iron and wrapped around his neck, and the other end tied to a doorknob. He had two lengths of rope in his van which he used for his job as a builder. Police believe his death was suicide. Erroll's family say a vicious feud with white racists which police ignored points to something more sinister. Erroll, 34, had been housesitting for James Ross who, talking to the press for the first time, yesterday told the Guardian that he did not believe that Erroll had taken his own life. He had asked Erroll to look after his home while he was in New York, having known Erroll since birth. Mr Ross said: "He was a happy kid. I don't think he would kill himself." Erroll had confided in Mr Ross that he was being hassled by white youths in the months leading up to his death: "He was talking about problems with the police not doing anything about the white lads." The chain of events since Erroll's death has seen his nephew, Jason, also found hanged and allegations that police bungled investigations into the deaths of two more black people. Mr Ross said: "It has upset me. Erroll was like my son." Erroll would visit Mr Ross, who lives on his own, and cook for him: "He would say 'Jim, relax'. He was so considerate." Investigation On Mr Ross's mantelpiece sits a picture of Erroll, smiling, with his fiancee Sharon. He had moved forward their wedding after his mother, Icyline, suffered a stroke. After Erroll failed to show up for work, his sister Doreen went with police to the house. They broke down the door, and she was the first to reach her brother's body. "Erroll was by the kitchen door, crouched. I just thought he was asleep." West Mercia police say an inquest into Erroll's death will be held on February 28. A police spokesman stressed that a full investigation had been carried out. But the police report has gone to the coroner, not the crown prosecution service where it would go if charges were pending. The family says that initially police tried to link Erroll to drug dealing and even suggested that he was a lottery winner who couldn't handle the pressure. Erroll worked as a bouncer at the Charlton Arms, a hotel in Wellington, where he refused entry to a white youth who was barred by the management after a fight. The family says a catalogue of hate started then, leaving Erroll fearing for his life. People drove past him drawing their fingers across their throats. White friends of his were asked: "Why are you hanging around with this nigger?" According to his brother Clifton, Erroll was working at the Charlton Arms when a colleague told him his girlfriend was on the phone. Robert, an electrician, bemoans the deteriorating fabric of the town's life. He believes Telford exists for little else but work - often poorly paid - and shopping. webTitle: To suit or not to suit?

fields.headline: To suit or not to suit?
fields.trailText:
Dear Alan,
Do suits make for a better workplace? Arthur Andersen, who this week dropped the requirement to wear suits from their company dress code, seem not to think so. I disagree: you might not be surprised to hear this, coming from a tailor, but I think most people feel the same. The effort we take in our own personal appearance and style of dress is, rightly or wrongly, always used by others as an initial indication of our character. Not very PC, I know - but a fact that has always been true and, I suspect, always will be.
fields.body:
Dear Alan,
Do suits make for a better workplace? Arthur Andersen, who this week dropped the requirement to wear suits from their company dress code, seem not to think so. I disagree: you might not be surprised to hear this, coming from a tailor, but I think most people feel the same. The effort we take in our own personal appearance and style of dress is, rightly or wrongly, always used by others as an initial indication of our character. Not very PC, I know - but a fact that has always been true and, I suspect, always will be.

In a business environment, first impressions are paramount. I'm not arguing for the introduction of office uniforms - the colour and style of a beautiful suit should, clearly, be as individual as the wearer - but a professional appearance nevertheless speaks volumes about the attitude of an individual and their company. And where do we stop? In 20 years, will office workers claim that there's no need to cut one's hair for six months, or shower only once a week, because it doesn't affect one's work?

Like it or not, most people instinctively want to enjoy the confidence and sense of wellbeing that a quality suit can offer, to a far greater degree than the most fashionable designer jeans and trainers.

Yours,
Tom Mahon
Tailor
Steed Bespoke Tailors

Dear Tom,
Chill, baby. Try and catch Arthur Andersen's new drift. This "first impressions are paramount" thing - it's true. But Andersen's are saying "look, guys, we're not starchy, we're not stiff - we're in the idea business here. We're creative people. We can be buttoned-down without being double-cuffed".

They're just catching a ride on new Britain's new informal approach to business. Take a look at today's high-rollers in commerce: Branson's in jumpers; Evans is in baseball caps; Lynne Franks and Anita Roddick are in kaftans, for Christ's sakes! These free-wheeling tycoons know that cut-away collars and twin-sets constrict the flow of blood to their brain. If someone wears a suit in my workplace, it's because they're off to a bereavement party, or they've been busted - or worse. And it's not just us - it's a lot our clients too. They wear slacks, they wear fashion tops and they're saying: "We're not Ms Brown and Mr Jenkins - we're Lisa and Dave. You can hang with us."

But I agree with you on personal hygiene. I mean, what if Arthur Andersen's employees actually did stop showering? I don't know about you, but I find the idea of meeting any kind of management consultant an alarming prospect, let alone a stinky one.

Increase the peace,
Al Young,
Creative director,
St Luke's advertising agency

Dear Al,
"Chill, baby"; "new drift" Help! The admen are coming! Branson and Evans as fine examples of the new trend? Well, I suppose so, if you consider delayed trains and ginger hair to be cool. I don't doubt the professional abilities of the high-rollers you mention, but aren't they just the ones at the tip of the business iceberg? We all know that changes in our working environment are leading to a diminishing amount of personal contact, which can, unfortunately, fool us into thinking that since everything can be done with computers and telephones there's no need to look good any more. But that way of thinking is a mistake: if we don't care how we look, why care how we think, or act? Who do you really want to look like, anyway? James Bond, or Richard Branson?

We are not all blessed with equal amounts of charisma; some people will be fantastically successful, regardless of the clothes we wear. But most of us need all the help we can get, and dressing smartly and with style each morning can only bring a little extra confidence, which makes us happier and more effective in everything we do.

All this 60s talk went out 40 years ago, Al. But don't worry - you can always hang with me. Still, I bet I get invited to more parties than you.

Love,
Tom

Dear Tom,
Please forgive me for the pseudo-hippy language. It was to illustrate the laid-back modus operandi that's becoming prevalent not just in businesses like mine, but in more "serious" enterprises like Andersen's. This stampede towards the casual has less to do with our growing use of telecoms, and more to do with the growing antipathy towards the uniformity of groups of men in suits. If they look the same, it suggests they think the same - the civil service, the military, the City of London in the 50s.

In advertising agencies, the most smartly attired people are the account handlers. Creative people often refer to them simply as "suits". It's a way to disparage them. They are seen as stuffed shirts, the enemies of creativity. Andersen knows business is hungry to foster individual, unconventional ways of looking at problems or, at the very least, to give the impression of doing so.

Additionally, we've been hearing a lot about the feminisation of the workplace. Booted and suited in a razor-sharp whistle may well increase a chap's confidence and scream success with a capital S - but it can also do damage to the nurturing and inclusive environment that commerce is currently trying to foster. Suits are good for confrontation with employees and suppliers, but perhaps not so good for collaboration.

It may depress you to know that the chairman of St Luke's gave all his work suits to Oxfam three years ago, and now slobs around the office in sweatshirts and jumpers. So keen is he to deformalise attitudes, he will even balk at me calling him "chairman".

Keep sharing that love,
Al

Dear Al,
At least we're in agreement about certain groups of men in suits: I, as much as anyone, have suffered from frustration at the hands of the grey-suit brigade. But I do believe my work to be an art, which couldn't survive without an ability to think creatively. To visit a bespoke tailor and choose the cloth, style and tiniest details of a suit is a very individual approach to the interpretation of one's ideas - a long way from a visit to the quartermaster's stores for a demob suit.

The point I'm trying to make is this: I make clothes for some of the most charismatic and free-spirited individuals anyone could hope to meet - people who would never let themselves be constrained by a suit. Both of us know that jobsworths who gain pleasure from narrowmindedness will do so just as well in casual jackets and slacks as in the finest Savile Row suit. You say a suit is a workplace uniform, but isn't the alternative just to switch to the uniform of the slob? Greyness would remain. We're all motivated to succeed, whatever our business: don't you think that, if wearing a smart suit were detrimental to free though and fresh ideas, we'd have discovered this a little earlier?

I'm confident that, if we have this same debate in 50 years, very little will have changed. In response to your chairman, who now slobs around the office, I'd just say this: I have just finished making two suits for a partner of a very successful London advertising firm. When they put on the completed garments and looked in the mirror, they said simply: "Image is everything".

Your call.
Tom

Dear Tom,
Good points well made. I'll come clean with you: I do have a couple of bespoke suits. It was as much a pleasure to have them made as it has been wearing them. Having clothes that fit - really fit - is wonderful, and whenever I don one, it sends my posture a couple of rungs up the evolutionary ladder. Both were made for the weddings of close friends. They helped me to make each event more important, and acted as a sign of respect to my friends.

On rare occasions, I'll put one on for work. These tend to be times of very high stress, when I want to feel and appear impenetrable, powerful. It's as if I'm putting on a suit of armour, and it works for me.

But I'd far rather look and feel approachable and open-minded. Being dressed up to the nines, however satisfying, doesn't deliver this. This may be one of the reasons why Andersen's are relaxing their dress codes. Business shouldn't be about doing battle and there can be a thin line between panache and posturing.

Unlike your client, I don't believe image is everything. I think how we behave in business is really what we should be looking at. Being good is more important than looking good. Still, it sounds like he was over the moon with his new threads.

All the best,
Al

webTitle: Do any of its current deals involve the borrower having to take the lender's buildings/ contents insurance?

fields.headline: Do any of its current deals involve the borrower having to take the lender's buildings/ contents insurance?
fields.trailText: Halifax: Axed compulsory insurance about seven years ago, so only "a handful" of existing borrowers affected.
fields.body:
Halifax: Axed compulsory insurance about seven years ago, so only "a handful" of existing borrowers affected.

Abbey National: Axed compulsory insurance from core product range about 10 years ago, so very few of the existing borrowers affected.

Nationwide: No.

Woolwich: Axed compulsory insurance in March 1999. Says "small minority" of existing borrowers affected.

Northern Rock: Axed compulsory insurance in summer 1999. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected.

NatWest: No. It has no figures for existing borrowers.

Barclays: No. Says "a small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected.

Alliance & Leicester: No. Only 2% of borrowers who took out loans in 1999 affected.

Norwich & Peterborough: Yes. It has 15 different deals, each available both with and without compulsory insurance (those without have less attractive rates).

Standard Life Bank: No.

webTitle: Does your lender calculate interest on a daily basis?

fields.headline: Does your lender calculate interest on a daily basis?
fields.trailText: Halifax: No, but launching a range of mortgages with daily interest calculation in June.
fields.body:
Halifax: No, but launching a range of mortgages with daily interest calculation in June.

Abbey National: A third of 30-plus mortgages currently on offer feature daily interest calculation, including its flexible mortgage.

Nationwide: No, but does offer daily interest calculation for overpayments.

Woolwich: On 10 of its 24 mortgage deals currently available, the Woolwich calculates interest daily but charges it monthly.

Northern Rock: Of 11 products currently available, only its flexible mortgage offers this. NatWest: No.

Barclays: No, though its base rate tracker features monthly interest calculation.

Alliance & Leicester: No. However, it calculates interest monthly on its flexible mortgages.

Norwich & Peterborough Building Society: No. But, does allow borrowers to make part repayments which are credited the following month.

Standard Life Bank: Yes (it offers only one deal, the Freestyle flexible mortgage, launched in January 1999).

webTitle: Do the loans carry extended redemption penalties, tying you in for perhaps several years after the fixed/capped period ends?

fields.headline: Do the loans carry extended redemption penalties, tying you in for perhaps several years after the fixed/capped period ends?
fields.trailText: Halifax: No - axed them from new mortgage products last year. Says only a "very small percentage" of existing borrowers likely to be tied in by overhanging redemption penalties.
fields.body:
Halifax: No - axed them from new mortgage products last year. Says only a "very small percentage" of existing borrowers likely to be tied in by overhanging redemption penalties.

Abbey National: Axed them from new mortgage products in 1998. Some existing borrowers tied in by penalties.

Nationwide: Current range - no. No idea how many existing borrowers affected.

Woolwich: Yes, six of the 24 deals have overhanging penalties. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected.

Northern Rock: Only one of the current deals has overhanging penalties, but the "overhang" is substantial (a two-year fixed rate with penalties for a total of six years).

NatWest: Current range, no.

Barclays: No - axed them more than six months ago. A "small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected.

Alliance & Leicester: Yes, three of the 10 deals on offer have overhanging penalties. Around 30% of home loans sold in 1999 involve extended redemption penalties.

Norwich & Peterborough: Current range, no. Some existing borrowers affected.

Standard Life Bank: The loan does have an overhanging penalty - the 6.65% standard variable rate is discounted by 0.89% for the first six months, with a penalty of three months' gross interest if you walk away in the first 12 months.

webTitle: What to look for in the new-style loans

fields.headline: What to look for in the new-style loans
fields.trailText: These are the new, supposedly user-friendly CAT-standard mortgages that will go on sale this April.
fields.body:
These are the new, supposedly user-friendly CAT-standard mortgages that will go on sale this April.

Charges:

No separate charge for mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance (also known as "MIG"). Interest must be calculated daily. All other fees disclosed up-front.

For variable-rate mortgages: Interest rate must be no higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate. No redemption charges at all.

For fixed-rate and capped mortgages: Arrangement fee (also known as "booking fee") must not exceed £150. Any early redemption charge must not exceed 1% of the loan for each remaining year of the fixed/capped period, must be set out clearly in cash terms and must reduce monthly. For example, the charge on a £50,000 three-year fixed-rate loan might be £1,500 in the first year (3 x 1%), reducing to £250 in the final six months (0.5 x 1%). No redemption penalties allowed after the end of the fixed/capped period.

Access:

Early repayments are permitted at any time. Regular payments made on any day of the month of the borrower's choosing. Mortgage portable if staying with the same lender when moving house.

Terms:

The information about the mortgage that the borrower receives must be in language that is "fair, clear and not misleading". No requirement to buy the lender's buildings/contents insurance, or other linked products. Six months' notice must be given of any changes to the CAT standard terms.

 Note that the CAT standards will apply to variable, fixed and capped rate deals only. Discounted variable rate deals and cashback mortgages are excluded.

webTitle: A tiger that forgot to roar

fields.headline: A tiger that forgot to roar
fields.standfirst: It should have been a CAT with claws. Instead, the government has produced a tame pussycat to deal with rogue lenders. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: It should have been a CAT with claws. Instead, the government has produced a tame pussycat to deal with rogue lenders.
fields.body:
Hearts sank this week when the government took the wraps off its long-awaited clean-up of the mortgage industry. What consumer groups were hoping for was a sharp-toothed tiger that would prowl the sector tearing strips off rogue mortgage brokers and leaping on lenders peddling rip-off loans.

But instead of a ferocious feline we've got a playful pussycat, say the critics.

Despite a wealth of damning allegations about the variety of ways that mortgage lenders penalise their customers, ministers have decided to take a softly-softly approach to reforming the industry rather than mounting a full-scale crackdown.

Some argue they have thrown away a golden opportunity to stamp out some of the worst scams once and for all, and that the changes will give home-buyers little protection against poor-quality advice and rogue salespeople.

There was a warmer welcome for the government's decision to bring in new minimum standards for mortgages aimed at outlawing misleading small print, exorbitant lock-in penalties and other hidden nasties. The new rules, modelled on those for individual savings accounts, have been dubbed the "CAT" standards (it stands for Charges, Access and Terms). To win the official CAT-mark of quality, loans will have to meet a range of conditions covering clarity, fees and flexibility. But look beneath the glossy fur and this CAT is more than a little moth-eaten in places.

Ministers announced this week that by summer next year, all the UK's mortgage lenders will be policed by the Financial Services Authority, the new "super-watchdog," which will be a given a range of powers to punish firms that break the rules. At the moment, lenders are regulated by a voluntary code of practice regarded by many as pretty toothless.

This change is clearly good news for consumers, as is the announcement that the FSA will regulate mortgage advertising and will insist that the information lenders give about their loans is clear, comprehensive and not misleading.

But where the government has royally blown it, say critics, is in failing to tackle two of the issues that have caused most concern: the poor quality and sometimes downright dodgy mortgage advice given by some salespeople that can leave borrowers trapped in the wrong deals, and the problem of rogue mortgage advisers, who are able to set themselves up in business without any qualifications or training, and go about their business unchecked.

For reasons no one seems able to fathom, ministers have decided not to regulate the mortgage advice on which millions of people rely to help them find the home loan that's best for them. In other words, the basic loan information you are provided will probably be pretty sound but there will be no rules governing the quality of the advice you get.

With more than 4,000 different products to choose from, all with different bells and whistles, mortgages are an area where home-buyers rely heavily on decent advice. Yet all too often it seems they don't get it. One example the Consumers' Association gives is the current scandal over mis-sold endowments, which it says has partly been caused by mortgage advisers falsely claiming that endowment mortgages are more flexible than repayment loans.

Even the FSA's own consumer panel is up in arms. It says the new regime will leave consumers "confused and unprotected against poor-quality advice".

Equally controversial is the government's decision not to bring thousands of mortgage brokers under the umbrella of the new regime. Many of these people are already policed by the FSA because they also sell regulated products such as personal pensions, but an estimated 10,000 are not and therefore fall outside the new system.

While the new regulatory system won't be in place for another 18 months, you will be able to buy a CAT-marked mortgage from April this year. The CAT standards (see panel) will be voluntary - lenders won't have to comply with them, but they will be required to tell borrowers whether or not a particular loan meets the standards and if not, why not.

One of the best reasons for switching to a CAT-marked mortgage is that with these, lenders will be required to calculate people's interest payments on a daily rather than annual basis. Many UK lenders, including the Halifax, the UK's biggest, operate annual interest systems which result in people paying interest on debt they no longer owe. Having their interest calculated daily could save a typical borrower perhaps £70 a year. However, this could be lost if unscrupulous lenders raise rates to compensate for loss of profit.

Other CAT standards include a requirement that all fees must be disclosed.

CAT-marked variable rate mortgages cannot impose any early redemption penalties, which means you can walk away at any time, while in the case of fixed-rate and capped mortgages, there must be no redemption penalties after the end of the fixed/capped period.

Where the CAT standards come unstuck is with the requirement that on variable rate mortgages, the interest rate you pay must be no higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate.

In the current low interest rate environment this will provide very little benefit to homeowners because it is such a wide margin.

Come April, if the base rate is still 5.75%, it means the lender won't be able to charge you more than 7.75%. As Patrick Bunton at mortgage broker London & Country puts it: "There's not a single high street lender with a standard variable rate as high as that at the moment. It's certainly not putting them under any pressure to reduce rates."

But the biggest problem with the CAT standards is that they exclude discounted variable rate mortgages and cashback deals. Discounted rate deals are hugely popular - latest figures from mortgage companies indicate they account for around 50%-60% of all new loans being taken out. Demand for them is likely to increase even further when the anticipated interest rate cuts arrive later this year or early next. Yet if you want a CAT-marked discounted deal, you won't be able to buy one.

So, are there many deals currently on the market that already meet all the CAT standards? Probably very few, reckons Mr Bunton. Many are ruled out because the interest is not calculated daily. With a lot of the fixed-rate and capped deals on the market, the arrangement fee is higher than the maximum £150 that can be imposed (in many cases the fee is around £200-£300), or the way the redemption penalties are structured doesn't meet the CAT requirements.

However, several lenders have come out and said they meet all or virtually all of the standards. Virgin Direct says its Virgin One account - an all-in-one account combining a current account and a mortgage - meets all the standards. Interest is calculated daily and the rate for a typical borrower is 1.2% above base rate. Moreover, there is no arrangement fee, no separate charge for mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance and no redemption penalties at any time.

Co-operative Insurance Society this week launched what it described as a "CAT-friendly" deal. It is a repayment mortgage with a variable rate of 6.7% and a 1% discount for new borrowers in the first year. Interest is calculated daily, it is free of redemption penalties and there is no arrangement fee or mortgage indemnity guarantee insurance to pay.

webTitle: UK and US growth too hot to handle

fields.headline: UK and US growth too hot to handle
fields.trailText: Interest rates look certain to rise on both sides of the Atlantic after new data showed yesterday that the US and the UK are both enjoying robust growth.
fields.body:
Interest rates look certain to rise on both sides of the Atlantic after new data showed yesterday that the US and the UK are both enjoying robust growth.

The UK economy grew by 0.8% in the final quarter of 1999, bringing the annual rate up to 2.7%, its strongest for nearly two years, according to figures published yesterday by the Office for National Statistics.

But, with output growth moderating - the Q4 increase was the same as that recorded in the previous quarter - there are signs that the increases in the cost of borrowing since last September are starting to bite.

"There is little doubt in our minds that further base rate rises are in the pipeline," said Philip Shaw at Investec Research. "But the pace is sufficiently moderate to limit the peak in base rates to 6.5% this year."

The Bank of England's monetary policy committee is next due to meet in early February.

The ONS said the economy expanded by 1.9% in 1999, a fraction above the Treasury's forecasts and well ahead of most private sector economists' predictions.

Growth in the US continued at a blistering pace in the last three months of 1999, according to the US Commerce Department. A consumer shopping spree helped propel the annual rate of growth in the fourth quarter up to 5.8%, the strongest reading for a year.

"Financial markets are telling us that the US economy is getting too hot to handle," said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investor Service. Most economists expect the US Federal Reserve to increase interest rates at its meeting next week, particularly as official
data showed an unexpectedly sharp jump in wage inflation last month.

Last week Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, promised that it would not call a halt to the US economy's record run of growth. February will mark the 107th successive month of expansion, surpassing the 106 month record set in 1969.

The UK expansion which began in the second quarter of 1992, a year and half after the start of the US recovery, broke all previous records for uninterrupted growth back in 1997. The recovery has been going for 30 quarters now, marred only by a quarter of stagnant growth at the end of 1998.

The ONS said industrial production grew at a slightly slower rate in the last quarter of 1999, after recording a 1.2% increase the previous quarter. The services sector expanded by 0.9% in fourth quarter.

"In terms of the various sectors, the economy is now looking better balanced than at any point since the outbreak of the Asian crisis two and half years ago," said Mr Shaw.

Computing services was one area which the ONS said was in recession. The millennium date change, which had been the motor behind demand for IT consultants for most of the year, saw other activity slow down. The millennium also prompted a credit card spending spree, according to separate figures from the British Bankers' Association.

"There was a heavy emphasis on credit card borrowing at the expense of personal loans," said Tim Sweeney, director general of the BBA. "Only time will tell if this borrowing was temporary and planned or whether people over-extended themselves amid the Christmas and millennium celebrations or in the high street sales."

webTitle: Introduction: To suit or not to suit?

fields.headline: Introduction: To suit or not to suit?
fields.body: On Monday, business consultants Arthur Andersen informed their 7,000 staff that suits are no longer compulsory in the office. Is it time to consign the buttoned-up, narrow-minded, suit-wearing hordes to a history of male-dominated, overcompetitive office environments? Or are we forgetting, as we hurtle into the new economy, that first impressions still count, and a professional appearance matters? Thomas Mahon, a Savile Row tailor who has cut for the Prince of Wales, and Al Young, creative director of St Luke's advertising agency, debate the question in this week's Saturday Review debate. Read it and tell us what you think.
