fields.headline: Gallaghers 'lived for drink and drugs'
fields.trailText: New father Noel Gallagher has revealed that he and wife Meg Mathews spent so much of their marriage surrounded by drugs that he worried that quitting them would end their relationship.
fields.body:
New father Noel Gallagher has revealed that he and wife Meg Mathews spent so much of their marriage surrounded by drugs that he worried that quitting them would end their relationship.

In an interview with today's Guardian Weekend magazine, the Oasis star describes his decision to undergo cold turkey and confesses that his wife's pregnancy made it easier for them to give up drugs and move out of London to the Buckinghamshire countryside.

Gallagher, 32, whose daughter Anais was born on Thursday two weeks early at the Portland Hospital in central London, describes their life at their former London home, Supernova Heights, as a continuous party with an open bar, until he decided it had to stop. He said he was worried that their relationship would be different without the drink and drugs.

"We met through drugs. Our relationship was surrounded by drugs. We got married when we were pissed, though we weren't drunk when we decided to get married.

"When I decided I was going to come off it and change the way I lived, in the beginning it was like - how's that gonna be with our relationship? Am I still gonna like her?"

Gallagher also discusses his mixed feelings over his younger brother, Liam. The Oasis frontman, who is also now a parent with his actress wife Patsy Kensit, recently disappeared on a three-day binge.

"If it wasn't for me he'd think it was all right to go on a bender for three days and not see his kid. There's two sides to Liam: when he's pissed he's fuckin' horrible and I hate him, and I really mean that. I fuckin' hate him. It's just psychotic alcohol bullshit and I've got no time for him."

Talking to Lindsay Baker, Gallagher is confident that Oasis have moved on from their early excesses and that the band's new album and forthcoming tour will be less known for the off-stage antics of the brothers.

"Everyone likes a drink and all that, but the chaos seems to have left, and I think we all know we're not some young punks any more. I don't like to say that we're responsible adults exactly, but we want to put on a good show for the people who've bothered to come and see us after all these years."

Gallagher also discusses his mixed feelings over his younger brother, Liam. The Oasis frontman, who is also now a parent with his actress wife Patsy Kensit, recently disappeared on a three-day binge. "If it wasn't for me he'd think it was all right to go on a bender for three days and not see his kid. There's two sides to Liam: when he's pissed he's fuckin' horrible and I hate him, and I really mean that. I fuckin' hate him. It's just psychotic alcohol bullshit and I've got no time for him." Talking to Lindsay Baker, Gallagher is confident that Oasis have moved on from their early excesses and that the band's new album and forthcoming tour will be less known for the off-stage antics of the brothers. "Everyone likes a drink and all that, but the chaos seems to have left, and I think we all know we're not some young punks any more. I don't like to say that we're responsible adults exactly, but we want to put on a good show for the people who've bothered to come and see us after all these years."

fields.trailText: • Find a guru: Ever started a job and wished for someone who would answer any question, no matter how stupid? Maybe you know that you have a certain talent or skill, but can't seem to find a way to use it in the workplace. What you need is a string of mentors, says career counsellor Amy Lindgren. "Some mentors will have the most interest in you when you're just starting out; others will stay connected for the duration of your career.

webTitle: When the offers flood in, let the contest begin

fields.headline: When the offers flood in, let the contest begin
fields.standfirst: But don't slip up if playing one employer against another
fields.trailText: But don't slip up if playing one employer against another
fields.body:
When supermarket giant Sainsbury's installed Sir Peter Davis as its new chief executive on an annual salary of £1.25m, it was only after "long and protracted negotiations". Manchester United captain Roy Keane has just signed a new contract for a staggering £50,000 a week, but, again, this was only after three months of trading and a threat to leave the club.

Bargaining may have paid off for them, but can it work for you? As a new graduate with no track record, it won't be easy - but don't let that deter you.

"Of course it helps if you have some industry experience," says Jeremy Langley of The Graduate Recruitment Company. "But graduates have more leeway than they think and they shouldn't approach their first job thinking I can't negotiate, I'm just a graduate."

Langley divides the graduate job market into two categories. "There's the one that everybody talks about - the blue chip graduate training schemes which account for the top 20,000-30,000 graduates. And the other category - those graduates remaining, which when you consider that 350,000-400,000 leave higher education with a degree every year, represents a huge percentage of the total market.

"It's this category - graduates applying to small and medium-sized firms - where you'll find more scope for negotiating salaries. Don't expect such flexibility from the large companies, which tend to set fixed salary bands for their graduates."

When it comes to talking money, a bit of preparation goes a long way. "Before negotiating, set your benchmark," suggests Langley. "But be realistic. The average salary for a graduate is around £16,000 so you can use that as a basis."

Rod Oakland, deputy director of the University of Birmingham careers centre agrees: "You'll need to present a strong, well-argued case and that means doing some research first."

Most university careers centres can provide data on average starting salaries in different sectors and for different degree subjects. "Whatever you do, don't just pluck a figure out of the air," warns Oakland.

If you have relevant industry experience through a sandwich course, use it. "You should expect to be remunerated accordingly, particularly if you have been working for a competitor," says Langley.

Avoid pricing yourself out of a job. John, a business development manager from London, did just that when he went for an interview as a marketing assistant. "I think it was part naivety and part arrogance. I had a mate in the City who had just started on £22,000 plus perks. So I thought I'd push it. I asked for £19,000 but they only wanted to pay £15,000.

"I thought things had gone well and I really expected them to come back to me with a higher offer. But they didn't and when I phoned they said they liked me but couldn't come close to matching what I was after."

As a top rate graduate, you can command an impressive starting salary in the City. But here, as with other large firms, graduate salaries are set. "If we really want someone, we might offer a sign-on bonus," explains an HR manager from a leading retail bank, "but other than that it's the same salary for any graduate with any degree." Still, £2,000 upfront is not to be sneezed at.

Back to the table and what to do next. A common ploy is to fabricate a counter offer. Curly Moloney of Moloney Search warns: "You have to be very careful. As far as I'm concerned it's best to be honest."

According to Moloney, most companies research their markets and have a good idea of what competitors are paying. "It will look quite odd if you say you've been offered a much higher salary for a similar job." She adds: "If you want to negotiate the salary, you should be open about it from the start. It will look very bad if you spring it on an employer at the last minute if all along you said money is not an issue."

If you are thinking of going down the "better offer" route, take heed. Business communities can be smaller than you think. People know each other - and they talk.

If all else fails, start thinking about your future prospects. Many employers might not be able to move far on salary but they might agree to a training allowance, say £1,500. This will be easier for your boss to justify to his or her superiors.

And it will do wonders for that crucial track record.

fields.headline: News
fields.trailText: • In the money: Graduate salaries in 1999 rose by a healthy 5%, says the Association of Graduate Recruiters annual survey. But the report also shows that the number of vacancies on graduate training schemes last year was down by around a third on 1998. This year, however, employers are predicting a 20% increase in graduate vacancies.
fields.body:
 In the money: Graduate salaries in 1999 rose by a healthy 5%, says the Association of Graduate Recruiters annual survey. But the report also shows that the number of vacancies on graduate training schemes last year was down by around a third on 1998. This year, however, employers are predicting a 20% increase in graduate vacancies.

 Book of the Week: You know you need a new job, but do you know exactly what you want from it and how to go about finding it? Anthony Weldon and friends offer practical advice in their recently updated Breakthrough which is published by Bene Factum. Order your copy at the special price of £8.99 plus p&p from our Cultureshop on 0500 316 6102.

 Dog days: Workers could learn a thing from the dumb dog, says a report in Psychological Bulletin . Whereas a dog will always reject an old bone in favour of a new one, Ohio University researchers say people will stick with unfulfilling jobs for years, even when new opportunities arise.

 Graduate of the Week: A granny who returned to university 60 years after she first began studying has become Britain's oldest graduate at the age of 82. Retired teacher Betty Power decided that you're never too old to learn something new and collected her degree in European and American Studies from the University of Derby at a ceremony last week.

 Halt, who goes there? Leaving your job might not be as easy as you think. A growing number of employment contracts include 'noncompete agreements' which bar you from joining a rival firm. With competition increasing and workers more likely to job-hop, companies see the agreements as a way to guard information that would give competitors an edge.

 Who am I? Although experts doubt that the microwave energy from mobile phones causes brain tumors, researchers at the University of Washington report that the same type of microwaves affect learning and memory in rats. Those exposed to the pulsed microwaves were slower to learn the location of a platform in a water maze than unexposed rats.

webTitle: The worst degrees in the world... ever?

fields.headline: The worst degrees in the world... ever?
fields.standfirst: Subjects that lead straight to the dole queue
fields.trailText: Subjects that lead straight to the dole queue
fields.body:
Have you heard the story about the environmental science graduate earning big bucks in the City? How about the tale of the peace studies graduate carving out a great career in the cut-throat world of media sales? No? Well, neither have I.

In the harsh world of graduate recruitment it is widely accepted that some degree subjects will not be ideally suited to certain types of employment. Blue chip financial institutions, for example, are generally accepted to be looking to recruit blue-chip financial graduates such as accountants or mathematicians.

The justification for this is much the same as that of a horticultural specialist looking for a botany graduate - they are more likely to have the skills required to get the job done. Yet many graduates still labour under the unrealistic belief that when it comes to entering the job market, all degree subjects will be viewed equally.

In reality, the degree subject you study can have an impact on your ability to find a job, the level of that job and the amount you are paid.

A report published last November by the Institute of Employment Research highlighted the different experiences of graduates. It found that the percentage of graduates unemployed for six months or more during the first three and a half years since leaving university was highest for those in the arts, humanities, natural sciences and interdisciplinary subjects - with more than 10% experiencing unemployment. In contrast, among medical, education and engineering graduates the figure dropped below 5%.

Similarly, law, maths, computing, medical, engineering and business graduates came out top in the earnings league while arts, humanities and natural sciences were at the opposite end of the scale.

These findings are backed up by people working on the front line of graduate employment: "Cultural studies graduates may come out of university very well-rounded individuals but trying to place them into jobs afterwards is not that easy," quips one recruitment consultant.

It seems that while most academics still regard a degree as a measure of excellence that proves your worth in the job market, this view is not often shared by employers: "There are more graduates than ever before and matriculation is easier, so companies are looking for more and more relevant degrees," says Asela Ali, development executive at Reed Graduates. "You get a lot of company brochures and careers fairs where companies say any degree subject considered - when what the employer actually means is you don't need to have studied accountancy, maths and physics will do."

Ali admits that she has found it harder to place graduates in certain degree subjects in the past - including film and media studies, American studies, fine art and history of art. Yet worried graduates in these subjects might be heartened to hear that she also has seen those with so-called vocational qualifications such as biochemistry struggle after opting not to pursue their subject as a career.

It is true that in the UK, unlike some of our European neighbours, it is not yet necessary to choose your degree according to your future career plans. Yet at the same time it is wise to accept that your choice of degree is likely to rule you out of certain areas of employment. This is certainly the view of Adam Bass, managing director of careers service Gradunet (www.gradunet.com). It allows employers to scan a database of graduates for suitable candidates and Bass admits that some clients will search the system on the basis of a degree subject.

Yet he suggests there are other ways to grab their attention: "If you're very good at your subject you will impress the employers much more than someone with a 'relevant' degree," he says. "While if you're not brilliantly academic then a relevant degree will load the odds in your favour."

Meanwhile if you're heading for a poor second in ancient Greek, don't panic. Impressing employers is all about scoring points and there are ways to make up the balance. Choice of university can be significant, as is the class of degree and having relevant work experience: "If a graduate has practical experience, irrespective of their degree, it is clearly very useful," says Chris Ingledew, head of recruitment specialist Graduate Link.

Peter Hawkins, an advisor at the university of Liverpool's Graduates Into Employment Unit (GIEU), believes students should focus on gaining employability skills during their years at university: "I tell my students, to be employed is a risk, to be employable is secure. This is not always about a choice of subjects but about tactics. Unfortunately students are often not ready for this message until it is too late."

fields.headline: Top rung, bottom rung
fields.trailText:
Andrew Coker, 40, Corporate comms manager, Tesco

James Jackson, 28, Management trainee, Tesco
fields.body:
Top rung

Andrew Coker
Aged 40
Corporate comms manager
Tesco

Leaving university with a politics degree, and after a spell as a prep school teacher, Andrew Coker fulfilled his boyhood dream of getting into broadcasting when he joined the BBC. "I spent 10 years as a journalist with the BBC and independent radio," he says.

But he decided on a career change into public relations - first with a voluntary sector organisation then, in 1994, with Tesco.

Check out: His role covers all corporate communications, including media relations. "If there's a major Tesco initiative (positive or negative) then I make the announcement."

Job buzz? "I love the diversity of it. And I work with tremendous people who, whatever they do, are all customer focused. It makes it a lot of fun."

Must-have qualities: Andrew believes graduates must be both team players and individuals with flair. "You have to like working with people - your colleagues and the customers.

"At the same time, you must show something that makes you a Tesco person - a desire to enjoy what you're doing."

Special offer: Tesco provides, he says, the best job graduates will ever have. "There are tremendous opportunities both in the UK and abroad."

Bottom rung

James Jackson
Aged 28
Management trainee
Tesco

Supermarkets must have seemed a million miles away to James Jackson as he studied malaria for his doctorate. "After all the years at Keele for my degree then Aberystwyth for my PhD, I decided academia was not for me. I didn't want to be stuck in a library. I wanted more activity," he says.

So, he joined Tesco's management training scheme - one of 13 graduates to do so from 3,000 or more who applied in 1998.

Shelf life: As part of an 18-month programme, James has had a spell working in aspects of a branch (from dealing with customers to operating tills) and a stint at head office.

Trainees receive support from branch managers and personnel, while there are internal and external business courses leading to professional qualifications.

Work environment: "Tesco is very graduate-friendly. It doesn't matter what degree you arrive with, graduates are seen as crucial to the future of the business."

In store? "I am hoping to become a buyer in convenience foods - that would be a dramatic opportunity in a multi-million pound area.

"Longer term, Tesco is a global company and there may be a chance to go abroad."

 For more details visit www.tesco.co.uk

fields.headline: Frequent flyer
fields.trailText: Captain Glenis Maloney, Helicopter pilot, currently posted to the army's ethnic minorities recruiting team (EMRT)
fields.body:
Name:
Captain Glenis Maloney

Status:
Helicopter pilot, currently posted to the army's ethnic minorities recruiting team (EMRT)

Past:
Computer science degree from Portsmouth University, followed by two years with NatWest. Signed up to Royal Corps of Signals at Sandhurst and commanded troops in Bosnia and North Carolina. Gained 'wings' in 1998. Took part in climbing expeditions to the Alps and Mexico.

Present:
Has just completed three years at Army Air Corps as a reconnaissance pilot in an anti-tank squadron, then as commander of ground support. Now responsible for tasking the EMRT.

Future:
"I want to continue climbing the promotion ladder and hope to make a difference in recruiting ethnic minorities."

Strengths:
"I'm a people person and I'm pretty caring towards the people in my charge. I also work well under pressure."

Weaknesses:
"I don't like desk jobs and my attention to detail isn't always that good."

Wisdom:
"Be flexible and adaptable. Look after the people under your command, and your career will look after itself."

References:
www.army.mod.uk or 08457 300 111

fields.headline: Moscow cracks down on media
fields.standfirst:
Crisis in Chechnya: special report
Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian authorities have arrested a journalist who worked to expose the suffering wrought by the Chechnya war, accusing him of joining the guerrillas in the Caucasus.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities have arrested a journalist who worked to expose the suffering wrought by the Chechnya war, accusing him of joining the guerrillas in the Caucasus.

The arrest came as the Russian leader, Vladimir Putin, yesterday stoked the fires of a new Russian militarism and nationalism by lashing out at "all sorts of scum" who were bent on tearing Russia to pieces and bringing it to its knees.

"Throughout the entire history of our country, it has always been that it only takes Russia to become weaker for all sorts of scum to pop up and try to beat our country, tear it to pieces, and force it to its knees," Mr Putin said. "No one has ever succeeded, nor will they ever, because simple Russian people have always stood in the way."

Russian intelligence sources yesterday told the Interfax news agency that Andrei Babitsky, a reporter for the US-funded Radio Liberty who had been missing for 12 days, had been arrested in Chechnya and faced charges of belonging to an illegal armed group.

Russian RTR state television confirmed the report, quoting Oleg Aksyonov, an interior ministry spokesman, as saying Mr Babitsky was being held in Chechnya because he lacked the proper military accreditation to work in the war zone.

Another leading Moscow journalist, Aleksandr Khinshteyn, who specialises in investigating sleaze in the government, has gone into hiding to avoid being taken to a psychiatric clinic by the police, who want him detained for alleged driving licence offences.

A couple of hundred journalists and human rights activists demonstrated yesterday outside the police ministry in Moscow to protest against the hounding of Mr Khinshteyn, an investigative television and newspaper reporter.

The press crackdown by forces under the former KGB agent Mr Putin, and the reversion to the old Soviet practice of dispatching dissident voices to psychiatric clinics, are sending ripples of fear through Moscow's independent media.

"Today they want to send us to the asylum, tomorrow they'll be closing down the newspapers," said Pavel Gusev, the editor of Moscow's bestselling newspaper, Moskovsky Komsomolets, said.

Mr Babitsky has courted great personal risk by spending weeks under Russian bombardment in Grozny and elsewhere in Chechnya during the four-month conflict. He is also a veteran of the past Chechen war of 1994-96.

On Wednesday, Sergey Yastrzhembsky, the Russian spokesman on Chechnya, said that Mr Babitsky's disappearance proved that the Russian authorities could not guarantee the safety of journalists working in Chechnya.

Oleg Panfilov, head of the Glasnost Fund monitoring media freedom, disclosed yesterday that Mr Babitsky was being held by Russian troops in a cellar in Urus-Martan, south of Grozny.

"The generals will go to any lengths to prevent journalists from seeing the present war and its consequences," he said. "The detention is absolutely illegal." The reporter could be jailed for five years if found guilty of joining the Chechen guerrillas.

Earlier this week Vladimir Kozin, a foreign ministry official, urged "more decisive and concrete action to create an information blockade for western journalists undertaking subversive work on Chechnya territory".

The World Association of Newspapers has just written to Mr Putin to point out that the killing of 11 journalists last year in Russia made the country the most dangerous place in Europe for the media.

"We remain seriously concerned at the appalling level of danger facing members of the press. Such violence fosters a climate of fear that inhibits journalistic investigation and promotes self-censorship," the letter said. "Independent journalists covering election campaigns reportedly remain at greatest risk."

webTitle: German cash scandal claims new scalp

fields.headline: German cash scandal claims new scalp
fields.standfirst:
Widening party funding inquiry throws doubt on Kohl-Mitterrand methods of safeguarding European unity
German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The German Christian Democrats' most senior accountant resigned yesterday as connections were made between two previously distinct aspects of the scandal surrounding the party's funding - with potentially explosive results.
fields.body:
The German Christian Democrats' most senior accountant resigned yesterday as connections were made between two previously distinct aspects of the scandal surrounding the party's funding - with potentially explosive results.

Horst Weyrauch stepped down as prosecutors began studying files seized in a raid on the party's offices in Frankfurt. He is alleged to have set up a web of secret accounts to recycle funds for the Christian Democrats in Hesse, the region which includes Frankfurt.

But he is also a key figure in the scandal surrounding donations to the party's central treasury, which has implicated the former chancellor Helmut Kohl and his successor as leader of the Christian Democrats, Wolfgang Schäuble.

The head of a parliamentary inquiry into the origin of the federal party's cash said yesterday that he would seek to widen the scope of the inquiry to take in Hesse, since there now appeared to be links between the two scandals.

It has become like one of those gigantic domino assemblies that the Chinese like to lay. Every piece in the scandal seems positioned to knock over the next and, as each line looks about to end, it sets off another. But now, it seems, they are starting to converge.

What started as an investigation into a millionaire's tax affairs has spread with breathtaking speed over an ever greater area. It is no longer about the reputation of Mr Kohl or the fate of his successor. It is no longer even about the survival of Europe's biggest conservative party. There is now a huge question mark over the methods used by Mr Kohl and his friend, the late French president François Mitterrand, to shape a more integrated Europe in the 1990s.

The scandal emerged on August 29 last year, when Royal Canadian mounted police arrested a businessman of dual German-Canadian nationality, Karlheinz Schreiber, in a restaurant in Toronto. Mr Schreiber was already the central figure in a separate controversy, over commission paid on the $1.5bn (£900m) sale of 34 Airbus jets to Air Canada in 1988.

The mounties were acting on a warrant issued by German prosecutors, who suspected Mr Schreiber of not paying DM25m (£8m) in tax on the commission from deals he had helped broker in the late 1980s and early 1990s.

As he fought extradition, Mr Schreiber began talking about his colourful past as an international intermediary - in particular about a donation of DM1m (£340,000) he had paid in cash to two senior Christian Democrat officials he met in Switzerland. One was the party's then treasurer, Walther Leisler Kiep. The other was Mr Weyrauch.

The first column of dominos had fallen, and was about to tip down another.

The prosecutors knew the contribution had never been declared by the Christian Democrats, but suspected it had been pocketed by Mr Kiep. In early November they issued a warrant for his arrest. Mr Kiep told them they had got it wrong: the truth was far more interesting. The money had secretly gone to the party.

His explanation was endorsed by the Christian Democrats' former campaign manager Heiner Geissler, one of many embittered party officials who had clashed with Mr Kohl in the 25 years he ran the party. Mr Geissler said there had been a string of bank accounts to disguise the origin of some of the party's funds.

German law requires all donations of more than DM22,000 (£6,700) to be made public. The party split up the money into lesser sums that did not appear to require disclosure. It was money laundering.

The third line of tiles began to fall on November 30, when Mr Kohl admitted the allegation was true. He later confessed to accepting up to DM2.2m (£670,000) in secret cash donations. He had not taken the money for himself but for the party, he said. The cash was used to build a power base for the Christian Democrats in the newly incorporated east Germany. But Mr Kohl refuses to say who gave it to him.

His account called into question the role of the Christian Democrats' current leadership. Most, including Mr Schäuble, had worked closely with him for years.

In a statement to parliament, Mr Schäuble gave the clear impression that he had had no significant dealings with Mr Schreiber. He was aware of having met him only once, at a fundraising dinner.

But less than a month later, the Christian Democrat leader astonished the country by altering his story in a television interview. He had met the ubiquitous intermediary again, on the day after the dinner, and been handed DM114,000 (£35,000) in cash. The money was never disclosed. But that, said Mr Schäuble, was not his fault. It was the responsibility of the then party treasurer. Mr Schäuble has refused to resign.

In different parts of the continent, several more domino tracks have been set tumbling.

In Berlin prosecutors are investigating whether the suicide this month of Wolfgang Hüllen, the official who kept the parliamentary party's books, was linked to the scandal.

Independent auditors in Berlin have meanwhile admitted they are unable to trace the origin of another DM11m (£3.4m) which cropped up in the federal party's books for the period 1989-92.

A joint investigation by French and German journalists reported last weekend that Mr Kohl took DM32.5m (£10m) in secret campaign donations arranged by Mitterrand. But that sum does not fit into the amount still unaccounted for in the party's central accounts.

In Hesse officials have acknowledged that the sum involved there could be as high as DM22m (£6.8m). But while its origins remain unknown, the money is said to have reached the party's local slush fund 10 years before the alleged French donation.

That raises the question of whether the Christian Democrats held on to cash arising from a previous exercise in irregular funding in the 1980s.

The momentous political scandal that began as the "Kiep affair" could involve up to £20m. But with so many questions unanswered, there are many dominos yet to fall.

webTitle: Why Apple's users can't raise a Smile

fields.headline: Why Apple's users can't raise a Smile
fields.standfirst:
Despite the huge success of the iMac, software developers seem intent on cutting its owners out of online finance. David Cohen reports

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: If you are one of the 1.35m people who bought an iMac in the past three months, congratulations, you've just joined a select group. You are also using an industry pariah. iMacs are second-class citizens when it comes to financial services on the internet.
fields.body:
If you are one of the 1.35m people who bought an iMac in the past three months, congratulations, you've just joined a select group. You are also using an industry pariah. iMacs - all Macs for that matter - are second-class citizens when it comes to financial services on the internet.

The latest example of this exclusion is the internet bank smile.co.uk - the first in the UK to offer a current account. Two months after its launch Smile is still inaccessible to Mac users because of a software problem. Surf to the bank's secure web site on your Mac and all you'll get is a blank page. Smile customer services say they "are aware of the problem and are working to fix it". But a little investigation reveals the glitch is just the tip of an iceberg.

Smile's owner, The Co-op Bank, puts the blame on flaws in the Mac version of Java - an internet operating system specifically designed to run on any computer. It says it trusts only Java to ensure online banking is kept hidden from prying eyes.

"We are unapologetically Java-based because only Java offers the level of security we need," says Co-op spokesman David Smith. He says the bank knew Mac users would have a problem using the service before the system's launch, though the fact was conveniently ignored during the Smile advertising campaign.

Smith claims Macs are at fault for the incompatibility. "[The service] is aimed at people with up-to-date equipment who are very comfortable with the internet," says Smith. "It's the Macs that need to be sorted out."

But Mac experts say it is not a Mac problem at all but a Smile problem. "Banks that claim [that Macs have] a security issue are talking nonsense," says Alex Sobosley, editor of MacFormat. Java was intended to create a single internet-wide standard for programming on the web. But Microsoft did not stick to the Java design standard when it wrote its version for Windows machines.

Consequently Smile programmers were left with two different systems to cater for and Mac users have drawn the short straw. Meanwhile Windows users are enjoying Smile's 4.33% interest rate and free £500 overdraft in their droves. Some Mac users regard it as a form of computer apartheid.

Smile is not the only example of Mac marginalisation. Two of the latest home-finance and accounting packages, Money 2000 from Microsoft and Intuit's Quicken, are not available to Mac users. The packages are designed to help you keep track of your daily credits and debits, connect to your bank account via the internet, gather mortgage information, manage investments, savings and bills, and even create a will.

Money 2000 is written exclusively for Windows machines, while the Mac version of Quicken is not for sale to European customers - though it retails for $49.95 in the US. And forget about buying Quicken online. Intuit will supply the Mac package only to customers in Canada and the US. If you're a European with a Mac, you're simply not getting it. The reason for this bizarre situation eludes Intuit's UK support staff, who don't even know the Mac version exists.

The main reason for this anti-Mac attitude is the financial cost of developing software for the proportionally small number of Mac owners - 1.6m in the UK, or one-in-10 of all personal computers. But some blame a deeper anti-Mac conspiracy.

Industry insiders accuse software publishers of trying to eliminate Mac versions of software to cut costs. John Cormack, the creator of the popular computer game Quake, recently urged Mac owners not to buy the Windows version of the game and run it on a Mac using a Windows emulator, but rather to wait until the Mac version was released. Both versions were ready at the same time, but the Windows version went on sale first. Cormack said that if the publishers saw that the Mac version was not selling (because Mac users had bought the Windows version) they would pull the plug on any further Mac development. The same applies to the financial software industry.

A case in point is Market Maker - an online share-trading package supplied by the CMC group in Hertfordshire. No Mac version is available because most of the company's existing customers use Windows PCs. Market Maker is the first system to give share prices in real-time and to perform transactions in seconds. Typical online share trading systems are email based, transactions can take anything from 30 seconds to 30 minutes, while new share prices are published every 10 to 20 minutes.

If you're not a budding Gordon Gekko, the email system might suit you just fine, but there is another advantage in Market Maker. CMC is pioneering a dealing service called Contracts for Difference, which effectively allows you to trade five times as many shares as you pay for. With as little as £5,000 you could become a day-trader from your home. The service, launched on January 10, has already gathered hundreds of customers - all Windows users. But Andrew Palmer, CMC marketing manager, believes the Mac market is simply too small to be worth the development costs.

Like the Quake players, one solution is to fork out for an emulator and fool the opposition into thinking you're using a Windows PC. But you'd be losing out on all fronts. There's the speed issue - programs run faster if they are written for the specific hardware. Worse still, not all software is compatible with the emulator and technical problems are a nightmare to sort out.

Despite all this, I believe my own iMac was worth the cash, if only to stick two fingers up at the Gates empire. The Mac has survived similar crises before, and there is other software out there, albeit non-standard. But there are greater forces than my iMac at play, and if industry attitudes don't change soon we privileged few may soon become quirky has-beens.

Smile

fields.headline: Can they sing in harmony?
fields.standfirst:
The linkage of giants like EMI and Time Warner could bring huge problems of integrating people and styles. John Crace reports.

Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The linkage of giants like EMI and Time Warner could bring huge problems of integrating people and styles.
fields.body:
This week's merger of Britain's EMI and America's Time Warner brings together into one giant music company stars as diverse as Madonna and Martine McCutcheon. And while Madonna is unlikely to be working with Martine, the staff of the two companies will have little choice but to get on - and the evidence of past mergers is that they often come unstuck on the shop floor.

The chief reason why they fail is mishandling of staff in the wake of a deal, and a clash of cultures between the companies.

"Even the best strategic logic will only work if it can be implemented," says Dr Richard Schoenberg, senior lecturer in international business strategy at London's Imperial College Business School. "And as the employees are closely involved in the implementation and have to live with any uncertainty, they need to be consulted every step of the way."

Part of the problem is that cultural differences between companies are notoriously difficult to measure. The number-crunchers dissect the balance sheets of potential acquisitions with ruthless efficiency, but base their analysis of the "softer" issues on little more than assumptions, because they have little real scientific data to go on.

The results are there for all to see. "We have gone from one new management fad to the next in the past 15 years," says Mike Fiszer, senior specialist in organisational development and change at the Irish Management Institute. "We've had restructuring and business process re-engineering, but neither has been particularly effective in smoothing the period of transition after a takeover. The reason is that more often than not companies have these solutions foisted upon them with little understanding of the values that underpin these organisations."

Five years ago, Mr Fiszer, and another business psychologist, Ros McCarthy, set out to construct a tool that could measure the core values of an organisation and could accurately predict potential areas of conflict and compatibility between two companies. The Organisation Character Audit profiled 20 different values, such as focus on performance, diligence and integrity, and constructed a form of group psychometrics that would allow them to map these values on a scale from 1 to 100.

The beauty of the method was that it could expose any myths a company might hold about itself, and that by superimposing the maps of the two organisations on top of one another, hotspots became readily apparent. Moreover, it provided the structure by which an acquiring company could best manage the transition by pinpointing the best type of people to put in charge to achieve the acquisition objectives.

As with many new ideas, the Organisation Character Audit has proved a step too far for many commercial accountants. However, Mr Fiszer's work with a finance company and a retail leisure group was so successful that SmithKline Beecham asked him to develop a cultural assessments tool for use in strategic initiatives. Mr Fiszer is unwilling to discuss his commercial work, but the failure of SKB's first attempted merger with Glaxo Wellcome in 1998 due to the incompatibility of management styles proves his point.

What Mr Fiszer and other leading management specialists are agreed on is that it is the quality of the leadership that will often determine the success or failure of a takeover. The key to this is communication. Ernst & Young and the Warwick Business School's joint report into acquisition management found a depressing catalogue of despair amongst staff.

"We were left in a complete vacuum," said one senior employee. "All we did was carry on. I had a futile role as managing director." Another reported that: "I was extremely frustrated and mystified that I never had any discussion with any board member about the future of the company. There was no discussion as to potential synergy."

Mr Fiszer believes that the new breed of manager needs emotional as well as business intelligence. "He or she needs the credibility to get performance in times of uncertainty," he says. "They must be able to communicate the vision and involve staff in it. There must also be an acceptance that many acquisitions can and will take years to integrate and that goals may shift along the way."

You don't have to look far to see what happens when companies get it wrong. The 1996 merger between Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance is universally acknowledged to have underperformed. "They fudged the leadership issue by maintaining a dual chief executive role between two men who were obviously in competition," says Trevor May, an insurance analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.

"It took the chairman 18 months to bite the bullet and sack them both. Moreover their declared cost-saving targets of £300m were not aggressive enough for the market. So they created unnecessary tensions and uncertainties by dragging out the unpleasant decisions. They have now announced a further £100m of cost-savings."

Mergers almost always involve redundancies, and there is no easy way for companies to sweeten the pill. Creating uncertainty merely makes a bad situation worse. The able people find another job, while the remainder often feel angry and insecure about the way they have been treated and lose commitment to the company's future. Let's hope the alarm bells are ringing at AOL, Time Warner and EMI.

Time Warner
fields.bodyText: This week's merger of Britain's EMI and America's Time Warner brings together into one giant music company stars as diverse as Madonna and Martine McCutcheon. And while Madonna is unlikely to be working with Martine, the staff of the two companies will have little choice but to get on - and the evidence of past mergers is that they often come unstuck on the shop floor. The chief reason why they fail is mishandling of staff in the wake of a deal, and a clash of cultures between the companies. "Even the best strategic logic will only work if it can be implemented," says Dr Richard Schoenberg, senior lecturer in international business strategy at London's Imperial College Business School. "And as the employees are closely involved in the implementation and have to live with any uncertainty, they need to be consulted every step of the way." Part of the problem is that cultural differences between companies are notoriously difficult to measure. The number-crunchers dissect the balance sheets of potential acquisitions with ruthless efficiency, but base their analysis of the "softer" issues on little more than assumptions, because they have little real scientific data to go on. The results are there for all to see. "We have gone from one new management fad to the next in the past 15 years," says Mike Fiszer, senior specialist in organisational development and change at the Irish Management Institute. "We've had restructuring and business process re-engineering, but neither has been particularly effective in smoothing the period of transition after a takeover. The reason is that more often than not companies have these solutions foisted upon them with little understanding of the values that underpin these organisations." Five years ago, Mr Fiszer, and another business psychologist, Ros McCarthy, set out to construct a tool that could measure the core values of an organisation and could accurately predict potential areas of conflict and compatibility between two companies. The Organisation Character Audit profiled 20 different values, such as focus on performance, diligence and integrity, and constructed a form of group psychometrics that would allow them to map these values on a scale from 1 to 100. The beauty of the method was that it could expose any myths a company might hold about itself, and that by superimposing the maps of the two organisations on top of one another, hotspots became readily apparent. Moreover, it provided the structure by which an acquiring company could best manage the transition by pinpointing the best type of people to put in charge to achieve the acquisition objectives. As with many new ideas, the Organisation Character Audit has proved a step too far for many commercial accountants. However, Mr Fiszer's work with a finance company and a retail leisure group was so successful that SmithKline Beecham asked him to develop a cultural assessments tool for use in strategic initiatives. Mr Fiszer is unwilling to discuss his commercial work, but the failure of SKB's first attempted merger with Glaxo Wellcome in 1998 due to the incompatibility of management styles proves his point. What Mr Fiszer and other leading management specialists are agreed on is that it is the quality of the leadership that will often determine the success or failure of a takeover. The key to this is communication. Ernst & Young and the Warwick Business School's joint report into acquisition management found a depressing catalogue of despair amongst staff. "We were left in a complete vacuum," said one senior employee. "All we did was carry on. I had a futile role as managing director." Another reported that: "I was extremely frustrated and mystified that I never had any discussion with any board member about the future of the company. There was no discussion as to potential synergy." Mr Fiszer believes that the new breed of manager needs emotional as well as business intelligence. "He or she needs the credibility to get performance in times of uncertainty," he says. "They must be able to communicate the vision and involve staff in it. There must also be an acceptance that many acquisitions can and will take years to integrate and that goals may shift along the way." You don't have to look far to see what happens when companies get it wrong. The 1996 merger between Royal Insurance and Sun Alliance is universally acknowledged to have underperformed. "They fudged the leadership issue by maintaining a dual chief executive role between two men who were obviously in competition," says Trevor May, an insurance analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "It took the chairman 18 months to bite the bullet and sack them both. Moreover their declared cost-saving targets of £300m were not aggressive enough for the market. So they created unnecessary tensions and uncertainties by dragging out the unpleasant decisions. They have now announced a further £100m of cost-savings." Mergers almost always involve redundancies, and there is no easy way for companies to sweeten the pill. Creating uncertainty merely makes a bad situation worse. The able people find another job, while the remainder often feel angry and insecure about the way they have been treated and lose commitment to the company's future. Let's hope the alarm bells are ringing at AOL, Time Warner and EMI. Time Warner

webTitle: Hamilton says backers may escape £2m bill

fields.headline: Hamilton says backers may escape £2m bill
fields.standfirst: Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton claimed yesterday that his supporters may escape the estimated £2m bill for his failed libel action against the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, if they can show they were motivated by a genuine sense of justice.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton claimed yesterday that his supporters may escape the estimated £2m bill for his failed libel action against the Harrods owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, if they can show they were motivated by a genuine sense of justice.

Lord Harris of High Cross, who coordinated the former Conservative MP's "fighting fund", was given until February 25 to disclose the names of backers who had donated more than £5,000. Mr Justice Morland, sitting at the high court in Manchester, also ordered that he hand over all documents which reveal the main donors' reasons for contributing to the fund.

There were signs last night that Mr Fayed, in his determination to recoup his legal costs, was turning his sights from the "broke" former corporate affairs minister to the wealthy Earl of Portsmouth, one of Mr Hamilton's principal backers. Laurie Mayer, Mr Fayed's spokesman, said: "Once we have all the information we will then be considering what further steps to take against one or more of the individual contributors."

Ten years ago the earl put up £376,000 to finance Nikolai Tolstoy's libel defence against Lord Aldington over alleged war crimes. Now he is understood to be determined to fight Mr Fayed to the House of Lords if necessary.

In the light of yesterday's ruling Lord Harris may have to disclose any correspondence which accompanied the donations: if any of the backers expressed derogatory comments about Mr Fayed, or demonstrated in any other way that they were motivated by a malicious desire to undermine the Harrods owner, they would find it difficult to avoid being pursued for more cash. But Mr Hamilton was confident that his supporters had acted genuinely, and challenged Mr Fayed to give up the fight to recoup his share of the legal costs. Lord Harris has claimed that many of those who had contributed to the fund, which stands at £410,000, were ordinary people who believed in the justice of Mr Hamilton's cause. "Theoretically Fayed could pursue every single one of the hundreds of people who donated modest amounts, and force a procession of the halt and the lame up the Strand to the law courts," Mr Hamilton said.

He argued that if his principal backers could prove the purity of their desire to prevent the legal process from being used as a "tool of oppression" of the wealthy against the poor it would be difficult for Mr Fayed to convince a judge to order them to pay up. The Earl of Portsmouth, who has confirmed he donated more than £5,000 to Mr Hamilton's fund, would be able to make a good case, Mr Hamilton argued. "I didn't know him from Adam."

Mr Fayed, however, remained defiant. His spokesman said some of Mr Hamilton's supporters had publicly stated their antipathy towards Mr Fayed. "We are pursuing our costs," he said.

Lord Harris must provide to Mr Fayed a witness statement identifying supporters who donated more than £5,000 to the Hamilton fund, and any documents outlining the reasons for their support, by February 25. Mr Hamilton must provide any similar information in his possession by February 11. The former MP was given until last night to confirm to Mr Fayed's solicitors the total amount raised by the fund, the amount donated by the Earl of Portsmouth, and the fund's bank details.

Mr Fayed can still pursue Mr Hamilton to recoup his costs; but the former MP said this would be fruitless. "I owe everything I've got to my own lawyers, so there is no way I could pay him anything. Either way, X equals nought."

fields.headline: Surgeon 'devastated' by kidney op blunder
fields.standfirst: Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The surgeon at the centre of the bungled kidney operation that has left a south Wales pensioner fighting for life spoke last night of his distress at what had occurred.
fields.body:
The surgeon at the centre of the bungled kidney operation that has left a south Wales pensioner fighting for life spoke last night of his distress at what had occurred.

As officials at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli decided to delay announcing their preliminary findings into what went wrong, consultant urologist John Roberts said that in 30 years of surgery he had been responsible for more than 30,000 operations and nothing such as this had ever happened before.

"As the consultant ultimately responsible for the surgical team that undertook the operation I am devastated by what has happened," he said in a statement issued through the medical defence union.

"I would like to thank my colleagues, staff and patients at the Prince Philip hospital for all their support to me and the team. At this difficult time for all concerned I want to be with my family to try to come to terms with all that has happened over the last week."

Graham Reeves, 69, a Korean war veteran, remained in a critical but stable condition in the intensive care unit of Morriston hospital, Swansea, where he was moved after what should have been a routine operation to remove a diseased kidney.

He is on a dialysis machine and is having round the clock treatment - a transplant may be considered.

As demonstrators gathered yesterday to protest about care at the Prince Philip hospital, it emerged that it has been at the centre of two recent police inquiries into patient deaths.

A spokesman for Dyfed Powys police confirmed that one of the investigations has been concluded and an inquest is due to be held, while police are awaiting a crown prosecution service ruling on the second death.

The two deaths, which occurred in June and October 1998, are said to be unconnected to one another or to the latest incident.

Carmarthenshire NHS trust, which launched an immediate internal investigation into the kidney blunder, had intended to release its preliminary findings yesterday.

But officials have now decided to wait the completion of a more detailed report from the two leading urologists appointed by the Royal College of Surgeons to carry out an independent inquiry.

The trust is carrying out an audit of 400 recent operations at the hospital. Nurses there say they have complained about post-operative care in the urology department.

Gwynedd hospital, in Bangor, north Wales, where Mr Roberts worked from 1983 to 1997, said it had no plans to carry out an audit of past operations similar to the one now taking place in Llanelli. During his time in Bangor Mr Roberts was reprimanded by management over his personal conduct after what one former employee recalls was a loss of temper with another member of the hospital staff.

The hospital has made it clear the reprimand did not involve a patient or patient care.

All members of the surgical team involved in Mr Reeves' operation are still at work but have been stopped from carrying out similar duties.

Carmarthenshire NHS Trust could face a huge bill for compensation after the case. It has already admitted liability and said any claim would be settled quickly.

Llanelli MP Denzil Davies said he wanted the public to be given the results of the Royal College of Surgeons' independent investigation.

"All the evidence given to the inquiry and the conclusion should be made public so that people can maintain confidence in the hospital," he said.

fields.headline: The Dome in the dumps
fields.standfirst:
It looks in greater trouble than it deserves.

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: It looks in greater trouble than it deserves.
fields.body:
In Xanadu did Kubla Khan (according to ST Coleridge) a stately pleasure dome decree, where Alph, the sacred river, ran through caverns measureless to man down to a sunless sea. Of course it was easy for him. He paid for it, as far as we know, out of his own resources. He had no Daily Mail to snap at his heels, deploring the whole endeavour and printing tables to show how many nurses, teachers, police constables or new railway stations you could buy for the sort of additional money that might have been needed later to keep it afloat.

But unlike Kubla Khan, we live in a democracy. His dome was no doubt obsequiously hailed as a miracle of rare device. Ours is more and more assigned by a near consensus of media comment to the fiasco zone. Which is why, where a month ago the complaints were all of endless queues and horrible overcrowding, now the cry is that no one is going there; the place is pulling in only about a quarter of the custom it needs to break even; and the organisers may have to be loaned £60m from the Millennium Commission to keep the show on the road.

Does it deserve such obloquy? That rather depends on what you expect. The Great Exhibition of 1851 and the 1951 Festival of Britain were clear statements of purpose. The Britain of 1851 was saying: we are the most ingenious and inventive of nations, a mighty engine of trade and prosperity, the hub of the greatest of empires, respected across the world. The 1951 festival said: "Look! we have come through. There was a time when the world must have feared for us. But we have survived and now we shall build something new."

Judge the Dome by those standards and it is, in truth, an empty affair. It carries no vibrant message and will leave no lasting memorial, unless you enter on the credit side of the ledger the new stations on the Jubilee Line, which are truly something for the nation to be proud of. The justified charge against Michael Heseltine, Peter Mandelson and those who first steered the project is this: they decreed their dome without knowing what it was for.

And it shows. There is far too little sense in it of a brand new century and millennium. There are moments of true astonishment, like the great pulsating heart in the body zone, but little which those who go there today will talk of with awe to their grandchildren.

And yet the condemnation heaped on the place is unjust. It is simply not true, as those who are making war on it like to pretend, that the punters are all trooping out with long faces and a sense of money wasted. Most polls so far have found satisfaction outweighing complaint. The children, to judge from yesterday's crop, are having a whale of a time. The best of the zones, like work and learning, from its hilarious 85-a-side football match to the true coup de theatre in the school hall, and the shows in the central arena, atone for the lack of inventiveness often apparent elsewhere.

As a source of spiritual uplift, the Dome is a lemon. As a place to have fun with the family, it works very much better. The £758m it cost to create looks excessive, but £20 a head for the day to get in (£56 for families) is scarcely exorbitant. You can spend more than that to watch Bradford City v. Watford. The real test comes this weekend, when the children are out of school. If the queues do not form for the body zone then, the badmouthing will have succeeded, and north Greenwich's seas will truly be sunless.

fields.headline: Counting the cost of care
fields.standfirst:
The flu epidemic may have tempted many towards private insurance, but this may not guarantee that your needs will be met, especially if you are old.
Special report: The future of the NHS
fields.trailText: The flu epidemic may have tempted many towards private insurance, but this may not guarantee that your needs will be met, especially if you are old.
fields.body:
Former BBC tv editor Sue Cokyll, 57, thinks her Bupa private medical plan has been "fabulous", covering her for countless back operations that would have cost her "tens of thousands of pounds" if she had paid for treatment directly. She would rather lose her car than lose her private healthcare policy.

But retired administrator Marjorie Hemming, 71, cancelled her £1,000-a-year policy with Prime Health after it failed to cover her for the treatment she wanted for glaucoma. Instead she obtained "fantastic" service at her local NHS hospital and says she will never again cough up for expensive private insurance. The recent flu epidemic will tempt many to consider going private. Even Tony Blair's dad was revealed this week to have taken out private health insurance.

But while Ms Cokyll is evangelical about the benefits of her policy, the experience of Ms Hemming underlines how taking out a private policy may be no guarantee that your full needs will be met.

A Jobs & Money survey this week of monthly charges on budget plans - which may have extensive exclusions and high "excesses" - also reveals that while premiums are affordable for 30-50-year olds, they rise steeply for 70 year olds. Fully comprehensive policies that mirror everything available on the NHS can cost pensioners £400 per month or more.

Buying a medical policy on price grounds alone, in the same way that people shop around for car insurance, makes little sense for most people, says David Worth, managing director of Medical Fees Insurance Agency (MFIA). "Buying on price alone is where most people come to grief, finding later on that the policy is not as extensive as they believed. Look at stress-related illness. It's a serious problem, which the more expensive policies cover, but the cheaper ones don't.

"The public also have to understand that private medical insurance is designed for acute, curable conditions and can't cover chronic conditions. Often the public don't appreciate the difference" Mr Worth says.

Anybody considering buying a private medical policy should check the following items:

Excesses: The soaring cost of medical bills has prompted many insurers to introduce excesses on policies as a way to reduce premiums. The two most common excess levels are £100 and £250, ie: you pay the first £100 or £250 of the medical costs.

As a rule of thumb, a £100 excess tends to reduce the average premium by 10%, while a £250 excess cuts the cost by around 25%. Excesses are most common on policies sold to elderly people. One thing to look out for is whether the excess is per claim or per year. If you make two claims in one year you could end up paying £500 in fees on top of your premiums. And even though a "per year" excess is usually cheaper, it is not watertight; if your treatment occurs at a time when you your policy is up for renewal, you will end up paying the excess twice over, for the former and the new policy.

Exclusions

It is near-impossible to find an individual medical insurance policy that will cover you for Aids, drug or alcohol addiction or self-inflicted injuries. Beyond that, each company will have its own list of excluded conditions. Gener ally, the more conditions excluded, the cheaper the policy, but the less use it will be. Employer-sponsored schemes tend to have fewer exclusions - some even include Aids - as it reduces the problem of "selection" for the insurance company. Selection is where people buy medical insurance policies knowing that they are at particular risk from a condition, whereas in an employer scheme, the risks of "poor" lives which result in high claims is cancelled out by the "good" lives.

Family policies: Buyers of private healthcare usually take out family policies, which cover children for little extra cost. But the cut-off ages for family policies can vary widely, with some policies stopping cover for children at 18, while others include them until 21. Some policies will even continue to cover children until the age of 25 if they remain in full-time education.

Another item to look out for is if the policy will pay for a parent's bed when a child has been hospitalised. Some policies offer this benefit at no extra cost, while others exclude it, leaving the parent to pay £50-£100 night bed fees.

Pre-existing conditions: This is one of the most contentious areas of private medical policies. Currently, insurers operate two different approaches; full medical disclosure or "moratorium" underwriting. Under full disclosure, the applicant has to complete an extensive medical questionnaire form before a policy will be granted, and in the case of older applicants, will have to attend a medical with a doctor approved by the insurer.

Any pre-existing condition notified to the insurer may then be excluded from the future cover, so if you get it again, bad luck, you may have to go on the NHS. What's more, if you lie on the form and the insurer finds out, your policy is invalidated and the insurer could take even tougher action against you.

The second approach is moratorium underwriting, where the applicant does not have to give any medical evidence about themselves at all. But under these policies you will be automatically disqualified for two years from any cover if you develop a condition you have had in the last five years.

Premium escalation and age bands: Despite huge and expensive advertising campaigns by the major companies such as Bupa and PPP, the number of people with private medical insurance was static or falling for most of the 90s. For every new buyer of a policy, another has fallen out because they can no longer afford the soaring cost of premiums. MFIA's Mr Worth says it is essential that buyers take a realistic view of how much the policy will cost over the years: "Don't just look at the initial cost that is quoted, as the insurance companies rarely tell you what it's going to cost you in later years." Most policies operate 10-year age bands, with premiums leaping upwards as you get older and move into the next band.

One way of controlling costs is to buy a fixed-price plan, such as Bupa's new plan in which you pay a little more now to ensure that your premiums will not rise for at least five years.

Employer schemes:

For the "selection" reasons set out above, employer schemes are usually much cheaper than individually bought plans. However, these vary widely in quality. Many are free for certain categories of employee, but others oper ate by offering employees discounts on the premiums for a particular provider. If the discount is only 10-20% then the scheme may have little value over buying one individually through a broker. But other schemes offer more generous discounts, such as Ms Cokyll's BBC scheme, which gives members 46% off the standard Bupa price.

If you are not as fortunate as Ms Cokyll and do not have an employer scheme - her last operation was at London's Wellington Hospital, where fees are some £525 a day before surgery - it is probably worth consulting a broker before buying an individual policy. The newly formed Association of Medical Insurance Intermediaries operates a freephone number, 0800-421216, to help you locate a local broker.

Anybody considering buying a private medical policy should check the following items: Excesses: The soaring cost of medical bills has prompted many insurers to introduce excesses on policies as a way to reduce premiums. The two most common excess levels are £100 and £250, ie: you pay the first £100 or £250 of the medical costs. As a rule of thumb, a £100 excess tends to reduce the average premium by 10%, while a £250 excess cuts the cost by around 25%. Excesses are most common on policies sold to elderly people. One thing to look out for is whether the excess is per claim or per year. If you make two claims in one year you could end up paying £500 in fees on top of your premiums. And even though a "per year" excess is usually cheaper, it is not watertight; if your treatment occurs at a time when you your policy is up for renewal, you will end up paying the excess twice over, for the former and the new policy. Exclusions It is near-impossible to find an individual medical insurance policy that will cover you for Aids, drug or alcohol addiction or self-inflicted injuries. Beyond that, each company will have its own list of excluded conditions. Gener ally, the more conditions excluded, the cheaper the policy, but the less use it will be. Employer-sponsored schemes tend to have fewer exclusions - some even include Aids - as it reduces the problem of "selection" for the insurance company. Selection is where people buy medical insurance policies knowing that they are at particular risk from a condition, whereas in an employer scheme, the risks of "poor" lives which result in high claims is cancelled out by the "good" lives. Family policies: Buyers of private healthcare usually take out family policies, which cover children for little extra cost. But the cut-off ages for family policies can vary widely, with some policies stopping cover for children at 18, while others include them until 21. Some policies will even continue to cover children until the age of 25 if they remain in full-time education. Another item to look out for is if the policy will pay for a parent's bed when a child has been hospitalised. Some policies offer this benefit at no extra cost, while others exclude it, leaving the parent to pay £50-£100 night bed fees. Pre-existing conditions: This is one of the most contentious areas of private medical policies. Currently, insurers operate two different approaches; full medical disclosure or "moratorium" underwriting. Under full disclosure, the applicant has to complete an extensive medical questionnaire form before a policy will be granted, and in the case of older applicants, will have to attend a medical with a doctor approved by the insurer. Any pre-existing condition notified to the insurer may then be excluded from the future cover, so if you get it again, bad luck, you may have to go on the NHS. What's more, if you lie on the form and the insurer finds out, your policy is invalidated and the insurer could take even tougher action against you. The second approach is moratorium underwriting, where the applicant does not have to give any medical evidence about themselves at all. But under these policies you will be automatically disqualified for two years from any cover if you develop a condition you have had in the last five years. Premium escalation and age bands: Despite huge and expensive advertising campaigns by the major companies such as Bupa and PPP, the number of people with private medical insurance was static or falling for most of the 90s. For every new buyer of a policy, another has fallen out because they can no longer afford the soaring cost of premiums. MFIA's Mr Worth says it is essential that buyers take a realistic view of how much the policy will cost over the years: "Don't just look at the initial cost that is quoted, as the insurance companies rarely tell you what it's going to cost you in later years." Most policies operate 10-year age bands, with premiums leaping upwards as you get older and move into the next band. One way of controlling costs is to buy a fixed-price plan, such as Bupa's new plan in which you pay a little more now to ensure that your premiums will not rise for at least five years. Employer schemes: For the "selection" reasons set out above, employer schemes are usually much cheaper than individually bought plans. However, these vary widely in quality. Many are free for certain categories of employee, but others oper ate by offering employees discounts on the premiums for a particular provider. If the discount is only 10-20% then the scheme may have little value over buying one individually through a broker. But other schemes offer more generous discounts, such as Ms Cokyll's BBC scheme, which gives members 46% off the standard Bupa price. If you are not as fortunate as Ms Cokyll and do not have an employer scheme - her last operation was at London's Wellington Hospital, where fees are some £525 a day before surgery - it is probably worth consulting a broker before buying an individual policy. The newly formed Association of Medical Insurance Intermediaries operates a freephone number, 0800-421216, to help you locate a local broker.

webTitle: Cash straight down the Dome drain

fields.headline: Cash straight down the Dome drain
fields.standfirst:
Financial prudence? Not where the Greenwich blot is concerned

The millennium: special report

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Events this week established that it is time for observers of the Blair government to follow the money. Not specifically in connection with the financial affairs of the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson, but because the first no-tax-and-no-spend Labour government can see examples all around of the money running out.
fields.body:
The breakers of the Watergate story - Woodward and Bernstein - were advised by "Deep Throat", their anonymous informant, to "follow the money". And this whisper from an underground car park serves as a useful strategy for understanding almost any aspect of modern life.

Events this week established that it is time for observers of the Blair government to follow the money. Not specifically in connection with the financial affairs of the former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson - although these may well prevent Tony Blair from running for re-election, as he ran for election on an anti-sleaze ticket - but because the first no-tax-and-no-spend Labour government can see examples all around of the money running out.

Political leaders can judge how long they have been in office by the position of the hands of those around them. In the first few months, a single hand is deferentially held out to be shaken. After a year or two, both hands are cupped together, wanting money for pet causes. If the hands remain empty then - after another year or so - both bunch into fists.

In the past few days, Blair has decisively reached the cupped-hands stage. His decisions will decide whether fists come next. Already embarrassed by a failure to match money to mouth on the NHS, the government now faces a financial crisis at the Millennium Dome - where £60m is needed to pay the staff to shepherd the dwindling visitors around the yawning folly - and in British theatres. A report commissioned by the Arts Council claims that most regional theatres are now technically trading while insolvent because of funding reductions caused by a retreat from belief in subsidy.

That same cultural shift means that many will think that the poverty of a few luvvie temples scarcely matters - still less the possible closure of the hated Dome. But the point is that here we have the first concrete tests (apart from the flu-stretched NHS) of the government's attitude to money, subsidy and bailing out. It was decided yesterday that a "loan" from Lottery funds will be made available to the Dome if needed. The theatres await a response but are likely to be met with a silence of Beckettian and Pinteresque intensity combined.

These responses are revealing. The mystery of Blairism has always been money. During the 1997 election, even the leader's admirers suspected that his glossy philosophy was trading while insolvent. How could he achieve anything without raising taxes? Optimists assumed that the extreme prudence was a ruse to get to power. It was Labour's sums which had tended to lose them elections and so the arithmetic needed to be rigged. In fact, as they now know, he has stuck to his non- spending pledges in the hope of retaining the support of the middle England middle-classes who raised him to power last time.

There were two main tactics to Blairism: high-spin and low-tax. As discussed here last week, the presentational aspect of the package has lost its gloss in recent weeks. This week's begging-bowl moments have suggested that the financial strategy is now becoming problematic.

A few closed theatres - indeed even a virtual full house of closed theatres - won't matter to most voters. Blair isn't going to be writing his memoirs earlier than planned because people in Ispwich or Stoke can only see A Midsummer Night's Dream on video. And at least some money will be found for the NHS as the next election nears.

Blair's problem, as his chancellor well understands, is that the Millennium Dome increasingly mocks the administration's rhetoric of financial prudence. To any reasonable observer the Dome sends the message that there is money around and that - if initial estimates are targets are not met - top-ups will be on offer. How arrogant and stupid it now seems that at the very time when ministers were tersely explaining to voters that there were no funds for things they did want rescued, cash was found for a project which no one desired.

And - even as the numerous educational exhibits remain unvisited - the Dome promotes a lesson which Blair is unlikely to want on a political syllabus. It shows what a treacherous mechanism the market is and how inappropriate it may be for delivering cultural services in particular.

As the hole in the Dome's finances grows, the public and press seem unlikely to respect the government's careful distinction between tax revenue (none of which will go to Dome) and Lottery money. Like the American hellfire evangelists who spend their afternoons playing Adam and Eve with hookers in motel rooms, the prime minister will seem to have one view towards other people's needs and one towards his own.

Although having survived longer than almost any other Labour government without a serious financial crisis, Blair's reputation is now threatened by money; the work of his iron chancellor undermined by the single, wilful, spendthrift gesture which is the Dome. The only gloominess in all this for the Labour left will be the alternative universe in which - but for an imprudent mortgage deal - this week's publicity would be destroying Peter Mandelson's career rather than the expendable Lord Falconer's.
