fields.headline: Extra £60m to bail out dome
fields.standfirst:
Government allocates extra lottery money without repayment plan

The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday agreed to allow an extra £60m of lottery money to be made available to the beleaguered Millennium Dome with no requirement that the money should be paid back.
fields.body:
The government yesterday agreed to allow an extra £60m of lottery money to be made available to the beleaguered Millennium Dome with no requirement that the money should be paid back.

Despite Downing Street claims that the money would be "a short-term cash flow boost" to be repaid over the lifetime of the dome, the Millennium Commission admitted there would be no compulsion to repay if the project hit further crisis.

Attendance figures have fallen unofficially to barely 5,000 a day, with the attraction needing 20,000 to break even. Takings are only just sufficient to cover running costs.

The extra funds will come from the national lottery, which has already granted the project £399m, plus a £50m slush fund to cover costs until cash from ticket sales began to flow in.

The Conservatives accused ministers of "throwing good money after bad", while the Institute of Charity Fund Managers said that to use more national lottery money to further subsidise the dome was "a misuse of donated funds".

The New Millennium Experience Company has not yet made an official request for financial help but is widely expected to ask for £60m to cover the dome's financial problems.

The commission, the dome's financial watchdog, approved the extra money yesterday. Sources said the NMEC would be expected to pay it back, but a spokeswoman said: "We do not use the word loan because they do not absolutely have to pay it back. But we fully expect them to. It is practically impossible to speculate on total disasters happening.

"They would not necessarily have to pay it back at the end of the year - they would pay it back when they could afford to, but there is not a deadline."

Earlier, Downing Street had suggested the money was a loan, which the company would be expected to pay back this year. A spokesman said the commission would not agree to hand over the cash "without their accountants looking very carefully at the numbers, at the ticket projections and at the risk involved". He said the NMEC would not be given any extra grant for the dome, whose budget totals £758m, including sponsorship.

The commission said: "Cashflow difficulties are often associated with large-scale start-ups and therefore provisions to deal with them have always formed part of the arrangements between the commission and the NMEC."

But the shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said: "There is absolutely no point in ministers throwing good money after bad. The Millennium Commission should not risk £60m on a project that has been so chronically mishandled in recent months."

webTitle: Flu and snow add to misery in tent cities

fields.headline: Flu and snow add to misery in tent cities
fields.standfirst:
Chechens face pressure to return home as disease spreads in overcrowded camps in Ingushetia.

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Liza Batayeva expects the impending birth of her ninth child to take place in a corner of the draughty tent she shares with 53 other Chechens in Ingushetia's largest refugee camp.
fields.body:
Liza Batayeva expects the impending birth of her ninth child to take place in a corner of the draughty tent she shares with 53 other Chechens in Ingushetia's largest refugee camp.

Designed to accommodate no more than a dozen people, the tent offers no privacy and is neither clean nor warm, but Ms Batayeva, 37, believes she has no alternative. "I'm terrified of giving birth in these conditions, but we don't have any money so I don't have any choice," she said.

There is a maternity unit in the main hospital in Ingushetia - Chechnya's neighbouring republic - but she is worried she will be made to pay for her care. Three months after fleeing with her husband and eight children from their home in Bamut, western Chechnya, her savings have been spent.

The five other families who live alongside her have tried to make things easier, giving her the tent's only bed which is made from three worn mattresses piled on top of each other. Everyone else sleeps crowded together on thin mats laid out on the wooden floorboards.

With wood supplies scant and the first heavy snow of the winter piling up outside, some of her children yesterday resorted to chopping up a wooden door stolen from the camp toilets to use for fuel.

Elsewhere in the Sputnik camp many people regard Ms Batayeva's position as enviable. She, at least, has been assigned somewhere to stay. New arrivals from Chechnya yesterday were turned away.

The deputy camp administrator, Alikhan Dukhilgo, said that with 9,000 people living in a camp meant for about 5,000, conditions were already unbearable.

The official Russian policy is to encourage those Chechens whose homes are in the designated "liberated areas" to return to their villages or to camps within Chechnya; rations and wood supplies have been withheld to pressurise families to comply.

But most are reluctant to go back to Russian-controlled areas, especially after recent violent Chechen counterattacks sent people who had returned home rushing back to the security of the camps in Ingushetia.

"People are afraid they will be bombed if they go back or that their young sons will be taken to concentration camps within Chechnya, so they won't leave. Instead, more and more people arrive and we don't know what to do with them," Mr Dukhilgo said.

The news that there was still nowhere for her family to stay reduced Muisa Magometova, 30, to tears. She arrived in Ingushetia on Tuesday after a three-week journey from the besieged Chechen capital, Grozny, and has spent three days standing in the snow, waiting to be allocated somewhere to stay.

"They told us that the camp was full and that we should go back to Chechnya. We can't return because we no longer have any money. Last night some other refugees felt so sorry for us that they let us sleep on their floor. We don't know where we will sleep tonight," she said.

Fed daily rations of bread and soup, no one is starving, but doctors are working 24-hour shifts to cope with disease. Rosa Isayeva, a paediatrician, said the camp had been struck by a flu epidemic and estimated that 1,500 of its 2,000 children were suffering from flu and other infections.

"The situation is becoming much worse because of the close conditions people are forced to live in. They get better only to get infected again; they are malnourished and they have no immunity. We have some medicine but nowhere near enough," she said.

Only a small percentage of the 172,000 Chechen refugees in Ingushetia are housed in these official camps. Life for people such as Isa Ibrahimova, forced by limited space to find shelter in the private sector, is often much worse. For three months she and her family have lived in dank, abandoned animal stalls on the outskirts of a rundown farm, paying rent to a local landowner for the privilege.

There are thousands more displaced civilians in camps within Chechnya. Less is known about their living conditions because Russia will not let international monitors work there.

But among the refugees there is disappointment that the western aid agencies are not doing more to help. A handful of international organisations are working hard to help the victims of the conflict, but the wholesale mobilisation of agencies last year in Kosovo has not been repeated here.

This is partly a result of Russia's unwillingness to allow aid agencies to operate freely, and partly because of the organisations' reluctance to work in the region. The UN classifies Chechnya as the world's top danger spot, primarily because of the kidnapping risk, and does not permit expatriate staff to base themselves there or in Ingushetia.

"The north Caucasus is the only region in the world where every single major aid agency has been hit, either by murder, rape or kidnapping," one UN worker said.

fields.headline: Zero tolerance begins at home
fields.standfirst: "Hadn't they cared about the misery they were causing? They hadn't thought about it, they said. They had just enjoyed smashing things"
fields.trailText: "Hadn't they cared about the misery they were causing? They hadn't thought about it, they said. They had just enjoyed smashing things"
fields.body:
In Northamptonshire last weekend, I bought a copy of the Northampton Chronicle to see what was going on. Its front-page story was about children throwing stones at firemen. The firemen had gone to a Northampton industrial estate after getting reports that a factory was on fire. They weren't clear where the fire was so, as they approached the estate, two fire officers got out of the fire engine to consult a group of children who were standing by the road.

The children, whom the firemen estimated to be between six and 12 years old, first tried to send them off in the wrong direction. They might have succeeded in this devilish plan had the firemen not spotted black smoke billowing away in a different place. The children then gathered up stones and rocks, and started throwing them at the fire engine as the two officers were getting back into it. The officers were spared injury, but the engine is now covered with chips and dents.

As it so happened, the fire had been a false alarm. There was no burning factory, just a bonfire of rubbish and old mattresses. But as sub-officer Declan Mullan of Mereway fire station told the Chronicle, "It makes you wonder what would have happened if it was one of their families that had needed us. We're here to save lives and protect the public, and we shouldn't have to put up with this type of behaviour. If we get called out to the same place again, we've asked the police to attend so we can get on with the job and not have to worry that we're going to get hit by stones."

The question that always seems to puzzle grown-ups is why children behave in this way. One day this week, I forgot to turn off the television after the breakfast news and found myself watching Kilroy on BBC1. The theme was juvenile vandalism and how to prevent it. There was the usual gathering of interested parties dug up by the programme's researchers - reformed young vandals (all claiming to have given up vandalising), virtuous young people who had never vandalised, victims of vandalism, voluntary youth workers, council officers and the like. The grown-ups divided along predictable lines - those of a certain age who thought that delinquent youngsters who smash windows and daub graffiti on walls should be given "a bit o' that" (ie, a good thrashing) by their parents, as they would have been in the old days, and those who thought that they ought to be talked to and, above all, listened to.

Robert Kilroy-Silk, the programme's presenter, tried to find out from the reformed delinquents why they had spent so much time vandalising instead of engaging in more constructive pursuits. They said they had been plagued by boredom, that there had been nothing else to do, and that it gave them a buzz. Hadn't they cared about the misery they were causing? They hadn't thought about it, they said. They had just enjoyed the excitement of smashing things and then running away, imagining that they were being chased. Nobody was chasing them, of course. There were no police on the beat. It had been a pretty safe kind of thrill.

The adults in the listening category complained about the absence in deprived areas of such things as swimming pools, ice rinks and youth centres that would keep children entertained. They blamed the government. They blamed local councils. They blamed parents who push children into the streets just to get them out of the house. When the youngsters were asked what they would say to adults who were willing to listen to them, they fell curiously silent. The viewer might have been left with the impression that the only solution to the problem was fierce disciplinary measures, especially as the proponents of the tough approach were always greeted with loud applause.

The truth is that the hardliners are in tune with the spirit of the times. In France, where violence in schools is perceived as a major problem, "zero tolerance" is now the prevailing principle. Schools aren't allowed to beat children, but they expel them in droves. They weren't clear where the fire was so, as they approached the estate, two fire officers got out of the fire engine to consult a group of children who were standing by the road. The children, whom the firemen estimated to be between six and 12 years old, first tried to send them off in the wrong direction. They might have succeeded in this devilish plan had the firemen not spotted black smoke billowing away in a different place. The children then gathered up stones and rocks, and started throwing them at the fire engine as the two officers were getting back into it. fields.headline: Of Winsfords and Winifreds
fields.trailText: Could this be the day which puts the "win" back into Winsford? Since Smallweed began to take a kindly interest in this struggling Unibond Premier League team, its fortunes have improved out of all recognition, as the following table shows.
fields.body:
Could this be the day which puts the "win" back into Winsford? Since Smallweed began to take a kindly interest in this struggling Unibond Premier League team, its fortunes have improved out of all recognition, as the following table shows.

Before Smallweed

P W D L for agst pts

18 0 2 16 10 46 2

After Smallweed

7 0 3 4 4 14 3

To put it another way: had the team been as successful before Smallweed's intervention as it has been since, its full programme of 25 games would now have brought it 10.7 draws instead of a meagre five and only 14.3 defeats instead of the actual 20. It would have scored as many as 14.3 goals, compared with the present skimpy 14, and conceded a paltry 50, instead of the actual 60.

It even seemed for a time last Saturday as though that elusive first win of the season was at last on the cards as Winsford United roared into a two-goal lead within 16 minutes. Unhappily a red card for one of our centre backs in the 38th minute and two goals in the 51st and 76th from opponents Guiseley produced yet another draw.

Winsford, seventh in this league last season, is a club fallen on bad days. The Yorkshire Post, reporting the match at Guiseley, cruelly observed that only three players took the field with the whole of the sponsor's name on their shirts, while on one shirt, every letter had disappeared. I gather the decline set in last season when the richest director disappeared from the board and the old team began to break up.

This season, under new manager Kevin Tully - hailed in his days with Blackpool and Crewe, my informant assures me, as a new George Best: but then, as he says, so many young footballers were - they have had to recruit a whole new band of performers, so many of whom have come and gone already that some 50 different players have appeared in Winsford's colours. A far cry, this, I imagine, from the days when the great Neville Southall was United's custodian.

Today they are home to Guiseley, the very side they so nearly conquered last week. A smattering of Smallweed readers on the terraces might just give the team the psychological boost which would sweep it at last to victory. I would go myself, but I have to appraise an antimacassar.

Though limbo dancing had until then been a craft little practised in Dingwall...

A mobile librarian peremptorily interjects: in his or her musings last week on the TV potential of libraries, Smallweed wholly omitted the role of the mobile library, which could bring far more thrills to the screen than any amount of parachute descents into gardens by paralibrarians.

One could posit, for instance, a scenario in which some scamp or ne'er-do-well had made off from Pinner library with a copy of Norman Fowler's memoirs. At a given signal, a fleet of mobile libraries would set off with lights blaring and sirens blazing in a high-speed chase reminiscent of Bullitt, eventually running the miscreant to earth in a cul-de-sac in south Ruislip. I do not, may I say, seek any payment for this idea, but invite Mr Spielberg to make an appropriate contribution to book-buying funds.

The dreary, cheerless mornings we seem to have had most days so far in this final year of this century have been lit up from time to time by the radiant tones of a stand-in presenter on the Today programme called Winifred Robinson. Smallweed has been swooning in adoration ever since he heard her some time last year interviewing the ultimately pompous Tory MP.

At the end of one characteristic answer combining preposterous bluster with shameless evasion, Winifred simply laughed: a merry spontaneous peal of mirth, far more apt and infinitely more devastating than any amount of rebuke or complaint. She is bright, and funny, and different, with a Merseyside accent which in every melodious syllable rebukes the familiar charge that this accent is necessarily ugly.

One of the Daily Mail's resident bigots complained this week that in two decades he had never heard any broadcaster with a local English accent - as opposed to the ubiquitous Scots, Welsh and Irish - presenting news and current affairs. Well, here is one, and one we ought to hear more of.

Mild progress on haddock sandwiches. I still have yet to hear from anyone who has experienced a genuine haddock sandwich, but Roy Duncan of Guisborough has sent me a menu from Morrettes of Schenectady, New York, which includes a fish fry fillet served on a kaiser roll. Sadly the fish is unspecified, but I hope to be in New York in October and may then be able to check.

Meanwhile, the very concept of sandwiches has taken a fearful knock with the allegation by a writer in the Sunday Times that the art form was not after all invented by the fourth Earl of Sandwich as a way of snatching a bite while gaming, as we were all brought up to believe. Just who did invent it, and why, if he wasn't a Sandwich, it got called a sandwich, is nowhere explained.

The earl, by the way, was a thoroughly disreputable person, of whom Charles Churchill wrote that he "wrought sin with greediness, and sought for shame/ with greater zeal than good men seek for fame." The Dictionary of National Biography speaks of the mass of opprobrium which still clings to his name, though this appears to have nothing to do with sandwiches - even those, for which no opprobrium can be too deep, which are swimming in mayonnaise.

webTitle: A blast of fresh air through the old grey matter

fields.headline: A blast of fresh air through the old grey matter
fields.trailText: Wave riding
fields.body:
As a programme title, The Brains Trust has nothing going for it except nostalgia. "Brains" and "brainy" are scarcely employed these days unless ironically, and hardly anyone but The National Trust uses the "t" word in that way. Presumably Radio 3 keeps reviving the iconic 40s Home Service discussion programme to prove that it isn't dumbing down. Having to borrow the gravitas of another era rather disproves it.

I'm not sure whether The Brains Trust's subjects or speakers are more maddening. The brains are billed as those of leading international intellectuals in science, history, theology and the arts. Yet hearing the first programme's cast last week (Theodore Zeldin, Jonathan Glover, Angela Tilbury and Ian Stewart), similarities were more apparent than differences. All were liberal humanists, aged within roughly 15 years of each other.

Where were the young people - or are grey hairs required to become a leading intellectual? In that case, where were the old voices? Why was there no non-western perspective? For a really challenging debate, you must surely pit fresh perspectives against the known. Otherwise the bourgeoisie is chattering to itself.

The listeners' questions are easy to parody. There's always a loopy romantic one: in the 40s, "what are the most beautiful words in the English language?"; last week "what is hope?" But mostly they occupy a well demarcated religio-moral terrain, asking whether fighting tyranny inevitably turns you into a tyrant, or why certain kinds of work are so little valued.

These are weighty matters but, on the issue of work at least, the answers mostly seemed facile. There are many lenses through which the world is viewed today - politically, economically, psychoanalytically - but you wouldn't know it from these senior common room speculations. Curiously, the only really nuanced and critical take on received wisdom came from Tilbury, the voice of religion.

Of course, those who rue the frenzied contemporary culture of jargon and argot find The Brains Trust attractive because, with its Telemann opening music and unhurried ratiocination, it sounds as though it belongs in another universe. But this isn't the 40s anymore, when unscripted high table talk seemed positively revolutionary. Now we've got Start the Week and In Our Time regularly debating intellectual issues. The Brains Trust sounds like heritage radio.

Radio 4's award-winning series of teenagers' audio diaries, Fresh Air, rudely transposed us back to the 21st century. It kicked off with 16-year-old Tinu who, synopsised, sounds like PC incarnate: she is black, Christian and disabled, and was abandoned by her father when she was three.

In fact, this was one of the most powerful radio programmes I've heard. Tinu is so self-conscious and self-preoccupied that she is riled if people look at her but feels invisible if they don't. Hearing her talk softly into her mike as, braving the bystanders, she made the taxing journey into school put one right in there with her.

By the end, this had become an extraordinarily raw, intimate document. The articulate Tinu poured in all her hurt about the loss of her father and her struggle to avoid becoming a victim, exciting terrific empathy. If the BBC has any sense it will put her passionate fluency into one of those discussion programmes. Radio needs such voices, not just as case histories and social problems, but as definers and interpreters of the world.

Finally, the most memorable words of the week came from Paul Fox. In The House that Birt Built (Radio 4), he summed up John Birt's BBC reign as "too much bias and not enough understanding".

fields.headline: Turning rancid
fields.standfirst: "You can leave your kids or dump your spouse, and get away with it. But betray your talent, and there's the most ridiculous amount of wailing"
fields.trailText: "You can leave your kids or dump your spouse, and get away with it. But betray your talent, and there's the most ridiculous amount of wailing"
fields.body:
I seldom go to the cinema - largely for the same reasons that I rarely, if ever, lick out toilet bowls or watch paint dry - unless it is to accompany my 13-year-old son to one of those three-and-a-half-hour subtitled films about the Dalai Lama, which he feels are such a vital part of his spiritual and artistic development.

However, once a year comes a film so deliciously preposterous-sounding and so roundly and universally ridiculed that I am forced - in the interests of hilarity and sociology - to abandon my rule and treat myself. By and large, this divine error will be to see what they call a "British film", usually one that has been adapted from an acclaimed novel and that aims itself fair and square at Mr Blair's "trendy" New Britain. And, invariably, there will be a great deal of people associated with it - all of whom previously had a good deal of credibility - suddenly Losing It Big Time.

Last year's choice cut, for example, was Mad Cows, in which a veritable smorgasbord of previously immaculate reputations - among them, Anna Friel, Joanna Lumley, Sophie Dahl, Kathy Lette, director Sarah Sugarman - were roundly trashed, rather in the manner of that awesome machine that can reduce the lushest of luxury motors into a one-inch metal cube. This year's treat has got to be Rancid Aluminium, in which a gaggle of ace Brit faces - Tara Fitzgerald, Rhys Ifans, Sadie Frost, a Fiennes, Dani Behr, Nick Moran - are left with a good deal of egg on them. Bless!

The reviews for the film have been uniformly vile, but the one that interested me most pointed out that, as both Steven Berkoff and Keith Allen were in it, its dreadfulness was signalled well in advance and so anyone who parted with their money for a ticket expecting decent - as opposed to indecent - entertainment had only themselves to blame. The way this critic described it, the Allen/Berkoff alliance was a sort of Stalin-Hitler pact of bad acting and general hammery.

Now, I know that, while living the lotus-eating life down here in soft old Sussex, I've taken my eye off the ball a bit in recent years, but the last time I looked both Berkoff and Allen were bywords for raw, simmering sexuality, fierce integrity and, frankly, incendiary talent. Now, apparently, they pack a punch somewhere between that of Mutt and Jeff, and Crystal Tips and Alistair. In short, they've Lost It. How'd that happen?

I think I know. It's because people want to lose it. This is a previously unexplored avenue, as credibility is popularly considered something that we cling to through thick and thin. As a lividly thin, pale, credible young thing (moi) wrote in the Face back in - aaiiieeee! - 1984: "Credibility has replaced paying one's dues as the official credentials needed before a career in the communications industry can get off the launch pad. When you are rich and famous, you can do without it - though it hurts you so! - and once it is gone you will just have to live with the loss. Like virginity or a contact lens, once you lose your credibility you won't get it back, at least not in this life."

But was I happy? Well, yes, but not as happy as I am now that I'm a portly old hack with about as much cred as a hostess trolley. I was talented, too; why, looking back at my second collection, Sex And Sensibility, I think there's a case for saying that between the years of 1983 and 1992 I was the best critic and essayist in this country, which probably means THE WORLD. Those were the days when I could change Kim Philby's mind about giving another interview to the West; when Radio 4 called me "the cleverest woman in Britain".

And did I enjoy it? No. Couldn't handle it. Used to get actually physically sick before I wrote; I was thinking too much, you see. Nowadays I only get sick when I drink too much, which is a much better deal.

There is a real, sensual kick that comes with Losing It, which I'm sure Messrs Berkoff and Allen have discovered for themselves and which explains why they are pursuing their goal so thoroughly. You're not meant to say it, though. You can leave your children, dump your spouse and put your parents out to grass on a sex farm, and still get away with it, in reasonably Bohemian circles. But if you - happily! - admit to betraying your talent, there's the most ridiculous amount of wailing, teeth-gnashing and finger-pointing.

It's mean to say it, of course, but the types who go in for this sort of moralising - oh what you could have been! - are always the types who never had any talent themselves in the first place, and so can't believe you had the gall to throw yours away. Think of poor Salieri, beseeching God to give the Gift to him and not to that moronic, dirty-minded "creature", Mozart. Or of the hotel waiter who turned up at George Best's suite door bearing two bottles of Moët on ice: Best was back in Belfast to open a supermarket, for which he'd been paid £20,000 in cash, which now lay scattered across the king-size bed; his latest squeeze was the current Miss World, Mary Stavin, who was sat at the dressing table wearing two wisps of oyster silk and fixing her hair. The waiter took it all in - the Miss World, the £20,000, the champagne - and uttered the heartfelt cry, "Oh, George, where did it all go wrong?"

Likewise, Laurence Olivier told Vivien Leigh, "I am sick of the myth of the Glorious Couple", and promptly retired to Brighton with Joan Plowright, a woman as plain as her name, to commute every day to the Royal Court in London, taking a great delight in wearing his sober suit and hat, carrying an umbrella and briefcase, and passing for normal. Making films as bad as Harold Robbins' The Betsy was the ultimate luxury for him, not hardship - he was cocking a snook at that final sacred cow, his talent. The same happened to Richard Burton when he dumped the goddesses for a BBC PR girl and threw himself into a welter of bad films. It's like climbing Everest, destroying your talent; you do it because it's there.

If you've got it, flaunt it; if it ain't broke, break it. After a few years, there's something a bit precious about having too much talent, something a bit up yourself. Far better to throw it on the fire and join the hoi polloi. This, I am sure, was the reasoning behind the decision of those Titan talents, Keith Allen and Steven Berkoff, to make a film as bad as Rancid Aluminium. As one who has gone before them into the kingdom of mediocrity and found it a right laugh, I salute them.

Like virginity or a contact lens, once you lose your credibility you won't get it back, at least not in this life." But was I happy? Well, yes, but not as happy as I am now that I'm a portly old hack with about as much cred as a hostess trolley. I was talented, too; why, looking back at my second collection, Sex And Sensibility, I think there's a case for saying that between the years of 1983 and 1992 I was the best critic and essayist in this country, which probably means THE WORLD. Those were the days when I could change Kim Philby's mind about giving another interview to the West; when Radio 4 called me "the cleverest woman in Britain". And did I enjoy it? No. Couldn't handle it. Used to get actually physically sick before I wrote; I was thinking too much, you see. Nowadays I only get sick when I drink too much, which is a much better deal. There is a real, sensual kick that comes with Losing It, which I'm sure Messrs Berkoff and Allen have discovered for themselves and which explains why they are pursuing their goal so thoroughly. You're not meant to say it, though. You can leave your children, dump your spouse and put your parents out to grass on a sex farm, and still get away with it, in reasonably Bohemian circles. But if you - happily! - admit to betraying your talent, there's the most ridiculous amount of wailing, teeth-gnashing and finger-pointing. It's mean to say it, of course, but the types who go in for this sort of moralising - oh what you could have been! - are always the types who never had any talent themselves in the first place, and so can't believe you had the gall to throw yours away. Think of poor Salieri, beseeching God to give the Gift to him and not to that moronic, dirty-minded "creature", Mozart. Or of the hotel waiter who turned up at George Best's suite door bearing two bottles of Moët on ice: Best was back in Belfast to open a supermarket, for which he'd been paid £20,000 in cash, which now lay scattered across the king-size bed; his latest squeeze was the current Miss World, Mary Stavin, who was sat at the dressing table wearing two wisps of oyster silk and fixing her hair. The waiter took it all in - the Miss World, the £20,000, the champagne - and uttered the heartfelt cry, "Oh, George, where did it all go wrong?" Likewise, Laurence Olivier told Vivien Leigh, "I am sick of the myth of the Glorious Couple", and promptly retired to Brighton with Joan Plowright, a woman as plain as her name, to commute every day to the Royal Court in London, taking a great delight in wearing his sober suit and hat, carrying an umbrella and briefcase, and passing for normal. Making films as bad as Harold Robbins' The Betsy was the ultimate luxury for him, not hardship - he was cocking a snook at that final sacred cow, his talent. The same happened to Richard Burton when he dumped the goddesses for a BBC PR girl and threw himself into a welter of bad films. It's like climbing Everest, destroying your talent; you do it because it's there. If you've got it, flaunt it; if it ain't broke, break it. After a few years, there's something a bit precious about having too much talent, something a bit up yourself. Far better to throw it on the fire and join the hoi polloi. This, I am sure, was the reasoning behind the decision of those Titan talents, Keith Allen and Steven Berkoff, to make a film as bad as Rancid Aluminium. As one who has gone before them into the kingdom of mediocrity and found it a right laugh, I salute them.

fields.headline: Staunching the Clooney haemorrhage
fields.trailText: Channel surfing
fields.body:
'What we got?" said Alan Alda, pulling on rubber gloves as he marched towards the gurney. He was wearing scrubs and Dennis Taylor-style surgical-cum-snooker specs too, just in case. With all the blood flowing around the ER he wouldn't have been overdressed in oilskins, sou'wester and gum boots.

What we got? I'll tell you what we got. "17-year-old. Two gunshot wounds to the right chest and one to the left. VP 90 over 60. Pulse 128." It was serious. You could tell by the incidental music. 120 bpm. At least. It was all MacGuffin. ER (Sky 1) is big on that. But still. The VP was 80 and falling. Benton was nowhere. It was down to Greene and Alda to save the guy.

The chest tube output was high. Blood everywhere. It needed someone with a cool head and at least one pair of dab hands. A guy with a lot of experience dealing with gunshot wounds in a critical television-based drama situation. I think you know who I'm talking about. Yes, I know M*A*S*H was a sitcom, but that's not important now. Could you stand back, please?

Alda bent like Dennis Taylor poised to clear up the reds. I love Alda for having had, throughout his screen career, dreadful posture. No matter. That praying mantis pose was now paying dividends. "What are you doing?" said Greene, living up to his surname. "Check the balloon," said Alda improbably, but Greene knew what he meant. "We can't put pressure on the bleed- er from the outside so we'll do it from the inside." Of course! Suddenly, Alda was pulling tubes from the body and nimbly knotting them, as though preparing a particularly recherche dish of chitterlings.

The music slowed. The pressure was climbing and the chest-tube output was down to a trickle. "Old army trick," said Alda, "for tamper-knotting the sub-clavian." That, at least, was the gist of my shorthand note. "Cool," said a passing actor in scrubs, though how he would know is anybody's guess. "Very cool," conceded Greene, who really does know about these things.

It's heartening to learn - isn't it? - that the medical techniques learned in the field in Korea in 1953 can still be useful in Chicago in the 21st century. It's good indeed to have Alda on the show, to have his sagacious presence in this barmy environment. This week, by my reckoning, there was a mastectomy, a wedding, two men with gunshot wounds, a sex scene, some invasive surgery on an eight-year-old boy - the need for which I couldn't quite fathom - a punch-up between a Croatian doctor and a suspected wife-beater, an ectopic pregnancy and a man who got a bloody nose when his airbag exploded. Oh yes, and there was a shooting in the corridor - 20 bullets fired and only one man down. The security guard? Just fainted, though that wrist wound needed suturing. Nice touch.

Amid this weekly flurry of vignettes there never seems to be a quiet moment for coffee and a game of draughts. If architecture is frozen music, then ER is melted painting, where everything flows into everything else and yet - despite what you might expect - it's all delightfully artful and even occasionally beautiful. True, this isn't the best series. Post-Clooney panic has set in and celebrities have been thrown at the problem. There's Rebecca de Mornay, that ice-blonde sexpot dressed in white from the bottom of her high heels to the top of her tight suit, come to seduce callow Carter. There's the gorgeous Croatian doctor, a cross between Raul Julia and Davor Suker. Singular, that. He has arrived, clearly, to occupy the place left in Julianna Margulies' heart by Clooney, the headstrong idiot. And now we got Hawkeye in a white coat, another celebrity transfusion. What we got? We got a show that's critical but might just pull through.

fields.headline: Frank shares John's vision
fields.trailText: Frank Dobson is a good man and a politician who can deliver results. He was a valued colleague of my late husband John Smith and had his respect and affection. Like John, Frank has always put the Labour party first, campaigning tirelessly for candidates in byelections and general elections.
fields.body:
Frank Dobson is a good man and a politician who can deliver results. He was a valued colleague of my late husband John Smith and had his respect and affection. Like John, Frank has always put the Labour party first, campaigning tirelessly for candidates in byelections and general elections.

John appointed Frank as the first shadow minister for London because of his commitment to the city. Working with London members Frank helped to secure the best ever local election results in London. John was Labour through and through. I know that Frank is the same and that his vision for a more equal, fairer, decent London is one John would have shared. I urge London members to give him their support.
Baroness Elizabeth Smith
Edinburgh

 Slagging off Ken Livingstone in the national and London press is obviously part of a New Labour MP's job description. However, I was astonished to pick up the Argus in Sussex and find local Blairite MP Ivor Caplin accusing Ken of using Brighton as a "tax-haven". Before he wastes more ink, someone should remind Mr Caplin that London is 50 miles away and we don't get a vote.
Andy Player
Brighton
andyplayer@hotmail.com

 So Frank Dobson thinks Ken Livingstone is alienating Afro-Caribbean voters by not asking Trevor Phillips to be his running mate (Dobson attacks Millbank 'mess', January 28). What does this say about Dobson's choice of a man to be his deputy? Or maybe women's votes don't count.
Fiona and Nick Jenkins
Leeds
nick@235hpr.freeserve.co.uk

 I'm sick of receiving begging letters from Dobbo - seven to date. These mail shots have probably cost (who?) over £150,000.
Geoffrey Sheridan
London
geoffrey.sheridan@talk21.com

 Now you've found 101 uses for the Dome (Letters, January 27), can anyone think of 101 uses for a Dobson mailshot?
Chris Willis
London

 After 1,000 days, it is time to open a debate on the choice of New Labour's campaign song for the next election - one suspects that, no matter how appropriate, they won't be using Things Can Only Get Better again. Although tempted by alternatives such as I Never Promised You a Rose Garden and You Can't Always Get What You Want, my considered nomination is Sorry Seems To Be The Hardest Word.
Nigel Rogers
London

fields.headline: How will Portillo vote?
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's indecision over whether the vote on the repeal of section 28 should be a free one or whipped is shameful (U-turn on section 28, January 28). It panders to those who wish for a discriminatory society and sends the message that equality under the law is only a matter of "conscience".
fields.body:
Tony Blair's indecision over whether the vote on the repeal of section 28 should be a free one or whipped is shameful (U-turn on section 28, January 28). It panders to those who wish for a discriminatory society and sends the message that equality under the law is only a matter of "conscience".

William Hague's comments put pay to his stated desire that the Tory party should be inclusive, modern and forward-thinking. And how will Michael Portillo vote when the time comes?

The controversy over section 28, the age of consent, and lesbians and gays in the armed forces is, sadly, expected by those of us who have experienced homophobia all our lives. The recent rantings by Baroness Young and the actions by the head of Stagecoach, among others, has reinforced the need for an incitement to hatred law. When will these people realise that as a consequence of their actions, human beings suffer?
Stuart Colley
London

 Ivan Massow (Homophobia, January 27) suggests Baroness Young's opposition to section 28 is not representative of the Tory party and that William Hague is perfectly welcoming to lesbians and gay men. So why is he enforcing a three-line whip in opposition to section 28's repeal?
Mike Robinson
Leeds
m.robinson@leeds.ac.uk

 It's time for Ivan Massow to remove those rose-coloured spectacles and wake up and smell the coffee. William Hague, with his whipped vote on section 28, sacking of Shaun Woodward and naive opinion that the promotion of homosexuality in schools would undermine Tory family values, has clearly illustrated for the electorate just how tolerant his party is.

The hypocrisy of Ivan Massow standing for a party which has shown such hostility for people with his own sexual persuasion is astonishing. If he wishes to maintain any integrity within the gay community, he should follow Shaun Woodward in defecting to the supportive and inclusive ranks of New Labour.
Richard West
Brighton
richard.west@excite.co.uk

 I know and like Ivan Massow. Although I disagree with him, I respect his views and his principled support for the repeal of section 28. However, there can be no justification for his offensive description of Baroness Young simply because she holds a different, and principled, view to his own. Tolerance is a two-way process.
Trish Morris
Bolton
trishmorris@email.msn.com

 Your leader (January 27) rightly demands that this bad law must go. But it is not possible to scrap the climate of oppression which is promoted by section 28, if this also means promoting (ie placing higher value on) the stereotypical (and no longer real) portrayal of the "traditional family" in health and sex education for young people.

It is a poor day that sees the announcement that heterosexually transmitted HIV infections are higher than those from men to men, and that the repeal of section 28 is less important than strengthening "family values".
John Nicholson
Manchester
john@ght.org.uk

 In trying to formulate a code of practice to replace section 28, David Blunkett is reported to be "consulting widely among religious leaders". How does he imagine that he's going to get a balanced response, given the hysterical hate-mongering they've been engaged in?
George Broadhead
Secretary, Gay and Lesbian Humanist Association

 There are plenty of sound Christian reasons for abolishing the homophobic section 28. Would that more religious leaders could take the laid-back approach of the gospel writers. They couldn't even be bothered to tell us whether or not Jesus was a practising heterosexual, since they obviously had other priorities.
Rev Geoff Reid
Bradford

fields.headline: In the picture
fields.standfirst: The Readers' Editor on... how a photograph can tell the wrong story
fields.trailText: The Readers' Editor on... how a photograph can tell the wrong story
fields.body:
Encountering yourself, or someone close to you, unexpectedly in the pages of the paper can sometimes be an acutely uncomfortable, even shocking experience. A couple of weeks ago I received a call on behalf of a woman who had been distressed to see, on opening the Guardian that morning, what she was convinced was a picture of her mother lying in a hospital bed in Glasgow, an oxygen mask over her face.

It was with a report about the pressure being brought to bear on the health service by the flu epidemic. The caller rang the hospital who had no record of her mother. She rang her mother's home and there was no reply. A little later in the day her mother turned up. She had simply been out and had not been in hospital at all, although she had been a patient there a couple of years ago.

So convinced was the woman - with whom I had several conversations during the day - that our photograph showed her mother that she accused us of using an archive picture, and using it without reference to the people in it and their relatives, or giving thought to the possible effect on them.

In fact, it was established that the person in the picture was not the reader's mother, that the picture had indeed been taken the day before publication, that the photographer was at the hospital by invitation, that the permission of those in the picture had been obtained at the time it was taken, and that the hospital, which confirmed all those points, was happy with the outcome.

All complaints of this kind are investigated thoroughly. File or archive pictures are often used in the Guardian. In the vast majority of cases there is nothing wrong with this at all. The context in which they are used is neutral and does not invite any derogatory inference to be drawn about the character or habits of anyone recognisably depicted.

This is not always the case, though. About 18 months ago we carried a report about police fears of serious violence between rival gangs of motorcyclists at a weekend rally. In the event, no such violence occurred. However, we illustrated our report with a six-column picture of a group of people enjoying themselves at a rally - 11 years previously. The caption did not make it clear that it was an archive picture but it did attempt to emphasise that the people in the picture were peace-loving "easy riders". The rather more prominent headline read, "Bikers revving up gang warfare, say police".

One of the people in the picture had returned from holiday to find herself the subject of comment among colleagues at work. The paper conceded that it had been an inappropriate way to illustrate the story and apologised unreservedly.

Today we print another apology (see the Corrections and Clarifications column) brought about by the use of a file picture to illustrate a piece lamenting the rise or fall of Newport in South Wales to the title of "Britain's most violent town". The piece itself referred to "drunken yobbery" among more serious matters. The picture was captioned, "Up town... having fun in a Newport pub this week... but at weekends the population swells by 8,000 and some get into drink and drug-fuelled trouble..."

In fact, the picture was not taken "this week". It was taken in September 1996 in Le Pub, a public house in Caxton Place, Newport, as a possible illustration for a piece in the Guardian about Newport as the new Seattle of rock music. The blameless individuals shown are, two members of a band current at the time called 60ft Dolls, two members of the pub staff (one of them the manager), and a fifth person - the one who has complained - shown holding a bottle of lager out towards the camera.

He says in his complaint, "Without exception, all of those who saw it thought that the men in the photograph were the 'yobs' whose behaviour was in part the subject of the piece." On the day it was taken, he and others had acted as guides to help our journalist research the local music scene. The picture "was intended to be a 'cheers' photograph at the end of the evening".

Confusion about the date on which the picture was taken between the photographer, the picture desk, and the features department handling the page should not have occurred. The sub-editor involved asked whether the people in the picture had given permission for it to be used but was not provided with an answer. The caption was written to distance the people in the picture from the content of the piece but, in my opinion - whether or not it met any legal requirement - did not do that satisfactorily.

I believe that in these situations the first question should not be, is our use of this picture within the law? It should be, is it right to use the picture at all? For the journalist there is an easy test: put yourself in the picture. How would you feel?

I think we know the answer. That is why we print an apology today.

 Readers may contact the office of the Readers' Editor by telephoning 0171 239 9589 between 11am and 5pm Monday to Friday. Surface mail to Readers' Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Fax 0171 239 9897.
Email: reader@theguardian.com

webTitle: Living off the fat of the land

fields.headline: Living off the fat of the land
fields.trailText: The suggestion by Tom Marshall from the department of public health and epidemiology at Birmingham University (VAT on fat 'will save lives', January 28) is simply another shot across the bows for the less well off.
fields.body:
The suggestion by Tom Marshall from the department of public health and epidemiology at Birmingham University (VAT on fat 'will save lives', January 28) is simply another shot across the bows for the less well off.

Putting VAT on fatty foods such as dairy products will put a strain on those who barely survive on low incomes and benefit and, of course, the old, who rely heavily on these products simply because they are convenient, quick and for many, delivered to their door.

We are constantly reminded that many children in this country live either below or barely above the poverty line and yet a health expert suggests that for their own good they should do without and where necessary pay more for healthier alternatives.

He hopes that the result of the additional tax would mean that people will substitute their diets for low-fat alternatives. The reality is that the old and less well off will simply do without.
Mike Callanan
Coulsdon, Surrey
MCallanan@lsh.co.uk

webTitle: Anglican vicars are not nice people

fields.headline: Anglican vicars are not nice people
fields.trailText: Anglican vicars are not, by and large, "awfully nice people" (Leader, January 26) - 19 years of ordained ministry have taught me that. What they may be, at their best, are people who work with those experiencing life's harder side in an atmosphere of realism and hope.
fields.body:
Anglican vicars are not, by and large, "awfully nice people" (Leader, January 26) - 19 years of ordained ministry have taught me that. What they may be, at their best, are people who work with those experiencing life's harder side in an atmosphere of realism and hope. This year 30 to 40 couples will marry in our church; some of them are making second marriages. Not all those who ask eventually receive the reply they want. This has nothing to do with ersatz therapy, but with the work of discerning what is really going on inside people that has always been the job of a priest or pastor. Like any diagnosis it may be wrong, but it has to be attempted.

Those who marry here are certainly not doing it to please the church. Their previous relationships will have broken down for a number of reasons - social, personal, spiritual and psychological. They are looking for a new start in life for themselves and the people they belong to. Some of them will be helped to achieve this and that is good news.
Chris Swift
Rector of St Nicholas Shepperton, Middx

 Following a traumatic illness, my husband walked out on 26 years of happy marriage to live with his newly acquired mistress. I tried to preserve our marriage, but after five years, the court allowed the dissolution of the marriage and a vicar friend of the couple agreed to marry them in their local church.

I felt this apparent ecclesiastical approval of the couple's actions denied the sanctity and validity of my marriage and inferred that the responsibility for the breakdown was not theirs but mine. How does the church justify this lack of concern and respect for abandoned spouses who were true to their marriage vows?
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Chips with everything
fields.trailText: I must protest at Pass Notes' outrageous and ignorant treatment of Belgium and its peoples (January 27). I cannot be bothered to answer your criticisms in detail; they are too crass. I shall, however, point out that Belgium is a country of extraordinary culture and Brussels a city of extraordinary vitality and excitement.
fields.body:
I must protest at Pass Notes' outrageous and ignorant treatment of Belgium and its peoples (January 27). I cannot be bothered to answer your criticisms in detail; they are too crass. I shall, however, point out that Belgium is a country of extraordinary culture and Brussels a city of extraordinary vitality and excitement. The Belgians are not only masters of frites; for a small country they have more than pulled their weight in the sciences, in engineering, in the fine arts, in music, in architecture; even in comic books they exceed our mediocre efforts. We British have little grounds for feeling superior and making mock. And I haven't even mentioned their beer...
Dick Bentley
Southampton

 What is interesting about Britain's non-EU trade deficit (Non-EU trade deficit at record high, January 28) is that Britain is not in deficit. It is only the south-eastern corner which is. The other regions all export more than they import.
Jo Harding
Clitheroe, Lancs

 I don't understand all this fuss over downloading music from the internet. So what's new? Ever since tape-recorders came on the market, music-lovers have been able to "download" from the radio in what Huw Wheldon once described as "the piracy of their own homes".
Michael Delahaye
Oxford

 That government spelling error (Letters, January 28) is not an isolated case. After writing to the department of health, requesting that Crohn's disease be made notifiable, the response (two months later) was: "Given the present state of knowledge of Crown's disease and its causation, we have no plans to make it a noticeable disease".
Anne Luther
Director general, Action Research

fields.headline: Tossed about
fields.trailText: The home secretary seems determined to proceed with his plan to rename the probation service the community punishment and rehabilitation service (Straw plan to tag more re-offenders, January 27).
fields.body:
The home secretary seems determined to proceed with his plan to rename the probation service the community punishment and rehabilitation service (Straw plan to tag more re-offenders, January 27).

But punishment is properly seen as a function of the courts, not of the probation or prison services. When executive agencies have taken it upon themselves, the result has usually been collusion or abuse. Far from making the service's function more clear, this new title is likely to create its own confusion.
David Faulkner
Chair, Howard League for Penal Reform

 Does Jack Straw's plan to give the probation service a title that tells everybody what its business really is mean that he will be applying the same rule to his own ambiguous office? The minister for treatment, order, security, surveillance, extradition and rehabilitation could form an acronym, followed by: for imprisonment and punishment.
Dr Andrew Wilson
Department of social policy, London School of Economics
andy.wilson@newscientist.net

webTitle: TV show to unveil Nato's clash in Kosovo

fields.headline: TV show to unveil Nato's clash in Kosovo
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: William Cohen, the US defence secretary, has roundly dismissed British claims that Nato had been prepared to use ground troops to force Serb army and police units out of Kosovo.
fields.body:
William Cohen, the US defence secretary, has roundly dismissed British claims that Nato had been prepared to use ground troops to force Serb army and police units out of Kosovo.

Sharp differences between Britain and the US - strongly denied during the bombing campaign - about the possibility of sending in troops are exposed in interviews to be broadcast in a three-part series starting tomorrow with Mr Cohen and the British prime minister, Tony Blair.

"It was never a close call in getting a consensus to put land forces in," Mr Cohen says. "Out of the total 19 [Nato countries], I doubt very much whether we could have gotten the consensus. I'm convinced we could not have."

The ongoing dispute about proposals to use ground troops when Nato was desperately concerned with the continuing failure of air attacks to destroy military targets will be exposed in the Channel 4 series, War in Europe.

"To make preparations for [a ground campaign] would have meant 150,000 to 200,000 troops, most of which would have come from us and, given the fact that we had a lack of enthusiasm for even a peacekeeping mission in Kosovo, then it became very clear to me that it was going to be a very hard sell, if not impossible to persuade the American people," Mr Cohen says.

A US senate majority was opposed to a land campaign and the only option was to "stay the course" with bombing from the air, he adds.

However, Mr Blair says the US president, Bill Clinton, was prepared to consider sending in ground troops. "It would be wrong to think that the US administration was sitting there saying we're not contemplating ground troops because that wasn't their position at all," he says.

Mr Blair adds: "My belief is that President Clinton was prepared to see the thing through - and if that meant there was no other way we could do this, other than the use of ground troops, then I believe he was prepared to contemplate that. I think the bottom line about not losing was indeed the bottom line for people."

Mr Cohen also confirms that US military chiefs were split about a land campaign.

During the war, British ministers let it be known they were deeply frustrated with the Clinton administration's refusal to consider the use of ground troops. A string of US and British media reports which reflected this prompted Washington to deny any suggestion of a rift between Nato's two closest allies.

After the war, Whitehall claimed that overtly public discussions about the possibility of using ground troops was designed to keep Serbian President Slobodan Milosevic guessing.

Mr Blair tells Channel 4 that Mr Milosevic "had to know that we were prepared to do whatever it took to win".

However, Mr Cohen takes a different view.

"If you don't have a consensus for a ground campaign, then you shouldn't try to hold out the illusion that you have one," he says. "Empty gestures don't persuade your adversary that you're serious."

Part one of War in Europe to be broadcast tomorrow on Channel 4 at 8pm

webTitle: Living on borrowed time - and money

fields.headline: Living on borrowed time - and money
fields.standfirst: Could those extra Christmas presents bought on credit, push you into bankruptcy? Patrick Sherwen looks at a growing problem
fields.trailText: Shakespeare may have been voted the Man of the Millennium but it seems that no one gives a damn about his financial advice: "Neither a borrower nor a lender be."
fields.body:
Shakespeare may have been voted the Man of the Millennium but it seems that no one gives a damn about his financial advice: "Neither a borrower nor a lender be."

Debt has become an integral part of our lives. Many lose their credit virginity at university. The rare few who avoid student loans are unlikely to escape the ranked masses of banks at freshers' fairs offering tempting deals on overdraft-heavy current accounts.

The rest of us are targeted by a growing number of financial organisations whose survival depends on their ability to poach business from their competitors and then lock it in. "Live now, pay later" has become part of our everyday culture.

Figures produced by the Credit Card Research Group this week, show that last Christmas, shoppers and revellers built up record quantities of debt on credit and debit cards. In December, an unprecedented £14.6bn worth of presents, booze, food and other festive items were bought in the UK on such cards - nearly a quarter more than in December 1998.

David Thomson of DebtCall, a firm of independent debt counsellors, says: "We have Christmas and new year and we all tend to go over the top because it is a time to spend on our loved ones. This year was the millennium and there were extra public holidays so the opportunities to spend were even greater." On top of that many had to wait six weeks between their December and January pay cheques, so were forced to rely on credit to get through.

December topped off a record year for borrowing in general. DebtCall estimates that personal sector borrowing in 1999 reached £614.8bn, surpassing £600bn for the first time. Of this total, credit cards represent £30.5bn, a 30% rise on 1998 and an average balance for every card issued of about £750.

These figures indicate the extent to which we are increasingly comfortable with debt. But if comfort becomes complacency, that can be a dangerous thing.

DebtCall, which operates a free telephone advice line (see below for the number), has been bombarded with calls from people who cannot cover their regular monthly bills after the Christmas blow-out. Mr Thomson says the number of people who pay off their card bills every month has fallen and, according to the British Bankers' Association, fewer than half of all card holders now pay this way. As each month slips by, more people find themselves in arrears. DebtCall estimates that £30.7bn of the total private debt is due to late payments.

The symptoms of excessive debt are not hard to spot. First you will find it harder to meet normal costs, such as heating bills and the weekly shop. Then, as a temporary measure, you will consider using credit cards to cover these costs until you are "back on your feet". Finally, if the pressure does not let up, you may consider taking out a loan to get creditors off your back. If these symptoms seem to fit your circumstances now is the time to take action.

Failure to do so could lead to personal insolvency. This is defined in two ways: when your debts outweigh the means to pay them back, taking into account all worldly possessions; or when you are unable to pay bills as they fall due. Shirley Jackson, a council member of the Society of Practitioners of Insolvency, says the latter is the more common: "That's much more likely to catch people out. You shouldn't have to sell your house first," she says. The worst case is bankruptcy. If your debts are greater than £20,000, bankruptcy will last three years during which you will not be able to buy a mortgage, hold a credit card, look after anyone else's money, become a company director or stand as an MP.

How to cope when you can't pay

* Stop borrowing. Do not be tempted to borrow to pay off existing debts

* Do not try to ignore debts or hope your creditors will forget. Contact them immediately to let them know there may be a delay in payment

* Sit down with a piece of paper and work out how much you owe. Include everything from outstanding payments on hire purchase goods to mortgage instalments. Then work out your income and your expenditure. Anything left over from your income after you subtract essential expenditure should be put towards clearing debts

* Work out which debts must be paid first. This will require balancing between essentials - such as mortgage repayments and electricity bills - and priority debts, such as court fines

* Seek professional help. The calculations you have made so far will help advisers to understand your situation (see below for useful phone numbers)

* Draw up a pro-rata payment plan. Using your calculations, work out how much money, if any, you can spare to pay off debts. Then work out how much each debt represents as a total of the whole. Divide the available money up and pay this towards each debt every month. For instance, if your credit card bill accounts for 25% of your total debt and you have £100 available to cover the total you should put £25 towards that bill each month. This will be useful if you have to appear in court as proof that you have taken reasonable steps to pay your debts

* Do not be intimidated by debt collectors. Insist that all communication is by letter. This will be useful if you have to appear in court and you will find it easier to keep a cool head

* If you receive a court summons, do not ignore it. If you fail to turn up, an order for payment may be made in your absence - thereby adding to your problems.

Apart from DebtCall (0800-980-5060) the National Association of Citizens' Advice Bureaux offers debt counselling (0171-833-2181). Other sources of help are the National Debtline on 0808-808-4000 and the Consumer Credit Counselling Service on 0800-138-1111, which will arrange an appointment to see a counsellor.

webTitle: Now you can pay your way in bullion

fields.headline: Now you can pay your way in bullion
fields.standfirst: A real 'gold card' has been launched backed by reserves of precious metal. Dan Atkinson on a novel blend of old and new
fields.trailText: For the financial sophisticate, simultaneously keen to explore the new frontier of e-cash and disillusioned with the loss of status conferred by even the swankiest credit cards, a neat solution is at hand. Electronic bullion promises to make a "gold card" just that - a piece of plastic backed by precious metal.
fields.body:
For the financial sophisticate, simultaneously keen to explore the new frontier of e-cash and disillusioned with the loss of status conferred by even the swankiest credit cards, a neat solution is at hand. Electronic bullion promises to make a "gold card" just that - a piece of plastic backed by precious metal.

The concept - DigiGold - is still at the early stage, but the company behind it, US group Gold & Silver Reserve Inc (G&SR), has already launched "e-gold", a payments system whereby consenting adults can settle their debts in bullion rather than dollars. E-gold is available over the net to British residents and UK regulators have confirmed they are happy with the concept.

Whereas e-gold allows one customer to transfer value to another, DigiGold will, eventually, offer a gold-backed private electronic currency. And G&SR points out: "We wouldn't have gone into this business...if we thought government money was as good as gold."

The development, an intriguing marriage between the very latest in electronic payments technology and the oldest store of value in history, is arousing interest around the world. At a conference on November 19 in Paris called to discuss gold's role in the 21st century, Professor Forrest Capie of City University, London, noted: "This is a return to a kind of gold standard, but with some advantages."

The first of these, he said, is that G&SR is precisely what its name suggests: a reserve. E-gold, in contrast to national currencies even during the heyday of the gold standard 100 years ago, is 100% gold backed. By clicking on G&SR's internet site, it is possible at any time to obtain a complete breakdown of all the bullion in the reserve, although not, of course, the state of clients' accounts.

A trawl through the reserve's internet site reads like a numismatist's dream: 450 Napoleons (20-franc gold pieces), 2,896 silver Maple Leaf coins, 4441-ounce platinum American Eagles, and much more.

On the day in question - January 18 - there were 7,310.27 ounces of e-gold in circulation (worth about $2.1m) backed by 8,524.76 ounces in the reserve. Quantities of e-silver, e-platinum and e-palladium were backed by similar proportions of physical metal. This metal is deposited by the customers and then traded electronically among them using up-to-the-minute exchange rates with paper currencies, principally the dollar.

Because of the second advantage noted by Professor Capie - that e-gold is divided into units as small as 0.000001 of an ounce - it is as divisible and flexible as paper money, indeed, more so. So it is entirely feasible to pay for newspapers, cartons of milk and any other small-purchase item in e-gold, provided the newsagent or corner shop also has an account at G&SR.

G&SR is based in Delaware, and offers its services in the US, as well as in Britain, Switzerland, Germany, Japan, France and elsewhere. The company, clearly keen not to ruffle feathers in the Federal Reserve Board or elsewhere, notes: "G&SR has no 'monetary policy' - the choices of our customers will be the only factor determining [the] total quantity of e-gold in circulation."

There are disadvantages to e-gold, chief among them being the poor performance of bullion as an investment medium during the 19 years from 1980 to 1999. That will matter less to someone who wants e-gold merely to hold its value than to someone who is hoping for a handy capital gain from their e-gold.

Another downside comes with the fees G&SR charge for storage of the bullion and for each transaction. This is not an obvious attraction in the era of free banking with current-account interest payments. The company retorts that all banks find ways of getting clients to pay their overheads: "The costs of the... system banks administer are hidden in their interest-rate spread."

G&SR claims its own system is more transparent because it does not engage in lending. Others will, however. As e-gold circulates more and more, says G&SR, independent moneylenders will pop up to make a market. Indeed, G&SR may find itself in competition with other e-gold suppliers, competing on storage and transaction costs but not, of course, on the core product.

Not unless, that is, clients of modest means develop a taste for e-tin.

Electronic bullion promises to make a "gold card" just that - a piece of plastic backed by precious metal. The concept - DigiGold - is still at the early stage, but the company behind it, US group Gold & Silver Reserve Inc (G&SR), has already launched "e-gold", a payments system whereby consenting adults can settle their debts in bullion rather than dollars. E-gold is available over the net to British residents and UK regulators have confirmed they are happy with the concept. Whereas e-gold allows one customer to transfer value to another, DigiGold will, eventually, offer a gold-backed private electronic currency. And G&SR points out: "We wouldn't have gone into this business...if we thought government money was as good as gold." The development, an intriguing marriage between the very latest in electronic payments technology and the oldest store of value in history, is arousing interest around the world. At a conference on November 19 in Paris called to discuss gold's role in the 21st century, Professor Forrest Capie of City University, London, noted: "This is a return to a kind of gold standard, but with some advantages." The first of these, he said, is that G&SR is precisely what its name suggests: a reserve. E-gold, in contrast to national currencies even during the heyday of the gold standard 100 years ago, is 100% gold backed. By clicking on G&SR's internet site, it is possible at any time to obtain a complete breakdown of all the bullion in the reserve, although not, of course, the state of clients' accounts. A trawl through the reserve's internet site reads like a numismatist's dream: 450 Napoleons (20-franc gold pieces), 2,896 silver Maple Leaf coins, 4441-ounce platinum American Eagles, and much more. On the day in question - January 18 - there were 7,310.27 ounces of e-gold in circulation (worth about $2.1m) backed by 8,524.76 ounces in the reserve. Quantities of e-silver, e-platinum and e-palladium were backed by similar proportions of physical metal. This metal is deposited by the customers and then traded electronically among them using up-to-the-minute exchange rates with paper currencies, principally the dollar. Because of the second advantage noted by Professor Capie - that e-gold is divided into units as small as 0.000001 of an ounce - it is as divisible and flexible as paper money, indeed, more so. So it is entirely feasible to pay for newspapers, cartons of milk and any other small-purchase item in e-gold, provided the newsagent or corner shop also has an account at G&SR. G&SR is based in Delaware, and offers its services in the US, as well as in Britain, Switzerland, Germany, Japan, France and elsewhere. The company, clearly keen not to ruffle feathers in the Federal Reserve Board or elsewhere, notes: "G&SR has no 'monetary policy' - the choices of our customers will be the only factor determining [the] total quantity of e-gold in circulation." There are disadvantages to e-gold, chief among them being the poor performance of bullion as an investment medium during the 19 years from 1980 to 1999. That will matter less to someone who wants e-gold merely to hold its value than to someone who is hoping for a handy capital gain from their e-gold. Another downside comes with the fees G&SR charge for storage of the bullion and for each transaction. This is not an obvious attraction in the era of free banking with current-account interest payments. The company retorts that all banks find ways of getting clients to pay their overheads: "The costs of the... system banks administer are hidden in their interest-rate spread." G&SR claims its own system is more transparent because it does not engage in lending. Others will, however. As e-gold circulates more and more, says G&SR, independent moneylenders will pop up to make a market. Indeed, G&SR may find itself in competition with other e-gold suppliers, competing on storage and transaction costs but not, of course, on the core product. Not unless, that is, clients of modest means develop a taste for e-tin.

webTitle: Raid your savings now for a happier holiday

fields.headline: Raid your savings now for a happier holiday
fields.standfirst: Exchange rates
fields.trailText: The proud pound - at its highest point against a basket of foreign currencies for 11 years - may be the bane of exporters and industrialists hit by cheap imports. But anyone thinking of a holiday in Europe this year should be raising a glass to sterling's health.
fields.body:
The proud pound - at its highest point against a basket of foreign currencies for 11 years - may be the bane of exporters and industrialists hit by cheap imports. But anyone thinking of a holiday in Europe this year should be raising a glass to sterling's health.

Winter-sports fans heading off to France, Spain or Italy - all now tied to the euro exchange rate - will find their money buys 14% more in foreign currency than this time last year, according to Thomas Cook. And the other good news is that inflation has stayed low in Euroland holiday destinations so those extra francs, pesetas and lire are equal to an extra day free in a week's skiing or snowboarding. What cost £700 a year ago is now on offer for £600.

It's all down to the weakness of the single European currency. The euro, which started life in January 1999 with a 70p value, has now slumped to 61p.

Whether the pound will still be so strong later this year when the majority of people are heading off across the channel is less certain. And summer holidaymakers may have to act speedily to capture the best currency deals. Most holidaymakers buy their foreign money around 10 days ahead of their departure - but earlier might be better.

Foreign exchange market traders are betting that the pound will be little changed over the next month. At most, they suspect it will be 1% lower, a margin so small that holidaymakers will be able to make it up by shopping around for their currency. But the spring and summer could see the pound falling back - making European treats more expensive.

Economics experts see recovery in the euro, the key currency for many overseas holidays, this year. Forecasts from stockbrokers Goldman Sachs make gloomier pre-holiday reading. They reckon the pound will fall against the euro. Compared with the current 61p needed to buy one euro, they suggest you will require 67p by late April, 70p by August, and 74p this time next year.

The present 10-plus French francs to the pound, which brings so much joy to those summering in the Dordogne, could fall to a miserly nine if Goldman Sachs are right.

The solution is to raid savings and buy on the present exchange rate. It is certainly worth it on the Goldman Sachs forecast even if your money is in one of the better paying accounts. Losing 2% after tax - about six months' interest in a good instant access account - is a worthwhile sacrifice if the euro strengthens by any substantial percentage.

Buying currency notes is the easiest route but can present security worries: banks insist you take them home. And foreign currency accounts are designed for large sums.

Lloyds TSB believes the neatest solution is to buy travellers cheques now in the currency of your choice. The banks says this combines security with the certainty of fixing a rate.

The pound has not strengthened so much against the US dollar - the key to holidays in the Caribbean and Latin America - which is likely to stay little altered from the present $1.65 over the next year. Buying the dollar in advance is not necessary.

Nor is getting hold of Greek money. Although Greece is thinking of joining the euro, the experts see the drachma changing little against the pound from the present 330.
