webTitle: Keeping the Reds well in the black

fields.headline: Keeping the Reds well in the black
fields.standfirst: You can now turn your relationship with your favourite club into a financial one by joining a sponsored savings account, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Forget shirt sponsorship deals and TV rights to matches - a humble savings account launched just two-and-a-half years ago has helped raise more than half a million pounds for first division football club Norwich City.
fields.body:
Forget shirt sponsorship deals and TV rights to matches - a humble savings account launched just two-and-a-half years ago has helped raise more than half a million pounds for first division football club Norwich City.

The Canary account, offered by Norwich & Peterborough building society, allows fans to make a contribution to the future of the club while saving for their own futures.

A cash bonus, linked to the total amount invested by fans, is paid to the club each year. Last Saturday cookery guru Delia Smith, a director of Norwich City, was presented with a cheque for £283,000, representing 1999's contribution. Following previous cheques for £20,000 and £208,000, this lifts the total amount raised so far to £511,000.

With sums as sizeable as this and spiralling players' wages to be paid, it is no wonder that football clubs have been rushing to strike deals with banks and building societies.

The pioneer of football savings accounts is Albion Premier, which benefits first division club West Bromwich Albion and was launched by West Bromwich building society in 1995. The account boasts an impressive membership of around 10,000 fans and has raised getting on for £500,000 for the club.

Since then, almost 30 other clubs, from giants such as Manchester United to Unibond Premier League stars such as Barrow, have teamed up with banks and building societies to launch endorsed accounts.

The latest to take the plunge is Chester City, whose fans can now invest their savings in an account operated by West Bromwich building society. The interest rate starts at 3.50% gross and perks include discounts in the club shop and invitations to monthly fans' forums.

The accounts work by making a payment to the club each year typically equivalent to 1% of the average total balance in all accounts throughout the year. For the clubs, it is a great way of bringing in much-needed additional revenue, while the bank or building society gets to tap into a sector of the population that is likely to prove very loyal. But are the fans getting a good deal too?

Football club-linked savings accounts are not an area of the market where you can trawl the best buy tables in search of the highest rate. If you want to sign up to the club-endorsed account, there will be a choice of one. So there is less incentive for banks and building societies to offer a table-topping deal.

The latest issue of financial data magazine Moneyfacts reveals that rates on offer vary greatly. Accounts that top the league include the Bristol City account offered by Bristol & West, the Yorkshire Terriers account from Yorkshire building society, which raises money for Huddersfield Town, and the Barnsley-linked Reds Saver operated by Barnsley building society.

From tomorrow the Yorkshire Terriers account pays 4.70% gross on a minimum balance of £25, while from February 7 the Bristol City account will pay 4.75% gross on balances of £100-plus. The Reds Saver offers 4.50% gross on balances of £100 or more. In all cases, 1% of the average balance is paid to the club. However, while all three offer instant access, some come with restrictions - the Bristol City account only allows 12 withdrawals a year.

Other high-paying accounts include the St Andrew's Saver account for Birmingham City fans operated by Legal & General Bank, and the Woolwich's Charlton Premier, aimed at Charlton Athletic supporters. These offer rates starting at 4.15% and 4.25% gross respectively.

Less generous ones include Bath building society's Pirates Super Saver account for Bristol Rovers fans, which pays 1.50% gross on balances below £1,000, and Darlington building society's accounts for Darlington and Hartlepool United supporters, which pay a minuscule 0.10% gross on balances of £1 to £500 and just 1.60% gross from £500 to £4,999.

However, there are perks. The Canary and Bristol City accounts are among those that offer a 5% discount on a season ticket and a free mortgage valuation.

A bigger voice for fans

A new government-backed scheme will give football fans a bigger say in running teams they support. It could see clubs adopting mutual ownership.

The Supporters Direct scheme will help fans with advice on how to organise supporters' trust holdings in their clubs. These would control individual supporters' holdings so fans could use their united strength to keep clubs safe from asset strippers.

The project is backed by the Co-operative Bank which will give free banking and help. The bank foresees partnerships with local authorities, often the team's landlords, which could lead to a mutual form of ownership. It cites Northampton Town and Bournemouth as examples of good practice.

webTitle: A simple way to make precious little money

fields.headline: A simple way to make precious little money
fields.standfirst: Richard Simpson's own with-profits plan came a cropper. Does that mean we should shun all such schemes in future?
fields.trailText: For the past 10 years I have been saving the princely sum of £9 a month with a friendly society, because back in the late 1980s their savings plans were all the rage. You couldn't put much away each month - although the limit has since risen to £25 - but the plans had the key advantage of enjoying the same tax-free status as Peps and Isas.
fields.body:
For the past 10 years I have been saving the princely sum of £9 a month with a friendly society, because back in the late 1980s their savings plans were all the rage. You couldn't put much away each month - although the limit has since risen to £25 - but the plans had the key advantage of enjoying the same tax-free status as Peps and Isas.

In January 1990 I became one of almost 6m friendly society members when I took out a monthly savings plan with the Lancashire and Yorkshire Friendly Society, which at the time was near the top of the performance table.

In a few days that plan will mature, and when I called for a valuation recently I was told to expect a cheque for £1,147.28, which the Carol Vordermans among you will already have calculated is just £67.28 more than the £1,080 that I've paid in. It is a truly dire performance, and as my wife pithily pointed out I'd have been better advised simply to stuff the money down the back of the sofa each month and then rely on that mysterious but inevitable accumulation of loose change to beat my £67.28 profit.

In fact there are special circumstances surrounding the poor performance of my plan, because in the mid-90s the Lancashire and Yorkshire had to be bailed out by Family Assurance following problems with its investment portfolio.

But my little local difficulty triggered more general questions: how have people done who invested with other friendly societies over the same period? Have these plans been the good buys we were promised? And, most important of all, should we be buying into them in future?

To answer the first question I asked Family Assurance to tell me what I would be getting if I'd bought into one of its unit-linked savings plans back in 1990. Barry Chambers, Family's marketing director, said I would have been getting a cheque for at least £1,740, a very respectable performance. All friendly society savings plans are actually "qualifying endowment plans", which means there's a modest amount of life cover built-in. Many societies offer a with-profits version.

Tunbridge Wells Friendly Society specialises in such plans, which offer some protection against market volatility by locking in some profits by way of annual bonuses, and their Adult Friendly Bond would have returned £1,643 over the same period.

So it's clear that I made an especially bad choice. But in future should we continue to regard friendly society 10-year savings plans as being a part of a balanced savings strategy? Andy Cowan is an independent financial adviser at Aitchison and Colegrave, and for him the answer is a qualified "yes". "We do a fair few of these products but they're still a small percentage of our business because, unlike an Isa, friendly society products tie you in for 10 years and the charges can be high. However, they can be useful when you're saving for children because kids don't have an Isa allowance, or when a client has already used up their other tax-free allowances."

Clive Scott-Hopkins of IFA Towry Law is even less enthusiastic about friendly society savings products.

"I think that they're yesterday's tax exempt savings story. The problem is that with small premiums the charges tend to outweigh the tax savings, particularly when you compare these products with Cat-marked Isas. And if you're saving for children I think that something like the Foreign and Colonial Investment Trust is a better bet, because although the child won't get any tax relief it does have a full capital gains tax (CGT) allowance and the trust's charges are also very low."

The issue of charges is central to the whole debate and the friendly societies' endowment structure means that costs tend to be higher than for many conventional equity-based savings schemes, although most of those do expect investors to put away more than £25 a month. Family Assurance charges new members a one-off £120 when they join - which means that you'll only have invested £5 after your first five months of saving - and then there's a 1.95% annual management charge too. With-profits funds don't come cheap either although, as Ian Grimsell, national sales manager at the Tunbridge Wells Friendly Society, points out, they do at least provide a smoothing effect, which is especially useful if you're saving for a specific event, such as a child's 21st birthday. He adds: "It's a bit of a myth that friendly society costs are high," although even the lowest charges in his own plans lop 2.1% from whatever annual return the underlying fund manages.

Before 1948 friendly societies effectively provided the masses with a "welfare state" and, ironically, products like Tunbridge Wells' Baby Bond and their University Bond are now the most popular versions of friendly society savings plans, as parents and grand-parents save to fund their children's higher education. Barry Chambers reports that 80% of Family's new members are buying this kind of product now - so why do customers go for them? "Because they see a real reason for saving, they like the discipline of having to save regularly, and the product is very simply packaged."

Simplicity wouldn't be enough to tempt me to begin a new plan to help pay for my children's higher education, and because of my bad experience with Lancashire and Yorkshire I've already increased my monthly contributions to my investment trust Isa instead. But if I were to be tempted again I'd probably go for a with-profits product, because at least it offers some protection in the event of a major stock-market crash.

And, as Andy Cowan points out that's something which a conventional unit or investment trust Isa simply can't match.

A free booklet called Making Friends With Friendly Societies can be obtained by phoning 020 7397 9560.

webTitle: Is your perk a road to ruin?

fields.headline: Is your perk a road to ruin?
fields.standfirst: Your company car could be costing more than you think; it may well pay you to buy your own car or even get on your bike, reports Ian Wylie
fields.trailText: While successive governments have set their sights on driving them off the road, company cars are newer, have bigger engines, do more mileage and are worth more, according to the latest Lex Vehicle Leasing Report.
fields.body:
While successive governments have set their sights on driving them off the road, company cars are newer, have bigger engines, do more mileage and are worth more, according to the latest Lex Vehicle Leasing Report.

But company cars are also costing individuals more in income tax, with the promise of still bigger bills to come. If you are prepared to forego the convenience factor of hassle-free motoring - where your employer picks up the tab for insurance, road tax and servicing - then handing back the car keys could be very worthwhile. You may not even have to worry about organising your next car's purchase, financing, taxing, insurance and maintenance - there are a number of leasing schemes which do all the work of a company fleet manager while leaving you free of the tax inspector's embrace.

To work out the cost of your company car, you'll need to look up its list price (including accessories), how much you pay your employer for private use and an estimate of the business miles you'll have done by April 5, 2000.

You can get the first two figures from your form P11D for the 1998-1999 tax year. The basic taxable value is 35% of the list price if your estimated business mileage is less than 2,500; 25% if you will drive more than 2,500 but fewer than 18,000 business miles; 15% if your business mileage will be greater than 18,000. You can knock off a quarter of this if the car will be four years old or more by the end of this tax year.

If you pay your employer for private use of the car, you subtract this from the basic taxable value to arrive at the figure on which you pay tax. The car's tax cost is this figure multiplied by 23% if you are a basic-rate taxpayer; 40% if you pay higher-rate tax. The tax liability for running a company car is therefore likely to be cheaper if your business mileage is high and you would be happy trading down to a smaller or older car. And if your employer is among those offering cash instead of a car, the figures look even better.

If you plan to substitute a car of your own, you'll need an estimate of running costs. These should include: insurance; £155 for the annual tax disc; servicing and repairs; MOT costs for cars more than three-years old; breakdown cover and the cost of any finance deal or loss of interest on savings. You will be better off if the cost savings from relinquishing your company car added to any extra pay after tax (and national insurance at 10% if you earn less than £26,000) is more than enough to cover the cost of running your own car.

Remember that drivers can claim against tax for part of the cost of financing a car they use for business. For example, someone doing 20,000 miles a year, of which half are on business, could set half the interest on a car loan against tax.

Companies can also pay staff a mileage allowance if they use their own cars on business. The Inland Revenue sets approved rates and, as long as the company sticks within these, all mileage payments are tax-free.

The rates vary according to engine size and annual mileage. For example, the rate on a 1,800cc car is 45p a mile for the first 4,000 miles, then 25p a mile. This means someone who does 7,000 miles a year on business can be paid £2,550 without attracting tax - effectively subsidising the cost of a car.

If an employer pays less than the set rates, employees can still claim back the tax on the difference through their annual tax return.

If the company car looks cheaper and there's no cash on offer, it is still worth doing a few sums if you think you will still be driving your car in the 2002-03 tax year, when the current system will be replaced by one linked to the car's price and its exhaust emissions of carbon dioxide, the main greenhouse gas. Tax incentives for higher business mileage will be abolished, plus the discount for cars over four years old.

Alternatively, you could slash your tax bill by asking your employer to swap your Mondeo for a classic car. The tax definition of a classic car is one more than 15 years old and worth more than £15,000. These are taxed on current value. But if it is newer or worth less, it is a non-classic and taxed on its list price when new.

For example on a new £20,000 car the tax liability (at 25% a year) would be a further £20,000 within four years. On a comparable classic, the liability would be mitigated by a 25% rebate (applicable to all company cars that are more than four-years old), exposing you to a four-year bill of £15,000.

Another trick is to find a car which is non-classic according to Inland Revenue rules but classic for everyone else.

The other option is to give up motoring altogether and get on your bike. Since last April, the chancellor has removed the employee benefits tax charge on bicycles and on workplace parking for bicycles.

In addition, employees who use their own bicycles for business travel are now able to claim capital allowances on a proportion of the cost of the bicycle.

Your employer can even pay you up to 12p per mile tax-free for using your own cycle on business travel.

If your company is too stingy, you can still claim tax relief on 12p per business mile or claim relief on the balance up to 12p per mile if your employer pays less than this.

webTitle: 'I do... and we'll have that in writing'

fields.headline: 'I do... and we'll have that in writing'
fields.standfirst: Pre-nuptial agreements do not stand up in British courts, but the law may soon change to give them recognition, says Richard Colbey
fields.trailText: It may not be too romantic but, "How much will this cost me if it all goes wrong?" is a question that crosses the mind of many people about to marry.
fields.body:
It may not be too romantic but, "How much will this cost me if it all goes wrong?" is a question that crosses the mind of many people about to marry. For those who have already been through an expensive divorce the thought may be compelling enough to try to negotiate a pre-nuptial agreement which will regulate what happens should the marriage fail. Michael Douglas is reported to be the latest celebrity to have gone down this line, asking fiancée Catherine Zeta-Jones to sign an agreement which will restrict her share of his fortune should they divorce.

Such agreements are unenforceable in Britain, unlike in America where they are routine among the super-rich. However, it is possible the law here may change soon to give them limited recognition. The Matrimonial Causes Act 1973 lists the factors courts should take into account when making financial orders on divorce. These include the needs of the couple and their children, their resources and earning capacity, their health, their contributions and the length of the marriage. Conspicuously absent from this list is any agreement they may have made before or after marrying.

Nonetheless a legal website, Desktop Lawyer (www.desktoplawyer.net plans to provide a drafting service for such agreements. While legally unenforceable, it may well be that in the context of an amicable divorce a clearly worded agreement would provide the parties with a basis on which to divide their assets. Even if they are past the stage of being concerned about avoiding the personal animosity that inevitably arises once a case goes to court, the possibility of saving legal fees may make reliance on the agreement attractive. It is not unusual for a family's entire assets to be wasted on paying lawyers. It may have been this that led Spice Girl, Mel G, to pay £1.5m to estranged husband Jimmy Gulzar. It was paid despite the fact that courts attach considerable weight to the length of a marriage. In short marriages - and 18 months is a very short time to be married, even to someone who styles herself "Scary" - the British courts would not normally order any payment. The only exception would be if one of the couple had to give up work to look after the their child. In that situation a pre-nuptial agreement might have deterred Mr Gulzar from seeking anything.

Pre-nuptial agreements can deal with the marriage itself as well as the divorce. Although few will want to go as far as New Mexico couple, Teresa and Rex LeValley, who achieved international notoriety when details of their agreement were made public by the clerk of the court. Their agreement included a provision that they would have "healthy sex" three to five times a week. They also promised to make themselves "available for discussions 15 to 30 minutes a day". The agreement contained precise details about when they would have children as well as rules about how they would drive and a stipulation that they would keep their cars' fuel tanks at least half full.

Such an agreement may have worked well for that couple, but it contained matters that no court could ever deal with. Lodging it with a court was intended to give it a legal effect it could never have, and it backfired in an unpredictable way when it was "leaked". However, so long as everyone appreciates that they have, at the most, moral force, these agreements will help many couples clarify what they expect from their marriage.

Richard Colbey is a barrister.

fields.headline: Workers' playtime eases stress
fields.trailText: Stressed-out workers at Ogilvy Advertising can drop into a "play area" stocked with Playstation consoles to help them chill out, writes Nick Pandya. This is the brainchild of the agency's chief exec Paul Simon and is backed by the firm's staff council. This is a freely-elected body acting as workers representatives to management. To raise awareness of the scheme the company has set up an intranet with photos and details of each councillor.
fields.body:
Stressed-out workers at Ogilvy Advertising can drop into a "play area" stocked with Playstation consoles to help them chill out, writes Nick Pandya. This is the brainchild of the agency's chief exec Paul Simon and is backed by the firm's staff council. This is a freely-elected body acting as workers representatives to management. To raise awareness of the scheme the company has set up an intranet with photos and details of each councillor.

Disgruntled staff are encouraged to discuss thorny issues directly, or anonymously if they prefer. And the leader of the staff council is invited to the monthly board meeting.

The agency is keen to foster a sense of community among its corporate constituency of 700 workers. This is achieved by a monthly free drinks night just before payday, which helps to break down barriers between departments and improves internal communications. This allows all those irritating workplace niggles that typically soak up a disproportionate amount of time to be sorted out quickly in a convivial atmosphere.

Paul Simon says: " Working in an advertising agency takes a great deal of commitment and the nature of work requires unsociable and long hours. It's all about creating a comfortable work experience."

However, such staff councils have not been greeted with a chorus of approval in every workplace. And trade union organisers believe that most works councils are packed with "hand-picked cronies". They argue that where employees have the chance to elect union reps, the staff council will be independent of the company, stick up for the interests of all staff and have the back-up of national organisers to ensure that the council raises issues that matter. Without union backing staff councils would simply be quisling bodies.

Government regulations to implement the European Works Councils Directive and set out procedures for negotiations between employees and employers came into force on January 15, 2000.

webTitle: Back to the days of travelling hopefully

fields.headline: Back to the days of travelling hopefully
fields.standfirst: Opinionated, eccentric, xenophobic: guidebooks by the likes of Baedeker are going places in the market, says Stewart Dalby
fields.trailText: Opinionated, eccentric, xenophobic: guidebooks by the likes of Baedeker are going places in the market.
fields.body:
In a review of a book by Alan Sillitoe published in 1995 called Leading the Blind, a Century of Guidebook Travel, about Victorian guidebooks, reviewer Patrick French says: "The most striking difference between the guides of the last century and those of today is their willingness to make huge, crass generalisations about the people of other nations."

It is not the kind of book you would expect from the author of Saturday Night and Sunday Morning or the Loneliness of the Long Distance Runner, but apparently he was an avid collector of Victorian guides, notably those of Karl Baedeker and John Murray.

These two started their guides in the 1830s. In France Adolphe Joanne began his series of Les Guides Bleus in 1841, but it was Baedeker and John Murray who became identified with the golden age of Victorian travel between the end of the Napoleonic wars and the beginning of the Great War, when railways and steamships brought hordes of tourists to Naples, Paris and Coblenz.

Alan Sillitoe's book is a ramble through his library and he quotes extensively from the guides and from eminent travellers such as Henry James and Trollope. And rude they could be. We learn from one that the English are: "Rude, cruel, addicted to thieving and robbing, faithless, headstrong, inclined to strife and mutiny, gluttonous and superstitiously addicted to the predictions of foolish astrologers." The Italians, meanwhile, are: "Licentious types who openly encourage mixed bathing on their beaches," according to the rather prim John Murray.

He also took umbrage at having to pay four shillings for a passport to go to France only to find that he needed to pay a further two shillings to travel around France while his passport was sent to Paris to be picked up when he left.

Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley, in her Journal of a Six Weeks Tour, decribes her companions on a voyage down the the Rhine as "of the meanest class, smoked prodigiously, and were exceedingly disgusting".

But these guides were not just xenophobic diatribes. At a time when mass tourism has become near universal and guide books are 10-a-penny, it is salutory to read books written when travel was more arduous, as they were often important social commentaries covering everything from sports and architecture to the arts. There are also some wonderful, hilarious tips on health.

To avoid sea sickeness James Henry Bennet MD says: "The stomach should be absolutely empty before going on board, but to avoid exhaustion a good meal should be taken three, four, or five hours before - then one or two hours before embarking, some very strong coffee, tea, or spirits and water, should be taken, without milk or other food. Once on board, repose should be enjoined, the recumbent position is best."

Bernard Shapero of Rare Books has just bought one of the most extensive and finest collections of Baedeker and Murray guidebooks. There are nearly 2,000 volumes altogether (1,500 Baedekers and 500 Murrays). It is very rare for this kind of collection to come on the market.

It was assembled by Joel Tabor, himself a chronicler of Baedeker, who worked for Mr Shapero for a while. His 1988 catalogue on Baedeker guides, which comprises 650 items, is considered a standard work. Mr Shapero's plan is to sell the books individually. Prices start at £25 and reach £3,000.

For the past 10 years there has been steep inflation in the prices of Victorian guidebooks. And here I must put my hand up and declare an interest: I have been collecting them for some years.

The great disparity in prices is for two reasons: First, some are rarer than others, which I shall come to in a moment. Second, the condition of some of the books is not, how shall I put it, that wonderful.

Mr Baedeker produced cheaper items than Murray and therefore they sold in greater numbers. But they were less durable and printed on thin paper. The maps were coloured but tended to fade. Certainly the covers of some my books have now fallen apart.

As for rarity, Bernard Shapero reckons that the top of the range in the collection they have bought is a rare edition of Madeira, published in 1939 just before the outbreak of the second world war (undistributed stocks were lost in the bombing of Baedeker's premises during the war) and the English language guide to Russia published pre-revolution and pre-first world war, affording the last glimpse of Csarist Russia.

One guide, written in 1914, states: "The European continent is becoming more and more internationalised and only Great Britain is not participating in this movement": plus ça change.

For further information telephone Bernard Shapero 020-7493-0876.

webTitle: Crucial questions every borrower should be asking

fields.headline: Crucial questions every borrower should be asking
fields.trailText: Does your lender calculate interest on a daily basis?
fields.body:
Does your lender calculate interest on a daily basis?

Halifax: No, but launching a range of mortgages with daily interest calculation in June.

Abbey National: A third of 30-plus mortgages currently on offer feature daily interest calculation, including its flexible mortgage.

Nationwide: No, but does offer daily interest calculation for overpayments.

Woolwich: On 10 of its 24 mortgage deals currently available, the Woolwich calculates interest daily but charges it monthly.

Northern Rock: Of 11 products currently available, only its flexible mortgage offers this.

NatWest: No.

Barclays: No, though its base rate tracker features monthly interest calculation.

Alliance & Leicester: No. However, it calculates interest monthly on its flexible mortgages.

Norwich & Peterborough Building Society: No. But, does allow borrowers to make part repayments which are credited the following month.

Standard Life Bank: Yes (it offers only one deal, the Freestyle flexible mortgage, launched in January 1999).

Do the loans carry extended redemption penalties, tying you in for perhaps several years after the fixed/capped period ends?

Halifax: No - axed them from new mortgage products last year. Says only a "very small percentage" of existing borrowers likely to be tied in by overhanging redemption penalties.

Abbey National: Axed them from new mortgage products in 1998. Some existing borrowers tied in by penalties.

Nationwide: Current range - no. No idea how many existing borrowers affected.

Woolwich: Yes, six of the 24 deals have overhanging penalties. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected.

Northern Rock: Only one of the current deals has overhanging penalties, but the "overhang" is substantial (a two-year fixed rate with penalties for a total of six years).

NatWest: Current range, no.

Barclays: No - axed them more than six months ago. A "small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected.

Alliance & Leicester: Yes, three of the 10 deals on offer have overhanging penalties. Around 30% of home loans sold in 1999 involve extended redemption penalties.

Norwich & Peterborough: Current range, no. Some existing borrowers affected.

Standard Life Bank: The loan does have an overhanging penalty - the 6.65% standard variable rate is discounted by 0.89% for the first six months, with a penalty of three months' gross interest if you walk away in the first 12 months.

Do any of its loans track the base rate?

Halifax: Launched its first base rate tracker loans last summer. About 10 of the 30 loans currently on offer are trackers.

Abbey National: Only one, its flexible mortgage, launched in June 1999.

Nationwide: Only one, its base rate tracker, launched last year.

Woolwich: Nine of the 24 current deals do.

Northern Rock: Current range, no. Did offer a base rate tracker last year.

NatWest: Only one, its base rate tracker mortgage.

Barclays: Eight out of the 14 on offer do.

Alliance & Leicester: Four of the 10 deals on offer, including its base rate tracker, have rates linked "in full or in part" to the base rate.

Norwich & Peterborough: No.

Standard Life Bank: No.

Do any of its current deals involve the borrower having to take the lender's buildings/ contents insurance?

Halifax: Axed compulsory insurance about seven years ago, so only "a handful" of existing borrowers affected.

Abbey National: Axed compulsory insurance from core product range about 10 years ago, so very few of the existing borrowers affected.

Nationwide: No.

Woolwich: Axed compulsory insurance in March 1999. Says "small minority" of existing borrowers affected.

Northern Rock: Axed compulsory insurance in summer 1999. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected.

NatWest: No. It has no figures for existing borrowers.

Barclays: No. Says "a small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected.

Alliance & Leicester: No. Only 2% of borrowers who took out loans in 1999 affected.

Norwich & Peterborough: Yes. It has 15 different deals, each available both with and without compulsory insurance (those without have less attractive rates).

Standard Life Bank: No.

Is there an arrangement fee? If so, how much?

Halifax: No arrangement fee on any of current deals. A "small percentage" of existing borrowers will have paid one.

Abbey National: Says "under 50%" of current range carry a booking fee (typically £150). No figures on how many existing borrowers affected.

Nationwide: Of the 19 loans on offer, seven have a "reservation fee". Usually £95 and applies to fixed and capped rate products. No figures on how many existing borrowers affected.

Woolwich: Of the 24 deals, 13 have an "application fee" (typically £195).

Northern Rock: Nine of its 11 deals carry an arrangement fee varying from £395-£495. Existing borrowers on fixed/discounted rate etc likely to have paid a fee.

NatWest: Says all 23 products will have an arrangement fee. Typically £295, but for two of them (graduate mortgages) it is £1.

Barclays: Three of its 14 deals carry an arrangement fee (typically £295). Says majority of existing borrowers likely to have paid one.

Alliance & Leicester: Of the 10 loans on offer, five carry an arrangement fee (typically £295).

Norwich & Peterborough: All the deals carry an arrangement fee (typically £295) which is added to the account.

Standard Life Bank: No.
fields.bodyText: Does your lender calculate interest on a daily basis? Halifax: No, but launching a range of mortgages with daily interest calculation in June. Abbey National: A third of 30-plus mortgages currently on offer feature daily interest calculation, including its flexible mortgage. Nationwide: No, but does offer daily interest calculation for overpayments. Woolwich: On 10 of its 24 mortgage deals currently available, the Woolwich calculates interest daily but charges it monthly. Northern Rock: Of 11 products currently available, only its flexible mortgage offers this. NatWest: No. Barclays: No, though its base rate tracker features monthly interest calculation. Alliance & Leicester: No. However, it calculates interest monthly on its flexible mortgages. Norwich & Peterborough Building Society: No. But, does allow borrowers to make part repayments which are credited the following month. Standard Life Bank: Yes (it offers only one deal, the Freestyle flexible mortgage, launched in January 1999). Do the loans carry extended redemption penalties, tying you in for perhaps several years after the fixed/capped period ends? Halifax: No - axed them from new mortgage products last year. Says only a "very small percentage" of existing borrowers likely to be tied in by overhanging redemption penalties. Abbey National: Axed them from new mortgage products in 1998. Some existing borrowers tied in by penalties. Nationwide: Current range - no. No idea how many existing borrowers affected. Woolwich: Yes, six of the 24 deals have overhanging penalties. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected. Northern Rock: Only one of the current deals has overhanging penalties, but the "overhang" is substantial (a two-year fixed rate with penalties for a total of six years). NatWest: Current range, no. Barclays: No - axed them more than six months ago. A "small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected. Alliance & Leicester: Yes, three of the 10 deals on offer have overhanging penalties. Around 30% of home loans sold in 1999 involve extended redemption penalties. Norwich & Peterborough: Current range, no. Some existing borrowers affected. Standard Life Bank: The loan does have an overhanging penalty - the 6.65% standard variable rate is discounted by 0.89% for the first six months, with a penalty of three months' gross interest if you walk away in the first 12 months. Do any of its loans track the base rate? Halifax: Launched its first base rate tracker loans last summer. About 10 of the 30 loans currently on offer are trackers. Abbey National: Only one, its flexible mortgage, launched in June 1999. Nationwide: Only one, its base rate tracker, launched last year. Woolwich: Nine of the 24 current deals do. Northern Rock: Current range, no. Did offer a base rate tracker last year. NatWest: Only one, its base rate tracker mortgage. Barclays: Eight out of the 14 on offer do. Alliance & Leicester: Four of the 10 deals on offer, including its base rate tracker, have rates linked "in full or in part" to the base rate. Norwich & Peterborough: No. Standard Life Bank: No. Do any of its current deals involve the borrower having to take the lender's buildings/ contents insurance? Halifax: Axed compulsory insurance about seven years ago, so only "a handful" of existing borrowers affected. Abbey National: Axed compulsory insurance from core product range about 10 years ago, so very few of the existing borrowers affected. Nationwide: No. Woolwich: Axed compulsory insurance in March 1999. Says "small minority" of existing borrowers affected. Northern Rock: Axed compulsory insurance in summer 1999. Unable to say how many existing borrowers affected. NatWest: No. It has no figures for existing borrowers. Barclays: No. Says "a small minority" of existing borrowers likely to be affected. Alliance & Leicester: No. Only 2% of borrowers who took out loans in 1999 affected. Norwich & Peterborough: Yes. It has 15 different deals, each available both with and without compulsory insurance (those without have less attractive rates). Standard Life Bank: No. Is there an arrangement fee? If so, how much? Halifax: No arrangement fee on any of current deals. A "small percentage" of existing borrowers will have paid one. Abbey National: Says "under 50%" of current range carry a booking fee (typically £150). No figures on how many existing borrowers affected. Nationwide: Of the 19 loans on offer, seven have a "reservation fee". Usually £95 and applies to fixed and capped rate products. No figures on how many existing borrowers affected. Woolwich: Of the 24 deals, 13 have an "application fee" (typically £195). Northern Rock: Nine of its 11 deals carry an arrangement fee varying from £395-£495. Existing borrowers on fixed/discounted rate etc likely to have paid a fee. NatWest: Says all 23 products will have an arrangement fee. Typically £295, but for two of them (graduate mortgages) it is £1. Barclays: Three of its 14 deals carry an arrangement fee (typically £295). Says majority of existing borrowers likely to have paid one. Alliance & Leicester: Of the 10 loans on offer, five carry an arrangement fee (typically £295). Norwich & Peterborough: All the deals carry an arrangement fee (typically £295) which is added to the account. Standard Life Bank: No.

webTitle: Veteran grammar school faces first parent ballot on selection

fields.headline: Veteran grammar school faces first parent ballot on selection
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: One of the oldest surviving grammar schools in England, where the opposition leader, William Hague, briefly boarded before moving to a comprehensive, is to face the first parents' ballot on abolishing selective entry.
fields.body:
One of the oldest surviving grammar schools in England, where the opposition leader, William Hague, briefly boarded before moving to a comprehensive, is to face the first parents' ballot on abolishing selective entry.

The independent Electoral Reform Society confirmed yesterday that 587 signatures - the minimum needed to trigger a vote under new government rules - have been validated on a petition collected in Ripon, North Yorkshire.

National campaigners from both sides will now descend on the small market town to canvass parents of children at the grammar school's main feeder primary schools. The ballot paper will ask some 2,850 parents whether the 11-plus exam, which gives places at Ripon Grammar School to only 30% of local children, should be abolished or retained. The result is expected by Easter and a victory for reformers would see selection abolished in 2002.

The vote will be a pointer to the fortunes of England's 163 other selective grammar schools.

Ripon is openly divided on the issue, with strong anti-selection feeling matched by affection for the grammar, founded in 1663, which topped North Yorkshire's state school academic league table this year.

The argument has also been complicated by attempts to revive Ripon College, the nearby state school which came bottom of the same league table.

The school was awarded specialist technology status last week, bringing £120,000 funding plus £120-a-head for its 600 pupils over the next four years.

The heads of both schools are barred from campaigning, but have both declared their support for the status quo. A sizeable minority of Ripon parents meanwhile send their children to comprehensives in Knaresborough and Harrogate.

John Warren of the Ripon Secondary Schools Partnership said: "It has taken five months of intensive campaigning to collect just over 500 signatures. That says a lot about the support for change."

Petitions are also under way in Kent, in Sutton in Surrey, in the London borough of Barnet, and in Trafford in Greater Manchester.

All have larger electorates than Ripon and none are believed to be near the 20% threshold for a ballot.

fields.headline: Morning-after glory
fields.standfirst: Once, life was a cruise for Noel Gallagher. Oasis's brand of rock with attitude sold and sold, and the cocaine and champagne kept coming. Until, one day, he called a halt. He speaks from the heart about his brother Liam, his wife Meg, the baby on the way - and the album that charts his turnaround. By Lindsay Baker
fields.trailText: Once, life was a cruise for Noel Gallagher. Oasis's brand of rock with attitude sold and sold, and the cocaine and champagne kept coming. Until, one day, he called a halt. He speaks from the heart about his brother Liam, his wife Meg, the baby on the way - and the album that charts his turnaround. By Lindsay Baker
fields.body:
Just when was it that the glamour of Oasis first started to fade? When did their seductive supernova swagger cease to be sexy, and begin to seem graceless? Was it when a heavily bearded Liam Gallagher set upon an unsuspecting fan in Australia, breaking his nose? Or was it when even Liam's impeccable singing voice failed to disguise the fundamental pub-rock flavour of the band's third album? Somewhere along the line, a couple of years back, Oasis began to resemble a parody of themselves. Then, last year, to make matters worse, both the guitarist and bass-player suddenly walked away from the group, and were swiftly followed by the boss of the band's label.

The glorious, giddy heights of Champagne Supernova and Wonderwall seem long gone, as are the days when the irreverent, hedonistic Gallagher brothers, boozing for England, could do no wrong: Noel and wife Meg partying at Downing Street; luscious Liam and pouting Patsy posing glossily under a Union Jack duvet on the cover of Vanity Fair's Swinging London issue, the sexy ubercouple - so much more fun than their usurpers, Posh and Becks.

The Oasis party started in 1993 and continued pretty much unabated until 1997. They brightened the Major years, saw in New Labour and (What's The Story?) Morning Glory sold 12 million copies worldwide, topped only by the Spice Girls in the 90s.

Not that their third album, Be Here Now, didn't sell. It did - six million copies, to be precise. It was not that Oasis had become less successful, just less fashionable - and less likeable. For Noel Gallagher, it was the 1997 world tour that did it. The nose-breaking incident in Australia was symptomatic. "It just turned into a travelling piss-up," he admits now, as he sits sipping tea. "Bonehead and Liam were just fuckin' out of control, and I was trying to keep everyone together and trying to explain that people had stopped talking about the music and were just talking about the bullshit that surrounded the band. But after about a month, I just gave up and thought, fuck it, if you can't beat 'em, join 'em." It was not a great time for the band's public image: internationally, the view of them was "a bunch of lunatics who come roaring through town drunk, smash the place up, play a couple of gigs and fuck off again. We did some shocking gigs on the last tour purely because we'd been out too much the night before. As soon as we put the instruments down, we'd go out and get absolutely shit-faced."

He sounds almost repentant. I'd expected him to be sober (he'd recently declared his new, clean status), but I thought that he might be aggressive or arrogant. None of that. He's not what you'd call humble, exactly, but he's polite, friendly even. And in spite of what he fears may be the onset of flu ("you know something's wrong when cigarettes start to taste bad"), he looks rather well, all bright-eyed and clear-skinned. In spite of the band's downward spiral, something, it seems, stopped them from throwing it all away. They pulled themselves back from the brink of terminal self-indulgence and self-destruction, and have emerged from the chaos of the past few years with a new line-up, their own record label and an excellent new album, Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants.

It's not a radical departure, and Noel's songwriting style remains the same, but Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants is more subtle than its predecessors, more of a "grower", and sounds perceptibly more modern than the previous three albums. "We needed a fresh inspiration from somewhere," says Noel. They enlisted Mark "Spike" Stent to co-produce with Noel. "If there's one person who can embellish a rock'n'roll sounding band, then Spike's the man, because he's worked with U2, Madonna, Massive Attack and Bjourk, and he has one foot in the rock'n'roll camp and one in contemporary, electronic music. He'd always liked the band, but he thought that the records sounded crap, which was his opening line to us."

The songs are more personal, and there is less of the Supersonic-style sloganeering. Noel stopped writing lyrics "that just rhymed or sounded good. It's hard to write a really deeply personal song and then give it to someone else who's five years younger than you to express it down the microphone. But Liam's got to understand that, from now on, the songs are going to get more meaningful to me and probably less meaningful to him. And he'll understand as he gets older."

The way Noel describes it, it's hard to know which was more insane, being on a deranged, drugs-driven world tour or being at home in London, where the party continued in much the same way. The new album is more about the comedown than the highs. Where Did It All Go Wrong? is a track written just before Noel and Meg, both now 32, moved out of Supernova Heights, their home in Belsize Park, north London.

Their house had turned into a nightclub, he says, "a pretty good one at that. The bar was always open, the door was always open, there were more people coming in and out than I ever got to know. I must have wasted years sitting there with the curtains closed talking about bullishit - aliens, pyramids, debating 'did they really land on the moon, let's watch the footage again in slow motion' or 'crop circles - what's that all about?'" One morning, he looked in the mirror at his yellow skin and popping eyes, unable to focus, with a load of strangers in the kitchen, and thought, "Oh fuck, how did we get here?"

Sunday Morning Call is about a particular person on a self-destruct mission, who is "too rock'n'roll for their own good". My guess is Kate Moss. "Could be - she's one of my mates, but I wouldn't like to say who it's about." Did Noel never think of checking himself into the Priory, the usual drying-out route favoured by the rich and famous? "I never understand people who spend £50,000 a month to cure a £10,000-a-month habit. And it creates another shit storm and a media circus, and people lie about why they're going in, and say they're 'stressed out'." Instead, Noel and Meg sold their London house and moved to Buckinghamshire. He took the phone off the hook and stayed in. Gas Panic, the new album's darkest track, was written while weaning himself off cocaine - "going cold turkey, without wanting to sound too dramatic about it" - in the midst of a night-time panic attack. "It's basically a paranoid drugs song."

Even when the house wasn't full of party guests, life then at Supernova Heights sounds nightmarishly reminiscent of the Burton-Taylor carousing years. A drugs-and-booze-fuelled Noel and Meg were rowing "about fuck all. 'You said that to that person and they said that about me.'" Finally, says Noel, "I picked my missus up off the kitchen floor" and the two of them set off on a month-long holiday to Thailand. "We'd never really hung out together sober," he says. "We met through drugs. Our relationship was surrounded by drugs. We got married when we were pissed. Though we weren't drunk when we decided to get married," he adds hastily. "When I decided I was going to come off it and change the way I lived, in the beginning it was, like - how's that gonna be with our relationship. Am I still gonna like her?"

The holiday was a success, and he wrote the album's most uplifting track, the tranquil Who Feels Love, after a visit to a temple. "It was the calm after the storm. I suppose I was feeling at one with the world." He had become "re-acquainted" with his wife. "It was like, 'Yeah, she is cool'," he says. "'And I do actually like her. I love her.'"

Then, on their second wedding anniversary last year, Meg told her husband that she was pregnant, "as luck would have it", he beams (by the time you read this, the baby's arrival will be imminent). "That gave us something else. You go on being young and having nothing to keep you grounded... I like that I'm not going to be able to let myself go any more, because I'm going to have to be there." It was good timing, for both of them. Without the pregnancy, it might have been harder for Meg to quit the rock'n'roll lifestyle, says her husband. "Meg is hardcore, her and her fuckin' girlfriends are worse than any bunch of guys I've ever been out with." I find that hard to believe. "I mean it, man," he says seriously. "They are fuckin' hardcore rock'n'roll women. They can be a bit scary when they're out, actually," he smiles. "She's easily led, that woman," he says, rather fondly, "especially by mates who are 10 years younger than her. Meg always wanted kids, anyway, and I was, like, well, if it happens it happens, but I was over the moon that it did."

When guitarist Bonehead and bass-player Guigsy left the band in August last year, Liam "freaked out", but Noel was philosophical about it. "By their own admission, they weren't very good musicians," he says. They signed up rhythm guitarist Gem, formerly of Heavy Stereo, and bassist Andy Bell, formerly of Ride, to join the Gallaghers and drummer Andy White, and the new line-up made its debut in Philadelphia last December. The full world tour starts in Japan next month, ending up in the UK in July.

Noel is equally sanguine about the departure earlier this month of Alan McGee, the boss of Creation who originally signed up the band on the spot at a small gig in Glasgow and who has left to set up an internet company. "With two members leaving and then this, it looked like a big shit sandwich. But when you go to bed at night it's a crisis, and when you wake up in the morning it's just another problem to be solved." Liam was quoted as saying that he felt deserted by McGee, for whom the band had made around £30 million. "I know for a fact he just said that for effect, because I know he wasn't upset with Alan when he left. I dunno why he's saying he's broken-hearted because to be broken-hearted you have to have a heart, and he hasn't. He might think he does. He's got a soul, but he's not got a heart."

Creation Records has now folded, and 30 staff were made redundant. Noel feels for them, but says, matter-of-factly, "it's not the first record label that's folded, and it won't be the last . . . If it hadn't been for Alan, I wouldn't have signed off the dole. It works both ways. We made him a lot of money. He gave us the chance to make him a lot of money. He left us in a pretty decent position." The band have now set up their own label, Big Brother, though they remain under the auspices of parent company Sony.

A large number of young Britons spent their formative years on the late-80s rave scene, a movement that sparked a tabloid moral panic - and one that was largely outlawed by the Tory government. For those people, hedonism and anti-authoritarianism went hand in hand. So, when Oasis appeared in 1993, extolling the virtues of drugs - "like having a cup of tea", as Noel famously phrased it once - and proudly displaying their working-class, anti-establishment credentials, it's no surpise that the "chemical generation" took to them. Like the Happy Mondays and Stone Roses before them, Oasis tapped straight into the rebellious, feel-good moment.

After he'd made the famous drugs-and-tea comment, Noel recalls returning to his previous home in St John's Wood to find his house surrounded by journalists and the street cordoned off. He went to a friend's place. There had been questions raised in Parliament, and the then Home Secretary, Michael Howard, was on television demanding that he be kicked out of the country. "Two years later, I was arriving at Downing Street in a Rolls-Royce and thinking, 'I hope you're fuckin' watching this now.'"

His mum was very proud, he says, as was Meg's mother, a former trades unionist. "And, of course, I was entirely convinced I was going to get a knighthood," he laughs. The post-victory euphoria was still tangible in Britain. Again in repentant mode, he says that he wished he'd called his Liverpool docker acquaintances the night before to ask if there was anything they wanted him to say to Tony Blair. "But of course I went there for the infamy more than anything, and it was, like, 'You're top.' 'No, you're top.' 'No, you're fuckin' top.' 'Well, thanks a lot, here's a gold disc.'" Whatever he may think of Blair now - he says he became disillusioned when the Government started "taking money off single mothers and students" - he's still glad that he went to Downing Street. "Once. I wouldn't do it again." He concedes that Blair's spin doctors were using him to heighten New Labour's credibility, "but we'd had 18 years of the fuckin' Tories drip-drying this country almost out of business. I'd voted Labour all my life."

Oasis's laddish demeanour was also very of-the-moment in the early days. Back in 1993, Loaded magazine was soon to be launched, and "lad culture", though not to everyone's taste, had at least a new frankness and honesty about it. The band's brashness seemed emblematic of a shift in British male identity. The popular perception of Oasis is still steeped in drugs, violence and sex. Is that a good thing? Noel pauses for a moment. "I can see that when we came along at the arse end of '93, it was Suede and all them lot, and we were, like, 'Right. They're shit. They're shit. You're fuckin' totally shit. Chop 'em out. Get us a fuckin' beer. Hello darlin'.' And the kids went berserk, because they were, like, 'that's me incarnate, how cool is that'. And the more people said it, the more we just went berserk. And we lived up to it for a while."

Liam, although calmer nowadays, still does, off and on. He "went missing" for a few days last November, and the tabloids made the most of it. For Noel, such behaviour, even now, is not without its advantages: "I was thinking, 'For fuck's sake, not again', but to some kid living in a council block in Glasgow, I bet he was going, 'You fuckin' go on, my son, you really don't give a fuck, Liam'." Episodes such as this - and Liam's scrape with the law for drugs possession a few years back - help Joe Public connect with the band, Noel believes. He can understand the media obsession with Liam and Patsy, he says. "Rockstar. Headcase. Actress. Headcase. Little blonde chick, lunatic with a beard. I can see why people wonder what's going on behind closed doors." Patsy's recent comments in GQ magazine about the couple's sex life made front-page news in many of the tabloids.

Not that Liam and Patsy have a monopoly on the column inches, of course. At one point, Noel was approached by the tabloids to comment on more or less any subject: the Royal Family, the Labour Party, other bands. "They'd be, like, 'get someone round to Gallagher's house. He'll be up, he'll give you a quote'." And Noel would invariably oblige, usually drunk. "I'd be, like, 'What? The French? What've they done? Nicking our fish? Fuck 'em! Fuckin' French! And I'd go into one."

Nor has Meg exactly shunned the limelight. Her high public profile, frequently in Gucci, has added to the Gallaghers' seeming ubiquity. Unlike Patsy, who, since her days as the Bird's Eye peas girl, has been used to life in the public eye, celebrity was thrust upon Meg suddenly, and she embraced it. Her short-lived column in the Sunday Times, while curiously compelling, did little to enhance the band's mystique. Noel was not keen. "I went fuckin' ballistic. We have heated debates about stuff like that. To me it was just celebrity name-dropping and it was wrong." But the paper was offering her £50,000, and her party-organising business with friend Fran Cutler had not, at that point, taken off. "She wouldn't want anyone to think that she sits at home all day, eating cream cakes and spending my money. She's her own woman. At the end of the day, we had to agree to disagree. I would never put my foot down and tell her what to do. She'd tell me to piss off."

These days, "lad culture" has begun to look a bit tired. The Loaded ethos has been lifted and transformed by the wider men's magazine market, and the media generally, into something more ubiquitous and more cynical. For Oasis still to appear fresh, something more than a reputation for hell-raising is needed to justify their status, something more profound, and no one is more aware of that than Noel. But his approach is double-edged. On the one hand, he acknowledges that the mad-for-it melodrama helps people feel a connection with the band. On the other hand, he refuses to indulge his little brother. "I'm the only person who'll tell it like it is. He has a lot of people who pussyfoot around him and say, 'He does this because of that'. Fuck him. He's 27. He's a millionaire. I'm not having it that his life is any worse than someone who's living in fuckin' Leicester, who's got two kids and no fuckin' job. I'm not having any of that shit."

Liam doesn't always like hearing that, or reading it in print; it seems demeaning to him. "But if it wasn't for me," says his brother, "he'd think it was all right to go on a bender for three days and not see his kid. He'd think that was fine. He sees me and I'm, like, 'You're a disgrace.' It's for his own good. There's two sides to Liam: when he's pissed, he's fuckin' horrible, and I hate him, and I really mean that. I fuckin' hate him. It's just psychotic alcohol bullshit and I've got no time for him. When he's sober, he's a top geezer and you can have a rational conversation with him about anything." Rather sweetly, he adds, in his brother's defence, that it's a tall order to juggle the balls of rock-stardom and fatherhood, and that every so often Liam drops one of those balls, and that's when he goes on drinking binges. There's a track on the album written by Liam called Little James, about his stepson (Patsy's son by the singer Jim Kerr). "It's a good song," says Noel. "I wouldn't have let it be on the album otherwise."

Noel asked his brother recently which Liam would be coming on tour with them this year. He told him that if it was the same Liam who came on tour in 1997 - "with a beard and a stupid hat, blowing a stupid trumpet into his microphone" - then it would be the last tour on which Noel would be joining him. If, however, it was the Liam that he knows and likes, then that would be fine. "I just wanted to know what weapons to pack." Noel's worst nightmare is that somewhere in the middle of Texas, Liam will get drunk, start arguing, and the two new members of the band will bale out.

He's optimistic, though. "Everyone likes a drink and all that, but the chaos seems to have left, and I think we all know we're not some young punks any more. I don't like to say that we're responsible adults, exactly, but we want to put on a good show for the people who've bothered to come and see us after all these years." The remorse creeps back into his voice. "We've made some bad mistakes in the past, and still, in England, if we put out one photograph we sell out two nights at Wembley Stadium. To me, that is fuckin' astonishing. And we're not going to fuck it up this time."

It's perhaps no wonder that the Gallagher brothers are determined not to let their success slip through their fingers, nor that they went on a four-year bender when fame and wealth came their way. They had more reason to celebrate than most. Noel feels no nostalgia for his early years in Manchester. Out of his old friends, some are dead, some are in prison for drug-dealing or robbing, and a lot of them are "average Joes". He remembers going to his local, the Packhorse, on Friday nights. Everyone would stand around the pool table "talking about who was hardest, City or United". They are not romantic memories.

For Liam, their brother Paul, and himself, life was no worse than for anyone else on his street, but, he says, the 80s were not a good time to be growing up. His unhappiest memories were of "unemployment and desolation, growing up on the dole on £17 a week. My Mam used to take half of it, and I'm glad she done it now. I come from fuck all and if I go back to nothing I'll have had a good trip." He won't be rushing back there, though. He still supports Manchester City, of course, but he gets agitated when Mancunians expect a more general sense of loyalty. "I'm like, 'Get over it, we don't live here any more. It's just the place where I used to live.'" When he goes there now, he says, he gets the sense of being a huge fish in a tiny fishbowl. "I think I'd probably go insane up there. London's massive, and there are millions of famous people, so who gives a fuck."

Of course, there's more to it than the grim surroundings. "Home life was a bit of a pain in the arse," he says, more quietly, "because my Dad was a typical Irishman, flying off the handle for any reason, and my Mam was a typical Irishwoman, always stood by him, even though we were always going 'leave him'." Peggy Gallagher waited until her sons had grown up, "God bless her", and then off she went. He hasn't seen his father for years. Does he think they will ever be reconciled? "Never. I find it very hypocritical when he goes, 'my sons this, my sons that'. He doesn't even know us. He used to say that none of us would end up doing anything with our lives coz we were useless, coz we had no qualifications.

"If I went back to shake his hand and forgive him, that would condone everything he's done. He'd have got away with it. He's got to go to his grave knowing for a fact that I hate him and that Liam hates him and that my Mam doesn't want anything to do with him. He's got to fuckin' pay for his sins, man. Simple as that. Fuck him. He beat me up when I was kid. He actually physically had me on the floor, and I had black eyes because of him, up until I was 16, 17." His father has always denied this. But for Noel a reunion is off the cards. "There's no fuckin' way. There's nothing that anyone can say to me like 'but he's your dad'. Big deal."

Not that it was all doom and gloom. Learning to play the guitar in his teens was a happy time, he says, "strumming away on the same three chords - a bit like now." And listening to the Smiths ("Morrissey and Marr were like gods to me"), seeing the Stone Roses play, going to raves in his 20s, and working as a roadie for the Inspiral Carpets. His happiest childhood recollections are not of Manchester, but of summer holidays in County Mayo, Ireland, where the boys and their mother stayed with their grandma for six weeks every year, living on the farm and making hay. "My gran's got this house and the back garden is just fuckin' huge. The nearest neighbours are four miles away. She didn't have running water, so we went to the well to get water. It was back to basics. Those are my fondest memories."

So fond, in fact, that he recently went to a sanctuary and acquired two donkeys, because they reminded him of his childhood summers in Ireland. At their Buckinghamshire home, Noel and Meg also have four cats, some geese, some goats and five dogs (two Dobermans, two Jack Russells and one mongrel they found abandoned in a shop doorway in Camden). He's hoping for a Staffordshire bull terrier for his birthday. Noel Gallagher? An animal lover? Who would have thought it. "They're for the kids, really, when they get a bit older."

Noel is now a three-pints-of-Guinness man ("then I fall over"). The couple threw a Boxing Day party at their country abode, and Noel thought that there were probably guests sneaking to the toilets for a quick coke fix. It didn't bother him, he says. He doesn't want to preach to anyone, it's just not for him any more. He says that, a few years down the line, when his kids get involved in the "same shit that their mum and dad did", that his experiences will help him understand. When he eventually sits down to have that father-son or father-daughter conversation about drugs, "they'll understand that I've done it and that I'm not bullshitting them. When you're 24, and you're in one of the biggest bands in the world and you've got loads of money, you go mental. No one could have persuaded me then that, in six or seven years time, I was going to be lying in bed having a panic attack, getting the shakes. Life's for living."

The money he's saved from the drugs is "piling up in the bank". Along with a Porsche, a Range Rover, a Jag and 400 pairs of vintage Adidas trainers (which take up a whole room in the house), the couple have recently acquired a house in Ibiza. "Thinking 16 years ahead, our kids can go there and they'll be known on the island, they'll speak Spanish, the local police will know them - any trouble, their dad'll be over there."

And if, in their 40s, he and his wife get their "second wind", they'll be in the prime spot for a bit of clubbing. "We'll be the sad old gits at the back with our bottles of water who've forgotten how to dance," he says.

The baby is in "flight position", and Noel has been told by Meg that he will be at the birth. "I'm looking forward to the day after the birth. I've got a mental picture of the birth like some scene from The Exorcist with loads of swearing, people in masks, screaming, shouting, a smoke machine." His mother, needless to say, is ecstatic. "It's like a bus: you wait 10 years for a grandchild, then two come along at once." All is well, it seems. He wants a girl, he says. "Having two brothers and being in a band of five geezers, there are too many men in my life."

Another thing he will make sure of, he says, is that his kids know how privileged they are. "They won't grow up in a shitty council house with no money, but they'll have a pretty good idea what it's like, because I've been there." Recently, Noel was approached in the street by a fan asking for an autograph. He noticed that the boy was so over-awed that he was shaking. "Calm down," he told him. "We all shit in the same toilet. It's no big deal." The boy replied, "But you are my god." To Noel, this was absurd. But didn't he once say that Oasis were bigger than God? "I said we were bigger than God, but what I meant to say was taller. I believe Jesus was 5ft 7in and I'm 5ft 8 1/2 in," he smiles sheepishly. "I still stand by that."
