fields.bodyText: Just when was it that the glamour of Oasis first started to fade? When did their seductive supernova swagger cease to be sexy, and begin to seem graceless? Was it when a heavily bearded Liam Gallagher set upon an unsuspecting fan in Australia, breaking his nose? Or was it when even Liam's impeccable singing voice failed to disguise the fundamental pub-rock flavour of the band's third album? Somewhere along the line, a couple of years back, Oasis began to resemble a parody of themselves. Then, last year, to make matters worse, both the guitarist and bass-player suddenly walked away from the group, and were swiftly followed by the boss of the band's label. The glorious, giddy heights of Champagne Supernova and Wonderwall seem long gone, as are the days when the irreverent, hedonistic Gallagher brothers, boozing for England, could do no wrong: Noel and wife Meg partying at Downing Street; luscious Liam and pouting Patsy posing glossily under a Union Jack duvet on the cover of Vanity Fair's Swinging London issue, the sexy ubercouple - so much more fun than their usurpers, Posh and Becks. The Oasis party started in 1993 and continued pretty much unabated until 1997. They brightened the Major years, saw in New Labour and (What's The Story?) Morning Glory sold 12 million copies worldwide, topped only by the Spice Girls in the 90s. Not that their third album, Be Here Now, didn't sell. It did - six million copies, to be precise. It was not that Oasis had become less successful, just less fashionable - and less likeable. For Noel Gallagher, it was the 1997 world tour that did it. The nose-breaking incident in Australia was symptomatic. "It just turned into a travelling piss-up," he admits now, as he sits sipping tea. "Bonehead and Liam were just fuckin' out of control, and I was trying to keep everyone together and trying to explain that people had stopped talking about the music and were just talking about the bullshit that surrounded the band. But after about a month, I just gave up and thought, fuck it, if you can't beat 'em, join 'em." It was not a great time for the band's public image: internationally, the view of them was "a bunch of lunatics who come roaring through town drunk, smash the place up, play a couple of gigs and fuck off again. We did some shocking gigs on the last tour purely because we'd been out too much the night before. As soon as we put the instruments down, we'd go out and get absolutely shit-faced." He sounds almost repentant. I'd expected him to be sober (he'd recently declared his new, clean status), but I thought that he might be aggressive or arrogant. None of that. He's not what you'd call humble, exactly, but he's polite, friendly even. And in spite of what he fears may be the onset of flu ("you know something's wrong when cigarettes start to taste bad"), he looks rather well, all bright-eyed and clear-skinned. In spite of the band's downward spiral, something, it seems, stopped them from throwing it all away. They pulled themselves back from the brink of terminal self-indulgence and self-destruction, and have emerged from the chaos of the past few years with a new line-up, their own record label and an excellent new album, Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants. It's not a radical departure, and Noel's songwriting style remains the same, but Standing On The Shoulder Of Giants is more subtle than its predecessors, more of a "grower", and sounds perceptibly more modern than the previous three albums. "We needed a fresh inspiration from somewhere," says Noel. They enlisted Mark "Spike" Stent to co-produce with Noel. "If there's one person who can embellish a rock'n'roll sounding band, then Spike's the man, because he's worked with U2, Madonna, Massive Attack and Bjourk, and he has one foot in the rock'n'roll camp and one in contemporary, electronic music. He'd always liked the band, but he thought that the records sounded crap, which was his opening line to us." The songs are more personal, and there is less of the Supersonic-style sloganeering. Noel stopped writing lyrics "that just rhymed or sounded good. It's hard to write a really deeply personal song and then give it to someone else who's five years younger than you to express it down the microphone. But Liam's got to understand that, from now on, the songs are going to get more meaningful to me and probably less meaningful to him. And he'll understand as he gets older." The way Noel describes it, it's hard to know which was more insane, being on a deranged, drugs-driven world tour or being at home in London, where the party continued in much the same way. The new album is more about the comedown than the highs. Where Did It All Go Wrong? is a track written just before Noel and Meg, both now 32, moved out of Supernova Heights, their home in Belsize Park, north London. Their house had turned into a nightclub, he says, "a pretty good one at that. The bar was always open, the door was always open, there were more people coming in and out than I ever got to know. I must have wasted years sitting there with the curtains closed talking about bullishit - aliens, pyramids, debating 'did they really land on the moon, let's watch the footage again in slow motion' or 'crop circles - what's that all about?'" One morning, he looked in the mirror at his yellow skin and popping eyes, unable to focus, with a load of strangers in the kitchen, and thought, "Oh fuck, how did we get here?" Sunday Morning Call is about a particular person on a self-destruct mission, who is "too rock'n'roll for their own good". My guess is Kate Moss. "Could be - she's one of my mates, but I wouldn't like to say who it's about." Did Noel never think of checking himself into the Priory, the usual drying-out route favoured by the rich and famous? "I never understand people who spend £50,000 a month to cure a £10,000-a-month habit. And it creates another shit storm and a media circus, and people lie about why they're going in, and say they're 'stressed out'." Instead, Noel and Meg sold their London house and moved to Buckinghamshire. He took the phone off the hook and stayed in. Gas Panic, the new album's darkest track, was written while weaning himself off cocaine - "going cold turkey, without wanting to sound too dramatic about it" - in the midst of a night-time panic attack. "It's basically a paranoid drugs song." Even when the house wasn't full of party guests, life then at Supernova Heights sounds nightmarishly reminiscent of the Burton-Taylor carousing years. A drugs-and-booze-fuelled Noel and Meg were rowing "about fuck all. 'You said that to that person and they said that about me.'" Finally, says Noel, "I picked my missus up off the kitchen floor" and the two of them set off on a month-long holiday to Thailand. "We'd never really hung out together sober," he says. "We met through drugs. Our relationship was surrounded by drugs. We got married when we were pissed. Though we weren't drunk when we decided to get married," he adds hastily. "When I decided I was going to come off it and change the way I lived, in the beginning it was, like - how's that gonna be with our relationship. Am I still gonna like her?" The holiday was a success, and he wrote the album's most uplifting track, the tranquil Who Feels Love, after a visit to a temple. "It was the calm after the storm. I suppose I was feeling at one with the world." He had become "re-acquainted" with his wife. "It was like, 'Yeah, she is cool'," he says. "'And I do actually like her. I love her.'" Then, on their second wedding anniversary last year, Meg told her husband that she was pregnant, "as luck would have it", he beams (by the time you read this, the baby's arrival will be imminent). "That gave us something else. You go on being young and having nothing to keep you grounded... I like that I'm not going to be able to let myself go any more, because I'm going to have to be there." It was good timing, for both of them. Without the pregnancy, it might have been harder for Meg to quit the rock'n'roll lifestyle, says her husband. "Meg is hardcore, her and her fuckin' girlfriends are worse than any bunch of guys I've ever been out with." I find that hard to believe. "I mean it, man," he says seriously. "They are fuckin' hardcore rock'n'roll women. They can be a bit scary when they're out, actually," he smiles. "She's easily led, that woman," he says, rather fondly, "especially by mates who are 10 years younger than her. Meg always wanted kids, anyway, and I was, like, well, if it happens it happens, but I was over the moon that it did." When guitarist Bonehead and bass-player Guigsy left the band in August last year, Liam "freaked out", but Noel was philosophical about it. "By their own admission, they weren't very good musicians," he says. They signed up rhythm guitarist Gem, formerly of Heavy Stereo, and bassist Andy Bell, formerly of Ride, to join the Gallaghers and drummer Andy White, and the new line-up made its debut in Philadelphia last December. The full world tour starts in Japan next month, ending up in the UK in July. Noel is equally sanguine about the departure earlier this month of Alan McGee, the boss of Creation who originally signed up the band on the spot at a small gig in Glasgow and who has left to set up an internet company. "With two members leaving and then this, it looked like a big shit sandwich. But when you go to bed at night it's a crisis, and when you wake up in the morning it's just another problem to be solved." Liam was quoted as saying that he felt deserted by McGee, for whom the band had made around £30 million. "I know for a fact he just said that for effect, because I know he wasn't upset with Alan when he left. I dunno why he's saying he's broken-hearted because to be broken-hearted you have to have a heart, and he hasn't. He might think he does. He's got a soul, but he's not got a heart." Creation Records has now folded, and 30 staff were made redundant. Noel feels for them, but says, matter-of-factly, "it's not the first record label that's folded, and it won't be the last . . . If it hadn't been for Alan, I wouldn't have signed off the dole. It works both ways. We made him a lot of money. He gave us the chance to make him a lot of money. He left us in a pretty decent position." The band have now set up their own label, Big Brother, though they remain under the auspices of parent company Sony. A large number of young Britons spent their formative years on the late-80s rave scene, a movement that sparked a tabloid moral panic - and one that was largely outlawed by the Tory government. For those people, hedonism and anti-authoritarianism went hand in hand. So, when Oasis appeared in 1993, extolling the virtues of drugs - "like having a cup of tea", as Noel famously phrased it once - and proudly displaying their working-class, anti-establishment credentials, it's no surpise that the "chemical generation" took to them. Like the Happy Mondays and Stone Roses before them, Oasis tapped straight into the rebellious, feel-good moment. After he'd made the famous drugs-and-tea comment, Noel recalls returning to his previous home in St John's Wood to find his house surrounded by journalists and the street cordoned off. He went to a friend's place. There had been questions raised in Parliament, and the then Home Secretary, Michael Howard, was on television demanding that he be kicked out of the country. "Two years later, I was arriving at Downing Street in a Rolls-Royce and thinking, 'I hope you're fuckin' watching this now.'" His mum was very proud, he says, as was Meg's mother, a former trades unionist. "And, of course, I was entirely convinced I was going to get a knighthood," he laughs. The post-victory euphoria was still tangible in Britain. Again in repentant mode, he says that he wished he'd called his Liverpool docker acquaintances the night before to ask if there was anything they wanted him to say to Tony Blair. "But of course I went there for the infamy more than anything, and it was, like, 'You're top.' 'No, you're top.' 'No, you're fuckin' top.' 'Well, thanks a lot, here's a gold disc.'" Whatever he may think of Blair now - he says he became disillusioned when the Government started "taking money off single mothers and students" - he's still glad that he went to Downing Street. "Once. I wouldn't do it again." He concedes that Blair's spin doctors were using him to heighten New Labour's credibility, "but we'd had 18 years of the fuckin' Tories drip-drying this country almost out of business. I'd voted Labour all my life." Oasis's laddish demeanour was also very of-the-moment in the early days. Back in 1993, Loaded magazine was soon to be launched, and "lad culture", though not to everyone's taste, had at least a new frankness and honesty about it. The band's brashness seemed emblematic of a shift in British male identity. The popular perception of Oasis is still steeped in drugs, violence and sex. Is that a good thing? Noel pauses for a moment. "I can see that when we came along at the arse end of '93, it was Suede and all them lot, and we were, like, 'Right. They're shit. They're shit. You're fuckin' totally shit. Chop 'em out. Get us a fuckin' beer. Hello darlin'.' And the kids went berserk, because they were, like, 'that's me incarnate, how cool is that'. And the more people said it, the more we just went berserk. And we lived up to it for a while." Liam, although calmer nowadays, still does, off and on. He "went missing" for a few days last November, and the tabloids made the most of it. For Noel, such behaviour, even now, is not without its advantages: "I was thinking, 'For fuck's sake, not again', but to some kid living in a council block in Glasgow, I bet he was going, 'You fuckin' go on, my son, you really don't give a fuck, Liam'." Episodes such as this - and Liam's scrape with the law for drugs possession a few years back - help Joe Public connect with the band, Noel believes. He can understand the media obsession with Liam and Patsy, he says. "Rockstar. Headcase. Actress. Headcase. Little blonde chick, lunatic with a beard. I can see why people wonder what's going on behind closed doors." Patsy's recent comments in GQ magazine about the couple's sex life made front-page news in many of the tabloids. Not that Liam and Patsy have a monopoly on the column inches, of course. At one point, Noel was approached by the tabloids to comment on more or less any subject: the Royal Family, the Labour Party, other bands. "They'd be, like, 'get someone round to Gallagher's house. He'll be up, he'll give you a quote'." And Noel would invariably oblige, usually drunk. "I'd be, like, 'What? The French? What've they done? Nicking our fish? Fuck 'em! Fuckin' French! And I'd go into one." Nor has Meg exactly shunned the limelight. Her high public profile, frequently in Gucci, has added to the Gallaghers' seeming ubiquity. Unlike Patsy, who, since her days as the Bird's Eye peas girl, has been used to life in the public eye, celebrity was thrust upon Meg suddenly, and she embraced it. Her short-lived column in the Sunday Times, while curiously compelling, did little to enhance the band's mystique. Noel was not keen. "I went fuckin' ballistic. We have heated debates about stuff like that. To me it was just celebrity name-dropping and it was wrong." But the paper was offering her £50,000, and her party-organising business with friend Fran Cutler had not, at that point, taken off. "She wouldn't want anyone to think that she sits at home all day, eating cream cakes and spending my money. She's her own woman. At the end of the day, we had to agree to disagree. I would never put my foot down and tell her what to do. She'd tell me to piss off." These days, "lad culture" has begun to look a bit tired. The Loaded ethos has been lifted and transformed by the wider men's magazine market, and the media generally, into something more ubiquitous and more cynical. For Oasis still to appear fresh, something more than a reputation for hell-raising is needed to justify their status, something more profound, and no one is more aware of that than Noel. But his approach is double-edged. On the one hand, he acknowledges that the mad-for-it melodrama helps people feel a connection with the band. On the other hand, he refuses to indulge his little brother. "I'm the only person who'll tell it like it is. He has a lot of people who pussyfoot around him and say, 'He does this because of that'. Fuck him. He's 27. He's a millionaire. I'm not having it that his life is any worse than someone who's living in fuckin' Leicester, who's got two kids and no fuckin' job. I'm not having any of that shit." Liam doesn't always like hearing that, or reading it in print; it seems demeaning to him. "But if it wasn't for me," says his brother, "he'd think it was all right to go on a bender for three days and not see his kid. He'd think that was fine. He sees me and I'm, like, 'You're a disgrace.' It's for his own good. There's two sides to Liam: when he's pissed, he's fuckin' horrible, and I hate him, and I really mean that. I fuckin' hate him. It's just psychotic alcohol bullshit and I've got no time for him. When he's sober, he's a top geezer and you can have a rational conversation with him about anything." Rather sweetly, he adds, in his brother's defence, that it's a tall order to juggle the balls of rock-stardom and fatherhood, and that every so often Liam drops one of those balls, and that's when he goes on drinking binges. There's a track on the album written by Liam called Little James, about his stepson (Patsy's son by the singer Jim Kerr). "It's a good song," says Noel. "I wouldn't have let it be on the album otherwise." Noel asked his brother recently which Liam would be coming on tour with them this year. He told him that if it was the same Liam who came on tour in 1997 - "with a beard and a stupid hat, blowing a stupid trumpet into his microphone" - then it would be the last tour on which Noel would be joining him. If, however, it was the Liam that he knows and likes, then that would be fine. "I just wanted to know what weapons to pack." Noel's worst nightmare is that somewhere in the middle of Texas, Liam will get drunk, start arguing, and the two new members of the band will bale out. He's optimistic, though. "Everyone likes a drink and all that, but the chaos seems to have left, and I think we all know we're not some young punks any more. I don't like to say that we're responsible adults, exactly, but we want to put on a good show for the people who've bothered to come and see us after all these years." The remorse creeps back into his voice. "We've made some bad mistakes in the past, and still, in England, if we put out one photograph we sell out two nights at Wembley Stadium. To me, that is fuckin' astonishing. And we're not going to fuck it up this time." It's perhaps no wonder that the Gallagher brothers are determined not to let their success slip through their fingers, nor that they went on a four-year bender when fame and wealth came their way. They had more reason to celebrate than most. Noel feels no nostalgia for his early years in Manchester. Out of his old friends, some are dead, some are in prison for drug-dealing or robbing, and a lot of them are "average Joes". He remembers going to his local, the Packhorse, on Friday nights. Everyone would stand around the pool table "talking about who was hardest, City or United". They are not romantic memories. For Liam, their brother Paul, and himself, life was no worse than for anyone else on his street, but, he says, the 80s were not a good time to be growing up. His unhappiest memories were of "unemployment and desolation, growing up on the dole on £17 a week. My Mam used to take half of it, and I'm glad she done it now. I come from fuck all and if I go back to nothing I'll have had a good trip." He won't be rushing back there, though. He still supports Manchester City, of course, but he gets agitated when Mancunians expect a more general sense of loyalty. "I'm like, 'Get over it, we don't live here any more. It's just the place where I used to live.'" When he goes there now, he says, he gets the sense of being a huge fish in a tiny fishbowl. "I think I'd probably go insane up there. London's massive, and there are millions of famous people, so who gives a fuck." Of course, there's more to it than the grim surroundings. "Home life was a bit of a pain in the arse," he says, more quietly, "because my Dad was a typical Irishman, flying off the handle for any reason, and my Mam was a typical Irishwoman, always stood by him, even though we were always going 'leave him'." Peggy Gallagher waited until her sons had grown up, "God bless her", and then off she went. He hasn't seen his father for years. Does he think they will ever be reconciled? "Never. I find it very hypocritical when he goes, 'my sons this, my sons that'. He doesn't even know us. He used to say that none of us would end up doing anything with our lives coz we were useless, coz we had no qualifications. "If I went back to shake his hand and forgive him, that would condone everything he's done. He'd have got away with it. He's got to go to his grave knowing for a fact that I hate him and that Liam hates him and that my Mam doesn't want anything to do with him. He's got to fuckin' pay for his sins, man. Simple as that. Fuck him. He beat me up when I was kid. He actually physically had me on the floor, and I had black eyes because of him, up until I was 16, 17." His father has always denied this. But for Noel a reunion is off the cards. "There's no fuckin' way. There's nothing that anyone can say to me like 'but he's your dad'. Big deal." Not that it was all doom and gloom. fields.body:
Aunt Elspeth ambushes me by the dustbin, a look of perturbation clouding her honest sonsie face. "What's Y2K, dearrr ?" she enquires with furtive urgency. For a split second, I am myself caught in a no man's land between Y2K and KY Jelly, and produce a sudden blush. This despite the fact that there has been no need for KY Jelly in my life since - well, since quite a way back into the last century, actually. No Man's Land, indeed. Seeing me blush, the aunt flinches. Has she stumbled upon something obscene?

"It's the year 2000, Auntie," I inform her, hastily.

She scrutinises me. " Arrre you all rrright, dearrr ? You look feverrrish ."

"It's okay - just a hot flush," I protest.

"But, my dearrr, I thought you were on HGV?"

"No Auntie - just wild yam and red clover."

At this point, any sensible pair of people would gracefully bow, run off in opposite directions and make sure they didn't meet again for a month. But Aunt Elspeth is living downstairs. She is my destiny. Well, she's my ex-husband's destiny, really, being his aunt, but over the years I have acquired responsibility for all his social relationships, including the tight-lipped ultimata from his other ex-wife Elaine, regarding access to his vile brat. (I'm not being clannish here: my own brats are just as vile.)

"I do think this is a splendid dustbin!" Aunt suddenly recovers the conversational initiative. Yes, let's discuss dustbins - anything rather than the menopause. She lifts the lid and smiles benevolently at an empty packet of Wet Ones. This suggests such a rich vein of rectal misfortune that the aunt slams the lid down promptly and asks me urgently if I am sure I am quite well. Assure her that I am. Though secretly, of course, I am thinking how very much easier it was to live alone.

Some time later, it occurs to me that it was a mistake to say I was fine. Why, I am not fine. Moving house, living with teenagers, post-marital trauma, help the aged - I've done it all this winter. I need a break. In the past, the good aunt once paid for me to go to Barbados, where her niece Lesley lives with an elderly husband. And now I am even more broke and tired than I was then. But how can one drop such a monumental hint without seeming a complete and utter scrounger?

"When is Palm Sunday?" I enquire, innocently. "I've had palm trees on the brain ever since Charlie Dimmock did that garden for Nelson Mandela."

"I don't know what all the fuss is about that girrrl's bosom," ponders the aunt, picking up the wrong trail entirely. "And, frrrankly, herrr hairrr looks awful. I wouldn't like herrr serrrving me soup."

"I wouldn't mind her planting a few palm trees, though," I persist doggedly. "They've always cheered me up ever since that lovely time I had in Barbados with Lesley." The aunt falls silent. Is she contemplating a generous gesture? I sigh, and attempt to arrange myself in a piteous tableau suggesting a brave struggle against rectal misfortune.

"I'd like to go to Barrrbados myself, one day," confesses the aunt, "but my intestines just arrren't up to long-haul trrravel ."

Let me go for you, then auntie, I silently implore. My intestines are possibly worse even than hers and may rear up like a knot of South American rattlesnakes in a courtship dance at the first sign of a BA in-flight meal tray, but I'm prepared to endure all this in order to convey Aunt Elspeth's best wishes to the fair Lesley. The aunt, however, seems oblivious to my psychic messages, and goes to have a lie down. Harriet and Henry return from the unequal struggle with education, ex-Spouse emerges from his cave exactly as described in Men Are From Mars, and we all settle down to bicker over what to watch on TV.

Halfway through EastEnders, aunt bursts in waving a cheque, and cries, "I've been thinking, dearrr. You look so tirrred , and Gorrrdon's so low, I'm surrre you could do with a brrreak. What you said about palm trees made me think... so I'd like to send you all off on a weekend to Centerrrparrrcs !"

The sight of ex-Spouse trying to look grateful is such a tonic that I feel better already.

fields.headline: Charlie Higson
fields.standfirst: Charlie Higson, 41, is the son of a management consultant and a teacher. While studying at the University of East Anglia, he met Paul Whitehouse and Harry Enfield. He later made his name as a novelist and, more notably, as a scriptwriter for Enfield in the mid-80s. Today, he writes, produces and stars in BBC2's The Fast Show with Whitehouse. He is married with three children, and lives in London.
fields.trailText: Writer and producer of BBC2's Fast Show.
fields.body:
What is your idea of perfect happiness?
Checking in to an expensive hotel with my wife and getting a good night's sleep - among other things.

What is your greatest fear?
That the wind will change direction and I'll be stuck with this expression.

Which living person do you most admire?
No one really - they're all tossers.

What has been your most embarrassing moment?
Pretending to be French in a Bournemouth cafe for a laugh and nearly being killed by a bunch of drunken xenophobes.

What makes you depressed?
The amount of stupid people there are in the world - and TV advertising.

What do you most dislike about your appearance?
I try not to look these days.

What is your most unappealing habit?
Silence.

What is your favourite smell?
Pouring white wine on to frying garlic.

What is your favourite word?
Arse.

Should the Royal Family be scrapped?
I really couldn't care either way.

Do you believe in capital punishment?
It is an entirely witless concept.

Do you believe in monogamy?
Absolutely, but it takes work.

What do you consider the most overrated virtue
Niceness.

Have you ever said 'I love you' and not meant it?
Once, a long time ago, to stop a girl from stabbing me with a pair of scissors.

How do you relax?
Computer games, painting toy soldiers for my boys.

What single thing would improve the quality of your life?
More time.

What keeps you awake at night?
The children.

How would you like to die?
Are you threatening to kill me?

Do you believe in life after death?
Of course not.

How would you like to be remembered?
As a good father.

What is the most important lesson life has taught you?
Don't tie yourself down too young to a career, to a relationship or to a place.

fields.headline: How to... get dressed
fields.trailText: Guy Browning
fields.body:
The worst possible time to make a complex decision, such as choosing what to wear, is first thing in the morning. However, that's exactly when most people do it.

For women, this is an especially tricky moment. Smart or casual is the first big choice (smart-casual is a male thing, you see). No one really minds if you wear jeans in a meeting, as long as you don't expect to be taken seriously.

Then there's your mood: if you're feeling super-perky, you can wear that bright orange top and combat pants; if you're feeling like a grumpy old bag, then it's the black skirt and boring top; and on those rare days where you feel like Cruella Sexpants, you can wear your bright red suit with integral Wonderbra. Just make sure you don't change from one mood to another during the day.

Avoid colourful patterns in the morning, as trying to accessorise will take forever. (If a woman's wardrobe looks like a curtain shop, you can guarantee that she doesn't start work early.) You also need to think about the weather, and cross reference it with your office air-conditioning. There's no point going out in your woolly leggings if your office has the ambient temperature of Costa Rica. And don't bother looking for anything that's dry-clean only: those items live permanently at the bottom of your laundry basket.

There's also that one day in every week when you fling open your 70m drive-in wardrobe and decide that you have nothing to wear. One option is to wear the new outfit you liked enough not to take back but not quite enough to wear; you'll feel a bit of dork all day, but at least it's better than the second option, which is wearing the outfit that's curled up on the floor after a weekend of continual use.

A good tip it is to start with your shoes and work your way up. Go for black sensible shoes to be safe, because if you start with green platforms you're going to get in big trouble the further up you go.

Finally, give a thought to your colleagues. If you're going to be in a meeting with the 9ft blonde bimbo from hell, you need to make an effort to keep your self respect intact. (Then again, if you are a 9ft blonde bimbo, you know you can wear a bin-liner and still lead men to their doom.)

And how do men decide what to wear in the morning? Well, when they wake up, anything that they can't smell from the bed will do just fine.

fields.headline: Dear weekend
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Weekend, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER.
Email: weekend@guardian.co.uk.
Fax: 020-7239 9935. Letters should reach us by Tuesday afternoon for inclusion on Saturday, and may be edited.
fields.trailText: Your mail
fields.body:
How reassuring it was to read about the real Saddam Hussein (Father Of All Despots, January 22). If you have been nice to him, he won't forget it - and if he does and has you executed, he will be nice to your family afterwards. He is also well known for being nice to his mother and sons. Okay, so he's killed a few thousand of his countrymen and has a liking for shoes, but at least part of this can be explained by the fact that he was picked on at school. I am sure he would get a warm welcome if he visited London.
T Desmond
Nottingham

Simon Fanshawe is mistaken (Sam Smiles, January 22): Hitchcock did not refer to red herrings as 'McGuffins'. The term was used to describe the whole device around which a film was hinged.
Andy Taylor
London N4

You can criticise Asians, you know (Home, January 22). To describe as 'tradition' a wife eating her meal on the floor while her husband sits at the table is going too far in political correctness. This is the status that Asian women traditionally have in their societies, the wife believing she is worth so little that she is grateful for even being allowed to eat with the husband. Calling it 'tradition' does not excuse the underlying currents about inequality.

That's not to say all Asian families are like that - today's generation of women would not have it - but it exists. While glamorising Asians' love of food and big family meals, we mustn't forget this.
Sorab Shroff
London N17

Thank you for Fat's Life (January 22) - when will our doctors come to the realisation that most of our diseases are diet-related?
Allene Agor
London SE13

Fat's Life was a valuable insight into the connection between consumption of fats and modern diseases such as cancer. However, while arguing that our over-consumption of meat and dairy products is largely responsible for the increase in these illnesses, no mention was made of the vegan diet, which, in avoiding all animal products, is widely acknowledged to be beneficial to health.
Alex Forrest
Sutton, Surrey

Charlotte Abrahams says that a buffalo-hide basket might give vegetarians the creeps (Style Slave, January 22). Good job, too! It's time for the omnivore backlash: you invite a vegetarian to dinner, and good manners dictate that you serve them no meat. When they reciprocate, do they offer you meat to respect your preferences? Do they hell! Sit down. Deep breaths. Calm... calm... calm.
Don Jones
Devizes, Wiltshire

The suggestion that we buy two toothbrushes - one for show, the other to clean our teeth - gave me the biggest laugh of the weekend (The Best, January 22). It would be time for a new circle of friends if my present ones began popping into the bathroom to examine my non 'aesthetically-pleasing' brush. Thank you for reminding me that, contrary to my worst fears, I am normal.
Helen Cliff
Leeds

While one can be sympathetic towards Julie Burchill's recent loss of her mother (January 22), writing an article about it in a national newspaper hardly represents English 'repressing' behaviour.
S Parker
London

fields.headline: Morning glory: grapefruit
fields.trailText: The subject
fields.body:
The subject

The second most popular citrus fruit, and the most charmingly named by a long shot.

The basics

Grapefruits are poetically, I mean botanically, called Citrus paradisii . Unlike most citrus, they originated not in Asia but in the Caribbean, from a cross between the pomelo ( C. grandis ) and an ordinary old orange. Pomelos are also called Shaddocks, after the English captain who first took them to Barbados in the 18th century, but shaddock doesn't quite have the same ring to it. The name grapefruit derives from the fruit's tendency to grow in clusters, apparently.

The details

Currently available varieties of grapefruit include Marsh Seedless, Ruby Red, Star Red, Sunrise, Sweetie, etc. The principal distinction, if you want an easy life, is between white and ruby (usually called pink). Pinkies contain around 10% more carbohydrate than white, so they are sweeter. The white guys pack less acidic bite if eaten with honey or sugar. Breakfast with a kick: sprinkle a halved grapefruit with sugar and flash under a grill. Sybaritic breakfast: peel each segment individually and pop it in your mouth. Historical note: ruby grapefruit first occurred, as a natural mutation, on a farm in Texas in 1929. Medical note: certain drugs are absorbed more efficiently if you take them with grapefruit juice; your GP should warn you if there's a problem. Cook's thoughts: jellied terrines, mixed salads, and composed salads with chicken and bacon. Shopper's guide: buy fruit that's at least 12.5cm in diameter, heavy for its size, and with smooth, firm, shiny skin.

The easy way out

Grapefruit juice, which accounts for a large percentage of world production: all the flavour with none of the hassle. Freshly-squeezed is ferociously expensive. Frozen concentrate is of high quality and cheaper. Tinned segments = nursery food.

Where to buy

Any place where there's fresh fruit and veg in evidence.

fields.headline: Superplonk
fields.trailText: Red, red wine.
fields.body:
Freud had something sexual to say about the colour red, but we can safely ignore it on the grounds that he said much the same thing about everything else. More pertinent, I feel, is Churchill's observation that he had taken more out of alcohol than alcohol had taken out of him, which is much more encouraging, since this week's column is devoted to wines that can all claim to have a measure of redness, a degree of sensuality, and varying levels of health-giving antioxidants (aka tannins).

Shall we start with Marks & Spencer? The poor blighters need a bit of sunshine in their lives, as they seem to spend all their time these days obsessed with bras and knickers, but the answer lies on their very own shelves in the shape of Casa Leona Merlot La Rosa 1999 (16 points, out of 20, £4.49), from Chile, which slips down with satin-textured richness and style. It offers soft, rich fruit, a hint of strawberry to the resident blackberries, and warm yet soft tannins.

At Morrisons, whose eponym Ken became Sir Ken in the New Year's honours (which suggests, to this observer at least, that if M&S wants to lift itself from its present doldrums, it could do no better than to invite the feisty knight to become its chairman, or even to buy the company), there are two happy reds, both reported on before in this column but now the subject of absurdly generous price cuts. They are the non-vintage Bouches du Rhone Merlot (15 points, £2.99, or two for a fiver until February 6) and the Chilean Antares Merlot 1998 (16 points, £2.95 also until February 6). The Rhone has suffusing warmth of texture, savoury fruit and rich, chewy tannins. The Chilean has a touch of spice to the leather, but it's the grip of the wine, the sheer effrontery, the chutzpah of it - attached, as it is, to such a risibly low price tag - that makes it so brilliant.

At Fullers, the southern wine shops, there is the absolutely fantastically shaped, savourily assertive, meltingly tannic and tenacious syrah from Argentina called Trivento Syrah 1998. It rates 16.5 points and costs £3.99. Fullers has another Argentine, Norton Cabernet Sauvignon 1997, which exhibits an undertone of tobacco, a touch of chocolate, and a hint of cassis. This is enough excitement for any glass, and it rates 16.5 points and costs £4.99.

But what can you get at Fullers if you are prepared to spend a lot more? Well, for £14.99, you can buy Baileys 1904 Block Shiraz 1994 (16 points), from Australia, which is creamy, spicy, rich, gently earthy, hugely lingering and subtly lush. While it does not quite reach the outer limits of the possibilities of the grape, it might well do so given a few years' inactivity in a cold, dark hole (the 1993, which I tasted recently, rates two points higher)

At Majestic, there is Rosso Conero Conti Cortesi 1997 (16 points, £5.49), from Italy, which, though jammy and on the ripe side, has some gloriously meaty tannins to buttress the structure and give it heft. It is an admirable food wine.

Safeway offers Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile, which has superbly classy tannins allied to ruffled, corduroy-textured dark chocolate, subtle cassis and, yes, that suggestion of tobacco again. Safeway also has Chapel Hill Barrique Aged Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (16 points, £4.99), from the shores of Hungary's (and Europe's) largest lake, but there is nothing watery about the dry and comfortingly rich fruit.

Waitrose, not about to be outdone by anyone, has Ermitage du Pic Cuvée Classique Cteaux du Languedoc 1998 (16 points, £4.99), a somewhat intimidating assembly of syllables totally justified by the fruit in the bottle, which is aromatic, ripe, deep, balanced and hugely food-friendly, with a surge of energy on the finish. There is nothing hirsute about its young and well-softened tannins. Also at this retailer is a so-called Limited Edition Millennium Magnum of Special Reserve Claret Ctes de Castillon 1996, which, at £9.95 (for 1.5 litres), is a splendid bargain. This one's a real winter wine that wears a thick coat of richly-wrought tannins and rates 16 points.

They are the non-vintage Bouches du Rhone Merlot (15 points, £2.99, or two for a fiver until February 6) and the Chilean Antares Merlot 1998 (16 points, £2.95 also until February 6). The Rhone has suffusing warmth of texture, savoury fruit and rich, chewy tannins. The Chilean has a touch of spice to the leather, but it's the grip of the wine, the sheer effrontery, the chutzpah of it - attached, as it is, to such a risibly low price tag - that makes it so brilliant. At Fullers, the southern wine shops, there is the absolutely fantastically shaped, savourily assertive, meltingly tannic and tenacious syrah from Argentina called Trivento Syrah 1998. It rates 16.5 points and costs £3.99. Fullers has another Argentine, Norton Cabernet Sauvignon 1997, which exhibits an undertone of tobacco, a touch of chocolate, and a hint of cassis. This is enough excitement for any glass, and it rates 16.5 points and costs £4.99. But what can you get at Fullers if you are prepared to spend a lot more? Well, for £14.99, you can buy Baileys 1904 Block Shiraz 1994 (16 points), from Australia, which is creamy, spicy, rich, gently earthy, hugely lingering and subtly lush. While it does not quite reach the outer limits of the possibilities of the grape, it might well do so given a few years' inactivity in a cold, dark hole (the 1993, which I tasted recently, rates two points higher) At Majestic, there is Rosso Conero Conti Cortesi 1997 (16 points, £5.49), from Italy, which, though jammy and on the ripe side, has some gloriously meaty tannins to buttress the structure and give it heft. It is an admirable food wine. Safeway offers Concha y Toro Casillero del Diablo Cabernet Sauvignon 1998 (16.5 points, £4.99), from Chile, which has superbly classy tannins allied to ruffled, corduroy-textured dark chocolate, subtle cassis and, yes, that suggestion of tobacco again. Safeway also has Chapel Hill Barrique Aged Cabernet Sauvignon 1997 (16 points, £4.99), from the shores of Hungary's (and Europe's) largest lake, but there is nothing watery about the dry and comfortingly rich fruit. Waitrose, not about to be outdone by anyone, has Ermitage du Pic Cuvée Classique Cteaux du Languedoc 1998 (16 points, £4.99), a somewhat intimidating assembly of syllables totally justified by the fruit in the bottle, which is aromatic, ripe, deep, balanced and hugely food-friendly, with a surge of energy on the finish. There is nothing hirsute about its young and well-softened tannins. Also at this retailer is a so-called Limited Edition Millennium Magnum of Special Reserve Claret Ctes de Castillon 1996, which, at £9.95 (for 1.5 litres), is a splendid bargain. This one's a real winter wine that wears a thick coat of richly-wrought tannins and rates 16 points.

fields.headline: Lions in winter
fields.standfirst: What with winter sweet, forsythia and iris, midwinter should never be bleak, says Christopher Lloyd. And if it's too cold to appreciate them outside, cut them for the home.
fields.trailText: What with winter sweet, forsythia and iris, midwinter should never be bleak, says Christopher Lloyd. And if it's too cold to appreciate them outside, cut them for the home.
fields.body:
Most of the plants that flower in winter will do so far more freely if the preceding summer was long and hot. By the same token, those who live in London will get the clean end of the stick; those in the north and west the dirty end. Even in shade, a London garden is a lot warmer than sunshine in, say, Derbyshire.

Winter sweet, Chimonanthus praecox, is just about the most rewarding winter shrub imaginable, if you can make a go of it. Its spicy fragrance has been the highlight of my garden since late November, but its wood must be well ripened if it is to make flower buds. Radiant heat - from, say, a south-facing brick wall behind it - will provide ideal conditions, but if your garden is reasonably warm anyway, then an open position may produce decent results once the plant is sufficiently mature to settle down to the business of flowering.

The easiest way for the nurseryman to raise and offer winter sweet is as a seedling, but the juvenile condition of seedlings may last for six or seven years before there's a flower in sight. If you can secure a grafted plant of a named cultivar, propagated from an adult plant, juvenility will have been bypassed and it should flower quite quickly. 'Grandiflorus' and var.luteus are two such, both with the Award of Garden Merit. The latter has brighter yellow flowers than the rather dingily-coloured type-plant.

Like many winter-flowering plants, winter sweet is an exceedingly dull bit of goods in summer, so don't make the mistake of placing it in a prominent position, if you can at all help it. Much better to cut branches from it at the key moment and enjoy it indoors in comfort.

The same applies to the winter bush honeysuckle, Lonicera x purpusii, of which 'Winter Beauty' is allegedly the best clone. It will flower well in any open site and, given exposure, it will lose the last of its unsavoury leaves to autumn gales before its flowering gets into its stride. The heavily fragrant white flowers are remarkably frost-resistant. The shrub can grow huge, with masses of tired wood inside it. Far best, then, to thin this out every March. Young foliage will already be well developed by then, but don't let that worry you. Do your thinning before the foliage becomes too abundant to see what needs removing.

The flowers of early rhododendrons are woefully susceptible to frost, but that doesn't stop me - or anyone else, for that matter - from growing them. The rich mauve, almost deciduous Rhododendron dauricum 'Midwinter' (AGM) opened its first buds with me on January 2. Always pick liberally for the house as soon as the buds colour. In this coming month there'll be a clear, pink-flowered hybrid, 'Seta', to cheer us, and that is ideal for picking. It makes quite a modest-sized shrub - but is of no interest in summer. No matter; that is not to be resented.

From now on, forsythias will have received a sufficient winter chilling for us to be able to force their buds gently into flower indoors. (If picked prematurely, they won't oblige.) So, prune your forsythia now and benefit from the prunings inside. Again, it should be a question of opening the shrub up by thinning out old branches in their entirety, rather than making a hideous lump of it by clipping it over.

In a hot London garden, you can get away with pruning an entire forsythia down almost to the ground after flowering. The young shoots thereafter, made during the summer, will ripen enough to flower the next winter. Under cooler conditions, however, they will be too soft and sappy to flower and will need another year in which to ripen. In the far north, forsythias really need to be grown as warm wall shrubs if they are to flower decently. Never mind, you Scots - there are many good plants that are far happier under your conditions than down south.

The Algerian Iris unguicularis is a great favourite for winter flowering and for picking buds to open in the house (where they'll last for two or three days) during any mild spell from November to March. Their typically mauve petals have a sheen on them and seem far too fragile to be flowering at such a rough time of year. The plants, which need a nice hot position, are incredibly untidy and I am frequently asked what can be done about this without detriment to the next year's crop of blooms. There's really no straight answer. You can halve the foliage in spring, but I think that looks pretty awful, too. You can thin out the dead foliage leaving the rest intact, but that is quite a prolonged and tedious operation. More and more, I incline to doing nothing and to putting up with the mess in some discreet corner of the garden where it doesn't matter.

A good reason for this inaction is that, if the flowerbuds have to push their way through a lot of debris to reach the light, their stalks are much longer and better for picking than they otherwise would be. When you pick, snap the stalk as low as you can, but do not pull. The buds are made in pairs and open in succession. If you pull, the second, immature bud will break off with the first, and you'll have lost it.

I.unguicularis is easily raised from seed, which ripens near ground level (you have to look for it) in early summer. There are many strains of it around, some named, some not. 'Mary Barnard' is a rich, deep shade, and usually comes on in the New Year. 'Walter Butt' is one of the earliest, very pale and a little bit scented. The white variety is skinny and disappointing

fields.headline: Beautiful south
fields.standfirst: Buying from developing countries is not only great for the conscience, says Charlotte Abrahams, it's also good for the home.
fields.trailText: Buying from developing countries is not only great for the conscience, says Charlotte Abrahams, it's also good for the home.
fields.body:
Shopping. It's a national hobby, and even those of us who claim to hate it still thrill to the idea of having something new. How else can you explain that, only days after the Christmas shopping fest, we are back on the streets, queuing and fighting to get our hands on some discounted consumer durables?

But do many of us think beyond how our new purchase will improve our own lives? Or wonder where the products we are buying came from, and what it means to the people who produced them? Well, quite a lot of us - at least in theory. Back in 1997, a Cafod/Mori poll showed that 92% of British consumers agreed that British companies should insist on a minimum standard of labour conditions for their third-world suppliers. And, today, there are signs of a determination to foster responsible trade links between the wealthy, consuming north and the poorer producing south.

Of course, the idea of using trade to relieve poverty is practically as old as mankind - and, even in its modern form, is pretty well established. Carol Wills, who belongs to a body representing the worldwide alternative-trade movement, says that "the biggest fair traders appeared in the 10-year period between 1965 and 1975, and they were set up partly in response to natural and environmental disasters and partly in response to poverty".

In those days, fair trade was heavily linked to charity: guilt was at the core of any sales pitch. But today, tags such as "this product is made by destitute women in Bangladesh", which might once have nudged the conscience and opened the wallets of potential customers, is now considered demeaning to the producers. And the fair-traders themselves have also learned that tugging the heartstrings of northern consumers does not guarantee strong sales.

So today, charity is largely reserved for disaster relief, while trade, both fair and ethical (and there is a difference: fair trade is about empowering impoverished people, while ethical trade is trade with an ethical dimension) is conducted with high-quality goods and on proper business terms.

Elisabeth Faure, chief executive of Eastern Vision, an ethical trading mail-order company that deals in Indian textiles and furniture, is clear about her objectives: "My aim is to create a successful business, then I can develop the ethical side further. Ethics and commerce are compatible." Her business works, she says, because she sells the kind of goods that appeal to western urban sophisticates. "Eastern Vision is an opportunity for artisans in India to become more aware of modern lifestyles in the west, and to assimilate changes in their work, so their traditional skills and techniques may survive and flourish in the future."

In practice, this will often mean taking designs to the Eastern Vision tailoring-and-embroidery unit; Faure sometimes goes to the market herself to buy the thread for the company's Wheel design curtains.

Other fair traders have also found that traditional designs sometimes need some alteration if they are to sell well over here. "I travel at least twice a year for my collection," says Natasha Rahman of the Muslin Trading Company, "and, as I work in a western market with eastern taste, I try to provide artisans of the Indian sub-continent with an insight into western lifestyle."

It is the same at Buy-Afrika, a South African project started by Liberty Life, one of South Africa's biggest insurance companies. Its purpose, to quote the blurb, is "to develop, package and market a spectrum of goods that combine the authentic and indigenous with international appeal". This means retraining some of the artisans.

While this may appear to be testing the boundaries of exploitation, these companies argue that they are not trying to replace traditional work but are putting traditional skills to modern use, thereby ensuring that the skills survive and everyone makes some money. (Other companies, says Faure, are not so scrupulous: she tells of one group of Indian mask-makers who were asked to stop producing traditional ceremonial masks and start making ones of Mickey Mouse instead.)

But making money is, in the end, what it's all about. Buy-Afrika was set up to help its participating crafters make a profit. Through free entry on to the Buy-Afrika website, manufacturers who do not have the resources to promote their products can reach international markets. At the moment, potential buyers contact sellers direct and negotiate their own terms, but from next month it will be possible to buy products online.

And, while they are both commercial businesses, Eastern Vision and the Muslin Trading Company work very closely with non-governmental organisations (NGOs) - although, Elisabeth Faure admits, this can often slow down production. Customers at the Muslin Trading Company shop, in London's Denmark Hill, enter and find an Aladdin's cave of gorgeous Indian textiles; it's all there thanks to the determination of Natasha Rahman, and her mother/business partner, Farzana, to help women achieve economic independence.

But while Faure might be less feminist in her approach, she is equally committed to helping people achieve independence and self-respect through economic strength. To this end, Eastern Vison has its own small workshops. The Calcutta unit is made up of 15 women, most of whom were abandoned by their husbands, and who, without this source of income, could easily have been forced into prostitution. There is also a team of carpenters in Andra Pradesh.

It's all a long way from money-raising jumble sales. These are products made with pride and sold with integrity, and we buy them not because our conscience is pricked by the sight of a starving family, but because they are well made and they look good. Shop till you drop, by all means, just try and do it responsibly, fairly and ethically

Eastern Vision, 020-7580 5955. Muslin Trading Company, 020-7701 6002. Buy-Afrika, 020-8340 6277, www.buy-afrika.com

webTitle: It's rich, it's smart and it comes at a price

fields.headline: It's rich, it's smart and it comes at a price
fields.standfirst:
Matthew Fort visits Homewood Park
14/20
Telephone: 01225 723 731
Address: Hinton Charterhouse, Somerset
Open: All week, lunch, 12 noon - 2pm; dinner 7-9.30pm
Price: Set lunch, £19.50 and £22.50 All major cards, except American Express. Wheelchair access (no WC).
fields.trailText: Matthew Fort visits Homewood Park
fields.body:
As I sat in the library at Homewood Park, I was reminded of Osbert Sitwell's novel Laughter In The Next Room, because there was plenty of it. Laughter, that is - guffaws, giggles, tinkling trills, brays and basso profondo oompahpahs, and all the other sounds of a party under full sail. Although, to be accurate, it came from the room the other side of the entrance hall.

I was waiting for Jack and Cecily, who were doing a spot of Bumbrying, and had agreed to meet me at Homewood Park for dinner. Over the years, I'd been bombarded with regular bulletins as to the progress of its kitchen, and as to its one-Michelin-star status, achieved under the guidance of the present incumbent, Andrew Hamer. In the end, my nerve cracked and I thought I'd better see what was going on.

I can't give you a detailed picture of the physiognomy of the place, having arrived after dark - as far as I could make out, the park was there all right, and the outlines of the house were handsome, but not grand. The welcome was pleasant and warm, and the interior done for bright good cheer. It all seemed pleasant enough without being exactly memorable. That goes for the dining room, too: it had the kind of decor that wasn't going to distract anyone from the business at hand.

To judge by the menu, and its prices, that business was going to be quite serious. Was it to be pan-fried foie gras with shallot confit, pancetta and potato galette (£14.50), followed by roast breast of Trelough duck with Anna potato, celeriac mousse and apple-and-ginger-scented sauce (£25)? Or pan-fried scallops with crispy vegetables and shellfish-infused oil (£13.50), and then medallion of beef fillet with roast salsify, wild-mushroom sabayon and red-wine sauce flavoured with fresh truffles (£25)? There was also ravioli of spinach and Parmesan with leeks, wild mushrooms and rosemary- scented juices (£12.50), and roast chump of West Country lamb with kidney, parsley and winter vegetables (£24). You can see from the menu rubric, and the cost, that Homewood Park does not lack for ambition.

In the end, Cecily settled for the foie gras, then pan-fried fillets of sea bass and scallops with aubergine, tomato and fennel (£25); Jack for scallops and crispy veg, then lamb; and I for warm salad of mallard and celeriac, grain mustard and lentils flavoured with Sauvignon vinegar (£13.50), followed by the beef. To drink, we began with a bottle of soft, honeyed Gewürztraminer, which we started by the fire in the library, and then a bottle of Monthélie 1996 from the oddly perfunctory wine list that, nevertheless, had one or two goodies sorted away in its pages.

I'll say one thing about Hamer's cooking: he doesn't stint on the bits and bobs on the plate. There's loads to look at and to eat. Take my mallard. Dead centre was a little wigwam of duck breast resting on a heap of celeriac remoulade. All around were splodges of lentils and splashes of sauce - all very Jackson Pollock - and little cubes of apple and, I think, more celeriac. It all tasted rather good: nice duck, lustrous and not too rank; decently mustardy remoulade; grainy lentils; fine, salty reduction sauce. Yes, all in all it added up rather satisfactorily.

Not as satisfactorily, we all agreed after she had handed out generous sub-portions, as Cecily's foie gras, which was a star dish, rich, melting, sexy, seductive - the works. Jack reeled at the scale of his scallops and veg, but on closer inspection the scallops were on the button mushroom size and rather oversalted, he thought. He had no such reservations about the lamb, which came in a tower, slices perched precariously on top of one another, like the model of some medieval defensive outpost, and surrounded by vegetable out-buildings. In fact, each of our dishes came in a similar arrangement.

In the end, our table looked like San Gimignano delle Belle Torre. But the tastes were there. My beef was a fine piece of meat, all coddled up with sauces of varying degrees of richness: a creamy mushroom sabayon and a rounded, fruity red-wine sauce, which rather put paid to any subtleties on the part of the truffle. And there were loads of turned vegetables to provide fibre and other healthy matters. Cecily's sea bass was an altogether lighter affair, with fine, piercing flavours and very good, crisp fish. Jack's lamb was more in the style of mine, a similarly hearty bolster against the winter chills.

Cecily and Jack were blowing a bit by this time, and could manage only a plate of cheese between them. However, I was in training, and decided that I could manage a warm plum and frangipane tart with apricot ice cream, which I did very well, and enjoyed very much, as it was light and clean-flavoured, and carried that vaguely exotic perfume of ground almond. The cheese plate was something of a disappointment - four smallish slices of indifferent cheeses in indifferent states and heavily camouflaged by plate furniture. As Jack said, how much nicer one decent piece of well-kept cheese would have been.

Cheese apart, this was industrious, sound, Michelin-class food, with industrious, sound flavours, which industriously delivered sound satisfaction all round. But at a price - the price being £215, including the two bottles of wine (at £32 and £38, respectively), water (£5.50), and coffee and choccies (£8), which left the food tiptoeing in at £131.50, or a shade over £40 a head, which is quite heavy-hitting. But then, Homewood Park is aiming to be quite a heavy-hitting kind of place.

As we lingered over coffee, the party of laughers, who had been dining in another room, passed by the door. Of course, it turned out that we knew one of the party well and we greeted each other with delight. It turned out that she had buried her father that day, and they decided to have a splendid dinner by way of affectionate celebration. I hope my friends and relatives do the same when I pop my clogs.

Over the years, I'd been bombarded with regular bulletins as to the progress of its kitchen, and as to its one-Michelin-star status, achieved under the guidance of the present incumbent, Andrew Hamer. In the end, my nerve cracked and I thought I'd better see what was going on. I can't give you a detailed picture of the physiognomy of the place, having arrived after dark - as far as I could make out, the park was there all right, and the outlines of the house were handsome, but not grand. The welcome was pleasant and warm, and the interior done for bright good cheer. It all seemed pleasant enough without being exactly memorable. That goes for the dining room, too: it had the kind of decor that wasn't going to distract anyone from the business at hand. To judge by the menu, and its prices, that business was going to be quite serious. Was it to be pan-fried foie gras with shallot confit, pancetta and potato galette (£14.50), followed by roast breast of Trelough duck with Anna potato, celeriac mousse and apple-and-ginger-scented sauce (£25)? Or pan-fried scallops with crispy vegetables and shellfish-infused oil (£13.50), and then medallion of beef fillet with roast salsify, wild-mushroom sabayon and red-wine sauce flavoured with fresh truffles (£25)? There was also ravioli of spinach and Parmesan with leeks, wild mushrooms and rosemary- scented juices (£12.50), and roast chump of West Country lamb with kidney, parsley and winter vegetables (£24). You can see from the menu rubric, and the cost, that Homewood Park does not lack for ambition. In the end, Cecily settled for the foie gras, then pan-fried fillets of sea bass and scallops with aubergine, tomato and fennel (£25); Jack for scallops and crispy veg, then lamb; and I for warm salad of mallard and celeriac, grain mustard and lentils flavoured with Sauvignon vinegar (£13.50), followed by the beef. To drink, we began with a bottle of soft, honeyed Gewürztraminer, which we started by the fire in the library, and then a bottle of Monthélie 1996 from the oddly perfunctory wine list that, nevertheless, had one or two goodies sorted away in its pages. I'll say one thing about Hamer's cooking: he doesn't stint on the bits and bobs on the plate. There's loads to look at and to eat. Take my mallard. Dead centre was a little wigwam of duck breast resting on a heap of celeriac remoulade. All around were splodges of lentils and splashes of sauce - all very Jackson Pollock - and little cubes of apple and, I think, more celeriac. It all tasted rather good: nice duck, lustrous and not too rank; decently mustardy remoulade; grainy lentils; fine, salty reduction sauce. Yes, all in all it added up rather satisfactorily. Not as satisfactorily, we all agreed after she had handed out generous sub-portions, as Cecily's foie gras, which was a star dish, rich, melting, sexy, seductive - the works. Jack reeled at the scale of his scallops and veg, but on closer inspection the scallops were on the button mushroom size and rather oversalted, he thought. He had no such reservations about the lamb, which came in a tower, slices perched precariously on top of one another, like the model of some medieval defensive outpost, and surrounded by vegetable out-buildings. In fact, each of our dishes came in a similar arrangement. In the end, our table looked like San Gimignano delle Belle Torre. But the tastes were there. My beef was a fine piece of meat, all coddled up with sauces of varying degrees of richness: a creamy mushroom sabayon and a rounded, fruity red-wine sauce, which rather put paid to any subtleties on the part of the truffle. And there were loads of turned vegetables to provide fibre and other healthy matters. Cecily's sea bass was an altogether lighter affair, with fine, piercing flavours and very good, crisp fish. Jack's lamb was more in the style of mine, a similarly hearty bolster against the winter chills. Cecily and Jack were blowing a bit by this time, and could manage only a plate of cheese between them. However, I was in training, and decided that I could manage a warm plum and frangipane tart with apricot ice cream, which I did very well, and enjoyed very much, as it was light and clean-flavoured, and carried that vaguely exotic perfume of ground almond. The cheese plate was something of a disappointment - four smallish slices of indifferent cheeses in indifferent states and heavily camouflaged by plate furniture. As Jack said, how much nicer one decent piece of well-kept cheese would have been. Cheese apart, this was industrious, sound, Michelin-class food, with industrious, sound flavours, which industriously delivered sound satisfaction all round. But at a price - the price being £215, including the two bottles of wine (at £32 and £38, respectively), water (£5.50), and coffee and choccies (£8), which left the food tiptoeing in at £131.50, or a shade over £40 a head, which is quite heavy-hitting. But then, Homewood Park is aiming to be quite a heavy-hitting kind of place. As we lingered over coffee, the party of laughers, who had been dining in another room, passed by the door. Of course, it turned out that we knew one of the party well and we greeted each other with delight. It turned out that she had buried her father that day, and they decided to have a splendid dinner by way of affectionate celebration. I hope my friends and relatives do the same when I pop my clogs.

webTitle: Black voters out in cold as state basks in primary glow

fields.headline: Black voters out in cold as state basks in primary glow
fields.standfirst:
Candidates face make or break time in New Hampshire.

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Candidates face make or break time in New Hampshire.
fields.byline: Michael Ellison in Manchester, New Hampshire
fields.body:
Jose Cepeda is a special case in the state that has chosen the president of the US in 10 out of the past 11 primaries.

It is not because Mr Cepeda has his own business, nor because he is a reformed character, who turned his back on Florida and the street gang culture 14 years ago. What makes Mr Cepeda unusual - in the rugged, check-shirted democracy of New Hampshire - is that he is black.

Only 3% of New Hampshire's population of 1.2m is black. To borrow an expression, the state is as white as an Osmond family Christmas television special in Salt Lake City.

New Hampshire takes great pride in its primary, which is the first in the country and a dry run for the presidential election 10 months later. Win here and you have a good chance of gathering the momentum to take you to the White House, like the previously almost unknown Jimmy Carter in 1976.

But Mr Cepeda has chosen to be counted out while a large proportion of the 750,000 registered voters make their choice on Tuesday. Instead, he will be in his barber's shop in Manchester, the biggest city in New Hampshire.

"I don't vote on that stuff, man," he said, taking it easy in his friend Selene Thompson's hairdresser's salon on a day when a snowstorm kept many of Manchester's 102,000 residents at home.

"This primary election has nothing to do with me, being a black man. Why do you think this state only just started acknowledging the Martin Luther King holiday? If you're a candidate and you come to New Hampshire and win, that's excellent for you. But when you look at the people who are voting in New Hampshire, no, I don't think it's good. They're what they call all-American white people."

Ms Thompson does not vote either. "All I'd be doing is voting for a white person to represent me from a white perspective of what a black person is," she said.

Just as Ms Thompson and Mr Cepeda are not representative of most New Hampshire voters, the state is not representative of the rest of the US.

For one thing, it is smaller than all but six of the 50 states; the average income is $29,022 (£17,700), the seventh-highest in the country; and its unemployment rate of 2.6% is the third-lowest in the US.

New Hampshire is partly defined by its role in the primary campaigns. One of the first things you see on arrival at Manchester airport is an exhibition devoted to previous presidents; walk a few more paces and there is more memorabilia.

It is to this New England state, also known for its mountains and beaches, that the men who would be president come to seduce voters in their homes, their school halls and their streets, simply because New Hampshire votes first.

Polls show that 20% of New Hampshire voters have met George W Bush, John McCain, Al Gore or Bill Bradley, or at least one of the other candidates.

They might as well enjoy the attention while they can, for there are those within both main parties who want to change a system they believe is undemocratic. The critics say that once New Hampshire legitimises the frontrunners, who are then likely to be endorsed five weeks later when 16 states including New York and California make their choice on the same day, the decision-making process is all but done.

"There is a very considerable number of states that feel they have no voice and frankly an awful lot of people feel they have no voice in the selection process," said William Brock, a former Republican senator and head of his party's advisory committee on the nomination process.

William Mayer, a political scientist at Northeastern university, Boston, said: "The problem is, the system will probably reach a conclusion at a very early stage and for everyone after that, they're not likely to see a lot of the candidates, the press is not likely to spend a lot of time covering the process and turnout will fall off the table."

But you need not leave New Hampshire to find people disaffected by the arrangement. Customers in the Wild Rover pub in Manchester appear to confirm survey findings that young people accustomed to a strong economy are much less likely than their parents to vote in the primary.

"I really should vote but I don't know if I will," said Jacob Warshaw, 24, who works in health insurance. Shannon Dube, also 24 and between jobs, is marginally more enthusiastic than her boyfriend: "I'm not real interested but I'm going to vote for [Republican challenger] John McCain. Our friends aren't interested, people are more concerned about their own lives.

"This is a very conservative state. Have you seen the movie Jungle Fever? I was watching it and my dad came down and I said: 'That guy just beat up his daughter for going out with a black man.' And he said: 'I'd do the same to you'."

The barber Jose Cepeda is not acquainted with Ms Dube's father, but he knows what she is talking about. "If I was voting for someone from my culture then maybe things would change," he said. "There's nothing around here structured for me.

"I go to church, I listen to soul-gospel. I go home, I listen to soul-gospel. I get into my car, I listen to soul-gospel. I get out of my car, I've got to conform to white America. I'm tired of being here. I'm going back to Florida."

webTitle: Spreading the net: First Tuesday, and then the world

fields.headline: Spreading the net: First Tuesday, and then the world
fields.standfirst: John Browning Optimistic internet pioneer
fields.trailText: On Tuesday, 600 people who want to be millionaires will meet for cocktails in London hoping to meet someone who will help them grow rich and have fun on the way. "Please don't print where," says John Browning. "I'm trying to avoid the first new media riot."
fields.body:
On Tuesday, 600 people who want to be millionaires will meet for cocktails in London hoping to meet someone who will help them grow rich and have fun on the way. "Please don't print where," says John Browning. "I'm trying to avoid the first new media riot."

The First Tuesday parties, where budding internet entrepreneurs meet potential backers, have spread to 15 European cities. Browning, an American who helps to run them, seems bewildered and amused by their success.

"When we started to get calls from overseas last year, asking whether they could copy our idea, I thought why are these people asking our permission to hold cocktail parties where they live?"

One reason is that the internet is meant to be the place where everyone can magically get rich without the tedious need to make a profit or even to sell anything much. Everyone who comes to these meetings is looking for a little of that magic.

"I was in Madrid two weeks ago. I didn't understand a word anyone was saying. But it was still recognisably First Tuesday. One of the things that this demonstrates is the irony of email. People said there would never be any more face-to-face meetings. What actually happens is far more. People travel more because they have a much wider acquaintance, and there is so much that can't communicate by email."

In the late 1980s Browning was working at the Economist, having come over here to do a second degree at Oxford. He knew Louis Rosetto and Jane Metcalfe, founders of Wired magazine; he helped and encouraged them, and still remembers fondly their claim, in the first issue, that the internet represented the greatest technological advance since the discovery of fire.

"At least they redefined hyperbole," he says. But he adds: "I've always believed it, though. I still believe it. The impact of technological change is the most interesting thing that's going to happen in my lifetime."

Wired, it is easy to forget, was founded before the world wide web existed. We talked about the days, nine years ago, when there were only 15 or 20 sites (or servers as they called themselves) on the whole of the web and you got at all of them by dialling into a site in Switzerland.

In five years Wired went from being a revolutionary secret through world domination to implosion into a lifestyle magazine. But in the frothing world of new media, Wired was the bubble before last. About the current bubble, which First Tuesday feeds, he is optimistic.

"Everything depends on how it pops. When you have something in short supply people rush to supply it and that's what is happening with internet shares now. Valuations start to ease and you end up with something that vaguely resembles normalcy."

I don't think he is desperately interested in the technology. It is the effect on human imaginations that he likes, and the way the same patterns recur through the ages in different settings. "I'm fascinated by the ways cultures and societies set themselves up. First Tuesday is like the medieval fairs. People meet, they do business; they hire each other and exchange information and ideas. When you make allowances for the speed of travel, what took place every quarter then should take place every week now."

Not all the parallels with the past are so cheering. At Berkeley, he did a thesis on the economics of vaudeville, the American music hall. What made it possible, he says, was one man realising that it could be a monopoly. If he owned the right theatre in New York, he could tell performers that they might appear there, but only on bills he chose; and then tell provincial theatres that they could book his performers, but he would choose which they got.

"He understood the link between content and conduit: he realised how to link what people wanted to see with the railway schedules. Now the conduit is not the railway but the internet; and that's why we've got AOL buying Time Warner."

Profiles by Andrew Brown
