webTitle: Stuck in the middle ages with you

fields.headline: Stuck in the middle ages with you
fields.standfirst: Andrew Prescott Medievalist who helped put Beowulf on disk
fields.trailText: Never mind the fuss about the latest translation of Beowulf: on Monday, Andrew Prescott will take delivery of the original, repackaged as two CD-roms to bring out the full glory of the Anglo-Saxon text.
fields.body:
Never mind the fuss about the latest translation of Beowulf: on Monday, Andrew Prescott will take delivery of the original, repackaged as two CD-roms to bring out the full glory of the Anglo-Saxon text.

He is currently working at Sheffield university, but he was a curator in the manuscript department of the British Museum in the 90s when it was first proposed to digitise the original manuscript of Beowulf. This was an enormous job, because it involved the manuscript and not just the text.

All our knowledge of the poem descends from one manuscript currently in the British Library, which was burnt in a fire in a manuscript collection in 1736; so to establish the best text involved photographing every single page in exotic lightings to bring out obscured or damaged characters.

Prescott was then, he says, the sort of historian who was in any case more interested in the confusions of the source material than the elegant reconstructions of narrative.

"I did research on medieval history, specialising in the Peasants' Revolt of 1381. There are an enormous number of records of this in the public records office, which could not easily be presented in a conventional edition. For instance, in 1381 they burnt down the Savoy palace. There are records of the criminal cases that followed. But there was also subsequently private litigation and you can follow that and see which lawyers were involved in both cases.

"It's very much easier with computers. You can present more of the stuff for use by others. You can search it more easily and find things quicker. Then you can present it in new configurations, especially in the case of public record material where the inter-relationship is extremely complex. I suppose it's a medieval historian's version of what the credit card companies do to us all now."

This interest of his is related to a wider resurgence of Anglo-Saxon studies on the internet which has led to some wonderfully useful things such as the construction of modern glossaries: we now know that if Beowulf had wanted to boot up his computer he would have called the process "inspinninggehweorfastyrian".

Prescott is distant from the more frivolous end of these studies. After his doctorate, he went to work straight away at the library. It is easier to learn the specialised skills of a museum on top of a background as a professional historian than the other way around. But then he became enchanted by the transformations that technology can bring to even the oldest facts and the additional knowledge that can be gained from a text simply by looking at it on a screen.

Because the original manuscript of Beowulf continued to deteriorate after the fire, each successive transcript of the poem was made by a scholar who could see less than his predecessors.

"If you are dealing with a literary text like this, and you have a series of 18th- and 19th-century transcripts, it's absolutely fantastic to compare what different scholars saw on screen."

It is degeneration of this sort, he says, that is responsible for the story of Alfred burning the cakes. The only manuscript life of Alfred was destroyed in the same fire as damaged Beowulf. What remained were copies made earlier; and it is possible to see how one of the copyists inserted the story of the cakes simply because it was interesting.

Prescott was part of the team that moved the manuscript collection to its new home in the British Library. "Eight vans a day for six months: we must have seen close to a million items on to the shelves. They covered 7km of shelving end to end."

How much would that take up as a tower of CD-roms? The answer, he says, is that it would be quite impossible. To preserve the kind of detail an illuminated manuscript deserves, the pictures have to be so detailed that you could only fit four pages on a CD. It is wonderful to realise that the skin from a sheep's stomach - for that is what vellum is made from - remains a better medium of information storage than anything we can manage with lasers.

webTitle: Woman may have new variant CJD

fields.headline: Woman may have new variant CJD
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: A woman with a three-month old baby was last night seriously ill in hospital with a suspected case of new variant Creutzfeldt Jakob disease, the human form of BSE.
fields.body:
A woman with a three-month old baby was last night seriously ill in hospital with a suspected case of new variant Creutzfeldt Jakob disease, the human form of BSE.

The 24-year-old woman was in Walsgrave hospital, Coventry, where she has been seen by specialists from the CJD surveillance unit based in Edinburgh, who fear she may have the brain disease. Her baby daughter is also ill, but is not believed to have contracted new variant CJD.

Hospital chief executive David Loughton said of the woman's condition: "We are awaiting confirmation of a diagnosis that she has new variant CJD. There is no danger to any other patients."

The woman will be taken to St Mary's hospital in Paddington, west London, for tests next week, but her baby will not undergo further examination for the brain disease, which is believed to have an incubation period of at least four years.

Mr Loughton added: "The baby is ill but there is no suspicion of the child having CJD."

Graham Medley, of Warwick university's biological sciences department, said: "There is evidence of maternal transmission of this disease in cattle, but the situation with humans is unknown."

Her baby daughter is also ill, but is not believed to have contracted new variant CJD. Hospital chief executive David Loughton said of the woman's condition: "We are awaiting confirmation of a diagnosis that she has new variant CJD. There is no danger to any other patients." The woman will be taken to St Mary's hospital in Paddington, west London, for tests next week, but her baby will not undergo further examination for the brain disease, which is believed to have an incubation period of at least four years. Mr Loughton added: "The baby is ill but there is no suspicion of the child having CJD." Graham Medley, of Warwick university's biological sciences department, said: "There is evidence of maternal transmission of this disease in cattle, but the situation with humans is unknown."

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText: An image of a baby injecting itself with heroin in an advert for Barnardo's has been replaced with a one of a "happy and bonny" child. The Committee of Advertising Practice had said the original advert was "too shocking" to be shown.
fields.body:
Barnardo's replaces heroin ad

An image of a baby injecting itself with heroin in an advert for Barnardo's has been replaced with a one of a "happy and bonny" child. The Committee of Advertising Practice had said the original advert was "too shocking" to be shown.

Most newspapers, including the Guardian and Observer, decided to run the advert, but some refused it. A replacement will appear in some papers while the original will appear in others over the weekend.

Andrew Nebel, Barnardo's director of marketing and communications, said the charity stood by the original.

"The readers of the newspapers that refused to carry the advert should be allowed to make up their own minds. We would love to be able to use soft cuddly images all the time, but we feel that we must raise public awareness of the deprivation that can blight the lives of thousands of children today." The original advertisement, which first appeared last weekend, read: "John Donaldson. Age 23. Battered as a child, it was always possible that John would turn to drugs. With Barnardo's help, child abuse need not lead to an empty future."

The new text reads: "We're sorry if our recent baby ad upset some people. Unfortunately, in this very real world, tens of thousands of children don't have a bright, rosy future ahead of them. Their lives are being ruined by drugs, abuse, poverty, neglect."

Bally K's Quigley dies

Tony Doyle, the Irish actor who played wily entrepreneur Brian Quigley in the BBC television drama Ballykissangel, died suddenly yesterday.

A BBC spokesman said the exact cause of death was not yet known. Doyle, who was in his 50s, was pronounced dead at 2am at St Thomas's hospital, London.

Dublin-born Doyle made his name playing a succession of troubled family men. Last year he starred as one of four northern working-class dads in the ITV drama Four Fathers.

He won acclaim for his role in the BBC's Amongst Women - which also earned him the first Irish Film and Television Academy Award for best leading performance. He was due to start filming a new detective series, McCready and Daughter, next month. He leaves a wife, Sally, and three children from his first marriage and three from his second.

BBC1 controller Peter Salmon said he was shocked. "Tony Doyle was one of the brightest stars of Ballykissangel."

Veterans lose atomic tests fight

A long-running legal battle over British nuclear tests in the Pacific during the 1950s ended in failure yesterday for two former servicemen who claimed they were illegally exposed to radiation.

Kenneth McGinley, 61, of Johnstone, Renfrewshire, and Edward Egan, 60, of Glasgow, had claimed there was new evidence to be considered which was not available when the Strasbourg judges delivered the original ruling against them in June 1998.

But human rights judges in Strasbourg rejected an appeal by the men to reopen the case. They had already ruled that the then government did not breach the human rights convention by conducting six atmospheric tests of nuclear weapons in the presence of servicemen.

The men blame health problems on exposure to radiation stemming from the tests in November 1957 and September 1958, when Britain carried out tests at Christmas Island in the Pacific Ocean. Mr McGinley was then serving in the army on the island and Mr Egan, who was in the navy, was stationed on a ship nearby.

The two men, who took their case to Strasbourg in 1993, claim the intention was deliberately to expose servicemen to radiation for experimental purposes.

Both had first lodged claims for war pensions, which were rejected by the department of social security, acting on data provided by the ministry of defence.

Sex killer's affair with care worker

A mentally ill woman who killed the son of a bishop during a sado-masochistic sex game had been having a relationship with a health professional which affected the way she was treated, a report revealed yesterday.

The report into the psychiatric care received by Justine Cummings also revealed that the authorities failed to take action against the health worker involved, leaving the danger that it could have happened again.

Cummings, 28, is serving a life sentence for the manslaughter of Peter Lewis, the son of the former bishop of Taunton, in May 1998.

Cummings, who has a psychopathic personality disorder and regularly mutilated herself, killed Mr Lewis, 27, at their home in Taunton in October 1997. He died from a single stab wound to the heart and was wearing a blindfold and handcuffs.

Somerset health authority commissioned an independent inquiry into the care which Cummings, now in Broadmoor hospital, received. The report said: "While it is clear it was impossible to predict the action that led to the death of Mr Lewis, local services made no attempt to collect information that would have allowed them to make a proper assessment of the risk she posed.

"It is deeply worrying there was such confusion about who had clinical responsibility for a patient with such a history of mental illness."

Clarice Cliff collection goes on sale

Mr Plate had one ambition in life and he failed: he set out to collect an example of every plate ever designed by the Art Deco Staffordshire designer Clarice Cliff, and in the process accumulated the largest private collection of her work in the world.

Mr Plate, as fellow collectos called him, was engineer Barry Jones, who died in 1995. More than 400 pieces from his collection, originally sold in the 1930s for a few shillings, will be auctioned at Christie's next month and are expected to raise up to £250,000.

His passionate collecting, beginning in the early 1980s, helped drive prices to their present meteoric level: the records, set last year in the centenary of her birth, were £13,800 for a Jazz Age figure and £13,570 for a Bizarre teaset.

The auction, on February 25, includes a unique plate, in a familiar "Bizarre" pattern but the only one known in a blue/purple colourway, which the Clarice Cliff Collector's Club named "Bazique" in Mr Jones's honour when he died in 1995. It is expected to sell for up to £1,400.

A castellated circle plate carries an estimate of £300-£500.

"He really was a remarkable collector," said Michael Jeffrey of Christie's. "He didn't achieve his goal of collecting every example of every plate, but he came closer than anyone else. Nobody could - more examples are turning up every day." - Maev Kennedy

Police on patrol ran taxi service

Police patrol car drivers who turned cabbies to give lifts to colleagues have been disciplined after complaints from taxi drivers that they were being done out of fares.

Detectives used one of their own security cameras to confirm claims that two squad cars supposed to be patrolling Barnsley in South Yorkshire were actually running a shuttle from a nightclub. One marked car picked up off-duty police close to Pharoah's, one of the biggest clubs in the town centre, and returned twice to give other colleagues a lift. No money changed hands.

South Yorkshire police said yesterday that 13 officers, mostly constables but including some sergeants, had been given a formal warning, some for giving lifts and others for accepting them. Barnsley cabbies have long complained that little was done to stop unlicensed touts. - Martin Wainwright

webTitle: Kidnapped boy home safe after Crimewatch tip-off

fields.headline: Kidnapped boy home safe after Crimewatch tip-off
fields.trailText: Rubbing his eyes and clutching his Teletubby, Daniel Grimshaw was reunited with his mother yesterday after a three month hunt for the gang who snatched him from his pushchair in a Bradford street.
fields.body:
Rubbing his eyes and clutching his Teletubby, Daniel Grimshaw was reunited with his mother yesterday after a three month hunt for the gang who snatched him from his pushchair in a Bradford street.

A clandestine night-time meeting and a tip from the BBC's Crimewatch ended a search in Britain and Pakistan for the 16-month-old boy, who was left at 2am yesterday in an agreed "safe house", for Asian community leaders to collect.

"It's the best feeling in the world holding my baby again - I'm never going to let him down," said Amy Grimshaw, 18, who was squirted with chemicals as Daniel was grabbed and stuffed into a car boot on November 9.

The boy's father, Muhuzar Mahmood, 25, who parted from Ms Grimshaw last summer and was subject to a court order to stay away from her and his son, has fled to Pakistan.

Chief Supt Stuart Hyde, who led the search for the child, said West Yorkshire police were unlikely to seek extradition but would wish to inter view the father if he returned. Six Bradford men have been charged in connection with the abduction, which involved three switches of car. Further arrests are unlikely.

Mr Hyde said that the breakthrough - "a tip-off which linked everything together" - came among hundreds of calls to Crimewatch after a reconstruction of the kidnap.

He said: "It didn't take us straight to such-and-such an address, but it greatly intensified the pressure on those who knew where Daniel was and were acting out of misplaced loyalty in a family dispute."

The run-up to the child's return was masterminded by a restaurateur, an ex-policeman, and the prospective Conservative candidate for Bradford West, who have worked behind the scenes in Bradford's Muslim community since November.

Fazal Hussain, who runs a chain of Asian diners in the city, joined the reunion yesterday and said: "We kept repeating the message that the child must be where he belongs, which is with his mother. Finally I was rung on my mobile at midnight last night by a voice I didn't recognise, and two hours later my colleagues went to a place which we can't reveal and found the boy safe and well. He had been alone, but only for 10 to 15 seconds, and they brought him straight to the police station."

Mr Hyde said that Mr Hussain, former PC Rashid Awan of Bradford police and community ethnic monitoring unit, and Raja Najabat Hussain, Tory candidate for Bradford West, had been "instrumental" in the happy outcome. He said: "They have done wonders for my faith in the local community and the way that we all work together in Bradford."

Ms Grimshaw, flanked by her mother, Elaine Dobson, 49, who had offered a £5,000 reward for the child's recovery, said: "It's been a nightmare but we always knew that we'd get Daniel back. We bought him his Christmas presents and now he'll get them."

Police know that Daniel spent some time in Nottingham and he is thought to have been brought back from the Midlands to the rendezvous in Bradford.

fields.headline: Virgin promises rail fares deal
fields.standfirst: More about transport
fields.trailText: Virgin Rail last night promised to act following mounting criticism from passengers that its standard return fare between Manchester and London has risen by 50% to £150 over the past three years.
fields.body:
Virgin Rail last night promised to act following mounting criticism from passengers that its standard return fare between Manchester and London has risen by 50% to £150 over the past three years.

The company yesterday said that it was hoping to set up a special coach and charge around £70 for a standard fare so long as the ticket is booked three weeks in advance.

This follows pressure from passenger groups and a demand for an official inquiry into possible abuse of monopoly powers by Virgin.

Brendan O'Friel, chairman of the rail passengers' watchdog committee for the north-west, has called on the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, to investigate "the extortionate rail fares between London and the north-west".

Mr O'Friel said yesterday: "People are being driven off the railways by Virgin's predatory pricing, in direct contravention of the government's stated aim of encouraging rail travel."

Mr O'Friel, a former governor of Strangeways prison in Manchester, wants a government investigation into unregulated prices on the railways.

"There must be root and branch reform in the industry, so that there are additional powers to stop excessive price increases," he said.

The shadow strategic rail authority, the body responsible for rail pricing, which is still awaiting final legislation, is powerless to do anything apart from controlling the 50-mile regulated fares area in London's commuter land, where some passengers have to pay almost £4,000 a year for a season ticket.

A spokeswoman for Virgin Rail said the company agreed that passengers had a point and that fares before 9.30am were too high, and said the company's senior managers were looking at a more equitable system and setting up a different fares structure.

But Virgin was making a huge investment into the upgrading of the line and passenger improvement and the cost would have to be shared, she added.

webTitle: Kurds face deportation after appeal court ruling

fields.headline: Kurds face deportation after appeal court ruling
fields.trailText: More than 6,000 Kurds who are seeking asylum in Britain now face deportation after a test case brought against the home secretary, Jack Straw, failed in the court of appeal yesterday.
fields.body:
More than 6,000 Kurds who are seeking asylum in Britain now face deportation after a test case brought against the home secretary, Jack Straw, failed in the court of appeal yesterday.

Three high court judges ruled that Mr Straw had acted properly despite hearing evidence that serious forms of torture were still rife in Turkey and Kurds who refused to serve in the army faced up to three years in prison followed by military service.

The landmark appeal court ruling involved Abdullah Turgut, 30, who arrived in Britain in 1993 in the back of a lorry after fleeing from military conscription in Turkey. Lord Justice Simon Brown said that Mr Straw had made "a reasonable decision" in deciding that he should be deported and it was not up to the courts to review the evidence.

The judge said it had not been an easy decision as "many thousands of such claims for exceptional leave to remain in Britain" were affected by the case.

"Despite the great wealth of material available to show that grave human rights abuses still regrettably occur in Turkey, and despite the lingering sense of unease which one must inevitably feel at the return of those like this applicant to Turkey, I am unable to hold that the secretary of state was bound to find the risk of this particular applicant being ill-treated a real one."

Mr Turgut had challenged the home secretary's decision to deport him under article three of the European convention on human rights.

The convention says that nobody should be subjected to torture or to inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment.

His lawyers appealed to the court to make its own decision about the risk facing Mr Turgut if he was returned to Turkey.

But Lord Justice Brown said the courts could never exercise powers as a "primary decision-maker" and usurp the role of the home secretary.

He said that the home office had refused his application to stay in Britain on five separate occasions and found there were no grounds for believing he would be at risk if he was returned to Turkey.

A second judgment in the appeal court yesterday, which could affect hundreds of other Kurdish asylum seekers, upheld the right of the home secretary to send another Turkish Kurd back to Germany and rejected the claim that it was not a safe third country.

This case involved Abidin Altun, who refused to serve in the Turkish army on the grounds that he might be required to kill fellow Kurds.

Mr Altun came to Britain after being refused asylum in Germany.

It was also confirmed yesterday that a five-year-old London boy was being forced to leave Britain because his Kenyan mother had been refused political asylum.

Patrick Wandia Njuguna, who was born in Britain five years ago and has not been out of the country, was served with deportation papers just before Christmas.

His mother, Mary, 35, a nursery nurse, of Gospel Oak, north London, has been fighting to stay in Britain for more than five years. She fled Kenya after exposing a corrupt election commissioner while working for a Nairobi law firm.

webTitle: 'Foot soldier' Blair slams Labour old guard

fields.headline: 'Foot soldier' Blair slams Labour old guard
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report
The London mayor: special report

In an interview with the Guardian, PM tells why he fears a return to gesture politics of the 1980s, and why Dobson is the best man for London
fields.trailText: In an interview with the Guardian, PM tells why he fears a return to gesture politics of the 1980s, and why Dobson is the best man for London
fields.body:
Cruising at 25,000ft over the Alps, Tony Blair loses little time in blaming the old Labour left for his party's 18 wilderness years and for refusing to learn the lessons necessary to retain power now.

He does not quite say that if party activists in the capital elect Ken Livingstone as Labour's candidate for London mayor, it will cost them the historic second term in power that he is determined to win at next year's expected general election.

But he gets quite close. "I can't make predictions like that. But what you can say is that the gesture politics of the early 1980s was incredibly damaging to the Labour party. It prevented us effectively being a serious opposition, capable of forming a government.

"If there is any chance of that coming back again it would be bad for the Labour party, that is incredibly obvious. The issue is, who is the best person to lead Labour in London at this time?"

No guessing who that person is. The prime minister has decided to make a last-minute intervention, as 60,000 party members consider their ballot papers for the electoral college, to try to push Frank Dobson over the winning line ahead of the former GLC leader.

Mr Blair is certainly not resigned to a Livingstone victory, as reported. "I don't accept that, let's wait and see what the result is. As far as I can make out, it's close."

In the past few weeks he reckoned to have addressed up to 7,000 London party supporters at meetings, some of them hostile. Yet he uses the outward flight on a one-day trip to the World Economic Forum, in the Swiss resort of Davos, for one last shove.

Shirt-sleeved and characteristically impatient, he repeatedly taps his pen on the table inside his BAe 146 to signal frustration at the pace of change - and the resistance it encounters.

People are perfectly entitled to criticise him - "we have plenty of opposition from all sorts of quarters" - but now is the time to get serious about the future. "The idea that we should elect Labour's candidate for mayor of London on the basis that they should then provide a focal point of opposition to the government is a pretty extraordinary piece of, well, of infantile politics."

Mr Livingstone says that when he becomes mayor in May the two of them will get on well. Mr Blair does not renew previous personal attacks on the Brent East MP, and says: "I will work with whoever is the Labour candidate."

But Mr Blair says that where other GLC leftwingers have grown up and are ministers, Mr Livingstone is still a gesture politician, keener on confrontation than on cooperation - with police, Whitehall and the City - to make the mayoral system work.

He derides the claim that, in 1983, 8m people voted for socialism. In Sedgefield they voted Labour "despite the Labour party".

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Oil catastrophe for British birds
fields.body:
Oil catastrophe for British birds

Some 80% of the birds killed in the French oil slick disaster came from British and Irish breeding colonies. The final death toll could be 120,000, in what may be the largest recorded catastrophe for British seabirds. Over 60,000 birds have already perished since the tanker Erika sank in December. Thousands of tonnes of fuel oil have affected a 300-mile stretch of coast.

Queen Mother recovering

The Queen Mother, 99, was last night reported by Buckingham Palace to be recovering from a cold at Sandringham after sparking rumours, which spread to the internet, when she pulled out of her annual visit to Sandringham Women's Institute on Wednesday.

Nazi suspect's funeral

The funeral of suspected Nazi war criminal Alexander Schweidler, 78, took place in Milton Keynes, Buckinghamshire, yesterday, attended by his wife, daughter and a family friend. Mr Schweidler, who had been living in the town since 1994, died of a heart attack days after a national newspaper traced him.

Rock singer cautioned

Gary Daly, lead singer of the band China Crisis, has been cautioned for punching Mark Cowley, the manager of million-selling indie pop band Space, in a row over music rights outside recording studios in Liverpool this week.

fields.headline: Honeymoon's over for Mandelson
fields.standfirst:
As crunch-time nears over IRA arms decommissioning, the Northern Ireland secretary faces his toughest decisions since he took office

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: As crunch-time nears over IRA arms decommissioning, the Northern Ireland secretary faces his toughest decisions since he took office
fields.body:
Throughout his first 100 days back in government, Peter Mandelson's rehabilitation as a leading politician was easing effortlessly ahead. As Northern Ireland secretary, he was proving a class act.

True, he was lucky to arrive at Stormont just as George Mitchell, the former US senator, was somehow mapping a way through the arms decommissioning impasse that had long threatened the Good Friday agreement. But it was Mr Mandelson who put the backbone into David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, as he hesitated over selling the compromise to his sceptical colleagues.

Mr Mandelson's halo slipped on his 101th day last week, when he announced he was backing the report by Chris Patten, the former governor of Hong Kong, on reforming the Royal Ulster Constabulary. There were important, though scarcely noticed, concessions to Unionists, including postponement of district policing boards, which many fear would allow paramilitaries in some areas to wield undue influence.

But Mr Mandelson's performance in several subsequent television interviews infuriated many Unionists, includ ing staunch supporters of the agreement. They felt he was high-handed, even insulting.

This weekend, his honeymoon is over. General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, is on Monday to puncture earlier hopes when he will announce there has been no start to IRA decommissioning. Mr Mandelson faces the toughest decision of his ministerial career.

Mr Trimble has to face his ruling Ulster Unionist council on February 12. He promised its 860 delegates in November that he and his three ministers would quit the executive if he was unable to report a start to IRA decommissioning at the reconvened meeting, and the announcement on the RUC leaves him no room for manoeuvre.

He calculated that the conditional move was the only way to persuade his party to switch policy and allow devolution before decommissioning. He won relatively narrow 58% support.

To allow Mr Trimble to quit would cause huge problems. To be re-elected if a second review of the agreement then proved successful, he needs majority backing from Unionist and nationalist assembly members. With the defection of Peter Weir, he can no longer rely on his own side of the house to support him. That would indicate Mr Mandelson will take the initiative instead, and suspend the executive and cross-border bodies. That would mean restoring direct rule pending another review, under the British and Irish governments, to try to sort out the decommissioning issue.

But, as Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, made plain, such a move would be outside the agreement. There was no date set other than the aspirational date in May for the completion of all paramilitary decommissioning. Suspension now would make an IRA move less likely.

The government has so far stuck rigidly to the agreement, speedily implementing its side of the bargain. Mr Mandelson will be reluctant to provide republicans with a rallying focus.

He talks tough about suspension in the event of default on IRA decommissioning, but has carefully avoided giving any date of when he would take such action. Jitters are creeping in among Mr Trimble's circle.

Sources close to Mr Trimble say Mr Adams and his fellow Sinn Fein negotiator, Martin McGuinness, gave verbal assurances that Gen de Chastelain would be able to report a start to decommissioning in January.

Nonsense, says Sinn Fein. Perhaps nods and winks were misinterpreted, but it is more likely that Mr Trimble's unanticipated decision to impose the February deadline enraged Sinn Fein. It has long said it cannot speak for the IRA, and for any private arrangement even implicitly to become public jeopardised that highly successful approach.

Sinn Fein has talked a tough game this year on decommis sioning. Mitchel McLaughlin, the party's chairman, even said last week that the IRA had decommissioned because its guns were silent.

He also ridiculed the view that decommissioning could be interpreted as sealing IRA arms bunkers. The government had long been floating that option because it felt the IRA was less likely to view it as surrender. Sinn Fein is repeating an old mantra this week, emphasising its role in persuading the IRA to call a ceasefire. Some Unionists felt that approach indicated decommissioning was less likely.

Mr Trimble jumped first in November because he felt that republicans would attract worldwide condemnation if the IRA failed to decommission soon. He said: "Sinn Fein will pay an enormous price politically if that happens."

Mr Adams's speech on Thursday appeared to be designed to thrown the blame back on to Ulster Unionists if they force the collapse of the new institutions. He may well succeed: even the nationalist Irish News and Seamus Mallon, the SDLP deputy leader, make it clear they believe the responsibility would rest with republicans.

Mr Trimble also pointed out direct rule would now come without the Irish Republic's territorial claim to Northern Ireland and the detested Anglo-Irish agreement, rescinded last month. Sinn Fein has seized on that to suggest it was Mr Trimble's tactic all along.

Even if Mr Mandelson is forced to suspend the executive, there will be a shadow executive. That is much more than looked possible for a long time last year, and the long-term outlook is still bright enough.

Republican weapons

The IRA's arsenal includes

Three tonnes of Semtex

600 assorted detonators

600 AK-47/AKM Czech and Romanian-made rifles

40 Webley .455 revolvers

40 rocket propelled grenade launchers

20 DShK heavy machine guns

12 FN MAG 7.62mm medium machine guns

6 flame throwers

2 SAM-7 anti-aircraft missiles

1 Barrett 50 sniper rifle

webTitle: Established authors get the elbow as Penguin Classics relaunch

fields.headline: Established authors get the elbow as Penguin Classics relaunch
fields.trailText: Lovers of Conrad, Lawrence, and Colette may be in for a shock when Penguin Books relaunches its Modern Classics series next week. The publisher plans to update and broaden its list of 20th-century novels, and there may be some prominent casualties.
fields.body:
Lovers of Conrad, Lawrence, and Colette may be in for a shock when Penguin Books relaunches its Modern Classics series next week.

The publisher plans to update and broaden its list of 20th-century novels, and there may be some prominent casualties.

This spring Penguin is to add 80 titles to its list, which will eventually reach 600 books. The first batch, out on Thursday, includes Martin Amis's Money, Raymond Queneau's Zazie in the Metro, JL Carr's A Month in the Country, and Raymond Chandler's The Big Sleep, as well as new editions of established 20th-century works such as Franz Kafka's Metamorphosis, Vladimir Nabokov's Lolita, Jean-Paul Sartre's Nausea, and James Joyce's Dubliners.

Simon Winder, editor of the series, said yesterday that he was eager to redefine the classic to include influential genre writers such as Chandler, John Wyndham, and MR James, and to give better representation to the second half of the century.

"Classics - even modern classics - have suffered from a worthy image," he said. "Yet books like Animal Farm and On the Road are the equivalent of the Beatles' White Album or the film Apocalypse Now."

In weeding the existing list, some authors will suffer: Joseph Conrad will cease to have all his work in print, and Rudyard Kipling likewise. DH Lawrence and F Scott Fitzgerald will be treated less reverentially, while the future of Colette and André Gide looks even shakier.

In part, the new list is a changing of the generations, with pre-war work reduced to make way for more recent writers: Jane and Paul Bowles, Malcolm Lowry, Jack Kerouac, Muriel Spark, Jean Rhys, and the American essayist John McPhee.

Mr Winder said he intended to make the list more inclusive and to build "a series to be enjoyed, rather than something that is good for you". He added: "There is no reason why Molesworth should not sit alongside The Trial, Mrs Dalloway, and Ulysses."

The novelist and critic, Malcolm Bradbury, who has written an introduction to a new edition of Saul Bellow's Herzog, said: "The end point of a classic gets closer and closer.

"It was important to give better representation to the past 50 years, and there are clearly 25 or so books written in the 1950s, 60s and 70s that deserve to be called classics."

fields.headline: Jail for clifftop wife killer
fields.standfirst: Cheated husband gets 30-month sentence
fields.trailText: A teacher who pushed his unfaithful wife over a cliff as they went for a walk to discuss their pending divorce has been jailed for 30 months after pleading guilty to manslaughter.
fields.body:
A teacher who pushed his unfaithful wife over a cliff as they went for a walk to discuss their pending divorce has been jailed for 30 months after pleading guilty to manslaughter.

Denis Day, 55, sparked a fruitless clifftop search by police and coastguards after reporting his wife Ann missing. He later changed his story on a number of occasions and did not admit to his part in her death until four weeks ago when he was due to go on trial for murder.

Ann Day, 47, died after falling on to rocks at Trewent point, one of the highest headlands on the Pembrokeshire coastal path, on April 14 last year. The family dog, a labrador named Jess, also went over the cliff.

Swansea crown court was told yesterday that only Mr Day knew what really happened. The prosecution said it had no choice but to accept his denial of murder and plea of guilty to involuntary manslaughter.

Sentencing was adjourned earlier this month pending probation reports, and Day, who had spent five months in jail on remand, was bailed to live with his late wife's mother, Joan Bingham, until yesterday's hearing.

Mrs Bingham, a humanities teacher at Pembroke school, was not in court to hear her son-in-law sentenced.

The court heard that the Days' 24-year marriage had turned into a "shell" and that Mrs Day, deputy head of Barn Street primary school in Haverfordwest, had been having an affair with a fellow teacher, Wayne Davies. On the day she died Mrs Day had spent the afternoon with her lover before suggesting a clifftop walk with her husband to "clear the air" over the divorce.

Leighton Davies QC, prosecuting, said that after Mrs Day fell from the clifftop Day drove to Haverfordwest and withdrew money from a cash machine before returning home and telling the youngest of the couple's three teenage sons that his mother was missing.

He waited 90 minutes before telephoning police and telling them his wife had not returned from a walk to meet him as planned.

Two days later Day changed his story and claimed that the family's pet labrador had jumped up and knocked her over the edge of the cliff. He said he had made up the first story in panic.

Mr Davies told the court that Day persisted with the charade through four police interviews until he was about to go on trial for murder. He finally said that a quarrel developed over his wife's insistence over a divorce and that he gave her a push after she became angry and rushed at him.

John Charles Rees QC, defending, said that Day had pushed out in the course of an altercation, causing his wife to stumble backwards over the headland. "He did not intend, or foresee, such consequences."

It was, he told the court, a tragic case. "Up until 2 years ago they were almost the perfect family. All that changed when Wayne Davies came into their lives and caught Mrs Day at a vulnerable time in her life."

Passing sentence, Mr Justice Turner told Day he had misled his sons, relations, friends and colleagues about the true circumstances of his wife's death. He still failed to show true remorse. "For almost nine months you have denied your involvement. You spun a fanciful tale. For a person of your intelligence and apparent honesty that is surprising.

"Your sons are the true victims. Once again they will have to learn the true circumstances before they can give vent to the natural feelings to grieve that will finally help them get over the death of their mother."

fields.headline: To the lighthouse
fields.standfirst: Spectacular island up for sale
fields.trailText: The gale force winds and occasional blasts from the foghorn can be a bit of a problem, but as a spectacular water feature, the garden takes some beating. One of the most isolated homes in Britain is up for sale - at £200,000.
fields.body:
The gale force winds and occasional blasts from the foghorn can be a bit of a problem, but as a spectacular water feature, the garden takes some beating. One of the most isolated homes in Britain is up for sale - at £200,000.

Those determined not to be deterred by the experiences of volunteers for the BBC Castaway 2000 project could find the tiny island of Buchaness a tempting prospect.

The rocky outpost comes complete with lighthouse and three more conventional homes.

Anyone wishing to buy the island, however, should beware: Buchaness is cut off at high tide.

But, when the weather is kind enough to allow com muting, the nearest town is five minutes away.

For the past 11 years the island has been home to doctors Gordon and Avril Barratt. They warned yesterday that, although it has been a perfect home to them, it may not suit everyone so well.

"People have got to accept this place for what it is - you get good weather and bad weather.

"You have to take it in all weathers. Some people would like that and we have thoroughly enjoyed it," said Mrs Barratt, a forensic psychiatrist.

The couple bought the island when the Northern Lighthouse Board was selling a number of its coastal properties.

Buffeted by the worst storms of the North Sea, the distinctive lighthouse, with its red stripe, has since 1827 guided sailors into the Aberdeenshire port of Peterhead.

The lighthouse is still operational and the lighthouse board has access to the island to maintain it, though it is now fully automated.

Its loud foghorn has annoyed some neighbours, but the Barratts have grown used to it. "The foghorn only goes off in deep mist. It is simply not a problem.

"If you live on the Embankment in London you have to contend with the noise of traffic and that sort of thing," said Mrs Barratt.

The property actually comprises three houses - two of which were built by the lighthouse board for its staff in 1825. There is also a large modern four bedroom bungalow. All the buildings are shielded from the weather's worst excesses by a high wall.

The lighthouse, which became fully automated in 1988, was built in 1827 to an engineering design by Robert Stephenson.

New uses for old buildings

Former Free Church
Saline, Scotland

19th century solid stone church. Open-plan interior with spiral staircase, sunken dining room, 4 bedrooms and heated swimming pool.

£235,000. Stirling Eunson & Ferguson

Swingate Windmill
Nr Dover, Kent

Built in 1849 this converted windmill has 4 bedrooms over three floors set in farmland.

£325,000. Frank Knight

Corsewall Lighthouse Hotel

One of the most isolated homes in Britain is up for sale - at £200,000. Those determined not to be deterred by the experiences of volunteers for the BBC Castaway 2000 project could find the tiny island of Buchaness a tempting prospect. The rocky outpost comes complete with lighthouse and three more conventional homes. Anyone wishing to buy the island, however, should beware: Buchaness is cut off at high tide. But, when the weather is kind enough to allow com muting, the nearest town is five minutes away. For the past 11 years the island has been home to doctors Gordon and Avril Barratt. They warned yesterday that, although it has been a perfect home to them, it may not suit everyone so well. "People have got to accept this place for what it is - you get good weather and bad weather. "You have to take it in all weathers. Some people would like that and we have thoroughly enjoyed it," said Mrs Barratt, a forensic psychiatrist. The couple bought the island when the Northern Lighthouse Board was selling a number of its coastal properties. Buffeted by the worst storms of the North Sea, the distinctive lighthouse, with its red stripe, has since 1827 guided sailors into the Aberdeenshire port of Peterhead. webTitle: Jenny, Eric and Martin are still living happily

fields.headline: Jenny, Eric and Martin are still living happily
fields.standfirst:
Section 28 explained
Stonewall
fields.trailText: Now Britain has a new government, a supposedly more liberal society - and a fresh debate about section 28. Like the last time, Susanne Bösche's book is being deployed by the pro-section 28 camp, and the battleground is as much about interpreting what people believe as about what people should do.
fields.body:
Once upon a time, a little girl called Louise lived in a snowy land far away with her mummy and two men who weren't her daddy but sometimes hugged and kissed each other.

One day the rulers of another country called Britain heard about Louise and said her story was a disgrace and a dangerous example to young people.

But Louise grew up and lived happily ever after. And so did the two men who weren't her daddy.

Thus runs the true story behind the infamous children's book, Jenny Lives With Eric and Martin, which for two decades has been used by supporters of section 28 as a terrible warning of the flood of "homosexual propaganda" which would be unleashed on British schoolchildren if the measure wasn't there.

Yesterday the book's Danish author, Susanne Bösche, spoke of her anger at how the children's book she wrote in 1981 became a political pawn.

Published in England in 1983, the book was a photo-narrative showing a little girl who lived with her father and his homosexual partner. One picture showed the girl having breakfast in bed with the two men. The girl was actually Ms Bösche's four-year-old daughter Louise, and the two men were actor friends, lovers who shared the house.

Far from being traumatised by the experience, Louise, now 23, a kindergarten supervisor, is living happily with her male partner, Michael, and is expecting a baby in May. "Eric" and "Martin" - real names Henrik and Lars - are happily settled together in Spain.

"I was really shocked at the way it was used in England and the way it was called homosexual propaganda," said Ms Bösche. "You must have very little confidence in your teachers in England if you think they will use propaganda or promote anything."

Now Britain has a new government, a supposedly more liberal society - and a fresh debate about section 28. Like the last time, the Bösche book is being deployed by the pro-section 28 camp, and the battleground is as much about interpreting what people believe as about what people should do.

The researcher whose groundbreaking study of British sexual behaviour found a society with deep-rooted homophobia spoke yesterday of her "loathing" of the way her statistics are being used as ammunition, 10 years on, by evangelical Christians campaigning to keep section 28.

Kaye Wellings, who led the five-woman research team which compiled the 1990 report Sexual Behaviour in Britain, said she believed homophobia had eased in the decade since. Then, the team found 70% of men and 58% of women thought gay sex was always or mostly wrong.

As the debate over section 28 intensifies, so does the argument over how tolerant middle England has become of sexual diversity.

Signs of tolerance, like the 1997 election victory of gay MP Ben Bradshaw over his gay-hostile opponent Adrian Rogers, have to be set against cases like the suicide of a Burton upon Trent schoolboy in 1998, bullied by taunts of "gay boy" and "poof" simply because he liked cookery and drama.

The Welling team's figures form the centrepiece of the argument by the Christian Institute, the evangelical think tank leading opposition to repeal of section 28, that the law is essential because "the great majority of parents think homosexual practice is wrong".

Sexual attitudes tend to shift slowly, she said, by between 5% or 10% a decade, so it was quite possible that a bare majority of Britons still felt gay sex was wrong.

This was no argument for keeping section 28, she said. "We should have legislation to counter our homophobic attitudes."

The Newcastle-based Christian Institute aims to bolster the pro-section 28 views held by faith community leaders like Roman Catholic cardinal Thomas Winning, Anglican bishop James Jones, and the chief rabbi, Jonathan Sacks.

Its director, Chris Hart, denies that he wants to see discussion of homosexuality banned in schools. But teachers, he said, should not bring it up without telling children that most people disapprove of it.

Mr Hart claims Christians who spread the word of majority disapproval are not being intolerant. "Of course any form of physical violence against homosexuals is wrong. Nobody's advocating gay-bashing," he said.

fields.headline: Teachers fight sex guidelines
fields.standfirst:
As debate on repeal of anti-gay legislation heats up, both sides call for guidelines but education unions are angry at government 'meddling'
Section 28 explained
Stonewall
fields.trailText: Teachers' leaders yesterday reacted with fury to disclosures from Downing Street that schools are to be given new guidelines on promoting marriage and family life, and they accused the government of suffering from "interventionitis".
fields.body:
Teachers' leaders yesterday reacted with fury to disclosures from Downing Street that schools are to be given new guidelines on promoting marriage and family life, and they accused the government of suffering from "interventionitis".

The two largest teaching unions argued that schools could be trusted to devise their own sex education policies without extra guidance.

Their objections followed an announcement that the department for education and employment is to prepare a new circular on teaching about sex and relationships following criticism from religious groups and a handful of Labour MPs over plans to repeal section 28 of the 1988 local government act, which forbids local authorities from "promoting" homosexuality.

Teaching unions say their members have been left uncertain how to deal with pupils' concerns or incidents such as homophobic bullying.

The education secretary, David Blunkett, told cabinet members on Thursday that schools would be set clear limits on what should be taught, and would be told to stress the importance of marriage and stable family life. Downing Street's claims that the guidelines would prevent homosexual "proselytising" in the classroom have alarmed some gay campaigners, who fear an effective reintroduction of section 28 by the back door.

The general secretary of the NASUWT teaching union, Nigel de Gruchy, backed the repeal of section 28, but he said: "The last thing schools need is yet more guidance from a government suffering from chronic 'interventionitis'.

"The law already requires a school's sex education policy to be approved by the governing body. The government should leave such matters to the common sense of people on the ground who have to respond to a thousand and one different kinds of questions which pupils ask."

He added: "Instead of confronting its critics head-on and arguing the merits of its case, the government seeks to placate them by imposing yet more bureaucracy on schools."

The National Union of Teachers also condemned further ministerial intervention. A spokeswoman said: "Teachers always find advice helpful, but what they don't want is dictation.

"Advice has to be taken or ignored in the context of the school you are in, the community you serve and the pupils you are dealing with. Teachers take their responsibilities to their pupils extremely seriously."

The union's policy document argues that the national curriculum should prepare pupils for life in a society which includes lesbian, gay and bisexual people.

The moderate Association of Teachers and Lecturers, however, suggested the outcry over the repeal of section 28 was "a storm in a teacup", and argued the new guidelines would be "thoroughly sensible".

A spokeswoman for the union, which has no formal policy on the repeal of section 28, said: "Sex education is a sensitive area which is being dealt with sensitively by the department."

The hardline gay and lesbian pressure group OutRage! wrote to Tony Blair and Donald Dewar, first minister of the Scottish parliament, calling for amendments to the bill repealing section 28 to establish new guidelines for teachers.

The proposals, which will not be accepted by the government, include a bar on schools promoting or encouraging any form of sexuality and an instruction that "all sexual orientations must be discussed in an honest, factual manner".

webTitle: Row looms on spy HQs overspend

fields.headline: Row looms on spy HQs overspend
fields.trailText: The government yesterday laid the ground for a serious dispute with MPs over spending by the intelligence and security agencies by rejecting their demand that a report on high overspending on new headquarters for MI5 and MI6 be published.
fields.body:
The government yesterday laid the ground for a serious dispute with MPs over spending by the intelligence and security agencies by rejecting their demand that a report on high overspending on new headquarters for MI5 and MI6 be published.

The parliamentary intelligence and security committee revealed last year that MI5 spent more than £200m, or three times the original estimate, and MI6 spent more than £80m, or nearly four times the first estimate, fitting up buildings by the river Thames in central London.

The committee said publishing national audit office reports would "not prejudice national security or compromise commercial confidentialities". Yesterday, the government replied that it could damage the security of MI5 and MI6.

But it said it would talk to David Davis, the Tory chairman of the commons public accounts committee, parliament's financial watchdog.

Mr Davis said last night: "There is a great deal of information that could and should be put into the public domain. I am of the view that the arrangements for keeping certain information secret must be confined to issues which are genuinely secret." He added: "The government gave permission for the latest James Bond film to use the MI6 HQ as a backdrop, so this is clearly not an amazingly well-kept secret. If it is good enough for 007 and the film industry, it ought to be good enough for the British public."

fields.headline: Hostel drug case plea fails
fields.trailText: The director of a charity for the homeless, jailed for five years after being convicted of allowing heroin to be supplied at a hostel she ran, was yesterday refused leave to appeal against her conviction.
fields.body:
The director of a charity for the homeless, jailed for five years after being convicted of allowing heroin to be supplied at a hostel she ran, was yesterday refused leave to appeal against her conviction.

A high court judge said he would only allow Ruth Wyner, 49, head of the Winter Comfort charity in Cambridge, leave to appeal against her sentence. The judge announced his decision in a letter to Wyner's lawyers following a hearing in London last week.

One of Wyner's managers, John Brock, 49, who was jailed for four years after being convicted of the same offence, was also given leave to appeal against his sentence but not his conviction. A spokesman for the Winter Comfort charity said last night: "We are very, very disappointed by this ruling because we feel that their convictions are wrong - although we obviously welcome the granting of leave to appeal against sentence."

Supporters of Wyner and Brock have launched a campaign for their release.

The key issue at their trial at Kings Lynn crown court last year was whether Wyner and Brock had a duty to inform on hostel residents they knew to be dealing in drugs. Both argued they had a duty of confidentiality.

Police said the Cambridge hostel had become a centre for drug dealing and that Wyner and Brock had turned a blind eye. Winter Comfort officials said the decision could have wide implications for people working with the homeless and with drug addicts.

fields.headline: Lawrences to sue Met for £500,000
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: The parents of the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence are to sue the Metropolitan Police for more than £500,000 for the way they were treated during the failed investigation into the racist killing of their son.
fields.body:
The parents of the murdered teenager Stephen Lawrence are to sue the Metropolitan Police for more than £500,000 for the way they were treated during the failed investigation into the racist killing of their son.

They are also claiming for psychological damages, the cost of their son's funeral in Jamaica, and for the cost of the campaign to achieve some kind of justice for Stephen.

Neville and Doreen Lawrence also plan to sue the five white youths who they believe killed Stephen, 18, in Eltham, south-east London.

The couple lodged writs for damages at the high court in April last year, but the details of their claim has only been recently revealed, 11 months after an independent inquiry report harshly criticised the police investigation into Stephen's murder.

Using the race relations act as the backbone for their claim, the couple - who have divorced since the murder of their son - have asked for £500,000 in total from the 41 officers involved in the inquiry into the killing of Stephen on April 22, 1993.

The outgoing Metropolitan Police commissioner Paul Condon is one of those being sued. The couple are also suing the Met for negligence for an additional, undisclosed sum.

Mrs Lawrence, 46, is claiming £22,352 in damages for the detrimental effect the bungled police investigation had on her studies at Greenwich university in south London.

Her writ also asks for £7,000 to pay for trips she took to America and South Africa to try and get over the murder and for £4,900 for visiting Stephen's grave in Jamaica.

The writ also requests the cost of taxi fares to take her son Stuart to his part-time job at McDonald's - a cost of £2,189. It is claimed he could not take public transport because the whole family was under the witness protection programme at the time.

Other elements of Mrs Lawrence's claim include:

 £8,736 for four years of help looking after the other Lawrence children, Stuart and Georgina, during the police investigation

 £3,900 for phone bills

 £2,800 to cover expenses when the family moved home

 £18,960 for travel expenses

 £98,898 for loss of earnings due to the psychiatric damage of police negligence.

Mr Lawrence has claimed £8,000 for the cost of the funeral and is also seeking compensation for loss of earnings.

Neil Acourt, 24 at the time, his brother, Jamie, 22, David Norris, 23, Luke Knight, 22, and Gary Dobson, 24, were all charged with Stephen's murder but the charges were dropped because of lack of evidence.

The Lawrences' writs against the five suspects are unlikely to yield concrete damages as they are not wealthy. But a court case would oblige the five to account for their movements on the night of the murder in a court.

A Met spokesman said: "We can confirm we have received a claim of compensation for negligence from solicitors acting for Mr and Mrs Lawrence. In addition, a number of officers have received claims under the race relations act."

webTitle: Woman, 81, jailed for not paying rates

fields.headline: Woman, 81, jailed for not paying rates
fields.trailText: An elderly spinster yesterday began a two-week prison sentence for owing £2,700 in rates.
fields.body:
An elderly spinster yesterday began a two-week prison sentence for owing £2,700 in rates.

Ellen Copson, 81, was jailed by magistrates at Droitwich, Worcestershire, on Thursday, having been prosecuted for non-payment of £13 a week business rates on premises she owns below the high street flat she has lived in all her life - one shop is let, but the other is empty. The jailing brought protests from local traders, who yesterday festooned Droitwich high street with "Free Nellie" posters.

Miss Copson had claimed she could not afford to pay out of her £87 a week income, and also maintained it was unfair to charge the rate while one shop was empty. She owed £2,726, covering 1995 to 1999, and had been prosecuted by Wychavon district council, responsible for collecting the rates as an agent for the inland revenue's valuation office.

Her neighbour shopkeeper, Simon Barugh, of ETU International hair products, said she could not solve her problem by selling the shop, because property in the area was unsaleable.

"I like and admire her. She is a little stubborn and very determined. I am shocked by the sentence. I didn't believe the courts would go to that extreme."

Mr Barugh talked to her yesterday by phone at Brockhill women's prison, near Redditch. "Nellie's a tough nut," he said. "But I think it may be more traumatic for her than she's letting on. Surely educated and responsible people could come up with something that would have enabled her to still be at home tonight."

Tom Lymer, a butcher, said: "We can't believe what has happened. She is in the twilight years of her life and should not have to put up with the stress." Rosemary Wright, who runs a nearby fish and chip shop, said: "There's an absolute furore in the town right now. I think the council should go shoot themselves."

The district council's managing director, Sid Pritchard, said: "The council is as unhappy as everyone else at the thought of an 81-year-old woman being sent to prison. We did absolutely everything we could to avoid Miss Copson's situation coming to this.

"Despite our best efforts, and those of the court, she repeatedly refused to help us to find a solution."

fields.headline: Briton's murder shocks paradise island
fields.trailText: A British millionaire was shot dead in a bungled robbery on the paradise Caribbean island of St Kitts as his daughter listened on the telephone.
fields.body:
A British millionaire was shot dead in a bungled robbery on the paradise Caribbean island of St Kitts as his daughter listened on the telephone.

Tony Fetherston, 67, was shot through the heart after refusing to hand over cash to a masked gunman in the grounds of his holiday home on the island on Wednesday evening. He died instantly.

The retired businessman, from Sutton, in Suffolk, is thought to have left his bungalow, near the island's capital Basseterre after hearing the doorbell ring. He was shot after a brief argument with the gunman.

Mrs Fetherston ran out to find her husband dead on the porch. As she bolted the front door, the masked man appeared at a window and demanded money. The killer fled when she ran to another room to call the police.

Mrs Fetherston was yesterday being comforted by her daughter, the couple's only child, who flew to join her at the home of the British honorary consul, Peter Allcorn, who is a family friend.

The assistant commissioner of police on St Kitts, Claydon Mills, said two suspects were being questioned by police and a mask had been found discarded outside Mr Fetherston's home.

A postmortem was due to be carried out today.

Mr Mills said the two men had not been charged, but added: "It would appear that only one man was involved and robbery appears to be the motive.

"It is not drug-related. A crime like this is very unusual here. The island remains a safe place and we are certainly hopeful of finding the killer."

Sandra Murphy, resident acting high commissioner for St Kitts, said Mrs Fetherston, a voluntary worker with a British cancer charity, was distressed but "bearing up remarkably well in the circumstances".

Friends paid tribute to Mr Fetherston, a keen sailor and pilot, describing him as "kind-hearted" and "the finest sort of English gentleman".

The prime minister of the two-island state of St Kitts and Nevis said the murder hunt would be a top priority.

Denzil Douglas said: "I roundly condemn the senseless, fatal shooting of a British visitor to the island of St Kitts. Our law enforcement officials will be unflinching in their ef forts to bring the perpetrator to justice.

"I share the grief and shock of all right-thinking citizens and will be personally conveying regret and sympathy to Mr Fetherston's widow."

The couple, whose home is a £1m mansion set in 25 acres in Sutton, near Woodbridge, arrived on the island earlier this month for their annual four-month winter break.

A family friend, Elizabeth Miles, 64, said: "Alex rang me from New York to say she had terrible news that her daddy had been shot and killed.

"She told me that she had heard the shots because she was on the telephone at the time to her mother."

Mrs Miles later spoke with Mrs Fetherston by telephone. She said: "Margaret told me how Tony was just about to go to bed when he got up to answer the door.

"She heard this man demanding money and her husband replying that he had not got any.

"The next thing she heard was him shouting 'Oh God' and then shots ringing out. She went outside and found him dead on their porch.

"There was nothing she could do for him so she rushed back inside and bolted the door before calling the police and getting back in touch with Alex to tell her what happened."

Mrs Miles said the death of Mr Fetherston, who retired 10 years ago after selling his import and export business, was "absolutely shocking", adding: "Tony was a very nice man who never did anybody any harm."

She said the couple had been concerned about the rising tide of drug-related violence on the island after two burglaries at their St Kitts home.

The former British colony's reputation as a playground for the rich and famous - including, at one time, Diana, Princess of Wales - is fast being overtaken as that of a haven for drug traffickers.

The authorities were forced to call in British police to investigate a string of murders six years ago.

A foreign office spokeswoman said officials were waiting to speak with consular staff in St Kitts to find out more details about the incident on the 68 square mile island, which has a population of 35,000.

webTitle: Bullish Birmingham baits London with plans for Britain's tallest tower

fields.headline: Bullish Birmingham baits London with plans for Britain's tallest tower
fields.trailText: As Birmingham prepares to demolish its most infamous landmark, the brutalist Bull Ring shopping centre, the go-ahead is expected on a site nearby for what will be the city's boldest project so far: Britain's tallest building.
fields.body:
As Birmingham prepares to demolish its most infamous landmark, the brutalist Bull Ring shopping centre, the go-ahead is expected on a site nearby for what will be the city's boldest project so far: Britain's tallest building.

The regeneration minister, Beverley Hughes, said this week that the environment secretary, John Prescott, will announce next month whether the city council and a developer can go ahead with the £350m Arena Central project.

At the heart of the 14-acre redevelopment is a plan for a 50-storey skyscraper a few feet higher than the 777ft Canary Wharf tower in London's docklands. It has won the backing of most Brummies, including the Labour council.

"We are confident that Mr Prescott will respond to the overwhelming support for this regeneration project," said Martin Field, of the developers Hampton Trust, yesterday.

Local planners, anxious to go one better than rival cities, urged the developer to think big, and abandon the original idea of a modest 25-storey tower.

"This is a statement Birmingham is going to have to make about its future," said Albert Bore, the leader of the city council, confidently.

The developer is certainly not selling Arena Central short. It talks of Birmingham preparing to take its place among the world's great landmark cities with an "internationally renowned development of unquestionable architectural stature" that would take its place on the international stage alongside the Sydney opera house, the Eiffel tower, and the Empire State building.

The senior architect, Pierre Baillargeon, from the international practice HOK, said the proposed design had broken away from a conventional, box-like structure with a "very sculptural form, triangular with a slight rounded inflection.

"Consequently, it's a bit more slender than you usually see ... and a very strong landmark ... a very powerful icon that will bring identity to the city," he added.

Dwarfing surrounding buildings, it will be seen from at least 20 miles away as a spacecraft-style structure topped with a long spike - handy, perhaps, to make Arena Central marginally taller than its rival in London.

The building will be the first "mixed use" skyscraper in Europe - incorporating offices, an hotel, flats, and penthouses. Other tall buildings, such as Canary Wharf and Commerzbank's 981ft extravaganza in Frankfurt, are invariably office blocks.

Mr Field denied that his project represented a race for the sky.

"Obviously, everyone wants to say it is going to be taller than Canary Wharf," he smiled. "Everyone in Birmingham would love it to be taller... they feel they have been second best for too long."

He believed that Arena Central, which will also incorporate a plaza, shops and entertainment, and lots of water below a big glass roof, would be a match for London. "We're creating a new urban living and working quarter, Covent Garden and Leicester Square rolled into one, and a new heart for the city.

"At present Birmingham doesn't have a central quarter where you can say 'It's all happening'."

webTitle: The production line behind 30,000 meals a night

fields.headline: The production line behind 30,000 meals a night
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: It's 2am in one of Britain's biggest and most hygienic chicken factories. Clean, bright, light and noisy. The 200 nightshift workers are knuckling down to the last hours of the "gulag" shift, exhausted and desensitised, pretty miserable. With luck we shall earn £40 tonight.
fields.body:
It's 2am in one of Britain's biggest and most hygienic chicken factories. Clean, bright, light and noisy. The 200 nightshift workers are knuckling down to the last hours of the "gulag" shift, exhausted and desensitised, pretty miserable. With luck we shall earn £40 tonight.

The live chickens have been trucked in from up to 300 miles away and scurry out of their crates like vermin.

Many are barely able to walk because their feet are so weak. Most panic and defecate everywhere as the shacklers catch them and string them up on a line which runs through the factory.

First they pass through a bath of electrocuted water. They emerge stunned, but the odd one is still very much alive.

The belt continues into the "killing room", a noisy, smelly and bloody place where giant blades, by now clogged with flesh and bone, feathers and blood, shear off their heads and then their feet. They fall into great plastic skips. The workers are covered in blood, their spattered white coats stink.

The line grinds and jerks on inexorably, the carcasses swinging with the motion. They move to a scalding tank which loosens their feathers. Faeces and dirt wash out and by the end of the shift the contents of the tank resemble a vile smelling chocolate stew.

On they go to the de-feathering machine, whose cogs are partly coated with feathers, fat and skin. The birds are sprayed with a chlorine solution.

From defeathering, they pass to the evisceration room where their guts and organs are blasted out with water. It is messy.

The line goes on, at different speeds depending on the production schedule. Now it is picking up to about 7,000 chickens an hour and the factory's trussers and packers are working flat out.

The carcasses shoot off the line into work stations. The first man saws down their legs to stumps, and chucks the birds on to a conveyor belt.

We inspect them cursorily, bend their wings and legs, shape them for packing. Sometimes a wing is broken and sticks through the flesh. Occasionally, the cold pimply flesh has pink blotches, a possible sign of contamination.

They take hygiene seriously here but at this time of night, after six hours standing doing the same monotonous job, we are like robots and some of us are past caring.

The company is proud of its hygiene record. Only one in 20 of the birds have salmonella, they say.

We are told many times to reject anything doubtful but clearly the odd contaminated bird gets through. Men regularly hose down the floors. In the background are two inspectors, both employed by the company.

The best way to check for contamination like salmonella, septicaemia, campylobacter is to check the heart or the guts or, better still, put them under a microscope.

But the birds are passing through so fast that the inspectors can only take the odd sample.

The shift ends. We smell vile. We wash our hands and boots.

Another 30,000 chickens will be in the shops tomorrow.

fields.headline: Holidaymakers buy money early
fields.trailText: British holidaymakers are buying foreign currency months before their summer vacations to take advantage of the soaring value of sterling, travel firms reported yesterday.
fields.body:
British holidaymakers are buying foreign currency months before their summer vacations to take advantage of the soaring value of sterling, travel firms reported yesterday.

Thomas Cook's sales of Spanish pesetas are up 46% on a year ago, with holidaymakers picking up 264 pesetas for £1, compared with 230 this time last year. The pound has leapt 14% against the euro over the past year, bringing down the cost of a week's car hire in Spain from £130 to £120, and a bottle of house wine from £3.70 to £3.45. This week the euro tumbled to a record low, and is now worth around 60p compared with 70p at its launch on January 1 1999.

Few holidaymakers expect the pound's strength to last, in line with forecasts by City experts. This week the investment bank Goldman Sachs issued a report predicting that the pound would fall by 10% by August. It says British visitors to Paris enjoying a rate of 10 francs to the pound are likely to obtain nine francs or less this summer.

The euro reached new lows against the dollar and the pound yesterday, falling to 97.63 cents against the US currency before recovering slightly to close in London at 98 cents. The euro sank to 60.26p against the pound.

fields.headline: Having chicken for Sunday lunch?
fields.standfirst:
British abattoirs are dirty, badly run and poorly monitored say Brussels vets

What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: The way Britain kills its chickens for the nation's dinner tables was last night condemned by vets for the European Commission.
fields.body:
The way Britain kills its chickens for the nation's dinner tables was last night condemned by vets for the European Commission. They said that the country's most popular meat - accounting for 40% of all meat eaten - was being processed under unhygienic and poorly supervised conditions. Their devastating report, which has prompted the commission to consider legal action against the government, lists dirty equipment and knives, mouldy ceilings and walls, and inadequate inspection of birds through the slaughtering process.

The vets reported "severe deficiencies" in factories which pluck, kill, cut and pack 700m chickens a year and said Britain was breaking commission rules because vets were not in permanent attendance and sometimes lacked the right qualifications.

The inspectors also said Britain's own checks at abattoirs were unsatisfactory and there was a risk that UK government inspectors were being pressurised by their managers and owners to give higher hygiene scores than were warranted.

The industry last night admitted that some failures at the plants were "unacceptable" but blamed other shortcomings on "outdated" European rules which would waste resources. Britain has recently had to employ vets from Spain and elsewhere in Europe for its sheep and cattle abattoirs because they too were understaffed.

More training

The ministry of agriculture has written to all poultry meat plants about improving standards and wants vets to offer more training in basic hygiene. A ministry spokesman said: "The report did highlight some problems that we are now working with the commission to address."

But food safety expert Tim Lang of Thames Valley university said the findings raised "fundamental questions" about poultry plant safety and the way the government checked the industry. He criticised the ministry letter, saying it smacked of "the worst time of the 1980s food scandals when the ministry's reflex was to have cosy chats with industry rather than lay down the law".

The meat hygiene service, which is responsible for monitoring abattoir standards, is being transferred to the food standards agency in April and Professor Lang wants assurances that "such sloppiness is not carried over into the agency".

Standards in Britain's poultry industry have been under attack for years following salmonella and other food scares. The Guardian exposed many of the failings highlighted by the EC vets in a special investigation last year. Poultry chiefs insist they have done much to clean up their act, including the phasing-out of growth-promoting antibiotics.

The vets' report, whose existence was revealed yesterday by Environmental Health News, a trade paper, raised concerns about the speed of production lines. They said there were neither enough government inspectors nor industry-appointed inspection assistants to check the body, offals and cavities of the birds.

The vets, which visited eight of 155 British poultry slaughterhouses along with a handful of poultry farms and other plants last August, recommended that the EC should initiate legal action against Britain because it was infringing EC law on approval of meat factories and checks on poultry before they left farms.

In a long-running row with the EC, Britain has suggested that measures such as protecting the health of flocks are more important than trying to look at every bird on production lines that sometimes carry up to 9,000 birds an hour.

Peter Bradnock, of the British Poultry Meat Federation , said the lack of full-time veterinary presence had "no bearing on the safety of poultry meat being produced or on the considerable extent of the inspection and controls already in place to safeguard public health". It was EC legislation that needed to be changed.

What the EC vets say is wrong

Dirty equipment

Poor hygiene

Dirty floors, walls and ceilings

Lines move too fast for proper checks on dead birds

Lack of protective clothing for staff

Insufficient paperwork

Insufficient veterinary supervision
