webTitle: Mallon tells IRA: choose arms or elections

fields.headline: Mallon tells IRA: choose arms or elections
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Seamus Mallon, Northern Ireland's nationalist deputy first minister, yesterday issued a stark message to republicans that they must now choose between democracy or terror as the peace process faced a make or break few days.
fields.body:
Seamus Mallon, Northern Ireland's nationalist deputy first minister, yesterday issued a stark message to republicans that they must now choose between democracy or terror as the peace process faced a make or break few days.

Mr Mallon, deputy leader of the SDLP, piled the pressure on Sinn Fein with a hard-hitting statement ahead of Monday's report from General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning. It is expected that the general will be unable to say IRA decommissioning is under way, plunging the peace process into crisis once again.

First minister David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, has already forced a debate in the Northern Ireland assembly on Tuesday on Gen de Chastelain's report. He wants Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to suspend the eight-week-old institutions and reimpose direct rule if the IRA fails to deliver.

Mr Mallon, who had previously refused to take sides on the arms controversy, referred to the "understandings and expectations" in former US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement which broke the impasse on decommissioning. Mr Trimble agreed to devolution, believing IRA arms would soon follow.

Mr Mallon said: "This is a time of choice for the republican movement.

"It cannot continue forever to hedge its bets, to claim the benefits of the ballot box while at the same time denying the imperative to decommission; to organise intimidation and street protest while at the same time exercising the prerogative of executive authority. It cannot continue to claim to act on behalf of the people of Ireland while defying their clearly expressed will that decommissioning happen now."

Mr Mallon's statement came after Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, pleaded for more time for the IRA. It raises for the first time the prospect that the SDLP has shifted policy and would form an executive without Sinn Fein ahead of May's deadline for the completion of decommissioning.

Mr Adams said that suspending the institutions now would make IRA decommissioning less likely, and warned that it could scupper the peace process. He blamed Mr Trimble for setting a unilateral deadline for a start to IRA de commissioning 21 months after the agreement was reached.

In November, Mr Trimble won the backing of his ruling Ulster Unionist council to go into the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein - but only after telling the council that he would resign if there had been no start to IRA decommissioning before the council reconvened on February 12.

Party sources claim they understood the IRA would move by the end of this month. Sir Reg Empey, the Ulster Unionists' chief negotiator, said: "Unionists have been stretched to and beyond limit after limit. Our patience is completely exhausted in this matter. What more can we do? There is not a single thing that we are obligated to do under the Good Friday agreement that we have not done."

But Mitchel McLaughlin, Sinn Fein's chairman, said: "Experience, just commonsense, tells us that the IRA are not going to respond to deadlines set by the Unionists."

Mr Mandelson has indicated he will suspend the institutions if the IRA defaults on decommissioning. But he has refused to indicate when he will make that decision.

Sinn Fein, which reiterates that settling the arms issue is up to him, would find it difficult to argue against such a move.

fields.bodyText: Seamus Mallon, Northern Ireland's nationalist deputy first minister, yesterday issued a stark message to republicans that they must now choose between democracy or terror as the peace process faced a make or break few days. Mr Mallon, deputy leader of the SDLP, piled the pressure on Sinn Fein with a hard-hitting statement ahead of Monday's report from General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning. It is expected that the general will be unable to say IRA decommissioning is under way, plunging the peace process into crisis once again. First minister David Trimble, leader of the Ulster Unionists, has already forced a debate in the Northern Ireland assembly on Tuesday on Gen de Chastelain's report. He wants Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to suspend the eight-week-old institutions and reimpose direct rule if the IRA fails to deliver. Mr Mallon, who had previously refused to take sides on the arms controversy, referred to the "understandings and expectations" in former US senator George Mitchell's review of the Good Friday agreement which broke the impasse on decommissioning. Mr Trimble agreed to devolution, believing IRA arms would soon follow. Mr Mallon said: "This is a time of choice for the republican movement. "It cannot continue forever to hedge its bets, to claim the benefits of the ballot box while at the same time denying the imperative to decommission; to organise intimidation and street protest while at the same time exercising the prerogative of executive authority. It cannot continue to claim to act on behalf of the people of Ireland while defying their clearly expressed will that decommissioning happen now." Mr Mallon's statement came after Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, pleaded for more time for the IRA. It raises for the first time the prospect that the SDLP has shifted policy and would form an executive without Sinn Fein ahead of May's deadline for the completion of decommissioning. Mr Adams said that suspending the institutions now would make IRA decommissioning less likely, and warned that it could scupper the peace process. He blamed Mr Trimble for setting a unilateral deadline for a start to IRA de commissioning 21 months after the agreement was reached. In November, Mr Trimble won the backing of his ruling Ulster Unionist council to go into the power-sharing executive with Sinn Fein - but only after telling the council that he would resign if there had been no start to IRA decommissioning before the council reconvened on February 12. Party sources claim they understood the IRA would move by the end of this month. Sir Reg Empey, the Ulster Unionists' chief negotiator, said: "Unionists have been stretched to and beyond limit after limit. Our patience is completely exhausted in this matter. What more can we do? There is not a single thing that we are obligated to do under the Good Friday agreement that we have not done." But Mitchel McLaughlin, Sinn Fein's chairman, said: "Experience, just commonsense, tells us that the IRA are not going to respond to deadlines set by the Unionists." Mr Mandelson has indicated he will suspend the institutions if the IRA defaults on decommissioning. But he has refused to indicate when he will make that decision. While Gen de Chastelain will be unable to announce IRA decommissioning is under way, he is expected to emphasise positive engagement with the IRA's linkman. He is believed to be Brian Keenan, 57, the army council member who once said the only decommissioning he wanted was of the British presence in Ireland. Gen de Chastelain may stipulate a date by which decommissioning must start if it is to be completed by May. Sinn Fein, which reiterates that settling the arms issue is up to him, would find it difficult to argue against such a move. Meanwhile, John White, one of the Ulster Freedom Fighters' linkmen to Gen de Chastelain, called yesterday for the UFF to decommission immediately. He said that would pile the pressure on the IRA, and would make it clear who was to blame if the peace process crashed.

webTitle: We must be more radical, Blair admits

fields.headline: We must be more radical, Blair admits
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair admits today that one of the biggest mistakes of his first 1,000 days in government was failing to push hard enough for reform of key public services such as health and education.
fields.body:
Tony Blair admits today that one of the biggest mistakes of his first 1,000 days in government was failing to push hard enough for reform of key public services such as health and education.

In an exclusive interview with the Guardian, the prime minister denies the widely held view among Labour MPs and supporters that his government is running into trouble with voters because it stuck too tightly to spending plans inherited from the Tories in 1997.

"How many times do people want to learn the lessons of Labour history? The reason why the economy is performing well is not luck or chance. It is because we took major decisions to make it perform well," he says.

That has not only meant policy changes such as independence for the Bank of England: it has meant building trust and credibility and not "increasing spending one year and cutting it the next" - as previous Labour governments were forced to do.

Pledging himself to a radical election manifesto that will deliver improvements "in a quicker and more effective way" if he is re-elected, Mr Blair also rejects claims that his managerial administration lacks an inspiring big idea.

He insists that his vision of an economically efficient and socially just society is a "pretty big message" to inspire the support of restless activists.

Wary of specific pledges after last week's "aspiration" to raise NHS spending to EU average levels by 2006, Mr Blair argues: "Despite short-term difficulties caused by tight spending policies for two years, I really promise people in the Labour party that it is better for us in the long term. We have greater credibility to govern, we have greater trust and we can provide investment step by step in a way that is sustainable."

Mr Blair, who flew yesterday to the world economic forum in Davos, where he told fellow leaders that the EU must also pull its reformist socks up, refuses in the interview to say what he thinks has been his worst error in government. "It's my business to know and yours to find out," he says.

The prime minister renews his plea to party activists in London not to slide back towards "infantile gesture politics" by picking Ken Livingstone as their candidate for mayor - because he would stand up to Downing Street.

Mr Blair argues: "Where the government has reformed, that is where we have worked best" - in pushing initiatives such as welfare to work, higher schools standards and NHS Direct.

"Driving forward reform is the most important part. Every bit of reform we have done, certainly in relation to the public services and welfare, I'll never regret. The task of government is to become more comfortable with driving forward the government machine to step up the pace of reform. So if you say to me what have I learned in these 1,000 days, it is that reform is right. If anything we need more of it."

The idea that Labour could have spent more generously earlier is dismissed. There was a huge deficit to pay off and "we had to make sure we ran the economy stably in case there was a downturn, without a recession, which we achieved".

Now the government can "build on the foundations of a solid stable economy". Unlike previous Labour governments, this one will increase spending on health and education "year on year on year".

fields.headline: Stalkers
fields.standfirst: Stalkers don't torment only the rich and famous. Anyone can find themselves a target. It is a chilling experience that is becoming ever more common, reports Sean O'Hagan
fields.trailText: Stalkers don't torment only the rich and famous. Anyone can find themselves a target. It is a chilling experience that is becoming ever more common, reports Sean O'Hagan
fields.body:
It begins with the discovery of an unaddressed, unstamped envelope in the morning post at an east London house. The owner, who we shall call Peter, picks it up, thinking it is just more unsolicited junk mail. It reeks of cheap perfume. Inside, is a handwritten letter that begins, "Dear Ewen..." It reads like a teenage love letter to a famous person. There is no clue as to the sender's identity, save for an illegible signature. Peter assumes that it has been put through the wrong letterbox; he throws it aside and forgets all about it. A few days later, another hand-delivered letter arrives. Again, it smells heavily of perfume and begins, "Dear Ewen..." Intrigued now, Peter compares it to the first letter: same handwriting, same scrawled signature. This time, however, there is a marked difference in the tone, which is more plaintive, forlorn even, the writer pleading for a meeting with her object of desire. Peter studies the signature; he thinks it reads "Angel".

Over the next few weeks, the letters keep arriving, fitfully at first, then virtually every day. Peter's initial bemusement turns to anger - his wife, Joan, is eight months pregnant, and the last thing they need is some nutter bombarding the house with letters to someone who doesn't even live there. Peter keeps watch at various times, but never catches sight of anyone loitering near the house. Then, one day, a bunch of flowers and another letter are put through the letterbox. A few nights later, Joan is awoken by the sound of a tremulous female voice reciting a poem - or it might be a prayer? - outside. It is 3am. She wakes Peter. As he stumbles to the window, they hear the sound of footsteps scurrying away.

Joan is now spooked, and finds it hard to be alone in the house. Peter takes the next day off work and, in the afternoon, sees a young woman hanging around on the corner opposite. He runs down into the street, but she has disappeared. Nothing happens for a few days, but it soon starts up again: irregular letters, flowers, all usually delivered in the dead of night. Once, Peter brings some flowers of his own home to cheer up his wife. He places them in a vase by the window. That night, he finds a note in his hall: "I saw the sign you left in the window for me. I know you want me." Peter says nothing to his wife, but, before going to bed, he snatches up the pile of letters and throws them into the street. It makes him feel better. Until morning, that is, when they are again piled up in the hallway. Furious now, he throws them in the bin. Then he does what he should have done weeks before. He calls the police.

"It sounds stupid," Peter says now, "but, for a long time, I didn't take it seriously. There are a lot of benign nutters on the streets. I guess I thought it would just stop." A policeman duly calls and tells them that he'll keep an eye on the house, but that there is not much more that the police can do without hard evidence and Peter, ironically, has destroyed it.

A few days later, alone in the house, Joan is woken from an afternoon nap by the cat leaping on to the bed beside her. Instinctively, she reaches out to stroke it. She recoils at once: in its mouth, the cat is carrying a pair of blood-stained knickers wrapped in a pink bow. Joan freaks out and runs out of the house. Distraught, she rings Peter from the high street. She refuses to go home. Peter rings the police again and "goes ballistic". It works. "I don't know if they just didn't believe me before, but as soon as they saw the knickers everything changed. We were interviewed by a very attentive and sympathetic woman PC. By now, though, I was at the end of my tether. I just wanted this deluded woman out of my life."

For a while, it seems as if his wish had been granted. There are no letters, no flowers. Peter organises a rota of friends to drop by to keep Joan company. Then, one morning, when she is expecting a neighbour to call, she opens the door to a stranger. A young, heavily made-up woman pushes past her into the house, oblivious to Joan's protests. She disappears up the stairs, leaving in her wake a familiar scent. Joan freezes. She can hear the bath being run upstairs and, unbelievably, the stranger singing merrily to herself. Joan grabs her mobile phone and runs into the street, where she rings first the police and then her husband. By the time Peter arrives home, police and paramedics are trying to coax a half-naked young woman down off the roof terrace. Except that she is not a young woman at all, but a young man in drag. He/she is eventually sedated and carried out of Peter's house on a stretcher. It feels like the end of a nightmare.

Although the names and location have been changed, this is the record of a recent stalking that lasted about three months. I know all about it not through journalistic investigation but because it happened to friends of mine. At one of the happiest moments of their life - the birth of their first child - their world was thrown out of kilter by a stranger who, without the slightest evidence, had become fixated on the idea that a celebrity lived in their house. It would be absurd - laughable, even - were it not so frightening. "It's strange," Peter tells me when things no longer seem so fraught, so unremitting, "but she seemed to be stalking the house, rather than us. I suppose she probably never meant us any harm." I nod reassuringly, but, deep down, I'm thinking, who knows? Who knows what someone that deluded and that obsessive might be thinking? Or, indeed, might do?

When I first heard about Peter's predicament, I thought that, maybe, I could find out. My plan was to hang around near Peter's house until I saw this irrational individual push a letter or flowers through the letterbox, then, in true investigative fashion, I would confront him/her, and demand to know what he/she thought he/she was playing at. That would have been a big mistake.

Why? Listen to Lorraine Sheridan, a psychologist at Leicester University, who has been collating statistical data on stalkers' victims: "Stalkers are often obsessional and deluded," she says. "To think that you can talk to them rationally about what they are doing is also deluded. Simply going up to a stalker in the street and asking them to explain themselves would probably be fruitless and, more to the point, could well be dangerous. First up, you are giving them attention, which, in their eyes, could well be a kind of vindication of their behaviour. Second, the stalking of a particular individual often stops only when the stalker becomes attached to someone else, usually someone who has given them attention."

Or there's the testimony of Dr Edward Petch, a forensic psychologist who works in the secure unit of Ealing Hospital and who has seen more than his fair share of disturbed individuals. "I deal with mentally-disordered offenders from the more violent end of the spectrum: murderers, rapists, sometimes multiple killers," he says. "But, in terms of my own safety, it's the stalkers who keep me awake at night. I find myself worrying about what they are capable of, and the degree of their disturbance, trying to establish what it is that is driving them. There is often a separate quality to them, an inability to acknowledge that what they are doing is wrong, or to see the effects it is having on their victims. That is quite chilling."

In terms of media attention, stalking is the crime of the moment. It is also, despite the recent deluge of cases concerning ordinary individuals, fixed firmly in the public consciousness as a crime against celebrities. Writing in this paper last year, the psychiatrist Dr Raj Persaud claimed provocatively that having a stalker was the ultimate fashion accessory. I doubt that Monica Seles (stabbed by Günther Parche, who had a long-term obsession with Steffi Graf) or Madonna (stalked for five years by Robert Dewey Hoskins, who threatened to slice her "from ear to ear" unless she married him) would agree with him.

Sometimes, the media reports have a surreal element: the weatherman, Bill Giles, stalked by his own niece; the actor, Michael J Fox, pestered by a fan who sent him more than 5,000 letters, usually filled with rabbit droppings; Klaus Wagner, who followed Princess Diana to protect her from a "Satan conspiracy" supposedly waged against her by the Queen - "Elizardbeast, we are 666 of you" read one of his many bizarre placards. More often, however, the stories confirm Petch's conclusion that there is something uniquely chilling about stalkers and their methods: the widow of murdered headmaster, Philip Lawrence, stalked by a stranger wearing a hood; Ulrika Jonsson, bombarded with obscene phone calls and nude photos by Peter Casey, who threw himself under a train after police questioning; Lady Helen Taylor, stalked by Simon Reynolds, who also committed suicide. A few weeks ago, 30-year-old Jeremy Dyer was jailed for two-and-a-half years for stalking TV newsreader, Sarah Lockett - his campaign included bombarding her with 80 obscene letters, two of which alluded to the recent death of another newsreader, Jill Dando: "I think the whole Jill Dando thing is great. I was hoping a celebrity would be murdered by a stalker, and it makes it even better that she read the news."

Some experts, Petch among them, even claim that our society inadvertently encourages stalking, whether through the pursuit of the famous by the tabloids and the paparazzi - remember, for instance, the short-lived debate about whether Princess Diana was stalked to death? - or in the more collusive intrusions in magazines such as Hello! and OK!. Here, a carefully staged intimacy is sold to the highest bidder, often by those same stars who bemoan media incursions into their privacy. "Those magazines peddle a kind of titillation," says Petch. "If you see a star stretched out on her bed in her house, you can fantasise that you know her intimately because you know what her bedroom looks like. Those kind of images foster a false sense of intimacy and even identification. The fan-celebrity relationship is a very confused one in our society because we are encouraged to think that we know so much about the famous when, in effect, we know very little."

So, on one quite complex level, a celebrity, as defined in the pages of Hello!, say, is a stranger whom we think we know; a stranger, what's more, who encourages our gaze, whose very being is tied up with our fascination with them. Is it any wonder, then, that celebrities often attract strangers who are convinced that, should the object of their devotion simply meet them, a bond will immediately be formed, a special intimacy born? When this turns out not to be the case, fan worship often mutates into a different, darker kind of obsession. Steven Spielberg is only one of many celebrities who have had to seek court restriction orders to deal with obsessive fans whose fascination seems somehow linked to fantasies of revenge and punishment. Spielberg's stalker, who on one occasion tried to ram the security gates of the director's Malibu home, was recently apprehended lurking near the house. In his car boot, the police found handcuffs, industrial adhesive tape, a knife and a collection of syringes.

Stalking might appear to be a quintessentially contemporary crime, a phenomenon linked to our culture's collective and seemingly insatiable obsession with the minutiae of the celebrity lifestyle. In fact, the activity is neither new, nor is it a crime more likely to happen to the famous than to those engaged in more "ordinary" careers - though some evidence suggests that certain professions attract an above-average degree of stalkers, including, perhaps predictably, actors and politicians and, perhaps surprisingly, doctors.

"Stalking has probably been going on for hundreds of years," says Petch. "It seems like a recent phenomenon probably because our ability to detect it has improved of late. That said, most cases involving ordinary people don't come to the attention of the courts at all, either because the stalkers haven't broken any laws - standing on a corner or sending flowers is not breaking the law, necessarily - or the stalker is convicted for some single thing that they have done in the course of their stalking, maybe breaking-and-entering or making an obscene phone call, and it's not recorded as a crime of stalking. I'd say it is probably a lot more prevalent than we think."

Petch's overview is borne out by the increasing number of cases that are reported in the press concerning ordinary people who, without recourse to the kind of security and protection that celebrities can afford, often undergo prolonged ordeals of the most nightmarish kind. My friends' experience, though intrusive and frightening, was a relatively low-level persecution compared with some recently reported incidences: the dental nurse, Perry Southall, who was stalked by Clarence Morris, a convicted rapist, for eight months and endured 200 incidents of harassment; 13-year-old Maria Cross, who was followed relentlessly by unemployed loner Stephen Gomes; David Greenhaulgh, who was obsessively pursued by Anita Hall (when she was prevented from entering his workplace, she poured petrol over two receptionists and tried to set them alight).

A 1977 survey carried out by NOP Solutions found that 19% of women and 8% of men in the UK had experienced threatening behaviour of the kind associated with stalking; that 25% of all respondents said that they knew someone who had been a victim of stalking, either face to face or through persistent phone calls. In the US, meanwhile, an estimated 8% of women have been stalked at some time, more than 1 million women are stalked annually, and an estimated one in six of women murdered each year have first been stalked.

Stalking is a crime that, as Peter and Joan found out, often begins without motive, escalates in occurrence and in intensity, and, in many cases, continues for years rather than months. Many of the recorded stalkings in the UK have lasted between five and seven years, though Lorraine Sheridan at Leicester University told me of one woman she had uncovered in her research who had been stalked for 40 years. "Research about stalking is still in its infancy," says Petch, "so there is not a lot we can say with absolute certainty about the activity. Except this: stalking persists."

In the shorter Oxford English Dictionary, stalking is defined simply as "walking cautiously or stealthily. Pursuing a quarry or game by stealthy approach, especially undercover." The stalking of human quarry, however, is an activity that resists such easy definition. Australian psychologists, Michele Pathe and Paul Mullan, who have studied the subject, write: "Stalking describes a constellation of behaviours in which one individual inflicts on another repeated unwanted intrusions and communications. The intrusions can involve following, loitering nearby, maintaining surveillance and making approaches. The communication can be through letters, the telephone, electronic mail, graffiti, or notes attached, for example, to the victim's car... Specific or implied threats to the safety of the objects of these attentions may be made, and physical and sexual assaults may also occur. Third parties, including friends and relatives of the victim, may also attract threats and violence from the stalker."

Finding a workable legal definition has proved more difficult. In the US, it was the burgeoning threat to celebrities from stalkers that brought about Section 646, Part 9, of the Californian Penal Code, which defines a stalker as "any person who wilfully, maliciously and repeatedly follows and harasses another person and who makes a credible threat with the intent to place that person in reasonable fear for his or her safety". To date, 29 states have implemented stalking laws, and Los Angeles - where else? - has set up a Police Threat Management Unit specifically to deal with the crime.

The US definition has proved problematic not least because it requires proof of intent and, thus, puts the onus on the victim. Ironically, many stalkers have no intention of harming their object or, indeed, any understanding of the harm they are causing. (One of the most common delusions that prompts stalking is erotomania, which, put simply, is the false belief that someone else loves you, when there is no evidence to support that belief. Erotomaniacs make up about 10% of all stalkers and, as Petch points out, "their misguided belief in the certainty of their cause is a classic illustration of the folly of including the notion of intent in the law".)

The case that changed the law in the UK concerned Tracey Morgan, who was stalked by Anthony Burstow, a casual acquaintance, for seven years. Burstow was someone whose sole intention was to cause severe distress. "I wanted to muck around with her head," he told the police. "That's what this is all about." His sustained campaign of terror included threatening phone calls and letters, veiled death threats, constant surveillance of her house, pouring oil on her car, covering her lawn with condoms, sending her sanitary towels in the post and breaking into her home to plant listening devices in the bedroom. When the police arrested him, they found a vast collection of medical paraphernalia in his house, including syringes, needles, a blood-transfusion kit and details of his future plans, which included sending her spiders and snails through the post.

In a recent television documentary, I'll Be Watching You, Morgan summed up the mental and physical cost of this harassment thus: "In a cruel and arbitrary way, I was isolated and rendered unable to function properly. I was simply destroyed by someone who was fixated on me, and left bewildered, frightened and without any real protection."

The ordeal cost Morgan her health, her house (she moved cities three times) and her marriage, but, in the end, through sheer force of will, she triumphed by going public and illustrating the huge gap in the law that allowed all this to happen. In 1996, Burstow was the first person ever to be charged with Grevious Mental Harm. He was found guilty and jailed for five years. Still, his persecution of Morgan continued: from his cell, he sent her an elaborate crossword puzzle wherein each clue referred to private, often intimate, information about her family; and later, while still in prison, he was arrested for soliciting to murder after guards found out that he had approached fellow criminals offering them £3,500 to kill Tracey's husband-to-be.

The year after Burstow's conviction, the government controversially pushed through the Protection From Harassment Act, a carefully-worded, wide-ranging piece of legislation that, though created to deal with the problem of stalking, studiously avoided using the term at all, so complex were the problems of definition. Sheridan, in her research paper, Stalking: Perceptions And Prevalence, points out that, even though the law was passed, "a legal definition of stalking was never provided, and no accepted definition of stalking currently exists".

The two main concerns about the act's enforceability are that it does not clarify what, exactly, constitutes the criminal act of stalking, and that it does not distinguish between the dangerous stalker and what one expert calls "the misguided fool wallowing in the anguish of betrayal". Surprisingly, much of the press reaction to the act concentrated on the possible effect it might have on what one writer called "persistent suitors", rather than on the protection of the victim. Mary Kenny, for instance, writing in the Express, claimed that, "Women are being turned into powerless, infantile victims encouraged to cry, 'Ma, he's making eyes at me!' and run for the protection of the State to deal with every vexatious private encounter... Even Romeo could be up before the beak for standing under Juliet's window."

But research has shown that people are reluctant to go to the law for help where stalking is concerned, particularily if they are being harassed by someone they know. And, as Sheridan notes, both the aforementioned concerns about the law have already been borne out in practice, but not thus far in the way Kenny predicted. "One of the first cases to be brought under the new act failed after a judge ruled that 'it was not a crime to court somebody'," she says. "This was despite allegations that the defendant had kept his victim under almost constant surveillance, and had bombarded her with unwanted gifts and letters over a two-year period, forcing her to move to another country. The judge ruled that the defendant's actions were innocuous, as no violent act had been committed."

The problem here is that one person's justified pursuit of a former lover is another person's unwarranted harassment. Somehow, the law has to decide, among other things, the point at which the former becomes the latter. Additionally, many of the activities associated with stalking are, of themselves, innocuous - sending flowers, for example - but, when repeated daily and combined with a whole range of other seemingly innocuous activities (love letters, hanging around, turning up in the same pub as if by accident) become intrusive and unsettling to the person on the receiving end of the unwanted attention.

Matters are complicated further by the fact that most of us, at some time or another - in the white heat of first love, say, or the intensity of adolescent infatuation - have probaly behaved, for a short while at least, just as a stalker might. We may have followed our object of devotion home more than once, or loitered around near their home. Does this irrationality in the face of extreme emotional turmoil - which is only an innately human response, after all - make everyone of us potential stalkers?

"Most people you speak to will eventually admit that they have been through this experience, either as object or as perpetrator," says Petch. "We will all, at one time or another, have displayed certain traits that could be defined as stalking. The thing is, though, that there is a borderline that most of us do not cross. Stalking is about a persistent or repetitive pattern of behaviour that almost always escalates in intensity until it becomes intrusive in a constant and often unrelenting way. It is up to the law to establish when that line is crossed. Judges and the police should have increased training in the uses of the Protection From Harrassment Act. It will be two or three years before we know whether it is working effectively, but, as it stands, many people who should know about it remain relatively ignorant."

To this end, Detective Inspector Hamish Brown of the Metropolitan Police is compiling a handbook on police procedure relating to stalkers, and at least one lawyer is writing a book on the ramifications of the act. His advice is simple: "People should contact the police as soon as possible if there is any repetition. It helps immensely if victims keep a log or diary of what has happened to them, but the main thing is that they should come forward and alert the police as soon as possible."

Nonetheless, stalking remains an elusive and complex crime, one that is both relatively easy to commit and relatively difficult to define, never mind prosecute. All of which must make it the most talked-about yet least understood crime of modern times. Here are some of the facts we know about stalking. More than 75% of stalkers are men who stalk women. Stalkers tend to be older than other criminal offenders, and to be loners. They also tend to be more intelligent and more resourceful than the average criminal, and better educated than other groups of offenders with mental disorders. An estimated 22% of stalkings are violent - 2% of all homicides in the US are stalking-related.

Professor Paul Mullen, an Australian psychologist, has divided stalkers into five categories: (1) Intimacy Seekers - those who attempt to form a relationship with their object or victim. These are often celebrity stalkers. They can suffer from erotomania or harbour a morbid fascination with their objects. (2) The Rejected - individuals who were once intimate with their victims, usually ex-partners, but often just friends or business associates. Stalking begins at the break-up of the relationship and, often, initial attempts at reconciliation turn into a quest for revenge. A fixation on the failed relationship exacerbates their behaviour and prevents them from forming other meaningful relationships. This is the largest group of stalkers, and the most likely to be violent. (3) The Resentful - the basic motivation is revenge. The intention is to frighten and distress the victim. Often, there is no prior intimate relationship, and professionals (doctors, lawyers, politicians) are the usual targets. These stalkers are often intent on punishing an organisation, so damage to property is common; they are more likely to specialise in frightening encounters than assault. (4) The Predatory - those who stalk prior to a sexual attack. They will derive excitement and sexual pleasure from planning an attack. Often driven by deviant desires and with a history of prior offending. (5) The Incompetent - individuals with a lack of general social confidence and an inability to form intimate, meaningful relationships. To compensate, they form a distant relationship with a love object. The relationship is never consummated, therefore never threatening to them.

According to Petch, the most dangerous type of stalker, and the most difficult to treat, is one whose motivation is, or includes, revenge: "Often, they are individuals who I would class as morbidly querulous. They tend to be argumentative, paranoid and often highly intelligent, with a morbid preoccupation with their own rights and little regard for the feelings or opinions of others. These individuals often have a warped perception of injustice based on fairly neutral events and are out to get revenge. They are definitely the most difficult to treat."

But has he ever treated a stalker who was simply a stalker - that is, someone who had no underlying psychiatric disorder? "No. Stalking is a behaviour, not a condition. A very high proportion of stalkers will be mentally ill; maybe 75% will have a psychological abnormality. It's common sense, but it needs to be stated. All psychiatric diagnoses are possible - schizophrenia, mood disorders, morbid infatuation, even substance abuse."

Fine, but that leaves 25% who, presumably, aren't mentally ill? "Well, that's where it gets complex, because they may not be mentally ill but they will almost certainly be suffering from a personality disorder of some description, probably a disorder of attachment. Any relationship is an attachment, and if that attachment is somehow abnormal - say, a fairly casual relationship that is invested with great importance - stalking may well follow. Most stalkers will have difficulties with attaching and unattaching themselves [from relationships], difficulties that stem from infancy, and they will have problems with abandonment, rejection, coping with low self esteem - all the things, in fact, that go with the ending of a relationship."

So, we are back on the shifting, often treacherous undercurrents of human relationships, trying to negotiate that ill-defined hinterland beween love and obsession. The nature of the relationship between stalker and victim is often a key determinant of the type of stalking that occurs: the closer the victim to the perpetrator, the more intense the stalking. Says Petch, "An ex-husband, say, will be more violent than a casual acquaintance. Usually. That is a broad generalisation. It will not necessarily be true in any individual case."

"Usually", and "probably", are words Petch uses a lot because, as he says time and again, "research is still in its infancy". To this end, his aim is to set up Britain's first clinic dedicated to treating stalkers. UK research has so far concentrated on collating information about the prevalence of the crime and the effect it has on victims; little or nothing is known about the response of stalkers to treatments that deal with specifically diagnosed underlying conditions such as erotomania. Stalkers, unlike murderers, are not required by law to submit to psychiatric diagnosis.

Petch is the first to admit that, if his plans come to fruition, he will be dealing with an almost unknown quantity and that, in other countries, there has not been a great success rate in the treatment and managment of stalkers. "They tend to reoffend," he says wearily, "and sometimes enforced separation through the courts is the only effective answer. Or enforced incarceration. The easiest way is not to treat them: to send them home or to lock them up. But it's worth trying. What we know for sure is that stalking is on the increase, and that we have to deal with it somehow. It makes perfect sense that we should do it sooner rather than later. We can't simply ignore it and hope it will go away," he concludes. "Just ask any victim - they will tell you that that is not what happens."

A few days after the police talked the stalker down from Peter's roof, another letter and a bunch of flowers arrive at the house, sent from a local hospital. Peter throws them into the bin. Another note arrives a few days later, then nothing. The last time I talked to him, the stalking seemed to have stopped, as suddenly and inexplicably as it began. "I hope and pray it's over," he says. "I still look out of the window from time to time - just in case. Ultimately, though, there's no way of knowing if someone is watching you. You have to assume they aren't and get on with your life. It's difficult but, the more I find out about stalking, the more I realise how lucky we are. Most victims are put through hell over and over again. It's relentless and inexplicable, and I can now see how it could affect your life forever. I don't understand it, but I do think these people need help, otherwise they'll just keep doing it. That's something I just don't want to think about right now."

fields.bodyText: It begins with the discovery of an unaddressed, unstamped envelope in the morning post at an east London house. The owner, who we shall call Peter, picks it up, thinking it is just more unsolicited junk mail. It reeks of cheap perfume. Inside, is a handwritten letter that begins, "Dear Ewen..." It reads like a teenage love letter to a famous person. There is no clue as to the sender's identity, save for an illegible signature. Peter assumes that it has been put through the wrong letterbox; he throws it aside and forgets all about it. A few days later, another hand-delivered letter arrives. Again, it smells heavily of perfume and begins, "Dear Ewen..." Intrigued now, Peter compares it to the first letter: same handwriting, same scrawled signature. This time, however, there is a marked difference in the tone, which is more plaintive, forlorn even, the writer pleading for a meeting with her object of desire. Peter studies the signature; he thinks it reads "Angel". Over the next few weeks, the letters keep arriving, fitfully at first, then virtually every day. Peter's initial bemusement turns to anger - his wife, Joan, is eight months pregnant, and the last thing they need is some nutter bombarding the house with letters to someone who doesn't even live there. Peter keeps watch at various times, but never catches sight of anyone loitering near the house. Then, one day, a bunch of flowers and another letter are put through the letterbox. A few nights later, Joan is awoken by the sound of a tremulous female voice reciting a poem - or it might be a prayer? - outside. It is 3am. She wakes Peter. As he stumbles to the window, they hear the sound of footsteps scurrying away. Joan is now spooked, and finds it hard to be alone in the house. Peter takes the next day off work and, in the afternoon, sees a young woman hanging around on the corner opposite. He runs down into the street, but she has disappeared. Nothing happens for a few days, but it soon starts up again: irregular letters, flowers, all usually delivered in the dead of night. Once, Peter brings some flowers of his own home to cheer up his wife. He places them in a vase by the window. That night, he finds a note in his hall: "I saw the sign you left in the window for me. I know you want me." Peter says nothing to his wife, but, before going to bed, he snatches up the pile of letters and throws them into the street. It makes him feel better. Until morning, that is, when they are again piled up in the hallway. Furious now, he throws them in the bin. Then he does what he should have done weeks before. He calls the police. "It sounds stupid," Peter says now, "but, for a long time, I didn't take it seriously. There are a lot of benign nutters on the streets. I guess I thought it would just stop." A policeman duly calls and tells them that he'll keep an eye on the house, but that there is not much more that the police can do without hard evidence and Peter, ironically, has destroyed it. A few days later, alone in the house, Joan is woken from an afternoon nap by the cat leaping on to the bed beside her. Instinctively, she reaches out to stroke it. She recoils at once: in its mouth, the cat is carrying a pair of blood-stained knickers wrapped in a pink bow. Joan freaks out and runs out of the house. Distraught, she rings Peter from the high street. She refuses to go home. Peter rings the police again and "goes ballistic". It works. "I don't know if they just didn't believe me before, but as soon as they saw the knickers everything changed. We were interviewed by a very attentive and sympathetic woman PC. By now, though, I was at the end of my tether. I just wanted this deluded woman out of my life." For a while, it seems as if his wish had been granted. There are no letters, no flowers. Peter organises a rota of friends to drop by to keep Joan company. Then, one morning, when she is expecting a neighbour to call, she opens the door to a stranger. A young, heavily made-up woman pushes past her into the house, oblivious to Joan's protests. She disappears up the stairs, leaving in her wake a familiar scent. Joan freezes. She can hear the bath being run upstairs and, unbelievably, the stranger singing merrily to herself. Joan grabs her mobile phone and runs into the street, where she rings first the police and then her husband. By the time Peter arrives home, police and paramedics are trying to coax a half-naked young woman down off the roof terrace. Except that she is not a young woman at all, but a young man in drag. He/she is eventually sedated and carried out of Peter's house on a stretcher. It feels like the end of a nightmare. Although the names and location have been changed, this is the record of a recent stalking that lasted about three months. I know all about it not through journalistic investigation but because it happened to friends of mine. At one of the happiest moments of their life - the birth of their first child - their world was thrown out of kilter by a stranger who, without the slightest evidence, had become fixated on the idea that a celebrity lived in their house. It would be absurd - laughable, even - were it not so frightening. "It's strange," Peter tells me when things no longer seem so fraught, so unremitting, "but she seemed to be stalking the house, rather than us. I suppose she probably never meant us any harm." I nod reassuringly, but, deep down, I'm thinking, who knows? Who knows what someone that deluded and that obsessive might be thinking? Or, indeed, might do? When I first heard about Peter's predicament, I thought that, maybe, I could find out. My plan was to hang around near Peter's house until I saw this irrational individual push a letter or flowers through the letterbox, then, in true investigative fashion, I would confront him/her, and demand to know what he/she thought he/she was playing at. That would have been a big mistake. Why? Listen to Lorraine Sheridan, a psychologist at Leicester University, who has been collating statistical data on stalkers' victims: "Stalkers are often obsessional and deluded," she says. "To think that you can talk to them rationally about what they are doing is also deluded. Simply going up to a stalker in the street and asking them to explain themselves would probably be fruitless and, more to the point, could well be dangerous. First up, you are giving them attention, which, in their eyes, could well be a kind of vindication of their behaviour. Second, the stalking of a particular individual often stops only when the stalker becomes attached to someone else, usually someone who has given them attention." Or there's the testimony of Dr Edward Petch, a forensic psychologist who works in the secure unit of Ealing Hospital and who has seen more than his fair share of disturbed individuals. "I deal with mentally-disordered offenders from the more violent end of the spectrum: murderers, rapists, sometimes multiple killers," he says. "But, in terms of my own safety, it's the stalkers who keep me awake at night. I find myself worrying about what they are capable of, and the degree of their disturbance, trying to establish what it is that is driving them. There is often a separate quality to them, an inability to acknowledge that what they are doing is wrong, or to see the effects it is having on their victims. That is quite chilling." In terms of media attention, stalking is the crime of the moment. It is also, despite the recent deluge of cases concerning ordinary individuals, fixed firmly in the public consciousness as a crime against celebrities. Writing in this paper last year, the psychiatrist Dr Raj Persaud claimed provocatively that having a stalker was the ultimate fashion accessory. I doubt that Monica Seles (stabbed by Günther Parche, who had a long-term obsession with Steffi Graf) or Madonna (stalked for five years by Robert Dewey Hoskins, who threatened to slice her "from ear to ear" unless she married him) would agree with him. So, on one quite complex level, a celebrity, as defined in the pages of Hello!, say, is a stranger whom we think we know; a stranger, what's more, who encourages our gaze, whose very being is tied up with our fascination with them. My friends' experience, though intrusive and frightening, was a relatively low-level persecution compared with some recently reported incidences: the dental nurse, Perry Southall, who was stalked by Clarence Morris, a convicted rapist, for eight months and endured 200 incidents of harassment; 13-year-old Maria Cross, who was followed relentlessly by unemployed loner Stephen Gomes; David Greenhaulgh, who was obsessively pursued by Anita Hall (when she was prevented from entering his workplace, she poured petrol over two receptionists and tried to set them alight). In the US, meanwhile, an estimated 8% of women have been stalked at some time, more than 1 million women are stalked annually, and an estimated one in six of women murdered each year have first been stalked. "Research about stalking is still in its infancy," says Petch, "so there is not a lot we can say with absolute certainty about the activity. Except this: stalking persists." "Just ask any victim - they will tell you that that is not what happens." A few days after the police talked the stalker down from Peter's roof, another letter and a bunch of flowers arrive at the house, sent from a local hospital. Peter throws them into the bin. Another note arrives a few days later, then nothing. The last time I talked to him, the stalking seemed to have stopped, as suddenly and inexplicably as it began. "I hope and pray it's over," he says. "I still look out of the window from time to time - just in case. Ultimately, though, there's no way of knowing if someone is watching you. You have to assume they aren't and get on with your life. It's difficult but, the more I find out about stalking, the more I realise how lucky we are. Most victims are put through hell over and over again. It's relentless and inexplicable, and I can now see how it could affect your life forever. I don't understand it, but I do think these people need help, otherwise they'll just keep doing it. That's something I just don't want to think about right now." fields.headline: Out of the frying pan
fields.standfirst: Hot oil is one of our favourite cooking mediums.  Len Fisher and Peter Barham explain why.  Recipes by Jeremy Lee.
fields.trailText: Hot oil is one of our favourite cooking mediums. Len Fisher and Peter Barham explain why. Recipes by Jeremy Lee.
fields.body:
The defenders of besieged castles in medieval times poured boiling oil on to their attackers below. They used boiling oil for the same reason that we use hot oil in cooking today - to carry plenty of heat to the place where it would be most effective.

Oil has an advantage over water in this respect. With boiling water, we have perfect control over the temperature, since water always boils at 100C. The downside is that this temperature is not high enough to initiate the complex Maillard reactions between the proteins and carbohydrates at the surface of food that produce browning and new flavours.

Cooking oils do not contain proteins or carbohydrates, and so do not contribute directly to the flavours in fried foods, but they can be heated to temperatures of more than 200C and are therefore ideal for promoting Maillard reactions, which begin when the temperature of the food surface reaches 150C or so.

Hot oils, like boiling water, are highly efficient at transferring heat to cooking food, because they are in direct contact with it and because they can carry a lot of heat due to their high "heat capacities". Their disadvantage lies in control of the cooking temperature. The boiling points of food oils are much too high for cooking food. Most domestic cooks - and many professional chefs, for that matter - get around this problem by checking the appearance of the oil. Is it moving smoothly? Is there a blue haze above it?

These, and other indicators, can give an approximate idea of temperature, but the best way to know how hot the oil is is to use a kitchen thermometer. Don't rely on the degree of smokiness of the oil; use a thermometer, and experience the thrill of control in the kitchen (a temperature of around 175C is perfect for most deep-frying, say). Your own experience will let you make personal modifications to suit your own taste.

Just remember that the temperature should be a little lower for larger pieces of food, so that the centre has time to reach the correct cooking temperature before the outside becomes overcooked. Remember, too, that if you double the thickness of the cooking food, it will take around four times as long for the centre to reach the optimum cooking temperature.

All of these comments apply to deep-frying. Shallow frying, is a completely different kettle of fish, metaphorically speaking - here, a thin layer of oil is used to conduct heat directly from the hot metal surface of a cooking vessel to the food. The oil also serves the purpose of stopping the food from sticking to the cooking vessel. In stir-frying, meanwhile, this protective layer of oil can drain from between the food and the pan surface if the pan is left standing - that's why you move the food around, so that the protective layer is continually renewed.

It is also a good idea to set aside a little of the used oil after you fry, be it deep or shallow. Then, next time you want to fry something, add some of the saved oil to the fresh oil. The reason? Heating breaks down vegetable oils and animal fats to produce monoglycerides, which are natural compounds that can coat the metal surface and prevent sticking. The pure, unused oils are triglycerides, and do not contain these useful monoglycerides.

Teflon-coated vessels get around many of these problems, but even then a thin layer of oil helps to distribute the heat more uniformly. Don't you just love being in control?

All recipes serve six.

Vegetable Tempura
18 French beans
1 red pepper, seeded
12-18 button mushrooms
12 spring onions
3 small courgettes
1 small aubergine
For the batter
300ml ice-cold water
1 large free-range egg
300ml by volume plain flour, sifted
For the dipping sauce
1 sachet dashi powder
200ml hot water (carnivores can use chicken stock)
1 tsp caster sugar
2 tbsp soy sauce
4 tbsp sake

First, make the dipping sauce: dissolve the dashi (get it from Asian supermarkets) in the water, and add the sugar, soy sauce and sake. Divide the sauce between four bowls. Next, prepare the vegetables (the ones listed are merely a guideline; feel free to choose your own). Top and tail the beans. Cut the pepper into strips. Remove the caps from the mushrooms. Trim the spring onions, and cut in half lengthways. Slice the aubergine into very thin lengths. Slice the courgettes.

Have to hand a large dish lined with kitchen towel. Heat a deep-fat fryer filled with clean frying oil to 190C. While the oil is heating, make the batter. Mix the egg with the water, then sift in the flour and stir. The batter is ready when it is lumpy with still-discernible traces of flour in it. Toss the vegetables in flour, dust off the excess, dip in the flour again and drop into the batter. Fry for two minutes, turning once. Drain on the kitchen towel. Cook in small batches, and continue thus until all are done. Serve immediately.

A squid salad
Equally delicious warm or cold.
1.35kg squid, cleaned
2 red peppers
2 red chillies
35g pinenuts
35g raisins
25g capers
2 tbsp red-wine vinegar
6 tbsp top-quality olive oil
1 handful flat-leaf parsley, picked
Sea salt and black pepper

Grill the peppers until their skin is blistered all over, place in a bowl and cover. Roast the pinenuts until golden. Split the chillies, remove their seeds, then cut into fine dice. Peel and deseed the peppers, retaining the liquid that has formed at the bottom of the bowl, cut into small dice, and put into a large bowl along with the raisins, pinenuts, capers, chillies, vinegar and oil. Mix well.

If the squid tubes are intact, cut them into thin rings. If not, flatten and score the flesh, and cut into 2cm squares. Heat a frying pan over a high flame. Place the prepared squid in a bowl and dress with olive oil, salt and pepper. Drop a handful of squid into the pan, leave it for a minute, then toss for 30 seconds longer. Tip into the bowl with the salad, and repeat the cooking until all the squid is done.

Mix the salad, then cover and leave for an hour. Add the parsley and serve, adjusting the seasoning as necessary.

Fegato alla veneziana
1.1kg calf's liver, in slices about 6mm thick
100g unsalted butter
8 medium onions, very thinly sliced
1 bayleaf
1 pinch sugar
Sea salt and black pepper
1 tbsp white-wine vinegar

Melt the butter in a heavy-bottomed pot, drop in the onions, and fry until soft and beginning to take on some colour. Turn up the heat, stir, and let the onions darken a little. Add the sugar, vinegar, bayleaf and seasoning, then cover and cook at a low heat for half an hour. Set the pot to one side.

Heat a large frying pan and pour in a little olive oil. Lay in some of the liver - do not let it overlap - and fry for 50 seconds or so. Season, then turn over and fry for 30 seconds longer. Remove and keep warm, then repeat until all of the liver is cooked.

Tip the cooked onions into the liver pan, mix in the liver, and serve. Grilled polenta makes a fine accompaniment.

Croquettes de pommes de terre dauphine
A classic from the days when every main course was served with six vegetable and four potato dishes.
1kg floury potatoes (ie, Maris Piper)
100g butter
Sea salt and black pepper
Nutmeg
For the choux pastry 130ml water
35g unsalted butter
1 pinch salt
105g plain flour, sifted
2 eggs
For the batter Flour
2-3 eggs, lightly whisked
Fresh breadcrumbs

Peel and wash the potatoes. Fill a large pan with lightly salted water, add the potatoes, and bring to the boil. Once the potatoes are cooked, drain them, lay them out on a tray and put in a warm oven for five minutes - this will help dry them out. Pass the potato through a mouli or fine sieve, beat in the butter, salt, pepper and nutmeg, cover and set aside until ready to use.

Now make the pastry. Put the butter and water in a pan, and bring to the boil. Beat in the flour, remove from the heat and beat in the eggs, one at a time, until smooth. Combine the pastry and potato mixtures, then, with lightly floured hands, form it into sausage shapes. Lay these on a floured tray and put in the fridge. Do not make them too large as they will not cook properly inside.

Dip the chilled potato shapes into first flour, then eggwash, then breadcrumbs. Heat a deep-fat fryer to 180C, drop in the 'sausages' a layer at a time and fry until golden brown, about five minutes. Drain on paper towels and serve at once.

Crepes suzettes
Aurum has a style that is rather lacking in more famous orange liqueurs.
For the orange butter
250g butter
2 oranges
40g caster sugar
100ml orange juice
4 tbsp Aurum (or other orange liqueur)
For the crepe batter
130ml milk
130ml water
3 egg yolks
25g caster sugar
3 dssp Aurum (or other orange liqueur)
130g plain flour
60g melted butter

First, make the orange butter. Cut the butter into cubes and put it in a bowl to soften. Finely grate the zest from the oranges, taking care not to scrape off any pith. Beat the sugar and zest into the butter, then add the orange juice and liqueur bit by bit. Cover the bowl and set aside.

Now make the batter. Put all the ingredients into a liquidiser and work until completely smooth. Decant through a sieve into a jug and leave to rest for a couple of hours or overnight. The crepes can be made in advance and reheated when required. Fry them in a pan using as little oil as possible and making them as thin as can be.

Just before serving, melt the orange butter in a frying pan and heat until bubbling. Add one crepe at a time, turn it in the butter, and fold into quarters, leaving the most attractive side visible. Coat three pancakes per person. A performer may want to splash a little more Aurum over each finished plate and set it alight

 Dr Peter Barham is a reader in physics and Dr Len Fisher is an honorary research fellow in physics at Bristol University. Jeremy Lee is chef at Blue Print Cafe, London.

webTitle: Scientists report initial results of Glenn shuttle mission

fields.headline: Scientists report initial results of Glenn shuttle mission
fields.trailText: Science - not joyriding or publicity - was what prompted NASA to send John Glenn back to space, the agency steadfastly insisted during 1998's high-profile shuttle voyage.
fields.body:
Science - not joyriding or publicity - was what prompted NASA to send John Glenn back to space, the agency steadfastly insisted during 1998's high-profile shuttle voyage.

And science - tests on plants, proteins and tumour cells performed by the former US senator and his colleagues on the Space Shuttle Discovery - took centre stage Thursday as the scientists behind the experiments enthusiastically described the findings.

The results of Mission STS-95 were being presented over two days, beginning with those operated by Glenn and his six crewmates. Glenn - who was 77 when he became the world's oldest spaceman - himself served as a geriatric test subject for studies of bones, muscles and sleep patterns. But those results were not to be released until Friday.

The flight contained more scientific experiments - 88 - than any previous shuttle mission, said NASA Associate Administrator Dr Arnauld Nicogossian.

"The mission was packed, really packed," he said as he opened the scientific gathering. "By one of those good fortunes we had, all of the experiments worked except one."

NASA scientist Dennis Morrison described one successful experiment into compressing a tumour-fighting drug into a special miniature balloon and directing the drug into the tumour. "We're actually on the right track," he said, explaining that such a system could enable future cancer patients to avoid the side effects of chemotherapy by receiving drugs only where the tumour cells have grown and not through their entire bodies.

Glenn, 78, did not attend the first day of scientific presentations. However, he said in a telephone interview that Morrison's experiment on microencapsulation was one of the tests that he found most fascinating during that nine-day mission in October and November 1998.

NASA expanded its experiment itinerary after Glenn was added to the crew, with the stated purpose of exploring the similarities between what happens to humans in the zero-gravity environment of space and what happens naturally on Earth during the ageing process.

He said he has been briefed about what happened to his bones and muscles during the voyage aboard Discovery but wanted to let scientists release details.

"I fared very well, but that's as far as I can go with it right now," he said.

Glenn participated in 10 experiments studying space- and age-related problems. He spent four nights in a wired-up sleep suit, provided 17 blood samples and wore a mini data recorder for 24 hours to monitor his heart rate. He also swallowed a capsule holding a tiny radio transmitter and temperature sensor.

Glenn, one of the original seven Mercury astronauts, was the first American to orbit the Earth, accomplishing the feat in 1962. He represented Ohio in the US Senate for 24 years, retiring at the end of 1998.

webTitle: Astronauts arrive for Monday launch of Endeavour

fields.headline: Astronauts arrive for Monday launch of Endeavour
fields.trailText: Six astronauts have arrived for the launch countdown of a long-delayed mission to map the Earth as never before.
fields.body:
Six astronauts have arrived for the launch countdown of a long-delayed mission to map the Earth as never before.

"Go, Endeavour!" said commander Kevin Kregel, raising his left fist, on Thursday.

Endeavour is scheduled to blast off at 17:42 GMT Monday. It should have flown last September, but was grounded along with the other space shuttles by defective wiring.

The main event will occur just five hours into the 11-day mission, when the astronauts extend a 197-foot radar antenna boom from Endeavour's cargo bay.

"The science on this flight is going to be spectacular," said astronaut Janice Voss, who's in charge of the radar. "The 3-D map of 80 percent of the surface of the Earth, we think, is going to be really a great product to bring back for everybody on this planet."

What's more, "when we get done we're going to have built the largest rigid structure that's ever been built in space before."

In other news, NASA officials said Thursday they will send shuttle astronauts to the fledgling international space station in April if the Russians do not launch a vital component before summer.

Space shuttle Atlantis was not supposed to fly to the station until the Russian service module was in place. But the module is more than two years late in taking off, and Russian officials say it won't be ready for launch until late July or August because of rocket problems.

If they visit the station in April, astronauts would replace bad batteries, fix electronics and drop off supplies. The rest of the work would have to wait for the service module.

fields.headline: Welcome to New Britain...
fields.standfirst: ...but what exactly is it?   Jonathan Glancey scans history - and the South Pacific - to find the roots of the prime minister's favourite concept
fields.trailText: ...but what exactly is it? Jonathan Glancey scans history - and the South Pacific - to find the roots of the prime minister's favourite concept
fields.body:
New Britain is, strictly speaking, an island in the South Pacific. It lies to the north-east of New Guinea, and is the largest island of the Bismarck archipelago. It's a mountainous place with several active volcanoes. The capital is Rabaul and the population, at the last count, 312,995. New Britain is also, of course, the nickname, often tagged with a telling "plc", many have given to Great Britain in New Labour's hands.

The Blair government has been at pains in its first 1,000 days to modernise this societyless land of individuals and families (a vision of Mrs Thatcher), of long shadows on county grounds, warm beer and invincible green suburbs (John Major), of broad sunlit uplands (Churchill), of fair play (common consent), class distinction (only the truth even though we are all supposed to be middle-class now) and privatised trains (the worst part); not forgetting multiculturalism, accessibility and focus groups.

A number of commentators noted that in a speech he gave recently, the prime minister used the word "new" no fewer than 38 times. If he had a personal mantra, it might easily be "new good, old bad". And it's not hard to imagine flocks of Westminster lobby fodder chanting "new good, old ba-aa-ad" like so many sheep. In fighting what he likes to call the "forces of conservatism" as if he were Luke Skywalker battling with Darth Vader, Tony Blair, imagines himself to be on some sort of crusade, part-political, part-evangelical that will lead a commercially-driven Britain towards the New Jerusalem. A new covenant will be struck between government and citizens. We will all be stakeholders in this dynamic, corporate, trains-run-on-time (except, understandably, in times of leaf falls and the wrong sort of snow) New Britain plc.

And yet, "new" has never been inherently better than "old" or "current", even though the idea of newness suggests a world somehow shinier and cleaner than the one we know: a new three-piece suite for your home, a new formula washing powder, a New Deal for the depressed US economy of the 30s, a new pair of shoes. It is no coincidence that the word has been bandied about by evangelists and fundamentalists since the Reformation at least. And in both war and peace. Oliver Cromwell's New Model Army, on whose uniforms the scary armour of Darth Vader might well have been based, was the military instrument by which the old order might be defeated and even destroyed.

The New Model Army was as much a political as military force, its muskets the smoking symbols of a New Britain, mid-17th century style. The new order lasted just a few years. In the same century, New Amsterdam (New York from 1664 when captured by the British from the Dutch) must have promised a better world than the tired old Europe protestant settlers had left 40 years before. The New World itself, which surely contained, or so Spanish conquistadores in the 16th century believed, El Dorado - the legendary city of gold - implied something a little closer to the New Jerusalem than the tired civilisations of the Old World.

She's just met new people outside her prescribed world on Prospero's magic island for the first time; they happen to be the unpreposessing Gonzalo, Sebastian and Antonio; "O my America, my new found land,/My kingdom, safeliest when with one man manned", just 15 years earlier John Donne wrote punningly, of his new love in his exquisite poem "To his mistress going to bed".

New lovers, aren't they the best? Free of "baggage" as it's fashionable to say (ie of having lived a life, an old life, and thus irredeemable and best replaced by the new as if they were a car, a clutch, a set of shock absorbers). "New fares"announced on London Underground posters are surely better than a price increase; the word "new" is there to take something of the bitterness from the long-suffering commuter's pill.

And so it goes on. Only last week I was shown a packet of ready-made dhal from Tesco Metro. "New!" squealed the packet, and yet Indians have been preparing lentils this way for many thousands of years; GM foods aside, as recommended by the New Labour government, there is nothing really new in the world's larder.

We do not think much of this new food. New Man would certainly have been suspicious of it. Remember him, that soft-bearded 80s wimp who liked dungarees and Kicker shoes and who would have adored to have breast-fed his babies in public if only he could have? Twit or not, New Man, as the words imply, was meant to be somehow better than Old Man, who drove Jags and drank whisky while pacing hospital corridors when the wife was in labour, and had about as much idea of how to change a nappy as how to identify the G-spot. What spot? G-spot; the sort of thing girls with nothing better to do wrote about in magazines with names like "New Woman".

And who remembers having to study the "New Maths" at school? This was new, therefore better than the old maths (trig, geom, alg etc) even though it made about as much sense to most 11-year-old schoolchildren as a reading of A Critique of Pure Reason in demotic Greek, loosely translated, would to a gnu.

And here the idea of newness begins to crack and strain at its neoprene seams. If the new maths was seemingly designed to make schoolchildren suffer, the "news" broadcast on television and radio is far more often sad than happy whilst there are few advocates of New Towns this side of Peter Hall, author of Cities in Civilisation. The idea of newness in religious, political and social thinking, far from being inevitably good and leading to the best possible of all worlds, is often fraught with danger. At best it's a conceit, an emotion, an advertising slogan whether used by the makers of "New Square Deal Surf" or neophiliac politicians. The sad truth is that in our quest for new beginnings, we have destroyed as much as we have created. Think of Pol Pot with his absurd, vicious Year Zero. What was the point of destroying an old civilisation? Because the Cambodian warlord could. As Mao could in the Peoples' Republic of China. A "permanent revolution" would keep society ever-red and ever new. Millions had to suffer to disprove an ill-made political point.

New covenants, new deals, newness in all things is no guarantee of better things to come. What became of the animals of Manor Farm when Napoleon, not forgetting his spin-doctor Squealer, ousted Farmer Brown? Were they better off than before? Of course not, said Orwell. Are we in Britain any happier today for being told what to do and what to say by what has been increasingly perceived as a bullying bunch of messianic and self-important control freaks obsessed with new technology like so many schoolboys sitting alone in their bedrooms downloading weird games?

Blair opposes the new with what he calls "the forces of conservatism", both left and right and with a large and small "c". William Hague and his party, well and fine, but conservatives in general? What on earth does he mean? To conserve is hardly a bad thing whether home-made jam, an ancient yew tree, an age-old right-of-way, a country house, a species of endangered animal or much loved customs and follies. And better than conserving is connecting old and new, the poetry and prose of our lives.

In his Reflections on the Revolution in France (1790), Burke compared the state to a tree that whilst it needed pruning to keep its branches healthy, the act of cutting it down or uprooting it could only destroy civil society. In his radical Vers une Architecture (1923), and despite its bombastic revolutionary language, Le Corbusier demonstrated how the new aesthetic of the motor-car, ocean-liner and aircraft could be translated into architecture without losing its connection to the age-old proportional systems that had given us the Parthenon in classical times, Notre-Dame in Gothic. Yet, when the book was translated into English by Frederick Etchells (1927), it was given the title Towards a New Architecture, which was was a different point and not the one the great Swiss architect was making.

Bach created radical music in the 17th century, yet it was rooted in the classical elements of mathematics and architecture. Of course, the Goldberg Variations or the St John Passion would have sounded odd at first if these pieces could have been played to ancient Greek audiences, yet they might well have decoded the structural relationship between their architecture and Bach's scores soon enough. Bach's music, in other words, was rooted deep down in a very old world indeed. As was, of course, the music of Stravinsky and the art of Picasso in the 20th century.

Visitors to the Museo Picasso in Barcelona are nearly always taken aback by the strength and conviction of this restless artist's student drawings, things of voluptuous classical splendour. Equally, Picasso was deeply influenced by the old arts of black Africa which he encountered with Braque at the great Paris exhibition of 1900. What all these artists had in common was their ability to connect with the sensual world in all its glory - old, new, exotic, close-to-home - and to reconfigure it through the clarifying or distorting lenses of their mind's eyes to push and even shock us into looking or listening to the world in fresh ways. They were never new in the Blairite sense of the word.

Oh, but "new" suggests vigour, youth, freshness and vitality. And it sells, washing powder, sex and politics. And, if you don't like this obsession, you can always clear off for an old way of life in the old New Britain, that island where, one imagines, time stands pretty still, somewhere in the Bismarck archipelago to the north-east of New Guinea.
