webTitle: Is it time to consign the suit to history?

fields.headline: Is it time to consign the suit to history?
fields.standfirst:
Yes: Alan Young, St Luke's advertising agency
No: Thomas Mahon, Savile Row tailor
fields.trailText:
Yes: Alan Young, St Luke's advertising agency

No: Thomas Mahon, Savile Row tailor
fields.body:
Dear Alan,
Do suits make for a better workplace? The Arthur Andersen company, which this week dropped the requirement to wear suits from its dress code, seems not to think so. I disagree: you might not be surprised to hear this, coming from a tailor, but I think most people feel the same. The effort we take in our own personal appearance and style of dress is, rightly or wrongly, always used by others as an initial indication of our character. Not very PC, I know, but a fact that has always been true and, I suspect, always will be.

In a business environment, first impressions are paramount. I'm not arguing for the introduction of office uniforms - the colour and style of a beautiful suit should, clearly, be as individual as the wearer - but a professional appearance nevertheless speaks volumes about the attitude of an individual and the individual's company. And where do we stop? In 20 years, will office workers claim that there's no need to cut their hair for six months, or shower only once a week, because it doesn't affect their work?

Like it or not, most people instinctively want to enjoy the confidence and sense of wellbeing that a quality suit can offer, to a far greater degree than the most fashionable designer jeans and trainers.
Yours, Tom Mahon,
Tailor, Steed Bespoke Tailors

Dear Tom,
Chill, baby. Try and catch Arthur Andersen's new drift. This "first impressions are paramount" thing, it's true. But the company is saying "look, guys, we're not starchy, we're not stiff - we're in the idea business here. We're creative people. We can be buttoned-down without being double-cuffed."

They're just catching a ride on New Britain's new informal approach to business. Take a look at today's high-rollers in commerce: Branson is in jumpers; Evans is in baseball caps; Lynne Franks and Anita Roddick are in kaftans, for Christ's sake! These free-wheeling tycoons know that cut-away collars and twin-sets constrict the flow of blood to their brain. If someone wears a suit in my workplace, it's because they're off to a bereavement party or they've been busted - or worse. And it's not just us - it's a lot of our clients too. They wear slacks, they wear fashion tops and they're saying: "We're not Ms Brown and Mr Jenkins - we're Lisa and Dave. You can hang with us."

But I agree with you on personal hygiene. I mean, what if Arthur Andersen's employees actually did stop showering? I don't know about you, but I find the idea of meeting any kind of management consultant an alarming prospect, let alone a stinky one.
Increase the peace,
Al Young,
Creative director,
St Luke's advertising agency

Dear Al,
"Chill, baby"; "new drift"_ Help! The admen are coming! Branson and Evans as fine examples of the new trend? Well, I suppose so, if you consider delayed trains and ginger hair to be cool. I don't doubt the professional abilities of the high-rollers you mention, but aren't they just the ones at the tip of the business iceberg? We all know that changes in our working environment are leading to a diminishing amount of personal contact, which can, unfortunately, fool us into thinking that, since everything can be done with computers and telephones, there's no need to look good any more. But that way of thinking is a mistake: if we don't care how we look, why care how we think or act? Who do you really want to look like, anyway? James Bond or Richard Branson?

We are not all blessed with equal amounts of charisma; some people will be fantastically successful, regardless of the clothes they wear. But most of us need all the help we can get, and dressing smartly and with style each morning can only bring a little extra confidence, which makes us happier and more effective in everything we do.

All this 60s talk went out 40 years ago, Al. But don't worry - you can always hang with me. Still, I bet I get invited to more parties than you do.
Love, Tom

Dear Tom,
Please forgive me for the pseudo-hippy language. It was to illustrate the laid-back style becoming prevalent not just in businesses like mine, but in more "serious" enterprises like Andersen. This stampede towards the casual has less to do with our growing use of telecoms and more to do with the growing antipathy towards the uniformity of groups of men in suits. If they look the same, it suggests that they think the same - the civil service, the military, the City of London in the 50s. In advertising agencies, the most smartly-attired people are the account handlers. Creative people often refer to them simply as "suits". It's a way to disparage them. They are seen as stuffed shirts, the enemies of creativity. Andersen knows business is hungry to foster individual and unconventional ways of looking at problems or, at the very least, to give the impression of doing so.

Additionally, we've been hearing a lot about the feminisation of the workplace. Booted and suited in a razor-sharp whistle may well increase a chap's confidence and scream success with a capital S - but it can also damage the nurturing and inclusive environment that commerce is currently trying to foster. Suits are good for confrontation with employees and suppliers, but perhaps not so good for collaboration.

It may depress you to know that the chairman of my advertising agency gave all his work suits to Oxfam three years ago, and now slobs around the office in sweatshirts and jumpers. So keen is he to deformalise attitudes that he will even balk at me calling him "chairman".
Keep sharing that love,
Al

Dear Al,
At least we're in agreement about certain groups of men in suits: I, as much as anyone, have suffered from frustration at the hands of the grey-suit brigade. But I do believe my work to be an art, which couldn't survive without an ability to think creatively. To visit a bespoke tailor and to choose the cloth, style and tiniest details of a suit is a very individual approach to the interpretation of ideas. It is a long way from a visit to the quartermaster's stores for a demob suit.

The point that I'm trying to make is this: I make clothes for some of the most charismatic and free-spirited individuals anyone could hope to meet - people who would never let themselves be constrained by a suit. Both of us know that jobsworths who gain pleasure from narrowmindedness will do so just as well in casual jackets and slacks as in the finest Savile Row suit. You say that a suit is a workplace uniform, but isn't the alternative just to switch to the uniform of the slob? Greyness would remain. We're all motivated to succeed, whatever our business: don't you think that, if wearing a smart suit were detrimental to free thought and fresh ideas, we'd have discovered this a little earlier?

I'm confident that, if we have this same debate in 50 years, very little will have changed. In response to your chairman, who now slobs around the office, I'd say this: I have just finished making two suits for a partner of a very successful London advertising firm. When he put on the completed garments and looked in the mirror, he said simply: "Image is everything."
Your call,
Tom

Dear Tom,
Good points well made. I'll come clean with you: I do have a couple of bespoke suits. It was as much a pleasure to have them made as it has been wearing them. Having clothes that fit - really fit - is wonderful and whenever I don one of the suits, it sends my posture a couple of rungs up the evolutionary ladder. Both were made for the weddings of close friends. They helped me to make each event more important and acted as a sign of respect to my friends.

On rare occasions, I'll put one on for work. These rare occasions tend to be times of very high stress, when I want to feel and appear impenetrable and powerful. It's as if I'm putting on a suit of armour, and it works for me.

But I'd far rather look and feel approachable and open-minded. Being dressed up to the nines, however satisfying, doesn't deliver this. This may be one of the reasons why Andersen is relaxing its dress code. Business shouldn't be about doing battle and there can be a thin line between panache and posturing.

Unlike your client, I don't believe image is everything. I think how we behave in business is really what we should be looking at. Being good is more important than looking good. Still, it sounds like he was over the moon with his new threads.
All the best,
Al

You say that a suit is a workplace uniform, but isn't the alternative just to switch to the uniform of the slob? Greyness would remain. We're all motivated to succeed, whatever our business: don't you think that, if wearing a smart suit were detrimental to free thought and fresh ideas, we'd have discovered this a little earlier? I'm confident that, if we have this same debate in 50 years, very little will have changed. In response to your chairman, who now slobs around the office, I'd say this: I have just finished making two suits for a partner of a very successful London advertising firm. When he put on the completed garments and looked in the mirror, he said simply: "Image is everything." Your call, Tom Dear Tom, Good points well made. I'll come clean with you: I do have a couple of bespoke suits. It was as much a pleasure to have them made as it has been wearing them. These rare occasions tend to be times of very high stress, when I want to feel and appear impenetrable and powerful. It's as if I'm putting on a suit of armour, and it works for me. fields.headline: The unknown master
fields.standfirst: Bernard O'Donoghue  on the man who didn't get the Whitbread prize - Beowulf's original author
fields.trailText: Bernard O'Donoghue on the man who didn't get the Whitbread prize - Beowulf's original author
fields.body:
When Seamus Heaney won the £21,000 Whitbread prize this week for his translation of Beowulf, he gave the credit to "the anonymous master who composed Beowulf". Heaney claimed to be only the "worker"; the major achievement was the work as originally composed. So who was the joint winner, responsible for the original "gravity and force" of the Anglo-Saxon poem?

It seems a strange collaboration: the Irish poet who demurred at appearing under the heading British in a poetry anthology and the writer of a founding masterpiece of English literature. The writer of Beowulf came from the far north of England some time late in the first millennium, but he was writing about events and places far away. This heroic elegist wrote an epic about a Scandinavian hero and wars. Perhaps he was writing about his own progenitors after they had settled in the north, like Irish-Americans leaving their origins behind, yet with a strong nostalgia for them.

The horror of violence that characterises Heaney's great poetry is evident in Beowulf. After the hero's violent actions, we are told that he rejoiced in his work; but the poet doesn't rejoice. The dominant tone is regret for the fate of the people: how they can be simultaneously motivated by compassion and vengeance, how their great capacities for loyalty come to naught. JRR Tolkien said the first 3,000 lines (the bulk of the poem) can be read as a long prelude to a dirge for the death of Beowulf, his society and its values. Heaney in pondering long over Beowulf must have heard echoes of the disintegration of civil values in his Northern Ireland. He also recognised a poet with his own extraordinary gift for language, the poet who greets God's creation so lyrically: "How the Almighty had made the earth/a gleaming plain girdled with waters;/in His splendour He set the sun and the moon/to be earth's lamplight, lanterns for men,/and filled the broad lap of the world/ with branches and leaves; and quickened life/in every other thing that moved". (Heaney's version).

The anonymous poet had earlier collaborators. Several 19th-century poets reworked the great lament for the passing of human life, what came to be called "the lament of the last retainer". But Heaney restores a most eloquent voice: "No trembling harp,/no tuned timber, no tumbling hawk/swerving through the hall, no swift horse/pawing the courtyard. Pillage and slaughter/ have emptied the earth of entire peoples." Here we hear the voice of a great imaginative writer. The mourners at Beowulf's funeral praise him as "of all worldly kings, the most gracious to men, the gentlest and kindest to people, and the most eager for fame". The poet's attachment to the life of society is evident in the poignancy with which he evokes its loss. Not that we can call the poet he with such certainty. It might be she, though not very probably.

Some modern readers have returned to the 19th-century assignment of the poem to many writers, perhaps as many as six. Attempts were made to see different stylistic components in the poem: different poems almost. The 19th century wanted to replace the Romantic notion of "the poet", as with Homer, with the German idea of composition over time by the folk: the poem as a product of oral public culture. A series of disparate lays or short poems had come together into a complex but somewhat disconnected whole. Responsibility is divided differently in our time, but still denies the notion of the individual inspired genius. But mostly we hear in Beowulf now a voice consistent and exalted, and it is to this inspired single voice that Heaney has responded.

The poet of Beowulf worked with what is now a dimly known amalgam of historical events (set in the 6th century), like a writer of the Celtic Revival working with medieval Irish legends and folklore. Stories of fratricide and vengeance are told side by side with sinister fairytales of dragons and humanoid sea-monsters. It would be interesting to know his Germanic sources, but only as we need to know the classical sources that Tennyson nodded to. As Heaney says, we don't know who Scyld Scefing is: less even than we know Yeats's Fergus, who ruled the shadows of the wood. But it doesn't matter because, like Yeats, the Beowulf-poet has a drive and conviction that sweeps the reader past wondering or misgiving.

He describes the infernal landscape, where the monsters Grendel and his mother live, with the power of Dante: "A mysterious land of wolf-slopes and windy headlands, a treacherous path where the mountain stream disappears under the spray of the cliffs, a flood under the ground." He evokes a world remote from social and natural values, where the hart pursued by hounds will turn at the edge of the ghastly mere and give up his life on the shore rather than plunge in. It is a world of symbolic evil of such depth that nobody, no matter how wise, can plumb it.

The Beowulf-poet is above all a social writer. The ideal community at the start is the Danish Heorot, the great Hart-hall, where humane values of light and warmth and music shine in the surrounding darkness. Grendel and the other monsters are figures of the socially destructive. (John Gardner's version of Grendel had a brief vogue in the early Picador lists in the 70s, making the case for the anti-social).

But we don't know exactly what kind of world the poet inhabited. Where did his learning come from, enabling him by some untraceable heritage to invite comparison with Virgil's watery Hell-entry? What audience was he addressing, with such knowledge of the Swedish and Danish and Jutish wars of the 6th century that the details could be left as elegant, suggestive hints?

He is a bookish writer, even if much of his material has not been mediated through books but by great set-piece short narratives . He has a gift for elegant brevity and for the Germanic laconic (Grendel's lake "was not a good place"). With the precision of the Anglo-Saxon riddles, he compares the sword that melts to an icicle "when the Father unties the bonds of frost, unwinds the water-fetters".

You can understand the appeal for Heaney when you read the stately A Ship of Death in Heaney's The Haw Lantern in 1987, which translates part of Beowulf's opening. But it is to the long-dead poet's profound humanism that Heaney, the most humane and social of writers, has principally responded. We can be confident that the poet of Beowulf would have been generous-spirited enough to be gratified to share a prize with the modern master of English poetry. Like the rest of Heaney's thankful readership, he would acknowledge that the Whitbread has gone to the right place, undivided.

 Beowulf, translated by Seamus Heaney, is published by Faber, £14.99

webTitle: The best tape in the world...  ever!

fields.headline: The best tape in the world...  ever!
fields.trailText: Lost in music
fields.body:
A mate was preparing a compilation tape for me. "Of course, it doesn't have to be a tape," she bragged, "I could always burn you a CDR off." Panic set in. " Burn " me a compact disc recordable " off "? Does she have her own seven-acre pressing plant, I wondered? What kind of profound things does this say about our relationship? Am I poised to be just another insignificant client in the distribution of some mother-of-all mix CDR which she "burns off" for all her acquaintances? "A tape will be fine," I replied tersely, making a mental note to compare the finished product with the compilations she'd made for her other friends.

I've seen far too many of these snazzy DIY CDR-mixes doing the rounds recently - insipid, personality-free things with neatly presented Helvetica tracklistings. Friends know that I'm waging a one-man war against them, but still they carry on. "What's that?" I asked Ellen on New Year's Eve, gesturing to the four and a half inch by five and a half inch rectangular bulge in the knee pocket of her combat trousers. "It's a large, unusually shaped piece of cheese," she replied. She was lying, of course. Closer inspection revealed it to be The Most Ellen CDR in the World... Ever!, lovingly collated and named for her by her boyfriend Greg a few days before. "Please don't confiscate it. It's easier to skip through the tracks than it is with a tape," she protested weakly.

The whole point of a personal compilation tape is that you shouldn't be able to skip through the tracks. This is not merely music; this is the most thoughtful, personal gift a friend can give. You should be padlocked to your stereo and made to give each song as much care and attention as your mate did when they taped it, including that Johnny Hates Jazz song they stuck on for "comedy" value but secretly quite like.

The compilation tape is not just a statement about the compiler's personality, it's also a braver statement about what the compiler presumes - or hopes - to be the compilee's personality. Putting brackets next to Hall and Oates's Maneater with the phrase "I think of this as your song" scrawled between them can be a make-or-break gesture in the early stages of a serious relationship. I never knew my ex-mate Mad Bob from Derby was such an anal retentive until he made me a collection of obscure trance folk with three seperate appendices detailing producers, recording dates, and manufacturers of mandolin.

In the technological age, comp tapes represent one of the few occasions when you get to see the handwriting of people you consider to be your soul mates. Filling out a tax form or an electricity bill, I have the scribble of a motormaniac orang-utan; with a neatly ruled TDK inner sleeve in front of me, I become an unsurpassed calligrapher. People save vast, unexplored regions of their souls for collating their favourite music. For non-musical music fans, the compilation tape is the nearest we'll ever come to the thrill of unveiling our own songs to the world.

In the best scene in Boogie Nights, Paul Thomas Anderson's account of the 70s porn industry, fallen star Dirk Diggler and his hangers-on attempt to pull a get-rich-quick scam in the house of a bigtime drug dealer. The dealer can't give them his full attention because it's absorbed by his own personal compilation tape, playing in the background. "I make these tapes of my favourite songs_ I don't like to be told what to listen to or when to listen to it," he says, rolling his eyes. The camera zooms in on the tape's label - "awesome mix tape six" - and everyone watching begins to laugh, because they suddenly find themselves relating to a mustachioed drugs baron in a silk dressing gown and Y-fronts. The scene is set in 1983, but it's still relevant. For all the illusions of freedom offered by the internet, the modern record store and the compilation album, they'll never provide the liberating autonomy of a good pen, a spanking new C90, an ample record collection and a lively imagination.

fields.headline: Dark knights
fields.standfirst: Judith Mackrell says the only problem with Arthur, the ballet, is the dance itself
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell says the only problem with Arthur, the ballet, is the dance itself
fields.body:
David Bintley's Arthur (Part 1) has all the hallmarks of a historic cultural event. It's a new full-length ballet based on what is probably the best loved, best known British legend and has a commissioned score from leading British composer John McCabe. It's also the final work being staged at the Birmingham Hippodrome before that theatre closes for refurbishment, with Arthur (Part 2) marking its reopening next year.

In fact, the production turns out to be a disappointing hybrid - a ballet that doesn't want to be itself. But the great and honourable point in its favour is that, despite its landmark status, it resists the cosy embrace of heritage. There is not a whiff of the Tintagel tea rooms about it. Rather, Bintley and his superb design team (Peter J Davison sets; Peter Mumford lighting and Jasper Conran costumes) have relocated the legend to a postmodern timewarp. Davison's vast metal scaffolding allows the stage to move from generic, smoke-choked battle scene to minimalist court, while the rock in which Excalibur is planted glows like a slab of Kryptonite. Conran's costumes mix medieval fantasy and contemporary catwalk, with soldiers in bikers' leathers, knights in dinosaur skulls and pony-skin trousers, and women in exquisite fancy dress.

The point of setting Arthur in this historical limbo is not only to tell the story freshly but also to universalise it as a study of power. Its concerns - that all great leaders have blood on their hands, that all just causes are complicated by evil and all individuals are trapped by larger destinies - remain today's concerns. So while Bintley gives due magical weight to Arthur's initiation into kingship via his miraculous seizing of Excalibur, the ballet is more interested in the deceit and violence that attend his rule.

The ballet may end with Arthur's joyous wedding to Guinevere but the ceremony is juxtaposed with a film collage of children being shot: a slaughter of the innocents planned by Merlin to rid the kingdom of the infant Mordred - Arthur's nemesis.

These are high aims, considered with high seriousness; but what is on stage is unfortunately less like a ballet than a high-class pageant. Stylish tableaux rattle past our eyes, adroitly taking in the detailed complexities of Bintley's libretto (to get a proper grasp of which you have to read seven pages of programme notes). But there is little that involves our brains or hearts. Apart from basic leitmotifs identifying the main characters, the choreography seems a dutiful afterthought. Neither the steps nor the mime look as if they've been imagined specially - rather as though they have been borrowed from the ballet library.

So despite the hard-working efforts of the dancers, we know little about the characters they portray and we care even less - though there are a few outstanding exceptions, which show us what this ballet could have been like. In the shocking duet in which Morgan Le Fay sexually assaults Arthur, Bintley's choreography creates images available to no other medium. Tiny Laetitia Muller is transformed into a female demon, a flying succubus, who whirls around Arthur, high on her points and jabs at him viciously with her groin. Then, in a reckless leap, she vaults through the air and latches on to him with her arms flailing and her legs outspread - a vision of satanic eroticism that is equal to anything in a Hieronymus Bosch painting.

Also remarkable for their depth of body language are Joseph Cipolla as Merlin, and young Sophie Jones as the child Morgan - her eyes flat and baleful with forbidden knowledge even as she moves with the innocence of a little girl.

To be fair to Bintley, he is not given much momentum by his score. McCabe is a master of sound painting - his volatile rhythms and variegated instrumentation serve the story vividly - but his music lacks an essential dance pulse. His strengths are most apparent at the ballet's violent conclusion, where the dancers freeze in a rictus of gaiety as above their heads film images relay the firing of guns, the screaming of children and the spilling of blood.

The controlled frenzy of McCabe's score here is electrifying - it would make fabulous film music. But what also becomes clear (and this says a great deal about the production as a whole) is that this most powerful, memorable climax has been achieved by sound, film and staging - not by dance.

 Arthur (Part 1) is at the Birmingham Hippodrome till January 29, the Bradford Alhambra from February 15 to 18, the Sunderland Empire from February 22 to 25, and Plymouth's Theatre Royal from February 29 to March 1. Details: 0121-622 2555.

fields.headline: A people clutching at straws
fields.standfirst: Orania is the Afrikaners' last hope of a homeland. But the vision is faltering, says  Chris McGreal
fields.trailText: Orania is the Afrikaners' last hope of a homeland. But the vision is faltering, says Chris McGreal
fields.body:
There is probably only one place in South Africa where you will see white men hauling crates on to lorries while black labourers paid to do the job lounge under a tree. But then the remote, almost comatose town of Orania likes to pretend that it is not in South Africa at all. It is a founding principle of the dilapidated settlement on the banks of the Orange river that only whites - Afrikaners specifically - can work within its borders. The black men on the trucks collecting sweet melons from the town's farm for shipment to Britain are astonished to find themselves waved aside.

But that is the paradox of Orania. It is almost so much the old South Africa that it is something new. Orania was a ghost town reborn nine years ago as the nucleus of an Afrikaner homeland, a "volkstaat", shortly after Nelson Mandela's release from prison sounded the death knell for white rule. The new trekkers have settled in some of the most barren and sparsely populated land in the country, hoping that it will grow into an independent Boer republic stretching from the banks of the Orange river to the South Atlantic.

But the South African government is redrawing municipal boundaries across the country and Orania is to be incorporated with two black townships more than 20 miles away, and the all-white town is about to get a black mayor. "I suppose it'll mean taxes," said Carel Boshoff, the town's leading Afrikaner philosopher and grandson of Hendrik Verwoerd, the architect of apartheid, and black homelands. "We'll have to pay to educate them in the township. This is what we were trying to get away from. This is a setback, but I don't think it'll destroy us."

Orania was built in the 60s by the water department to house families of men building irrigation canals to parched Northern Cape farmland. On one side of town the department constructed airy bungalows beside concrete roads. The open-air swimming pool and Dutch Reformed church stand sentry either side of the gateway to the rugby pitches. Over the hill the road turns to a track. There the water department built the remainder of Orania, the quarter for the black workers, called Little Happiness. The houses are crammed together in a jumble. The department did not extend the electricity supply from the "white" area. Orania was abandoned in 1981 after the canals were complete.

The town withered in the scorching heat for a decade until it caught the eye of the volkstaaters. A consortium of wealthy backers headed by Verwoerd's surviving family bought the town and turned it into a private company. That way the shareholders - the residents - can discriminate about who they let in. The new settlers built a pipeline from the river to irrigate the fields, and set about creating jobs with small factories making shoes and ironwork. They also erected a memorial to Hendrik Verwoerd on a hillock above the church.

Verwoerd is pervasive. It is not just that his wife, daughter, grandson and in-laws have all decamped to Orania where the family dominate political life. The pride of the only guest house is the HF Verwoerd room. Guests sleep under a large portrait of the most vilified man in modern South Africa. On the opposite wall hangs a certificate to his honourary membership of the Voortrekkers, a nationalist version of the Scouts. There is even talk of moving Verwoerd's grave from Pretoria.

But apartheid's architect is more divisive in Orania than might be imagined. "Even in town Verwoerd is a controversial figure," said Dr John Streydom, who moved there two years ago. "Some people think he might be a bit of an albatross. I consider myself neutral. Verwoerd wasn't that bad. He had a fair amount of goodwill for blacks. I wonder if it wasn't advanced thinking on his part to believe that people want to be among their own."

Much has changed in Orania over the past nine years. When the volkstaat was first declared, members of the neo-Nazi AWB wandered the town with guns on their hips. The talk was of war against the new order. Today, the racism is less overt. "The others" and "different nations" have taken the place of more offensive epithets, at least in front of outsiders. Orania attracts two kinds of settlers. There are those who simply want to escape the changing South Africa, and those who dream of the volkstaat. Just about anyone who wants to live in the town has to say they believe in the latter when they appear before Carel Boshoff and the council, which scrutinises potential residents. "Shareholders are asked if they ascribe to the broad concept of Afrikaner freedom. Are you self-sufficient? Are you going to be part of an economy or are you going to live off other peoples' labour? Of course you get people who express it in terms of racial categorisation. That's what South Africans grew up with," Boshoff says.

Yet the vision is faltering. Orania has failed to attract the thousands of Afrikaners its planners thought would be scrambling for places. There is room for 10,000 people but just 650 have moved in. Others have tried Orania and left, driven out by the hardship of scraping a living in a barren town with too few real jobs or simply overwhelmed by the oppressive politics of conformity to an imagined ideal of the distant past. And those who stay are not always as strongly committed to a volkstaat as some would like. "At the council meeting the other day one of the guys said 'The gardens are coming along very nicely' and one of the others said 'That's the problem. We should be striving for bigger things and you're tending your gardens'," Boshoff says.

The volkstaaters look to Israel as the ideological and practical model. It goes unmentioned that Verwoerd also despised Jews. The first apartheid-era prime minister, DF Malan, once stood on Cape Town docks in a futile bid to turn back a shipload of European Jews fleeing Hitler's Germany. These days, Orania's leaders make periodic visits to Israel to learn its lessons. The town imported £1m of milking equipment for its 500 cows, making it one of the most modern dairies in South Africa and a source of considerable pride which every visitor is shown. Self-sufficiency extends to the Volkskool where Verwoerd's daughter, Anna Boshoff, is headteacher.

Orania does not have enough teachers, so pupils learn at computers with a program in Afrikaans written by a company in the town. The school has a 100% pass rate in its school leaving exam, although it favours an independent version because of the dif fering interpretations of history between Orania and the South African education department. The volkstaat curriculum prefers not to dwell on recent events given so much attention in state schools. "If the learners come across something liberal or strange in an exam it can be a bit difficult," Anna Boshoff says.

Among the professionals willing to give Orania a try is Christiaan van Zyl, a young architect who is held up as the epitome of the pioneering spirit because he is building himself a house of straw. Mr van Zyl says similar homes using straw bales instead of bricks have stood for more than a century in America, a country he has come to Orania to escape. "I came here for the Afrikaner way of life. All the traditional things we used to do have fallen away. The whole cultural life is crippled by America, by American television. Families used to sit down after supper and read the Bible and sing. Now they just sit in front of the television until they fall asleep," he says.

When a group of teenagers tried to organise a disco they were scolded and told to put on a dance to traditional Afrikaner music. Ilze Smidt, 19, is one of the few young people to settle in Orania without her family. "My friends at university don't understand why I want to stay here. Most think I'm mad but I'm proud of it. People have the same goal to live in a volkstaat and practice our religion and our language and protect our culture. But there are not many opportunities for young women to work," she says.

Ilze is popular, not least because she is one of the few eligible young women in town. The elders discourage liaisons beyond Orania's confines. They would like to see marriages kept within its boundaries. Public dissenters are rare but women seem more ready to criticise. One mother said she only stayed because her husband insisted on it. "There is no future in this place. It's all in their imagination. What is there for our children? Can you imagine spending your whole life here just so you don't have to live with blacks?" she asks, after checking no one else was listening.

But the dream, or delusion, of the volkstaat lives on. The settlers plan to buy up land piecemeal until they reach the ocean 500 miles away. Then, according to Andreas Du Plessis, a member of the council, they will flood their homeland with Afrikaners. "We only need 200,000 people or so to create a majority. If the others move out for their own reasons that will suit us, but they won't be chucked out. They will even have a vote when we have a majority," he said. "It could take 40 or 50 years. It's just like Israel. In the 19th century many Jews laughed at the idea of an independent state of their own. The ideal is to create a hi-tech state. Take Singapore. It's small but it has big exports. You don't need a lot of rain to make high tech equipment."

webTitle: They tore down Lenin's statue - and raised one to Frank Zappa

fields.headline: They tore down Lenin's statue - and raised one to Frank Zappa
fields.standfirst: Kate Connolly  on how the artists in a neglected corner of Lithuania declared themselves an independent nation - and all because of the late great American rocker
fields.trailText: Kate Connolly on how the artists in a neglected corner of Lithuania declared themselves an independent nation - and all because of the late great American rocker
fields.body:
There aren't many Lithuanians who have seen Passport to Pimlico, the classic Ealing comedy in which a group of Londoners declare independence from Britain after uncovering documents that reveal their home streets to be part of Burgundy. That's a shame, because it might help the bemused residents of Vilnius understand what's going on in the ancient district of Uzupis. This too is a story of a bunch of eccentrics rebelling in their country's capital.

Uzupis, or the Republic of Angels as it has been dubbed, comprises only 148 acres and around 120 residents. It has one main street, surrounded by lanes and courtyards full of art galleries. But since last April it has had its own president, its own bishop, two churches, an embassy in Moscow and no fewer than four official flags - one for each season. Banners hang from neglected buildings, labelling them the Uzupis Sheraton, Chanel and Harods (sic).

Soon the tiny state will have its own Nelson's column or Eiffel tower - a bronze sculpture of an angel that will stand in the main square, in honour of Zeonas Steinys, a much-loved local painter who died in 1998. Its unveiling will mark the official founding of the Republic of Angels - and if that causes problems with the rest of Lithuania, there is a 12-strong army to call on.

In Pimlico the rebellion began with the detonation of an unexploded bomb left over from the second world war. In Uzupis the trigger was Frank Zappa, the gifted but undeniably weird American rock star.

Nine years ago Lithuania broke away from the Soviet Union, leaving a lot of empty plinths that had previously been occupied by statues of Lenin, Marx and their regional disciples. An obvious question remained: what to do with the empty plinths? Saulius Paukstys, a civil servant and member of the Vilnius bohemian set, saw the opportunity to fulfil a lifelong ambition. He founded the Frank Zappa Fan Club and commissioned a socialist realist sculptor to create a statue of Zappa on a patch of land in front of a children's hospital in the centre of the city. "We were desperate to find a symbol that would mark the end of communism, but at the same time express that it wasn't always doom and gloom," Paukstys recalls. He now holds the post of national security chief.

At first the authorities criticised the plan, particularly after discovering that Zappa was a bit of a leftie. "They said: 'What has he got to do with Lithuania anyway?' We said: 'Nothing really.' Then someone convinced them that Zappa had Jewish features and seeing as Jewish history is very important to Lithuania, they plumped for that."

The statue was erected in downtown Vilnius five years ago. The most famous of modern Bohemians, Czech president Vaclav Havel, was invited to the unveiling, where a military brass band played Zappa hits. Membership of the fan club ballooned; a radio station allocated airtime for a weekly Zappa broadcast, which included doses of Zappa philosophy; and a Zappa Love Letter Club was set up to bring Vilnius's lonely hearts together.

The fan club and the city's artistic community are practically synonymous, so when the artists started drifting back to their old haunt of Uzupis, Zappa was the natural candidate for patron saint. And last spring, when the local artists and young people decided to take a stand against the city council's neglect of Uzupis, he was the figure they rallied behind. "The spirit of Zappa made us see that independence from Moscow was not enough and persuaded us to declare independence from the rest of Vilnius," says Paukstys.

"We're trying to relearn the smell of identity," agrees Roman Lileikis, president of Uzupis and one of Lithuania's leading musicians and film-makers. The smell may be rather pungent. The name Uzupis means "the other side of the river" and the waterway has long served as a natural border - the area remained cut off from the old town until two bridges were erected in the 16th century. For hundreds of years it was the home of Russian and Jewish residents but during the war almost all of its population disappeared, leaving empty homes which were occupied by prostitutes and bandits.

When I visited the republic, having first obtained the visa stamp in my passport (a hand with a red hole to symbolise the blisters of a worker), it was not hard to track down the founding fathers, president and all, who were sitting sipping Trejos Devynerios - a Lithuanian mead made from 27 different roots and grasses - in their regular haunt, Uzupio Kavine. The place's menu is as ironic as the republic itself: Monmarto salad, Uzupio ruins and Bohemia roast.

Apart from the artists there was an engineer, a doctor and several business people, most of whom admitted they had been highly sceptical about independence, but who now fondly embraced Uzupian values and hoped their children would do the same.

President Lileikis, a Kenneth Branagh lookalike dressed in a fisherman's jumper, poured more mead and explained how he founded Uzupio Pingvinai (Uzupis Penguins) a few years ago, to preserve all things Uzupian, including its creative and community spirit. He was a natural choice for president and is so dedicated to the task of making the republic work that he has put a successful career making commercials on ice.

"We're trying to energise a community by asserting our indepen dence," Lileikis says. "It's very different from the independence gained in '91, but we're trying to foster the same spirit so that people can make things happen for themselves. That's a trait they lost through 70 years of oppression."

Uzupis certainly appears to be a unique place in Vilnius. No other part of the capital has a proper sense of community. The aim is to draw the rest of the city into the spirit by holding carnivals and pyrotechnic shows on the river, as well as open-house art actions. As the ultimate act of satire, the republic shares its national feast day with April Fool's day.

"We're taking the term carnivalesque back to its medieval origins, when it was used to turn the status quo upside down for a while and shake people out of themselves," says Vytautas Kalanauskas, an avant-garde artist who looks a bit like Picasso and who lived in Uzupis in the 50s before the authorities moved him on. He returned in 1984, and says the artistic community, having spent years using "Aesop language" in its work so as to outwit the authorities, is "now trying to get its own tongue back'.'

Vilnius has fancied itself as a cultural centre of Europe ever since its postwar poet Oskar Milosz had a vision of Vilnius as a northern Athens of the 21st century. "We think the term is a bit bombastic and pompous now, but we can still dream that it will become reality," says Linas Paulasukis, editor of the cultural magazine Siaures Atenai, or Northern Athens. Uzupis, Paulasukis believes, fits into the right mould. "They have a fine vision to create a community atmosphere through art," he says, "but maybe it's more important as a social phenomenon than as an artistic movement. It helps the Lithuanians to learn how to open up."

The question now is how far the process will go. So strong is the nation's drive for freedom that one Uzupian, a video artist, confides: "I've declared myself to be an independent state. Even the Republic of Uzupis doesn't satisfy me."

fields.headline: When a man can be the wrong kind of Virgin
fields.trailText: There's been a poster up near our local railway station this week. It shows a new mobile phone, all curvy and black and white, rather like a Chicago gangster's spats. The caption reads: "It had to look cool - we made it for Virgin," and seeing it the other day I realised the extraordinary fact that "Sir" Richard Branson and his company still think of themselves as the epitome of relaxed, laid-back chic - and, even more bizarrely, imagine that the public does too.
fields.body:
There's been a poster up near our local railway station this week. It shows a new mobile phone, all curvy and black and white, rather like a Chicago gangster's spats. The caption reads: "It had to look cool - we made it for Virgin," and seeing it the other day I realised the extraordinary fact that "Sir" Richard Branson and his company still think of themselves as the epitome of relaxed, laid-back chic - and, even more bizarrely, imagine that the public does too.

Ten minutes later I was reading the news report about Mr Roger Virgin, a carpenter who has been trading as a carpenter and renovator in Cardiff for 20 years, under the rubric of Virgin Building Services. Mr Virgin actually had the effrontery to use his own name for his own company! Naturally "Sir" Richard's lawyers were on to the matter in a trice, and sent him a bullying letter threatening legal action: "We believe the public is likely to be confused" and similar nonsense.

Apparently the matter may now be sorted out through Mr Virgin making it very clear that he has no connection with "Sir" Richard's enterprises. Wisely too, I would have thought, since I wouldn't dream of using any of them unless it was absolutely unavoidable. On a recent trip to Manchester I flew, because it's slightly cheaper and far more reliable than Virgin trains.

Now this appalling company has raised fares on the line for the fourth time in 12 months. A standard return from Manchester to London presently costs a staggering £150. When are we going to finally realise that Virgin isn't a loveable, people-friendly company run by an affable balloonist in a jumper, but just another incompetent and rapacious mechanism for ripping the public off?

 I'll return to your favourite worst songs shortly, just as soon as I've had a chance to listen to the tapes you've sent in. Thanks especially for the many favourable mentions of the hideous yet wonderful Old Rivers by Walter Brennan, which includes the deathless line: "I was bustin' up clods with m'own bare feet".

May I also draw to your attention an early CB radio song called Teddy Bear, sung by Red Sovine? Teddy Bear is the CB "handle" of a little crippled orphan whose father used to drive 18-wheeler trucks. He begs for a ride just to remind himself of what his poppa would have done for him if he had been still alive, and the narrator chokingly recalls the result: "Yer know, they was 18-wheelers parked right round the block."

Meanwhile Paul Flynn MP sent me the last verse of a song that he had to endure in his Welsh childhood:

"Please don't take my prayer book, Mister Burglar,"

The child in anguish cried,

" 'Twas given to me by mother,

The night before she died."

It evokes a wonderfully old-fashioned image of a time when men in striped vests with bags marked "Swag" broke into houses to steal prayer books.

 Many thanks too for your letters about mythical facts, such as the innumerable Eskimo words for "snow". Confusingly this particular fact may not be mythical at all. Several readers have sent in what they claim, and I have no reason to doubt, are extracts from Inuit dictionaries which have plenty of different words for snow - or at least, and this is slightly different, words for different applications or qualities of snow, such as drifting snow (perksertok), snow mixed with water (massak), snow used for building (auverk), and of course "iglu", a house made of snow.

I suppose if we included all words for "water" with those for "rain" - moisture, sea, lake, damp patch etc - we could make an even greater claim. Intriguingly, the Icelanders have, according to Alan Davidson in his book North Atlantic Seafood, 150 words for the different parts of a cod's head. Endless neo-lexicography may be one way of spending those 22-hour winter nights.

I am particularly indebted to Lucy Fisher, who is setting up her own website devoted to mythical facts, and who sent me a list of hundreds, including many old favourites. For instance, the Great Wall of China cannot be seen from the moon. Lemmings do not commit mass suicide (the event was created for a Walt Disney wildlife film.) King Canute never ordered the sea to retreat; according to legend he took sycophantic courtiers down to the sea to prove that the tide would not obey him. The V-sign was not invented as an insult by English archers at Agincourt.

Champagne glasses are not modelled on Marie Antoinette's breasts, nor is there any remotely reliable record of her saying "Let them eat cake." (Oh, and the word she didn't use was "brioche", which then meant the stuff left in an oven after the bread had been taken out, which would make it a more sympathetic quote if she had actually said it.) The Swedes don't have the world's highest suicide rate; as Janet Wright reminds me, this was invented by an American right-wing congressman to discredit a welfare state.

American history is a rich source: for instance, the Boston Tea Party was not a protest against British taxes. On the contrary, it was organised by tea smugglers who were outraged that the British had abolished the unenforcible tax on tea, and so had destroyed their livelihoods. Sometimes these myths oscillate between fact and fiction. When I went to live in the States we were told that Thomas Jefferson had had a child by one of his slaves. At his home, Monticello, they assured us this was a myth and there was no truth in it. This week, scientists have concluded from DNA tests that he probably had several children by the slave.

Many are folk tales that few people really believe: airlines don't pump sedative gas into their cabins, and you can't get appendicitis from swallowing grape pips. Nor was the inventor of the electric chair its first victim, and guinea pigs' eyes don't fall out if you hold them upside down. Thanks too for those of you who have performed real scientific tests on teeth in Coca-Cola (they remain unchanged, of course).

 Tuesday was a fascinating day. Alastair Hetherington's memorial service was a lovely occasion, a reminder of the old Guardian that I joined an eternity ago in 1968. Michael Frayn, who wrote the funniest column ever to appear in this paper, was present among the guests. It was he who invented the notion that the human world was divided into herbivores and carnivores. If so, this quintessential Guardian service was herbivore Ground Zero.

But then so, in the evening, was Alan Bennett's gentle, ruminative, cud-chewing play, The Lady in the Van. Along with Maggie Smith, it stars my neighbour Nicholas Farrell as one of the two Alan Bennetts who are onstage for most of the play. (This sounds an embarrassing device, but it works.) Nick and his wife Stella had wanted a baby for years, so when Stella got pregnant he was determined to be there at the birth. Eight weeks ago, she was rushed into hospital, providing the theatre with a serious problem. They got around it, and the audience heard this message before the curtain went up: "We regret that, owing to the indisposition of Mr Nicholas Farrell, the part of Alan Bennett will be played tonight by Mr Alan Bennett."

Naturally, the real Alan Bennett was the only Alan Bennett there who hadn't memorised the lines, and had to read them out from a copy of the text.

webTitle: Blair go-between in secret talks with Livingstone over mayor deal

fields.headline: Blair go-between in secret talks with Livingstone over mayor deal
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair has been conducting secret negotiations with Ken Livingstone through a ministerial intermediary, the Guardian has learned, over the shape of a possible deal if the MP wins Labour's London mayoral nomination.
fields.body:
Tony Blair has been conducting secret negotiations with Ken Livingstone through a ministerial intermediary, the Guardian has learned, over the shape of a possible deal if the MP wins Labour's London mayoral nomination.

The talks between Mr Livingstone and the transport minister Lord Whitty, who was Labour's general secretary until 1994, have covered the content of Labour's mayoral manifesto, who would be deputy mayor, and government plans for the future of London Underground.

The prime minister yesterday reiterated his support for the former health secretary Frank Dobson as London Labour party members began voting in what has become a bitter election contest.

But it is understood that discussions between Downing Street and Millbank over how to deal with a Livingstone victory have intensified in recent weeks, as the Brent East MP's commanding poll lead has shown little sign of slipping under the official onslaught.

Among those said to have been involved in talks about how to handle a possible official Labour campaign for Livingstone as London mayor are Lord Whitty's departmental boss, the deputy prime minister John Prescott, the chancellor Gordon Brown, Labour's general secretary Margaret McDonagh and Philip Gould, Mr Blair's pollster and adviser.

Labour insiders said yesterday that Lord Whitty met Mr Livingstone to hammer out the terms of an accommodation with the party leadership earlier this month, despite hopes that Mr Dobson might still beat him in the electoral college.

Party leaders are concerned about loss of face if there were any climbdown over government plans to part-privatise the tube and that Mr Livingstone, former leader of the Greater London Council, would fill his mayoral cabinet with leftwing allies. They are also strongly opposed to the Brent East MP's proposal to appoint Glenda Jackson as his deputy.

Both sides refused to comment on the back-channel talks last night, though a Labour spokesman said: "We're not going to get into hypotheticals. When we've got a winner, we'll go forward from there. Labour's machine will work for whoever wins to deliver a Labour victory".

Meanwhile, Mr Livingstone accused Mr Blair of a "crude intervention" in the balloting process, after a letter from the prime minister was included with members' ballot papers. Mr Livingstone claimed that the letter was effectively an endorsement of his main rival. Mr Dobson dismissed the complaint as nonsense.

The third candidate in Labour's mayoral race, Glenda Jackson, was yesterday warned by lawyers acting on behalf of Unity Security Balloting, the organisation which is running Labour's mayoral vote, that she was "verging" on breaking the party rules by appearing to question its independence.

Her spokesman said she would not be gagged and would continue to press for a full party inquiry into the conduct of the whole contest. That demand was yesterday backed by Mr Livingstone.

webTitle: MP's aide killed in surgery sword attack

fields.headline: MP's aide killed in surgery sword attack
fields.standfirst: Cheltenham Lib Dem escapes after fending off assailant
fields.trailText: An MP's assistant was stabbed to death yesterday as he tried to protect the Liberal Democrat MP Nigel Jones from an attacker who stormed his constituency office in Cheltenham armed with a sword.
fields.byline: Paul Kelso, Will Woodward and  Lucy Ward
fields.body:
An MP's assistant was stabbed to death yesterday as he tried to protect the Liberal Democrat MP Nigel Jones from an attacker who stormed his constituency office in Cheltenham armed with a sword.

Andy Pennington, Mr Jones' personal aide and a member of Gloucestershire county council's education committee, died from multiple stab wounds when the man burst into the office at 4.30pm yesterday.

Mr Jones, 51, who was conducting his weekly constituency surgery, received lacerations to his hands and arms after fending off blows from the swordsman. He was being treated at Cheltenham general hospital last night.

Mr Jones raised the alarm after staggering bloodied and stunned from the office in St George's Street. An armed-response unit attended the scene.

The attacker, believed to be a local man known to police, had walked from the office still holding the sword, and was arrested further up the street outside a branch of Littlewoods department store.

Eyewitnesses told how the assailant had walked calmly into the office as Mr Jones and colleagues began the surgery, before attacking the aide, who is thought to have received at least 10 stab wounds.

As Mr Pennington lay dying, Mr Jones managed to fend off the attacker and escaped to a nearby music shop. Assistant manager Ben Fielding tended his wounds.

An eyewitness at the office described how he watched the attacker flee the scene: "I saw this figure walking towards us and we raced out of the way. He was around 50 and armed with a sword.

"He was covered in blood, I backed out and he put the sword behind his back and fled up the street.

"I followed him and phoned the police on my mobile. I was still watching him when he was arrested by unarmed officers."

Lorry driver Graham North, 35, described how his friend David Copson, a local shop owner, cradled the dying aide in his arms.

"I saw David dash into the MP's office seconds after Nigel Jones ran out clutching his hands and screaming for help.

"My mate went in there, he was in there for a little while, but then he came out as white as a ghost. He said 'I could not do anything for him - he died in my arms. He had a gaping wound in his lower stomach and there was a lot of blood'."

Jeremy Whales, the former mayor of Cheltenham, paid tribute to Mr Pennington, describing him as an outstanding man and a born fighter.

"He was a courageous man, a fighter, long before this tragedy. He would never walk away from a fight. If I could describe him in one word I would call him a tiger," he said.

Liberal Democrats at Westminster last night expressed their horror at the attack. Party leader Charles Kennedy said: "I am shocked and horrified by this news. Members of parliament make themselves available to all their constituents. It is tragic that an MP and his staff, carrying out their duties, should be subjected to an appalling attack of this nature."

Local Lib Dem executive member and former councillor Steve Harvey said: "Everyone is totally shocked and appalled. Nigel was doing his ordinary Friday evening surgery. Perhaps someone who had been to Nigel for help and not got it may have taken it to an extreme."

Mr Jones, 51, is not a prominent Commons figure, but an affable backbencher and sports and beer enthusiast. The father of three took his Cheltenham seat unexpectedly in the 1992 general election after running against John Taylor.

Labour MP Fraser Kemp last night called for new guidelines to help protect MPs and their staff. The MP for Washington and Houghton, who was a Labour party employee in the West Midlands when a Labour councillor was raped in a con stituency surgery, said: "Jack Straw should talk to chief constables about issuing guidelines in terms of safety and advice, not exclusively for MPs but for their staff who are vulnerable at work."

He added: "MPs do not always do surgery work themselves - only today, for example, a Friday debate in the Commons will have meant that all over the country surgeries would have been conducted by staff."

The majority of MPs do not use an appointments system at their surgeries, simply advertising the hours they will be available in local newspapers.

MPs were given no guidelines on security, except in exceptional cases such as when racist or other organisations threatened to send letter bombs, he said.

webTitle: We cannot live in glass houses, says Kennedy

fields.headline: We cannot live in glass houses, says Kennedy
fields.trailText: "MPs cannot conduct their lives in glass boxes, hermetically sealed from their constituents," said Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, last night, hours after the assault.
fields.body:
"MPs cannot conduct their lives in glass boxes, hermetically sealed from their constituents," said Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, last night, hours after the assault.

While the sentiment will be echoed by all MPs, they will also share the concern expressed by Mr Kennedy at the repercussions of last night's attack. There can be few MPs who have not considered the risks of a job which requires them to be accountable and accessible to the public, with nothing and no-one to stand between them and their constituents if things get out of hand - unless they are senior enough to qualify for special protection. Many can recount incidents that have happened to others; some have first-hand experiences.

Harriet Harman, the former social security secretary, endured a 10-year vendetta by a former mental patient after she had represented him unsuccessfully while working for the National Council for Civil Liberties.

The man, who told psychiatrists he wanted her dead, would turn up at her constituency surgeries in the Commons in a "menacing mood", she stated in a court case last year. Thomas Hamilton, responsible for Dunblane, had no difficulty seeing local MPs George Robertson and Michael Forsythe before the massacre, though he did not threaten them.

The difficulty for MPs is that their job puts them in the front line, and any attempt to shield them would impair the openness of the political process. Dan Norris is Labour MP for Wansdyke and an honorary fellow at Sussex university specialising in violence against people working with the public. He said last night: "The MP's relationship is based on being accessible, on interpersonal powers. You have to get to know people, they have to address you, and you can't stand behind a screen or behind glass - that would completely change the job."

Mr Norris suggested that, with an average of 100,000 constituents apiece, statistically MPs could not help coming into contact with people with mental illness.

"Often they come to their MP desperate, as a last hope, probably with unrealistic expectations. When they find you cannot solve their problem immediately, they can get angry. In a way, MPs are set up to fail."

Many MPs, for ease of access, hold drop-in surgeries rather than organising appointments - giving them no warning of whom will attend.

They might hold surgeries in remote areas, and were often on their own. Mr Norris, who said he had had received death threats from pro-hunting fanatics, does not publicise the address of his constituency office and has mail routed via Westminster. Other MPs use box numbers. Some also have secure phone numbers whose address cannot be traced.

In reality, there is little more MPs can do. Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, last night called on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to talk to chief constables over possible safety measures. Few, however, would wish to be anything other than "open and accessible" - the description used by Mr Kennedy of Nigel Jones.

"Often they come to their MP desperate, as a last hope, probably with unrealistic expectations. When they find you cannot solve their problem immediately, they can get angry. They might hold surgeries in remote areas, and were often on their own. Other MPs use box numbers. Some also have secure phone numbers whose address cannot be traced. In reality, there is little more MPs can do. Fraser Kemp, Labour MP for Houghton and Washington East, last night called on the home secretary, Jack Straw, to talk to chief constables over possible safety measures. Few, however, would wish to be anything other than "open and accessible" - the description used by Mr Kennedy of Nigel Jones.

webTitle: How a routine MP's surgery ended in murder

fields.headline: How a routine MP's surgery ended in murder
fields.standfirst: It was an ordinary Friday afternoon at the Lib Dem office, when a swordsman entered and left one man dead and another wounded
fields.trailText: It was an ordinary Friday afternoon at the Lib Dem office, when a swordsman entered and left one man dead and another wounded
fields.body:
Around 4.30pm yesterday afternoon at the Liberal Democrat constituency office in Cheltenham, Nigel Jones and his assistant Andrew Pennington were preparing, as they did every Friday, for the MP's weekly surgery.

Mr Jones had thrown himself into his constituency work since being stood down from the party's front bench by Charles Kennedy, but with Mr Pennington he formed a regular double act, one the devoted locally born MP, the other the leader of the Liberal Democrat group on Gloucestershire couty council.

Together they made the surgery an open house where anyone could come in off the street with a problem. If the query was more appropriately handled by a councillor than by the MP, Mr Pennington was on hand to help.

Yesterday, according to witnesses, Robert Ashman stepped into the office on St George Street armed with a sword, not a question.

The unemployed 49-year-old had allegedly contacted the MP regarding what a colleague of Mr Jones described as "a difficult case".

Last night, it is claimed, the MP had become the focus for the violent frustrations of a man who in the last year had lost his job, his home, suffered the death of his sister and become separated from his wife.

Witnesses said that his attacker pushed his way past an elderly female constituent and lunged at Mr Pennington with the sword. The councillor appears to have tried to stop his attacker before he could reach Mr Jones.

The attack left Mr Pennington with more than 10 stab wounds, and what one eyewitness described as "a gaping wound into his stomach".

As Mr Pennington lay on the floor it is alleged that Mr Jones was attacked. The MP is said to have lifted his arms in front of his face in order to deflect blows from the sword. With his arms and hands lacerated and his shirt drenched in blood, the MP managed to force his way out on to the street.

As Mr Jones dashed into the street and called for help, he was allegedly followed by Ashman, who walked, apparently calmly, away up St George's Street.

Shop owner David Copson ran into the office to attempt to help Mr Pennington.

Graham North, a friend of Mr Copson, described the scene: "I saw David dash into the MP's office seconds after Nigel Jones ran out clutching his hands and screaming for help.

"My mate went in there, he was in there for a little while, but then he came out as white as a ghost.

"He said: 'I couldn't do anything for him he died in my arms. He had a gaping wound in his lower stomach and there was a lot of blood'."

Another man who said that he did not want to be named described how he went into the office after the attack.

"I went in and saw a man with a sword. He was covered in blood. I backed out and he followed me. He hid his sword behind his back and turned left up Chiltern High Street.

"I followed him up to the town and phoned the police on my mobile. And then he was arrested outside Littlewoods by unarmed officers."

Last night Ashman's parents revealed that their son, who has two daughters, had lost everything he held dear in the past year.

Ivy Ashman said: "It's a terrible time. We still don't really know what's going on. In the last year he's lost his home, his job and his family.

"In August his sister died and he has had two cycling accidents and ended up in hospital."

Ashman's father, Geoff, added: "He's the type of person who helped everybody out, but when he needed someone there was no one there for him.

"He's been trying to deal with a lot of things but his friends have abandoned him.

"When his sister died, that hit him really hard. He was at her bedside all the time."

Mr Pennington, who was unmarried, was described last night as a stalwart of the party and someone who was entirely dependable.

"He is going to be a heck of a loss to his family, his local community and the party," said a west country Liberal Democrat official who had known him for 15 years.

"It would be no surprise if he was there assisting with constituency problems.

"He was a real party stalwart, someone who could be relied upon."

A neighbour said that his death was a shock and a great loss to the community.

Nigel Davies, 50, who lives near Mr Pennington, said: "He was a fine, fine man, dedicated to his work, especially when local elections were coming up. It's just tragic.

"People will be deeply shocked because everybody knew him. He was a good Samaritan figure and we always had a laugh and a joke with him," he said.

fields.headline: Tony Doyle
fields.standfirst: Irish actor famed for varied television and classic roles
fields.trailText: The sudden death of the actor Tony Doyle, at the age of 57, has deprived Ireland of one of its greatest dramatic talents. Although best known to television audiences as Brian Quigley, the scheming local businessman in the BBC1 series Ballykissangel, his acting credits cover an extraordinary range of work on stage, radio, film and television in Britain and Ireland.
fields.body:
The sudden death of the actor Tony Doyle, at the age of 57, has deprived Ireland of one of its greatest dramatic talents. Although best known to television audiences as Brian Quigley, the scheming local businessman in the BBC1 series Ballykissangel, his acting credits cover an extraordinary range of work on stage, radio, film and television in Britain and Ireland.
Tony was born in French Town, Roscommon, on the Sligo-Leitrim border, where his father was a police sergeant. Later, the family moved to Churchtown, Dublin, when his father was stationed there in the late 1950s. He went to University College, Dublin, and later, took acting courses with Brendan Smyth in Dublin, while working briefly with a US oil company based in Dublin.
He began his acting career with small independent groups in Dublin, before moving to London where he played a number of roles in fringe theatre. I vividly recall him, dressed in a silver suit in a small theatre in Islington, singing Stewart Parker's pastiche of a 1970s Eurovision Contest song, Der Zig Zag Zong, in the play Catchpenny Twist. It stole the show.
Tony was passionate about the theatre and loved working on the stage. There were a number of roles at the Royal Court, London, including an exceptional performance in Ron Hutchinson's Rat In The Skull, and at the Abbey Theatre, Dublin, where his performance in The Gigli Concert was an emotional tour-de-force.
His television curriculum vitae lists no fewer than 81 titles. They include films such as The Hen House and The Nightwatch, directed by Danny Boyle, and his first major series role as the complex policeman John Deakin in the BBC crime drama, Between the Lines.
He was also a brilliant radio actor. Only last week BBC Radio 4 audiences had the pleasure of hearing him read a series of ghost stories. I understand from the young producer who worked with him that Tony's kindness to inexperienced raido producers had remained unchanged since I first worked with him in the late 1970s.
Outside his dedication to acting, it was clear that Tony's family and close friends were the most important things to him. He rarely took breaks from work but, when he did, it was often to spend time with his artist wife Sally in their house in France. He had three children from his first marriage - one of whom, Susannah, played the secretary, Joy, in Channel 4's Drop The Dead Donkey - and three from his second.
Tony's strength as an actor came from his qualities as a man. He had a natural authority, warmth, humour and intelligence, which informed all the roles he played. Anyone who worked with him recognised his uncanny ability to find something oddly heroic in all the manifestations of human weakness. Even when the characters he portrayed were cruel, ruthless or pathetic, one sensed they had an equal capacity for humour and tragedy. Perhaps this explains the exceptional range of the parts he played.
His creation of Quigley in Ballykissangel, justifying a lucrative franchise for confessionals containing fax machines on moral grounds, was funny because he somehow managed to show hypocrisy as something ludicrous, self-revealing and deeply human.
His portrayal of Michael Moran, in the BBC adaptation of John McGahern's Amongst Women, achieved the almost impossible feat of making us feel sympathy for a tyrannical patriarch who would otherwise have appeared merely a monster. It was a role that brought Doyle much deserved acclaim, including many major awards and nominations.
He was about to star in a pilot for a series that had been specially written for him - McCready and Daughter. He would have been great in it; in Tony's hands, a part didn't look like acting. On film-sets, his presence assured stability and integrity. His friendship was hugely valued.

Tony Garnett writes: Some deaths are unsurprising, even expected. Tony Doyle's was like a kick in the stomach. We were just doing the deal with his agent for his sixth outing as Brian Quigley, in Ballykissangel. Tony was the Jack Nicholson of British actors. A tough man to deal with - he knew his worth - but once done, the most consummate professional.
However warm, convivial (and late) the night before, he was always on the set on time, spruce, bright-eyed and ready, without temperament or side. In an age when some young actors mistake tabloid celebrity for talent, his impeccable professional manners were an example. You didn't mess with him. Who would want to? He always delivered.
In the 1990s, I was a privileged colleague through three years of Between The Lines and five of Ballykissangel. The roles were very different, but his subtlety, quiet authority and tart comedy timing were the same. As the bent detective and Machiavellian fixer, Deakin, he was cold and cynical, a man who believed in nothing, but enjoyed life as a game of bluff and double bluff. As Quigley, the entrepreneurial fixer, he brought warmth and an understanding of human weakness to the character. Rarely can a villain have been so loved by so many. Quigley playing with his grandson are scenes of great tenderness.
Tony was my kind of actor. Less was more, and you could never catch him doing it. He had presence. It will take a long time to fade.

Tony Doyle, actor, born 1942; died January 28 2000

fields.headline: Jean Metcalfe
fields.standfirst: Broadcaster bringing families together across the airwaves
fields.trailText: Jean Metcalfe, who has died aged 76, made her own quiet but distinctive contribution to British broadcasting from the war years well into the 1970s
fields.body:
Jean Metcalfe, who has died aged 76, made her own quiet but distinctive contribution to British broadcasting from the war years well into the 1970s. She was "compere" - as radio presenters were then termed - of the hugely popular record-request programmes Forces Favourites and Two-Way Family Favourites, and, much later, presenter of the pioneering BBC agony aunt programme, If You Think You've Got Problems.

Modest self-effacement was her forte. At the microphone, she got her effects by using her deep, cultivated voice in a manner which suggested patient understanding rather than self-projection. When she lost her second baby, she and her broadcaster husband, Cliff Michelmore, were deluged with letters of sympathy from listeners. They included one from a woman who had previously sent Jean a cheque for £100 as a token of gratitude for the pleasure her broadcasts had given (the money was politely returned).

Jean Metcalfe was born in Reigate, Surrey, the eldest child of parents who believed in giving their children more pocket money if they were on good behaviour. Her father, a Southern Railway clerk at Waterloo station, every night sponged his celluloid collar clean. "Ovaltiney people", she later called them - bathroom-less, lower middle-class folk who used their privilege railway tickets to take holidays in what they considered to be far-off Cornwall.

At the local county school, Jean shone at art and elocution. At home, she was fascinated by the wireless, to the extent that it became what she herself called a passion. Christopher Stone talking about the gramophone, the gardener Mr Middleton telling listeners how to produce the best carrots, Uncle Mac and Toy Town, of Children's Hour - they all "went into one ear and stayed there", as she wrote in her and her husband's joint autobiography, Two-Way Story. Jean joined Children's Hour's Radio Circle, which entitled her to enter competitions. The winners were invited to Broadcasting House to speak into the microphone. The competitions were stopped when she had entered only two, but her enthusiasm continued.

She left school in 1939 and went to secretarial college. Her father wanted her to work for the Southern Railway, but she was set on the BBC - despite the fact that, at that time, the corporation took on as secretaries only daughters of the professional classes. Adroitly describing her father as a "welfare officer" - to be fair, he did some charity work for injured railwaymen - and inventing grandparents in Norfolk (the right sort of country background), Jean got her first BBC job at £2.5s.6d a week.

Her first broadcast came when she was asked to read Thomas Ashe's poem, Spring, The Sweet Spring, in the Books And People programme. This led to an audition when the BBC and the war office formed a joint broadcasting service for the armed forces. Moving to the North African section, Jean did Forces Favourites, playing records for the forces several times a day, after first sitting in with Margaret Hubble for five demanding hours to discover how the job was done.

Later, she joined the Expeditionary Forces programme, in which the British, Canadian and US broadcasting services had an uneasy alliance. But it was while doing Forces Favourites from London that she linked up with the broadcaster Cliff Michelmore, who was doing the counterpart job in Hamburg while in the RAF. When the war ended, both switched to the peacetime programme, Two-Way Family Favourites. In 1950 Jean married, and in August that year was drafted in to present Woman's Hour, then a much blander programme than today. She once announced that Henry James could be considered an "erotic" (instead of "esoteric") novelist, but her prowess as a self-effacing, listening interviewer was well deployed in conversations with stars in their own homes - Vera Lynn, Frankie Vaughan, Kenneth More and Gilbert Harding were among her quarries.

It was in 1964, the year that Karsh, of Ottowa, took her photograph - a sure sign that she had really arrived - that Metcalfe stopped doing Two-Way Family Favourites, and briskly reported that it was "the beginning of a normal life again for all of us". By that time, she and Michelmore had had their daughter Jenny, who studied acting, and son Guy, later to be a television presenter.

Metcalfe returned to the media on a regular basis in 1971 with If You Think You've Got Problems, in which she was the lay chairman of teams of experts discussing real human predicaments, such as transvestism. The programme was made less "risky" by her sensible chairmanship, and before long she was saying words like "orgasm" with scarcely a blush. When the series was dropped in 1979, she concentrated on drawing illustrations for books and Christmas cards, a throwback to her school talent, and became less self-effacing and more idiosyncratic. "I have to admit to a vulgar hankering for a positive fiesta of a funeral, with flowers coming out of my ears," she once confessed. "Does that sound eccentric? I do hope so." She is survived by her husband, Cliff Michelmore, and their two children. Dennis Barker
