fields.headline: Prof Michael Hull
fields.trailText: Professor Michael Hull, who has died of cancer aged 60, was head of reproductive medicine at the University of Bristol and founder of its centre for reproductive medicine, internationally renowned for work on infertility.
fields.body:
Professor Michael Hull, who has died of cancer aged 60, was head of reproductive medicine at the University of Bristol and founder of its centre for reproductive medicine, internationally renowned for work on infertility.
When he took up an appointment as consultant senior lecturer in obstetrics and gynaecology at Bristol in 1976, he broadened his interest in reproductive endocrinology to include all aspects of male and female infertility, establishing facilities for basic laboratory studies on the disorders of sperm, egg and fertilisation which underlie the causes of infertility.
He combined the roles of scientist and clinician with consummate ease, and in 1989 the University of Bristol recognised his distinguished contribution by appointing him professor of reproductive medicine and surgery.
Born in India, the son of an army doctor, "Mike", as he was known, moved to England with his family at the end of the second world war. He commenced medical training at the London Hospital Medical College, where his academic commitment sometimes took second place to his love of sport, particularly hockey and cricket.
After deciding to specialise in obstetrics and gynaecology he worked at the Liverpool Women's Hospital, Queen Charlotte's, London, Charing Cross, Hackney, and later at St Mary's, Paddington, where clinical advances were being made in the rapidly developing area of reproductive endocrinology.
Mike will be remembered for the strong ethical principles which he brought to his medical practice, his clear thinking and his sensitivity to the views and feelings, not only of his patients, but also of his colleagues.
He is survived by his wife Gris, and his daughters, Natalie, Sophie and Emily.

Michael Hull, medical doctor, born July 2 1939; died November 22 1999

After deciding to specialise in obstetrics and gynaecology he worked at the Liverpool Women's Hospital, Queen Charlotte's, London, Charing Cross, Hackney, and later at St Mary's, Paddington, where clinical advances were being made in the rapidly developing area of reproductive endocrinology. Mike will be remembered for the strong ethical principles which he brought to his medical practice, his clear thinking and his sensitivity to the views and feelings, not only of his patients, but also of his colleagues. He is survived by his wife Gris, and his daughters, Natalie, Sophie and Emily. Michael Hull, medical doctor, born July 2 1939; died November 22 1999

fields.headline: Hackers shake up Japan
fields.trailText: The Japanese government is scrambling to defend itself against cyber crime amid a wave of hacking attacks that has filled several public websites with anti-Japanese invective and links to internet porn pages.
fields.body:
The Japanese government is scrambling to defend itself against cyber crime amid a wave of hacking attacks that has filled several public websites with anti-Japanese invective and links to internet porn pages.

The intrusions, which have forced the shutdown of two agency sites, appear to have been motivated by the government's refusal to ban a controversial conference that denied Japan's worst wartime atrocity.

Hackers have broken into at least five prominent government sites since Wednesday, leaving messages such as "Nippon [Japan] is rotten animal" and links to Playboy.

Yesterday they made 1,600 attempts within seven minutes to break into the Bank of Japan's computer system. The foreign, finance and defence ministries and at least two national newspapers have also been targeted.

The attacks started when hackers broke into the website of the government's statistical bureau on Wednesday, wiped off census data, and put up a message in Chinese and English declaring: "Japanese - As all peoples know, it's a folk which has no concern to face the truth of history. They are the disgrace of Asia."

The intruders, who signed off as Brazil p00 Hackerz, expressed anger at Tokyo's decision to give the go-ahead to a controversial conference in Osaka last weekend that described as a lie the Nanking massacre - in which it is claimed Japanese troops raped or murdered about 200,000 residents of the city now called Nanjing after they occupied it in 1937.

The ferocity of the attacks is a wake-up call for a country that has only recently started to address the need for computer security. Japan's parliament passed a new law against internet crime last summer, but it will not come into effect until early next month.

The government has said it will dispatch officials to the US to seek advice on measures to prevent cyber terrorism.

"We must defend our systems," said Akitaka Saiki, a spokesman for the prime minister, Keizo Obuchi. "It is extremely regrettable that this hacking of government computer systems has taken place."

After an emergency meeting on Wednesday, the Metropolitan police agency set up a special squad of 50 police officers to investigate internet crime.

The defence agency's system has not been penetrated, but officials said yesterday it would request 3.8bn yen (£22m) to strengthen security.

There was even a false alarm yesterday when newspapers reported that hackers had inserted the dancing baby - a famous internet animation - on the trade ministry's website. It turned out the graphic had been put on the page by the site's operators while they were checking for hacking attempts.

"It's so embarrassing," the trade minister, Takashi Fukaya, said in admitting the mistake.

webTitle: Orchestra's demise strikes sour note in new South Africa

fields.headline: Orchestra's demise strikes sour note in new South Africa
fields.trailText: Alex Hitzeroth joined South Africa's national symphony orchestra as its first black trombonist little more than a week ago. Within hours, the 18-year-old musician was told he was out of a job. The last national symphony orchestra in sub-Saharan Africa was to close.
fields.body:
Alex Hitzeroth joined South Africa's national symphony orchestra as its first black trombonist little more than a week ago. Within hours, the 18-year-old musician was told he was out of a job. The last national symphony orchestra in sub-Saharan Africa was to close.

On Thursday he played his second and last concert with the NSO, which was, he said, "the highlight of my very short career".

"Nobody else can say that at 18 they have played with a national symphony orchestra," he added. "I've got a whole load of experience in the past week but it's very disappointing. It makes you wonder why you do it at all if there's no orchestra."

The orchestra has lived hand to mouth for years, but finally closed when a potential sponsor backed out, leaving the orchestra 10m rand (£1m) short.

Some see its demise as evidence of the post-apartheid government's emphasis on popular black culture over "white, elitist" music - certainly it showed no enthusiasm to save the NSO, but the orchestra has never received government funds.

Others, including some of its own members, say it failed to adapt rapidly enough to the changing political realities of South Africa by recruiting more black players and developing a higher profile in townships.

The musicians played a final concert for free, partly as an act of defiance, partly in the hope a white knight might appear. "The workers of the orchestra you see here tonight are currently unemployed," the audience was told.

Before the performance, one of the flautists, Malane Hofmeyr-Burger, was handing out envelopes to other members of the company. She had no idea what was in them until she opened her own. It was the official redundancy notice and a payoff cheque of only £200, less than a week's salary.

"I will go on practising. There are not so many opportunities to play, so you must make your own," she said. "I'll try and establish an ensemble with others here. We must start creating culture. South Africans are not used to the notion of giving money but we must if these things are to survive."

Mr Hitzeroth, who was talent-spotted while playing with the national youth orchestra, did not even qualify for an envelope. He will go back to studying music at Port Elizabeth university.

"It's a long process to get blacks into the orchestra," he said. "They've been supporting me for three years. It's not like you can throw in millions of rand and have 10 black guys in the orchestra. You have to groom the players to a particular standard. If we lose the orchestra now, who's going to groom the new musicians?"

The NSO was once funded by the South African Broadcasting Corporation but this ended in 1997, when the cash-strapped corporation was reorganised.

Finding new sponsors is not easy, but the overwhelmingly white complexion of the orchestra has not helped. There are only two black musicians, including Mr Hitzeroth, and a third of the players are foreign born, mostly from Bulgaria and Russia.

Don Ezard, a Briton, took over management of the orchestra in August when it was already in deep trouble.

"I think the perception has been that this orchestra was exclusively white, and I think that used to be correct. But you can't say that any more. We are actively recruiting black players. Last Friday we were to audition two black string players but . . ." he trailed off.

The NSO has played in support of the Nelson Mandela children's fund, as backing for black choirs and at the popular nation-building concerts of South African music held every year for the past decade. Some of the players visited Soweto every week as part of an educational programme in six black schools.

But the orchestra really extended itself into township life only in the past two years. And Mr Ezard conceded that not all the players were keen to participate.

"There may be some reservations but only based on lack of experience. Those musicians who've been into Soweto are very enthusiastic," he said.

While some of the orchestra's supporters have accused the government of letting the NSO die in favour of promoting black culture, the National Arts Council says it is hardly in a position to help. Its annual budget is only £2.5m. It would take nearly half of that to keep the NSO afloat.

The arts minister, Ben Ngubane, said the government "cannot just pull 10m rand out of a hat".

He said that that when the NSO approached him for funding last year he asked it to draw up a business plan on how South Africa's various orchestras could pool their resources. He said the response was "totally unsatisfactory", adding: "Somehow I don't think these orchestras are interested in talking to each other. They each want to go their own way."

South Africa has three other professional orchestras, in Cape Town, Durban and Pretoria. They each receive subsidies from their respective city councils and provincial government, although the Cape Town Philharmonic has warned that it may have to close without a big cash injection.

But none of the regional or local authorities was willing to back the NSO, because it was a national organisation.

Some in the orchestra still believe it can be revived. But Mr Ezard does not hold out much hope. "I think it's gone," he said.

webTitle: Elf slush funds oiled French political machine

fields.headline: Elf slush funds oiled French political machine
fields.standfirst: Former finance minister faces questioning over payments
fields.trailText: The scandal over illegal political funding by the French state-owned oil firm, Elf, deepened yesterday when the Socialist former finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn was told he would be questioned over alleged fraudulent payments from the company.
fields.body:
The scandal over illegal political funding by the French state-owned oil firm, Elf, deepened yesterday when the Socialist former finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn was told he would be questioned over alleged fraudulent payments from the company.

Elf's role at the centre of backhanded payments sanctioned by the Elysée palace when the late François Mitterrand was president was underlined at the weekend by allegations that the oil firm contributed about £10m to Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrat Union (CDU) 1994 election campaign.

Some £2.1bn was allegedly milked from Elf's profits in a web of international corruption and mismanagement between 1989 and 1994.

The allegations facing Mr Strauss-Kahn are small in comparison. But if he cannot justify a payment of £19,000 from Elf's funds to his private secretary, Evelyne Duval, his political career could be over.

Mr Strauss-Kahn resigned last year to answer charges of fraudulently receiving unjustified legal advice fees from a students' health insurance fund, MNEF, used as a slush fund by the Socialist party.

Although he has dismissed the Elf accusation as baseless, it fuels a six-year scandal which has damaged many reputations, including those of Mitterrand and his friend, the former German chancellor Helmut Kohl.

More than six years of investigations into the oil firm have brought down the company chairman, Mitterrand's foreign minister and a score of lesser dignitaries. They have left no doubt that Elf was involved in a gigantic international illegal funding operation controlled from the Elysée palace.

Two examining magistrates, Eva Joly and Laurence Vichnievsky, have piled up so much evidence about Elf's undercover bribery and corruption that the judges' offices have been moved to a whole floor in a separate building.

Mitterrand would probably be facing a judicial inquiry had he not died in 1996. Instead, his close friend, the former foreign minister Roland Dumas, is expected to face trial this year over alleged kickbacks in an Elf-managed deal over frigates for Taiwan.

His former mistress Christine Deviers-Joncour, who this week brought out her third book on the inner workings of Elf, could join him.

The list of public figures under investigation for pumping millions of pounds of Elf profits for political causes or private gain becomes more impressive by the day. Most are from Mitterrand's personal entourage. They include Elf's disgraced former chairman, Loik Le Floch-Prigent.

Other leftwing figures suspected of profiting from Elf's largesse include the novelist Françoise Sagan; the SOS Racisme executive Eric Ghebali; and the late president's son and adviser on Africa, Christophe Mitterrand.

The Gaullist former interior minister Charles Pasqua allegedly used Elf to finance an influential network in Africa, headed by Omar Bongo, the president of Gabon, where Elf has large oilfields. All deny any wrongdoing.

Other allegations include routine operations to provide cash to friendly politicians from Russia to Venezuela and bizarre transactions, such as the purchase of handmade shoes worth £1,100 for Mr Dumas and a £1.8m divorce settlement for Mrs Floch-Prigent.

Several officials are on the run, including the head of the African operations, Alfred Sirven. But no one has dared to identify themselves as the source of revelations over the Mitterrand-Kohl deal.

Despite a categorical denial by the justice minister, Elisabeth Guigou, no media have refuted the allegations.

The transaction was allegedly covered by the purchase at an inflated price of a rundown oil refinery in Leuna, in former east Germany. A former manager of Elf International, Maurice Malet, said everyone knew that the refinery was worthless and would never make a profit.

"But we also knew at the time that the only factors that counted were political considerations," he said. "The sale was a good point for Helmut Kohl just before the general elections."

Mitterrand saw himself and Mr Kohl as the only men able to safeguard the single European currency project; £10m was a bargain for maintaining the odd-bedfellow friendship between conservative Germany and socialist France.

webTitle: Drug smuggler invited to go on the run with Olympic torch

fields.headline: Drug smuggler invited to go on the run with Olympic torch
fields.trailText: For a sports-mad country that is proud to be hosting the Olympics in September, there was meant to be a rigorous process to decide who would be the honoured 10,000 Australians to carry the flame on the 100-day torch relay across the continent.
fields.body:
For a sports-mad country that is proud to be hosting the Olympics in September, there was meant to be a rigorous process to decide who would be the honoured 10,000 Australians to carry the flame on the 100-day torch relay across the continent.

But one of Australia's most infamous drug-runners, who is serving a 12-year sentence in maximum security for conspiracy to import drugs, was invited to join the flame carriers in a letter sent to his cell.

Warren Richards, a former judo champion, accepted the offer to take the torch on part of its run from Ayers Rock to Sydney in early 1998. He even paid £150 for a replica of the torch he wanted to carry.

There were red faces yesterday after it emerged that Richards was one of the Australian Olympic Committee's (AOC) approved nominations, as a reward for participating in the 1976 Montreal Games.

The AOC secretary general, Craig McClatchey, admitted: "It would be inappropriate for us to endorse him to carry the torch, even though he is an Olympian."

He said the invitation had now been withdrawn, but the mistake was understandable even though Richard's conviction had attracted considerable publicity at the time.

"We don't hold detailed personal files on each Olympian. There are literally thousands of them - so it is possible for this situation to arise," Mr McClatchey said.

A prison spokesman said Richards would not have been allowed a temporary release to carry the torch. "He is doing a 12-year sentence, his earliest release date is 2006. He has been in jail since 1998 and is a maximum security prisoner. There is no way he will participate," the spokesman said.

The gaffe follows an earlier decision to allow Olympians who had tested positive for sports drugs to carry the flame on its journey through 1,000 Australian communities.

webTitle: EU leaders urged to keep Haider out

fields.headline: EU leaders urged to keep Haider out
fields.standfirst: Austrian chancellor backs call on European countries to help exclude far-right party from coalition
fields.trailText: European Union foreign ministers were yesterday urged to convene a special meeting to discuss ways of keeping Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party out of power in Austria, a key EU member.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels and  Kate Connolly in Vienna
fields.body:
European Union foreign ministers were yesterday urged to convene a special meeting to discuss ways of keeping Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party out of power in Austria, a key EU member.

Guy Verhofstadt, Belgium's prime minister, issued the call in a letter to his Portuguese counterpart, Antonio Guterres, whose country holds the EU's rotating presidency.

Austria's caretaker chancellor, Viktor Klima, urged fellow EU leaders to help influence the coalition bargaining between the conservative People's party and the Freedom party in Vienna.

EU members rarely discuss each other's internal affairs, but Mr Verhofstadt told Mr Guterres that a governmental role for the Freedom party would have serious implications for the EU's democratic values. "We have to work quickly toward a common position of all the partners in the union," he wrote.

Portugal reacted cautiously. "In Austria, the new government has not been formed yet, so we have to wait and see," a government spokesman said.

If such a meeting were held, Austria would be represented by Wolfgang Schüssel, the acting foreign minister who stands to become chancellor if negotiations with Mr Haider succeed.

Diplomats said that while an EU meeting was unlikely on constitutional grounds, the issue could be discussed by leaders of the Socialist International, whose members include a majority of the EU's centre-left governments.

Glyn Ford, a Labour MEP, yesterday asked the EU president, Romano Prodi, if he was prepared to use EU treaties to suspend a far-right Austria "in the interest of protecting the rights of third-country nationals and minority groups".

Austria displayed shock yesterday to the international reaction."Austria is not a Nazi country!" blared the headline in the pro-Haider Neue Kronen Zeitung, the country's most popular newspaper.

Austria is now waking up to the fact that Mr Haider, whose party finished second in October's elections, could cause serious damage to its international image.

While Austria's president, Thomas Klestil, tries to avoid the sort of international embarrassment Austria faced when Kurt Waldheim came to power in the mid-1980s, public opinion is largely in favour of letting Mr Haider "have a go".

"We need a breath of fresh air in Austria and that's just what Dr Haider offers," said Helene, a retired nurse.

Most feel that the critical reaction from abroad is unwarranted. "The foreigners should shut their mouths!" said Gerte, a market trader. "We don't interfere with their affairs, so why should they stick their noses into ours?"

More than one in three Austrians favour a coalition between the conservatives and the far right, according to opinion polls. A further third want new elections, which Mr Haider is likely to call if the current negotiations break down. Mr Haider's personal popularity is around 37%.

Thomas Vasek, a journalist with the current affairs weekly Profil, said Mr Haider seemed to symbolise something modern. "He has differentiated himself from the Austrian politics of the last decades and represents a turning point and he makes the other politicians look old-fashioned."

Wolfgang Neugebauer, head of the Documentation Centre for Austrian Resistance , a government-funded body which works closely with the Jewish community, has been unsuccessfully sued for libel several times by Mr Haider for calling him a "rightwing extremist and anti-semite" whose party "contributed to the reputation of Austria as a Nazi country".

Prof Neugebauer said: "I have no faith in the democratic principles of Haider. I cannot predict what will happen if he comes to power, but I certainly have my fears," he said.

"Austria, like any other country has its fair share of anti-foreigner sentiment, but Haider has cleverly taken advantage of this."

The centre was founded to tackle the issues of Austria's Nazi past. "But increasingly we're having to deal with the present, and a rising anti-foreigner, rightwing, extremist tendency which Haider has stoked," said Prof Neugebauer.

"Jörg is celebrating his triumph now," one of Mr Haider's close advisers said. "For years the political establishment treated him like a leper. Now the conservatives are being forced to come to him on bended knee. And now he's perfectly at liberty to shut the door on them."

Austria displayed shock yesterday to the international reaction."Austria is not a Nazi country!" blared the headline in the pro-Haider Neue Kronen Zeitung, the country's most popular newspaper. Austria is now waking up to the fact that Mr Haider, whose party finished second in October's elections, could cause serious damage to its international image. While Austria's president, Thomas Klestil, tries to avoid the sort of international embarrassment Austria faced when Kurt Waldheim came to power in the mid-1980s, public opinion is largely in favour of letting Mr Haider "have a go". "We need a breath of fresh air in Austria and that's just what Dr Haider offers," said Helene, a retired nurse. Most feel that the critical reaction from abroad is unwarranted. "The foreigners should shut their mouths!" said Gerte, a market trader. "We don't interfere with their affairs, so why should they stick their noses into ours?" More than one in three Austrians favour a coalition between the conservatives and the far right, according to opinion polls. A further third want new elections, which Mr Haider is likely to call if the current negotiations break down. Mr Haider's personal popularity is around 37%. Thomas Vasek, a journalist with the current affairs weekly Profil, said Mr Haider seemed to symbolise something modern. "He has differentiated himself from the Austrian politics of the last decades and represents a turning point and he makes the other politicians look old-fashioned." Wolfgang Neugebauer, head of the Documentation Centre for Austrian Resistance , a government-funded body which works closely with the Jewish community, has been unsuccessfully sued for libel several times by Mr Haider for calling him a "rightwing extremist and anti-semite" whose party "contributed to the reputation of Austria as a Nazi country". Prof Neugebauer said: "I have no faith in the democratic principles of Haider. I cannot predict what will happen if he comes to power, but I certainly have my fears," he said. "Austria, like any other country has its fair share of anti-foreigner sentiment, but Haider has cleverly taken advantage of this." The centre was founded to tackle the issues of Austria's Nazi past. "But increasingly we're having to deal with the present, and a rising anti-foreigner, rightwing, extremist tendency which Haider has stoked," said Prof Neugebauer. "Jörg is celebrating his triumph now," one of Mr Haider's close advisers said. "For years the political establishment treated him like a leper. Now the conservatives are being forced to come to him on bended knee. And now he's perfectly at liberty to shut the door on them."

fields.headline: Germany's avenging superhero: Binman
fields.trailText: Mayka doesn't look like the sort who'd get into trouble. She has an open face and a ready smile. But, as she confided the other day, she is on probation - to the binmen.
fields.body:
Mayka doesn't look like the sort who'd get into trouble. She has an open face and a ready smile. But, as she confided the other day, she is on probation - to the binmen.

Just before Christmas, she was putting out the rubbish and found a notice stuck to the container. It began with a breath-stopping "Achtung" and went on to say that the bin had been vermüllt.

This is a word that has yet to reach the dictionaries. Finding an English equivalent is tricky. A rough stab would be "made the object of a garbage-related infraction".

What Mayka had done was to put refuse in the wrong bin. That is not hard. In the courtyard of my own block, there are no less than seven different sorts: green bins with white, brown and green lids for different sorts of glass; a blue one for paper, a yellow one for plastic and metal, and a brown one for "bio-waste", in other words plate-scrapings and other yukky matter.

There are also a couple of black bins. They are meant for "other refuse", but seem to get used at dead of night by backsliders like me - garbage delinquents - to slip in the odd vermüllt bag.

The problems this causes should not be underestimated: either you run seven different containers indoors, or else you divide it up by hand outdoors without, for example, disposing of the plate scrapings in anything as convenient as a plastic bag. That makes it pretty unpleasant: in summer the brown bins play host to maggots and often sport a thick layer of mould.

Mayka had put a milk carton in the paper bin, forgetting the lining was made of silver foil. Two more slips, and she'll face a fine.

The German concern for waste disposal is remarkable. In Berlin there is a campaign running on the hoardings to promote the image of the city's orange-uniformed rubbish disposal crews. Binmen giving high-fives. Binmen posing with their shovels. Binmen, in short, as contemporary heroes.

This is a reflection of the high degree of environmental consciousness which is both a cause and effect of the Greens' influence on German society. But it also underlines the sacrifices and restrictions that people here are ready to accept in pursuit of a perceived social good.

The conventional wisdom is that Germany is slowly being won over to a Darwinian, devil-take-the hindmost model of capitalism. But Germany's leaders are aware that a more consensual, collaborative social market model has deep roots in the habits and attitudes of German society.

In some parts of the country the yellow bin has been replaced by a transparent bag, so the binmen can see what is inside. If it is vermüllt , they simply leave it where it is.

For as long as those transparent bags remain in use, I, for one, will believe that the social market is still in place.

Capital Letters is a regular Saturday column rotating between Guardian writers in three of Europe's most vibrant cities: Moscow, Berlin and Rome.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.body: Byron Harris and others: an apology. To illustrate a piece headed Exile on mean street, page 4, G2, January 5, we used a picture of Mr Harris and four other men in a public house in Newport, South Wales. The caption read, in part, "Having fun in a Newport pub this week ..." The piece itself dwelt on the high crime rate and prevalence of "yobbery" in Newport. In fact, the picture was not a new one. It was taken in September 1996 with others to illustrate a music piece in the Guardian. In using it we did not intend to associate Mr Harris or any of the others with the behaviour described in the Newport article. We are sorry if such a connection has been made and apologise for the embarrassment caused. [The Readers' Editor writes about the inappropriate use of archive pictures on page 7 of today's Saturday Review.] In an article headed Crocked players are up in arms, page 32 (Sport), January 27, we referred to a report prepared by Dr Ivan Waddington of Leicester University for the Professional Footballers Association. We said that the report found that many club doctors were "unqualified, untrustworthy and inefficient". Dr Waddington has asked us to make it clear that his report made no such claim. Neither did the report say, as we said it did, that out of 58 medics who returned a questionnaire, only three were properly qualified. What it did say was that out of 58 club doctor positions for which data was available only three had been publicly advertised. It was the process by which club doctors and physiotherapists were appointed that the report described as "a catalogue of bad practice". Dr Waddington wanted to emphasise that all club doctors were qualified medical practitioners, although relatively few had specialist qualifications in sports medicine. It was not true, contrary to what we said, that "most of the report's allegations involve physiotherapists abusing the use of cortisone injections so that teams can field players carrying injuries". The report makes no such claim and nowhere mentions cortisone injections. It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Knutsford's first bid talks end in failure

fields.headline: Knutsford's first bid talks end in failure
fields.trailText: Knutsford, the takeover vehicle led by former Asda supermarket chief Archie Norman, yesterday disclosed that its first public bid approach had come to grief.
fields.body:
Knutsford, the takeover vehicle led by former Asda supermarket chief Archie Norman, yesterday disclosed that its first public bid approach had come to grief.

It has abandoned talks with Wassall, the mini-conglomerate turned venture capital fund, after failing to agree terms which would "satisfy Knutsford's objective for the future".

Industry sources said the two sides could not agree on price, with Knutsford not prepared to pay more than 370p a share and the Wassall board holding out for at least 420p a share.

London-based Wassall, which is led by Chris Miller and David Roper, said it was in talks with another potential bidder. This is thought to be Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the US buyout specialist, which is expected to make a £600m offer for the company in the near future.

Mr Norman, with his colleagues Nigel Wray, Nick Leslau and Julian Richer, will come under pressure from shareholders who piled into Knutsford in the expectation of a string of stunning deals.

The market expected Mr Norman, with his retail experience, to bid for the likes of Marks & Spencer or Storehouse and was disappointed when the first attempt was for relatively low-profile Wassall.

Mr Norman and his colleagues paid 2p a share when they bought into Knutsford, a small leather company based in Cheshire, in November last year. Yesterday the company's shares were being traded at about 180p each, almost entirely on the expectation that the new management team would transform any business they successfully bid for.

At the end of last year Knutsford hired three City investment banks to advise on possible bid targets.

fields.headline: A Country Diary
fields.standfirst: South Shropshire
fields.trailText: It was a cloudless morning. The giant trees on Whitcliffe were draped in white, legacy of an overnight snowfall. The brown ramparts of Ludlow Castle lifted into the frosty air above the silent, swirling Teme. Hanging far away as an immaculate backdrop, we picked out the unmistakable   profiles of Brown Clee and Titterstone Clee. The snow carpet crunched as we turned from that famous view to go up into the deep shade of Mortimer Forest.
fields.body:
It was a cloudless morning. The giant trees on Whitcliffe were draped in white, legacy of an overnight snowfall. The brown ramparts of Ludlow Castle lifted into the frosty air above the silent, swirling Teme. Hanging far away as an immaculate backdrop, we picked out the unmistakable profiles of Brown Clee and Titterstone Clee. The snow carpet crunched as we turned from that famous view to go up into the deep shade of Mortimer Forest.

Our only companions were grey squirrels and a pair of crows floating on high. The low-angled sun sent a lattice pattern of golden light across the narrow glade as we went up towards Mary Knoll where a magpie was chattering somewhere in the branches. The fresh footprints of a fox diverted us to the extent that we wandered far from the right of way.

Soon we were espied by the farmer, out feeding his flock. He didn't like our wanderings across that shining, frozen country one bit, but showed us where we should go so as not to frighten the deer on to a neighbour's land. The neighbour, he assured us, would soon turn them into venison!

A couple of tiny, off-white cloudlets were the only punctuation in the western sky as we skirted the clinging, hillside conifers of Bringewood Chase. Here was breathtaking view towards Burrington Common, shining white and over-arched with a silence only broken by the mewing of a buzzard quartering the wintry acres.

We came to the remarkable Teme gorge at Downton just as the sun dipped to the Welsh borderland. An orange glow touched the icy crest of Hunstay Hill. The deepening frost sent us on our way past Downton-on-the-Rock with its antique motte and abandoned church. Here is one of the true founts of industry: at Bringewood Forge, close beside the Teme downstream of the gorge, the charcoal crated from local coppiced oak was used to smelt iron ore from Elizabethan times.

Night had fallen so our journey through Oakly Park was illuminated by the radiant stars until we came in sight of the floodlit towers of Ludlow's giant castle.

fields.headline: Lifeline for small post offices
fields.standfirst: Government looks at automation subsidy
fields.trailText: The government is considering plans to subsidise Britain's network of more than 18,000 post offices to offset the financial impact of automation on their business.
fields.body:
The government is considering plans to subsidise Britain's network of more than 18,000 post offices to offset the financial impact of automation on their business.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, said yesterday that a cabinet office unit could recommend a subsidy from local government, the treasury or some other body to help keep them open.

There are widespread fears that the new postal services bill, unveiled by Mr Byers yesterday and designed to give the Post Office greater commercial freedom, along with the switch in payment of benefits from girocheque to automatic credit transfer, or ACT, could hasten the closure of up to 5,000 local post offices.

The network of 18,300 outlets - said by Alan Johnson, the competitiveness minister, to be 10 times the size of WHSmith, Boots and Tesco combined - is shrinking at a rate of 400 a year. Although the idea of a subsidy is certain to be anathema to the treasury, Mr Byers said the government should retain it as an option and give itself the powers to implement it.

He also bowed to a sustained campaign over post office closures by announcing that claimants will continue to be able to receive their benefits in cash at PO outlets, many of them run by self-employed sub-postmasters.

Automation of post offices is due to be complete by the spring of 2001, with 300 a week now being switched to a computerised system. Fully automatic payment of benefits is due from 2003, but Mr Byers said claimants could still demand cash over the counter beyond that date, and 2005 when it is fully operational.

The PO has warned that the new ACT system could cost it £100m in profits and hit £350m of the annual £1.15bn turnover of PO Counters, provided by the department of social security. But Mr Byers said the present system was based on post-war rationing books, and "to be honest we can do better than that in the first few months of the 21st century".

Each ACT transaction cost 1p to administer, he said, compared with the 79p for issuing a giro and 49p for processing an order book, delivering substantial savings.

But PO sources cast doubt on whether the switch would provide enough income for local outlets, and said concerns about the 2m without a bank account had yet to be resolved.

Mr Byers said most rural post offices, most liable to closure, served customers with bank accounts, and experience with child benefit showed more than half chose to have it paid into a bank account.

Under the bill, which is due for its second reading on February 9, the PO will become a state-owned public company able to borrow up to £75m as of right, and more with government approval, to invest.

fields.headline: Full steam astern
fields.standfirst: Brand values: Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company
fields.trailText: The fortunes of the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company have risen and fallen like the tides.
fields.body:
The fortunes of the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company have risen and fallen like the tides.

The shipping, property and services group better known as P&O, was at one time the world's largest shipowner. But it lost the passenger liner trade to the airlines and added to its problems by diversifying into the volatile housebuilding and property sectors in the 1970s and 1980s. The £400m sale last week of the bulk of its investment property portfolio was a big step towards returning to its maritime roots.

P&O is one of the few British firms not governed by the companies act. It was set up by royal charter in 1840 to expand the shipping business established in 1822 by Brodie McGhie Willcox, a London shipbroker, and the Shetland-born Arthur Anderson, a former Royal Navy clerk then working in his office.

Their ships travelled between Britain and the Iberian peninsula. During the Spanish and Portuguese civil wars in the 1830s, they ran guns and provided warships and troopships for the royal families involved. The red, white, blue and yellow quarters of P&O's flag represents the colours of the Portuguese and Spanish royal families.

The partnership later won a Post Office contract to provide a regular service carrying mail between Falmouth, Vigo, Oporto, Lisbon, Cadiz and Gibraltar. The 800-ton paddle steamer, the Don Juan, was wrecked on its return journey. It was only partly insured.

The business formally became the Peninsular & Oriental Steam Navigation Company in 1840 when it raised £1m to finance the expansion of its mail service into the Mediterranean and beyond.

The company, which transported mail for the Far East by sea to Egypt and then overland to the Red Sea, was caught on the hop when the Suez canal was opened. P&O had thought the canal venture would fail. It was a costly mistake and a number of inappropriate ships had to be scrapped.

As an economy, the custom of free drinks at meals for P&O passengers was ended.

The company later dominated the long distance steam ship routes serving the British empire east of Suez. Mail, passengers and high-value cargo - including opium for China - were all carried.

About a third of P&O's fleet was used for transporting troops to the Crimean war and bringing back the wounded. During two world wars, more than 260 P&O ships, most of them cargo vessels, were sunk.

The last liner built for P&O was the Canberra in 1961. It was later used during the Falklands war as a helicopter-carrying troopship.

The P&O fleet changed rapidly in the post war years, with the arrival of supertankers and container ships. The company was one of the founders of Overseas Containers, which pioneered the transport of cargo in containers which could be carried on ships or lorries.

P&O almost disappeared in 1983 when Trafalgar House, the construction group which also owned the Cunard line, made a takeover bid. The attempt failed after Jeffrey Sterling took over as P&O chairman.

His acquisition of European Ferries in 1987 got off to a bad start. About a week after taking control, the Spirit of Free Enterprise ferry capsized with the loss of 193 lives.

The cruise business is heavily dependent upon the strength of the US economy. Should that falter, the newly focused P&O could find the tide is flowing out yet again.

fields.headline: Underside
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown need have no fear for his place in history. At a "bash Ken" gig in Bloomsbury last week, Tony Blair - citing one count on an enormous rap sheet - noted that Mr Livingstone had had the temerity to criticise the chancellor's economic policies.
fields.body:
 Gordon Brown need have no fear for his place in history. At a "bash Ken" gig in Bloomsbury last week, Tony Blair - citing one count on an enormous rap sheet - noted that Mr Livingstone had had the temerity to criticise the chancellor's economic policies. This, said the prime minister, was entirely out of order, given that Mr Brown is the greatest chancellor of this century. Three weeks into the said century, that is praise indeed.

 Meanwhile, the chancellor's former colleague, breakfast radio star Geoffrey Robinson, spoke with pride on Radio 4's Today Programme this week about the job creation record of his TransTec engineering group in the west Midlands, recipient of much government largesse. "I'm very pleased to tell you there that we created nearly double the number of jobs that we were required to," he declared. Yes, but was it deliberate? Over in Northern Ireland - where TransTec trousered an even bigger grant, £6.9m - much of the company's job creation seems to have been entirely accidental. The Campsie plant, established in the mid-1990s, was designed to be largely automated, with a line of robots doing all the serious work. Come the day, TransTec bosses switched on the line only to watch in horror as the robots promptly went potty - throwing molten metal on the floor, boring holes in the wrong places and having an all-round nervous breakdown. In despair, TransTec stripped out the tin men and hired some old-fashioned engineering workers.

 Elsewhere in the world of high technology, truly shameless Y2K types are refusing to admit defeat, insisting instead that February 29 carries a special bug of its own and that consequently yet more money must be hurled at computer experts in an effort to avert total disaster, aeroplanes falling out of the sky, that sort of thing. But the man who started it all, Robin Guernier, is throwing in the towel. Mr Bug yesterday announced his Taskforce 2000 hit squad was hanging up its anoraks. "Taskforce 2000 has done as much as it can, so it is time for us to retire from the front line." This seems a bit defeatist. Why not arrange a merger with all the other outfits whose names incorporated the once so distant year in which we now live? Transport 2000, for example, the pro-train pressure group, and Energy 2000 - anti-nuclear power. Not forgetting 21st Century Television, the Gerry Anderson vehicle that gave us Captain Scarlet - not a chap to be frightened by bugs of any sort.

 No such allegations of impropriety are ever levelled at our nation's second financial centre, Edinburgh, where two banks with the same name - except one has a Royal in front of it - are in the final round of a battle for NatWest. Come midnight on Monday and the legal deadline for offers for NatWest will arrive. Given that Royal Bank of Scotland is expected to play multi-billion-pound chicken during daylight hours, how will it comply with the need to have any final final offer in the post by the time the iron tongue tolls 12? "It's a lovely thought - George and I would be spurring off to the door of the post office with bundles of papers," said Peter Burt, chief executive of Bank of Scotland, of his foe Sir George Mathewson, chief executive of Royal Bank of Scotland. But there isn't going to be another offer. Is there?

 Round at Port-au-Prince - alias Elm Street- senior tonton Fred Coford is departing for the private sector to ply his trade as a barrister at the criminal set in Hardwicke buildings, Lincoln's Inn. As Fred, 50, hung up his mirror shades, sources close to the best government lawyer at the serious fraud office - he has acted for the Crown since 1973 - warned that his current bete noire, Andrew Regan - the Monaco-based former bidder for the Co-op - ought not to relax. Extradition looms, with or without Fred. Meanwhile, the man himself was set a punishing schedule this week. Between torturing suspects he handled a packed leaving bash at the Calthorpe Arms in Gray's Inn Road, London, on Thursday night, followed by a serious curry with fellow assistant directors the next day and, hours later, a strictly non-TT Hardwicke gig presided over by head of chambers Patrick Upward, QC. His SFO leaving collection hit a record total, we hear - just as well, given the alleged redistribution of wealth to the brewers, distillers and wine merchants - with Mama Doc contributing all the way from Australia, where she is visiting family.

 Finally, we learn that the tontons - quite apart from the indignity of having to comply with the human rights act - have received a cabinet office circular on "diversity" in their appointments. Is there to be no end to the tontons' humiliation?

fields.headline: Blair tries to bury Seattle
fields.standfirst: Davos luminaries arrive by executive jet but then attempt to soften their globalisation message
fields.trailText: Bloodied but unbowed after the battle of Seattle, the forces of globalisation are fighting back - but gently.
fields.body:
Bloodied but unbowed after the battle of Seattle, the forces of globalisation are fighting back - but gently.

Nowhere is this clearer than in Davos, the Swiss mountain resort where Tony Blair yesterday joined other global political leaders and businessmen for their annual brainstorming session about the future of the world economy.

The prime minister captured the mood of the World Economic Forum - which represented 60-80% of global industrial production -by echoing the call of Pascal Lamy, the European Union trade commissioner, for a new round of global trade talks before the end of the year.

Failure to do so in Seattle had been a setback, he said, but it did not mean open markets and free trade were wrong. "The worst thing we could do for developing countries would be to shelve the trade liberalisation agenda and sit back while trade barriers are re-erected around the globe."

The way to succeed, however, was not to bludgeon civil society into submission, but use the power of argument to convince it of the benefits of free trade.

"We cannot afford another Seattle but nor can we afford to postpone the massive gains that a successful new trade round would deliver," Mr Blair said.

He is not the only one preaching the message of reaching out to the campaign groups, trade unions and others who eye globalisation as a despoiler of the environment and a destroyer of jobs.

The summit host, Klaus Schwab, founder and president of the WEF, and Donald Johnston, secretary general of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development, were singing from the same hymn sheet.

In his opening address, Mr Schwab announced two initiatives to counter the impression that Davos is just a celebration of money-making by the rich industrialised countries.

To make up for the damage inflicted on the clear Swiss mountain air by the mass arrival of corporate jets, Mr Schwab said the forum would plant some trees in Mexico.

His second initiative involved setting up a fund to reward social entrepreneurs with substantial cash prizes.

While both are small gestures, they are designed to send signals that the lessons of Seattle are being learned.

Even before Seattle, the OECD was forced to ditch plans for a multinational agreement on investment in the face of campaign groups' internet-based opposition.

Now the OECD is using the internet to publish the draft of a new code of conduct for multinational businesses, to ensure everyone is included in the discussion.

The big question, however, is whether these moves by the bankers of Davos amount to anything more than gestures.

Mr Blair suggested rich countries could demonstrate that they did by offering poor countries tariff-free access to their markets without expecting anything in return.

The Seattlites await their response.

webTitle: Byers up against Walls on ice cream

fields.headline: Byers up against Walls on ice cream
fields.standfirst: Court threat as competition ruling singles out market leader
fields.trailText: Birds Eye Wall's , the Unilever frozen food subsidiary, yesterday threatened to seek a judicial review after the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers backed competition commission findings that the manufacturer has been unfairly stifling competition.
fields.body:
Birds Eye Wall's , the Unilever frozen food subsidiary, yesterday threatened to seek a judicial review after the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers backed competition commission findings that the manufacturer has been unfairly stifling competition.

After four months of deliberation Mr Byers accepted the commission's advice that all leading ice cream makers should be prevented from sealing exclusive deals with shops. Wall's will also be barred from keeping other brands out of its freezers, although Mars and Nestlé will be allowed to continue this in an effort to strengthen their competitive position.

"These agreements tie the retailer to a manufacturer and restrict competition and consumer choice. I hope consumers will see more choice in the shops this summer," he said.

Mr Byers stopped short of backing a commission recommendation which would have decimated Wall's distribution network by limiting its direct distribution to national accounts such as the leisure groups.

Mars, which has waged a 10-year battle against Wall's UK dominance, was cock-a-hoop. Describing the commission's report as "very balanced", Mars Confectionery managing director Bill Ronald, said: "For the first time consumers will be able to buy the ice creams they want, when and where they want and to benefit from competition in the market."

But Wall's chairman, Iain Ferguson, said the rulings were discriminatory and unworkable, and represented excessive intervention which was out of step with new Labour's market rhetoric. He was particularly concerned about the ruling specifying a minimum 22.5% discount for distributors.

"How much regulation can a £300m market take?" he asked. "This is micro management which looks more like a centrally planned economy."

Mr Ferguson said the company was consulting lawyers in the belief that some of the rulings may be beyond the secretary of state's powers.

The competition commission report ended 20 years of official attempts to open up the ice cream market. Three previous official investigations have made various adverse findings but have allowed Wall's to strengthen its grip on the market. It now sells more than two-thirds of all "impulse" products - ice cream and lollies sold in small retailers and other outlets.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Autonomy yields riches
fields.body:
Autonomy yields riches

Mike Lynch, founder of Cambridge-based intelligent software company Autonomy, has become the UK's richest self-made internet millionaire with his personal wealth totalling £480m yesterday.

The fortunes of Mr Lynch, 34, have leapt from £19m when he retained a 21% stake in Autonomy as it listed on Easdaq, the pan-European technology exchange, in July 1998. He started the company in 1991 with a £2,000 loan.

Mr Lynch hit out at critics of the wealth created by the internet and at UK companies for failing to invest in technology. "England has to adopt the attitude of the US: if people work very hard and use their skills and initiatives then success is a good thing. The thing is that wealth will cascade into other entrepreneurial ventures, they don't all go out and buy Ferraris."

Ericsson turns the corner

Ericsson, the world's largest maker of mobile phone infrastructure equipment, yesterday reported record fourth-quarter sales and profit, and better than expected full-year results. The improvement stemmed from a late turnaround in its mobile phone handset business which has been revamped over the past year.

The results cap a difficult year for the Swedish telecom equipment maker which had been forced to issue two profit warnings and replace its chief executive. Full year pre-tax profits at SKr16.4bn (£1.2bn) were 10% down on the previous year but above market expectations of SKr15.5bn. Analysts said the 25% rise in sales and 39% improvement in profits during the fourth quarter, indicated the group had turned the corner and the restructuring was beginning to pay off.

Net privacy faces trial

A woman has accused DoubleClick, the US online advertising company, of illegally obtaining and selling personal information from a lawsuit filed in the US. If successful, the suit filed by Harriet Judnick could prevent the company from collecting personal information without the prior written consent of internet users.

The lawsuit could also have consequences for the growing number of companies attempting to make money by collecting personal information such as which websites people visit and where they live.

Rolls wins Brazil order

Rolls-Royce yesterday secured a $480m (£293m) order to supply its AE 3007A engines to power Brazilian Embraer RJ 145/135 regional jets being bought by US-based Mesa Air Group.

The order, for 36 aircraft, with an option to purchase another 64, brings to more than 1,000 the total of Rolls-powered Embraer jets, which carry between 37 and 50 passengers, being ordered by the world's airlines.

Brown fails debt test

Gordon Brown has failed to meet his pledge that four countries will receive long-awaited debt relief by the end of the month, according to campaigners.

Jubilee 2000 said last night that relief is due to reach Uganda, Mauritania and Bolivia, early next week. However, Mozambique will not be on the agenda, due to concerns that money it recouped would not go towards poverty reduction.

fields.headline: TransTec investigators widen net
fields.trailText: Three overseas companies have fallen under the eye of government investigators looking into TransTec, the collapsed engineering company founded by former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson. The holder of the third largest single block of shares is a string of companies based variously in Amsterdam, London and Switzerland.
fields.body:
Three overseas companies have fallen under the eye of government investigators looking into TransTec, the collapsed engineering company founded by former treasury minister Geoffrey Robinson. The holder of the third largest single block of shares is a string of companies based variously in Amsterdam, London and Switzerland.

Various offshore interests were earlier this week reported to have been brought within the ever-widening net of the two department of trade and industry inspectors appointed last week. They are thought to be looking at both Mr Robinson's own trust fund in the Channel Islands and other non-UK shareholders unconnected with the former paymaster general.

After Mr Robinson who has a 16.1% stake, the insolvent group ranks $1bn Boston hedge fund Baupost as its second-largest shareholder, with 10%.

The third largest, with 6.19%, is Ducroire SL, a company whose ultimate owner -as disclosed to the London Stock Exchange - is First Britannia Mezzanine Capital NV, of Amsterdam. First Britannia's Dutch office referred all queries to the office in London of Mezzanine Management Ltd (UK), based in the Strand.

Mezzanine - which described itself as an investment advice and business services company - referred inquiries to company secretary Roderick Brooks, a British subject living in Hamilton, Bermuda.

Mr Brooks is a director of Marigot Investments, which owns 50% of Mezzanine. Marigot gives its address as care of Mezzanine in London, and is 98% owned by Romande Nominees, of Switzerland.

Romande could not be contacted last night .

webTitle: Buoyant Vivendi cagey over mobile link-up

fields.headline: Buoyant Vivendi cagey over mobile link-up
fields.trailText: Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, yesterday set out its ambition to become a dominant player in European internet and telecoms activities - possibly in alliance with either Mannesmann or Vodafone.
fields.body:
Vivendi, the French media and utilities group, yesterday set out its ambition to become a dominant player in European internet and telecoms activities - possibly in alliance with either Mannesmann or Vodafone.

Jean-Marie Messier, Vivendi chairman, unveiling a 30% rise in net profit last year to 1.43bn euros (£861m), made plain that any future alliance would combine these activities in a single European group.

The Vivendi board dealt a blow to the lingering hopes of Klaus Esser, Mannesmann chief executive, that he could enlist its aid in beating off Vodafone's £95bn hostile bid by making plain that no decision on any partner would be made until after the bid battle was over.

The board's comments about "different possible alliances" came after reports in the French media of a full-scale merger between Vivendi and Mannesmann on a 40-60 basis.

The German telecoms group, pulling a growing number of rabbits out of its hat in the run-up to the February 7 closing date for Vodafone's offer, announced a deal with Deutsche Bank on e-commerce banking.

Europe's biggest bank and Mannesmann said they were forming a 50-50 venture, a pan-European tele-commerce bank, which would combine the telecoms, IT and branded banking capabilities of the two groups.

Drawing on Mannesmann's 35m customers, they said, the new venture would provide deposit, secure transaction processing and other banking services across the internet using both fixed-line and wireless platforms.

Mannesmann, separately, confirmed it was in talks with Bertelsmann, the German co-owner of AOL Europe.

Vodafone, meanwhile, watched serenely as shares in Affinity Internet soared on news of a deal to supply online content, games and e-commerce for its third-generation mobile internet services.

fields.headline: Big-screen visionary
fields.standfirst: He played banjo in a band before his eerie explorations of subterranean sexuality in fiction and film earned him literary awards and an Oscar for The Crying Game.  John O'Mahony on the brooding pioneer of Irish cinema who is not afraid to court controversy
fields.trailText: He played banjo in a band before his eerie explorations of subterranean sexuality in fiction and film earned him literary awards and an Oscar for The Crying Game. John O'Mahony on the brooding pioneer of Irish cinema who is not afraid to court controversy
fields.body:
In the lush surroundings of Jimmy's night club, the party to mark the LA premiere of Neil Jordan's new movie The End Of The Affair is getting under way. By the lamentably low standards of such movie industry junkets, it's a fairly lively affair.

The small but vocal Irish contingent seems to have injected into the frantic jocularity of the liggers and the mid-level execs an air of genuine good cheer. Even the celebrities, who normally evaporate after 25 minutes, are still nattering away contentedly: a radiant Julianne Moore is talking babies with Jordan's partner Brenda, Ralph Fiennes is expounding on a horseback trek he plans to take across Mongolia, and Brad Pitt, who worked with Jordan on Interview With The Vampire and is here with his burly minder out of solidarity, chats up the director's daughter Anna, 20, who looks uncannily like her father, but with kohl and piercings.

Only Jordan himself remains resolutely detached, flitting morosely around the room or sitting uneasily in some corner, drumming with his fingertips on the table, staring passionately into the middle distance. Occasionally, he's playful and endearing, such as when he captures Brad Pitt with an awkward bear-hug and yells an abrupt: "How are ya, Brad?" But equally, his manner is quite unnerving when he collides with a journalist by the bar, and the conversation instantly breaks down into stunted exclamations, laced with Jordan's characteristic "hmmmms" and "you knows".

In contrast, the company of his loquacious pony-tailed producer, Stephen Woolley, is easeful: "I just don't think that Neil has quite mastered the art of polite conversation," he says. "He finds it really difficult to talk about the weather, and all that usual stuff. Most things are completely peripheral to his vision."

Of all the characteristics and influences that come together in Neil Jordan, it is this enigmatic reserve that is perhaps the most dominant and intriguing. "He knows very well how to work that to his benefit," says Hugh Linehan, a film critic for the Irish Times who has worked on Jordan films. "He will give you that blank look intentionally, to try to make you feel awkward. I have seen him do that on the set. He uses it to force people to come up with things." It seems particularly effective with actors, who find in Jordan's careful reticence a delicate and unimposing guiding hand: "He hasn't got a fixed idea of what he wants," says Ralph Fiennes, who plays Bendrix in The End Of The Affair, "he's open to the journey of performance, and his manner is very easy. He's never in the least imposing. I just think that he's very collaborative, very open."

Even more vital for a filmmaker in search of funding, producers view Jordan's lack of frills as unalloyed dedication: "He is a person of talent and passion," says David Geffen, producer of Interview With The Vampire and Michael Collins. "He understands how to solve problems. He is not temperamental or difficult to work with."

It might even be said that in Jordan's work, in the career choices he has made and the dogged determination he has shown, and even the material he has produced, there is also the mark of his restive persona and its attendant curiosity. Though a pioneer of Irish film, he has maintained a distance from the nascent Irish Film Industry that has now sprung up around him. He has opted to make films with a visual daring unknown among his fellow Irish directors and of an almost startling diversity, from big Hollywood blockbusters - such as Interview With The Vampire, to highly intimate pieces - The Miracle, to his current adaptation of The End Of The Affair, by the quintessentially English novelist Graham Greene.

Though he identifies himself as "not particularly political", and though he feels that there is nothing wrong with the idea of republicanism, his capacity to whip up political controversy with the sheer, and almost naive boldness of his political dramas has remained undiminished.
