Overall, however, he feels he has achieved what he set out to do with his political films: "I think they had some impact. Now it's all about change, isn't it?" Neil Jordan was born on Febru ary 25, 1950, in Rosses Point, County Sligo, the second child of Michael and Angela Jordan. A few years later, the family relocated to Clontarf on the north coast of Dublin Bay, consolidating a fascination with the sea that Jordan continues to indulge both in his life and art. Life in the Jordan household was relatively free, though rather strict. Michael Jordan was an educationist involved in broadening the Irish school curriculum and was writing a thesis on the adverse effects of different kinds of popular children's literature. While he forbade his own children to read comics, he kept a pile in his study as part of his research. He forbade television, and he limited cinema-going to "once every two weeks, whereas all my friends would go twice a week", Jordan says. Any artistic stimulation the young boy had was provided in classes run by his mother, an artist, by his father's library, which was crammed with Joyce and Graham Greene, and through playing the guitar. In school, Jordan generally performed badly: "I was a slow learner," he says, "which was ironic because my father was an educationist. I was a living refutation of all of his theories. The only thing I had any interest in was literature." After attending a local primary school in Clontarf, Jordan moved on to St Paul's College in Raheny, a mid-level private school. "He was a very reserved boy, but in no way a loner; he always mixed with people," remembers his English teacher, Father Joseph McCann. "Though his English compositions were quite conventional for a boy of that age, if you looked at them again it was always possible to see some new angle." In his final years, he won the school president's prize for a short story entitled Sunday. At University College, Dublin, Jordan studied medieval literature - his thesis was on the lives of the saints - and English literature, which he didn't enjoy: "I didn't understand how they thought it possible to dissect a book like a piece of meat. It seemed far too clinical." He maintained something of a low profile, and though he was drawn to the college drama society, always remained somewhat apart from the crowd. "He was a very good-looking guy, with long black hair and sallow skin, and he reminded me of Yeats as a young man," remembers filmmaker and journalist Michael Sheridan, who was a contemporary of Jordan's. "He was a withdrawn, shy type of person who didn't mix very very easily; like the rest of us in college, his social graces were limited. But he had an air of mystery which people recognised and drew them to him." During his college years he met Vivienne Shields, a law student who would soon become his wife: "We just met at the university one evening, as you do," Jordan remembers. "All my friends were getting married, so I thought that I had better do so as well." When he left college in 1971, it was almost impossible to get a job: "With the degree I had, I was basically unemployable. If you go back to 1972-74 in Ireland, there was nothing to do, no jobs to be had." And so, at the first opportunity, he headed off with his wife to London, and worked on a series of labouring jobs, writing short stories in his spare time. He returned to Dublin in 1973, for the funeral of his wife's aunt, decided to stay, and picked up occasional jobs as nightwatchman and teacher. While Vivienne found work in law, Jordan minded the kids and wrote. "I suppose you could say I was a bit of a house-husband," he says. "I couldn't actually find a job. Vivienne was the one who was earning the money." Around this time, though, Jordan teamed up with the future film director Jim Sheridan and his brother Peter to put on a number of theatre projects around Dublin. Sheridan remembers they met at a lecture, "and I think that within three months we were doing a show called Journal Of A Hole, in the Project arts centre." Another piece they performed was Oedipus Rex, with Jordan playing Tiresias. "The reviews were all terrible," says Sheridan, "but Neil was quite brilliant as Tiresias. All he had to do was come out and exert his personality rather than act, and at that he was very good, very powerful." It was also at this time that Jordan began to rent out his talents as a musician. It would turn out to be a formative experience. He joined a group called Eilis to play saxophone and banjo: "Neil certainly brought a distinctive flavour to the material," remembers Niall Stokes, founder of the band. "We did stuff that had a vaudeville feel, where the banjo worked well. He wasn't a virtuoso but he was a good player." Many of Jordan's experiences with Eilis would form the basis of his first film, Angel, the story of a musician who swaps his saxophone for a gun. "I once arranged a gig in the lunatic asylum in Portlaoise," remembers Stokes. "While we were doing our sound check, the patients started to filter into the hall, watching us as we tuned up. It was a very strange experience, and one that ended up directly in the film." Throughout all of this, Jordan was writing, producing the stories that would eventually be published in 1976 as Night In Tunisia, with the help of a group that he had co-founded, called the Writer's Co-Op. The stories were immersed in the imagery of Jordan's childhood: sad and lonely beachfront vistas, unsuccessful musicians, all shot through with shimmering, subterranean sexuality. The opening story, Last Rites, is particularly bleak and brutal piece about the suicide of a labourer in a public bath. "Incredibly savage," he reflects now, "It must have just been the way I felt, I suppose, as if I hadn't any prospects. I was working in that place and I was going in to shower there every day. That idea just grew from that." The collection picked up the Guardian Fiction Prize, signalling for Jordan a bright literary future. However, at this time he was also being pulled in another direction. He began writing for television and radio, producing some episodes of a dramatised biography of Sean O'Casey, and a couple of TV and radio plays. Jordan attracted the attention of the film-maker John Boorman, who says: "I became aware of him through the short stories; they had a very cinematic quality. I recognised that he had a vision and a talent." As a result, Boorman took the unprecedented step of diverting £25,000 from the budget of his film Excalibur so that Jordan could make a documentary about its making. At the same time, he set about producing a new script for himself to direct, the work that would become Angel, the story of a Northern Irish musician's descent into violence. After showing the script to Boorman, Jordan convinced him to come on board as executive producer. However, Boorman was also chairman of the Irish Film Board, which would provide a chunk of the funding. Though Boorman resigned his position before the decision was made to fund Angel, this apparent conflict was to kick off the first, though not the last, major controversy of Jordan's career. Boycotts were organised and irate meetings held: "There was one meeting when everyone was blackballing Jordan," Michael Sheridan remembers, "and he is reputed to have left in tears." For the lead role, Jordan cast an actor well known in Dublin theatre circles named Stephen Rea, who would become his long-time collaborator. "He was monosyllabic, and I didn't say anything at all," Rea remembers, "so it would have been difficult for us to know each other very well. It's really only over the years that I could say I knew him, he really was very shy and very difficult to talk to." Rea remembers tension on the set of Angel: "I had a sense that a lot of the crew rather resented that someone so inexperienced was directing a movie." When the film was shown at Cannes, to attract video distributors, it became a late-night sensation: "It wasn't in competition: it was showing in some backstreet cinema at midnight," remembers Stephen Woolley. "I saw it and thought it was absolutely fantastic. I wanted to buy it for my own film company, Palace, which was then still quite small." After a battle with Channel 4, which initially didn't want to release Angel for cinema distribution, it ran in Woolley's Scala cinema in London, and became a critical hit which drew modest audiences. But the film did lead to a meeting between Woolley and Jordan that would change both of their lives: "Neil flew over to London and he stayed with me. I had a copy of his short stories which I had read. We just started talking about stuff, what kind of movies we liked and that was it." Jordan showed him the script that would later become The Crying Game, then titled The Soldier's Wife. But since a rather similar film - Cal - had just been released, Channel 4 mooted the idea of adapting Angela Carter's post-feminist short story, The Company Of Wolves. The resulting film turned out to be a hit in the UK, bigger than Ghandi or Splash. Then, in 1986, came the picture that really brought Jordan to public attention for the first time: Mona Lisa. He had hatched the idea after he read a crime report about a prostitute's "chauffeur". From a treatment by Jordan, the screen-writer David Leland wrote the first draft of the script, and Jordan produced a second draft. It was sent to Bob Hoskins, who had first attracted Jordan's atten tion in The Long Good Friday, but he initially turned down the central role. Then late one night, Hoskins recalls, he got a knock on the door and opened it to find a bedraggled Irishman enquiring rather brusquely: "Why don't you want to do my script, what's wrong with it?" Hoskins tried to explain that the central character was simply too violent, no more than a pimp, and that if Jordan came up with a second draft, then he might reconsider. Jordan went off to produce the rewrites, and Hoskins took the part. It was after the critical and box-office success of Mona Lisa that Jordan made the first and most major of his wrong turnings. First, he decided to go to Hollywood; and second, he decided to do a comedy. High Spirits was from the offset something of a bad idea: "Never let me do a comedy again," Jordan said after it. The result, a mish-mash starring Steve Gutenberg, Daryl Hannah and Peter O'Toole, was a disaster. The studio moved in at the last minute to re-cut the film, pulling Jordan from his holiday in order to bully him into making the necessary alterations. Immediately afterwards, he turned to We're No Angels, a script that David Mamet had written for himself to direct. Yet again, though not quite of the egregious quality of High Spirits, the film misfired and didn't do well at the box office. After We're No Angels failed, Jordan recoiled from the Hollywood experience to make The Miracle, with his then girlfriend Beverly D'Angelo playing an actress whose son falls in love with her when she returns to Ireland after many years away. Since the breakup of his marriage to Vivienne Shields, he had a number of girlfriends until hooking up with D'Angelo around 1986, in what has been described as a "tempestuous" relationship. By the time of The Miracle, complications had arisen in the form an affair Jordan had had with an architect named Mary O'Donaghue, when they produced a child. "The shoot degenerated into soap opera," recalls one observer. "It all came out in a very public way and it proved very difficult for all involved." For D'Angelo, it meant the end of the relationship. "I can remember that I really couldn't give myself to that role because of events that were going on around me in my personal life," she says, refusing to elaborate. Shortly after the split, Jordan got together with his personal assistant Brenda Rawn, his current partner. The Miracle was also a commercial failure, making Jordan's next project, The Crying Game, very difficult for producer Stephen Woolley to sell. Even when funding had been put together from a patchwork of sources, the difficulties were not over: "I didn't have enough cash, we had started the film and we couldn't pay anyone," recalls Woolley. "I was using the money from my cinema, the Scala, or maxing out my credit cards." To add to the complications, Jordan and Woolley were living under the same roof throughout: "We would just use a cup in the morning when we got up. Neither of us ever washed up. There were hundreds of cups everywhere. We couldn't take our own company, so it was quite intense." At first, The Crying Game failed to find a major distributor, and played at a limited number of cinemas in England. Jordan was now seriously talking about giving up filmmaking and going back full time to novels. Then, having refused to contribute to the funding, Miramax suddenly decided to pick up the film's US distribution, and it became the surprise hit of 1992, transforming the way that arthouse pictures were viewed in the industry, and eventually grossing about $70m. It was nominated for six Oscars, including best picture and best screenplay, for which Jordan was famously late picking up the golden statue. "I was waiting in the bar and suddenly everyone was yelling 'you have got to get up on stage'." As an excuse, he told the billions of viewers that he had been in the bathroom. "He thought that waiting in the bar would seem too Irish," explains Rawn, "but in LA, being in the bathroom had even worse connotations." Winning the Oscar began an entirely new phase in Jordan's career. Until then he had been pretty much written off as a major force, but now the offers came flooding in. His first choice was to launch himself into a project that had been brewing since the early 80s: the biopic of Michael Collins. However, even after the success of The Crying Game, no Hollywood studio was willing to risk the necessary multimillion-pound budget for a film about a man who was essentially an Irish terrorist. So, Jordan returned to Hollywood, at the request of David Geffen, to make the $60m Interview With The Vampire, based on the cult novel by Anne Rice. Much to Rice's chagrin, the film was to star Tom Cruise as Lestat, the lead role. Slated by the critics, the film ended up making $250m world-wide. In Hollywood terms it turned Jordan into a big hitter. At the same time, he brought out an elliptical novel called Sunrise With Sea Monster, which dealt with a young man returning from the Spanish civil war, a startling contrast to the overblown gore and indulgence of Interview. For Jordan, though the film may not have been his greatest artistic success, its commercial triumph enabled him to start work on Michael Collins. The script had originally been commissioned by David Puttnam in the early 80s, but it languished as a rival version, which was to star Kevin Costner, constantly threatened to beat it to the screen. However, around 1995, when Costner's project finally collapsed, and the IRA ceasefire made the prospect of doing the film far more palatable, the money finally came through. Jordan returned to the script and completed it within weeks. Liam Neeson remembers how he got the title role: "He had seen me do a production of Brian Friel's play Translations. He asked to meet me and we met on a Sunday afternoon in 1984. He said he wanted me to play Collins and that it might be a long difficult road. I began researching as much of Collins as I could and the bug got under my skin." Right from the offset, however, the project was destined to be controversial. Collins had been one of Ireland's most contentious figures, a man who invented modern urban guerrilla warfare and helped "bring the British Empire to its knees" in Ireland, but had done so with great brutality. To add to his curious position in the country's mythology, he had also been the genius behind partition, which had created Northern Ireland and sparked the Irish civil war of 1922-23. Shooting began in January 1996, at a breakneck pace. In one of the most astonishing gestures of support that any nation could offer a film project, 5,000 Irish extras turned up for the first day of shooting, none being paid and many being expected to bring their own costumes. However, almost as soon as the film was out of post-production, the controversy began. The points that were most objected to were: showing that the British used tanks on the first Bloody Sunday, August 22, 1920; the introduction of a meeting with Eamon De Valera, the Sinn Féin leader, before Collins's assassination in 1922; the cruelly accurate depiction of De Valera by Alan Rickman; and the combining of a number of characters into one. It was these contradictions, however, that Jordan set out to explore: "One reason why I wanted to make Michael Collins was because he was actually a very contradictory figure - the figure that republicans loathed. Yet he was the most successful exponent of physical force that ever existed here. The guy gave rise to all of these contradictions and I thought that it was very fascinating." The film went on to take more at the box office than any other in the history of Irish cinema. After Michael Collins, Jordan set about making what many regard as his most successful film on an artistic level, the adaptation of Patrick McCabe's novel The Butcher Boy. And then, true to his history of unpredictability, he moved on to make In Dreams, a curious psychothriller involving apples and starring Annette Bening, which was critically panned in the US and did very little business in Europe. Jordan had been itching to make a film of The End Of The Affair for many years. And though it failed to pick up any of the four Golden Globes it was nominated for last week, it is likely to be in contention for Oscars. However, what is most remarkable about the film is the way Jordan has made Greene's concerns his own: the Catholic imagery, the possibility of spirituality, even the religious theorising that bung up the end of Greene's novel, are all given a sparkling visual dimension. And in a move that is sure to raise a few eyebrows, the film even makes it to the sea: "When I re-read the book, I just thought that it would make a wonderful movie, that the love affair could be told from two viewpoints. And the themes are really not all that different from my other work. What comes up in my films is I'm kind of interested in the point where rationality breaks down and doesn't explain things any more." Life at a glance Born: February 25 1950, Rosses Point, County Sligo. Education: St Paul's College, Raheny; University College, Dublin (BA 1971). Married: 1971 Vivienne Shields (two daughters, Sarah, Anna). Current partner Brenda Rawn (two sons, Dashiel, Daniel). Publications: Night In Tunisia (short stories) 1976; The Past 1980; The Dream Of A Beast 1983; Sunrise With Sea Monster 1995; Nightlines 1995. Films: Angel 1981; The Company Of Wolves 1984; Mona Lisa 1986; High Spirits 1988; We're No Angels 1989; The Miracle 1991; The Crying Game 1992; Interview With The Vampire 1994; Michael Collins 1995; The Butcher Boy 1997; In Dreams 1999; The End Of The Affair 2000. Awards: Oscar for best original screenplay, The Crying Game, 1992; Golden Lion for best film, Venice, 1996, for Michael Collins.  The End Of The Affair is released in the UK on February 11

fields.headline: The trouble with Europe
fields.standfirst:
It is reform that will save the project

Economic and Monetary Union: special report
The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: It has been a chilly week in Europe. The continent's currency is plummeting, its political fathers are being humbled. The European Union is lambasted from all sides for its secretive, intrusive ways. This frost bites particularly keenly in Britain, where we have never quite made up our minds on the European project. Mere tactical nous will not be enough to get Labour out of this one: genuine vision will be required - and soon.
fields.body:
It has been a chilly week in Europe. The continent's currency is plummeting, its political fathers are being humbled. The European Union is lambasted from all sides for its secretive, intrusive ways. This frost bites particularly keenly in Britain, where we have never quite made up our minds on the European project. Mere tactical nous will not be enough to get Labour out of this one: genuine vision will be required - and soon.

The problem begins with the European Union itself. These last seven days have hardly been an advertisement for that unloved institution. The secret cash scandal currently gripping Germany is not only shredding the reputation of the former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, and his Christian Democrats, it is also casting a pall over the modern era of European integration.

Mr Kohl, alongside his late ally Francois Mitterand, were the driving forces behind the ever closer union of the 1980s and 90s. Now they stand accused of corruptly bending the rules of the democratic game in order to drive through their shared vision, thereby tainting it as much as them. For the CDU scandal plays to the criticism most often levelled at the EU: that it is a secretive club for politicians who have more in common with each other than with the people they represent.

This week's new EU rules on freedom of information confirm that impression. Some of the changes are welcome, but the overwhelming preference is for opaqueness over transparency. Bureaucrats' emails will remain out of reach, as will documents affecting discussions within the EU's institutions. "Repetitive" requests by investigative journalists will be denied: the EU has no desire to face the tenacious probing of a David Hencke. There is even a hint that national governments with liberal openness policies will be told to slam down the shutters.

It is all part of the EU's talent for proving its critics right. Sceptics say there is a democratic deficit, so it promptly produces freedom of information rules which one watchdog calls "a charter for secret, unaccountable and illegitimate EU decision-making". Others attack the Union for its meddling, money-grabbing ways - and, sure enough, word comes yesterday of an EU demand for Britons to pay VAT on toll roads. No wonder the EU is such a hard sell.

Yet, for Tony Blair, this was meant to be the easy bit. His strategy has been to remind the British people how much they like being in the EU before asking them to take the next step - by joining the single currency. If the EU looks undemocratic, corrupt and incompetent that becomes a hard case to make. It is made even harder when the euro seems such a suspect prize. Yesterday the new currency - intended to be a strong competitor for the dollar - continued its slump and ended the day more than 16% lower than the dollar, compared with its launch just over a year ago. In the short run this might be good economically for the single currency because it will help Euroland's much delayed revival by boosting exports. But it is bad for Britain: for the flip side of a weak euro is a strong pound, eroding our export competitiveness.

It also presents the PM with a paradox. To win a referendum on the euro New Labourites reckon two conditions will have to be met. First a Yes vote will require strong political leadership to win the argument and inspire support. Second, there will have to be a gut sense that Britain will lose out if we stay out. That means Euroland's economy will have to be expanding faster than our own - a state of affairs that would reflect badly on the government. If Mr Blair was held to have messed up the economy, then few would listen to his advice on the euro. And yet the longer the UK performs better than the single currency area, the harder it will be to convince people that we are not better off on our own.

It may be this paradox, and the stalemate that logically flows from it, that led to the PM's speech in Davos yesterday. He gave one of his now-familiar lectures to the nations of Europe, urging them to be like us, to acquire Thatcherite/Blairite flexibility in the workplace and to shake off clunky old welfare systems. But he also stressed how the UK's economic cycle remains out of sync with the rest of Europe: a signal that the government's five economic tests are not about to be met anytime soon. It sounded a lot like an admission that winning Britons over to the euro is a challenge that will have to wait. It will not be immediately after the next election, Stephen Byers said on Thursday. Maybe it will not even be in the next parliament.

The best option for Europhiles now is not simply to harangue the government to do more or blame the right-wing press for spreading such disillusion in the EU. Instead friends of the European project, led by this government, need to work hard to make the EU a more attractive prospect. If it were to be more open and democratic, then closer integration would not seem such a dread thought to so many Britons. Mr Blair should step up his demand for this kind of political reform, as well as for economic change, in Europe. Until then, joining the euro will remain a project of the permanent tomorrow - and never today.

fields.headline: ECB in the dock over exchange rate
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report

European Notebook Single currency
fields.trailText: With Rhodia just about to sign up a 1.2bn euro Anglo-US acquisition, thus increasing its exposure to sterling and the dollar, the chief of the French speciality chemicals maker, Jean-Pierre Tirouflet could scarcely contain his satisfaction with the new European single currency. From 1992 to 1997 European industry suffered from an overvalued exchange rate, he said, a situation almost entirely due to the "absurd" monetary policy conducted at the time. Now monetary policy is reasonable, he reckons; since its introduction at the beginning of last year the euro has lost around 15% of its value against the dollar. As a result, industry in the eurozone is enjoying a recovery.
fields.body:
With Rhodia just about to sign up a 1.2bn euro Anglo-US acquisition, thus increasing its exposure to sterling and the dollar, the chief of the French speciality chemicals maker, Jean-Pierre Tirouflet could scarcely contain his satisfaction with the new European single currency. From 1992 to 1997 European industry suffered from an overvalued exchange rate, he said, a situation almost entirely due to the "absurd" monetary policy conducted at the time. Now monetary policy is reasonable, he reckons; since its introduction at the beginning of last year the euro has lost around 15% of its value against the dollar. As a result, industry in the eurozone is enjoying a recovery.

Nor does Mr Tirouflet appear to be looking at a rally in the euro. He argues that, on purchasing power comparisons, certainly against the dollar, the currency is scarcely undervalued. Well, it may be a bit on the low side, but he and his Rhodia colleagues are not grumbling.

They are not alone. Some quite big bits of the eurozone have plenty to smile about. The fall in the exchange rate has not (yet) triggered a rise in inflation, though this week's import prices data from Germany and the country's current wage round are causing flutters of concern. Growth, however, is looking healthier. The predictions are for 3-3.5% this year and probably next. That may even be enough to make a dent in the double-digit unemployment levels.

Not that the euro can take all the credit. The eurozone might not have bought into the new economic paradigm - technology-driven growth with low inflation - to the same extent as the US but (European Central Bank willing) supply side reforms as well as a weak exchange rate are helping.

Europe has been hit by a whole series of mergers and acquisitions. Whether or not Vodafone Airtouch's hostile bid for Mannesmann succeeds, the German corporate sector will never be the same again. The changes to the capital gains tax regime proposed by the German finance minister, Hans Eichel, will help too, by making it more profitable for German businesses to unwind cross shareholdings which can be such a frustration to takeover activity.

Nor is change confined to Germany. France has (partially) shaken up its banking sector. Not that long ago a merger between the retailers Carrefour and Promodès would have been thought unthinkable. Now it is a fact. In theory at least there is scarcely a company in the CAC40 index which can believe itself bid-proof. France and Germany have put big bits of their defence companies together. Pharmaceuticals and chemicals are in the throes of change, albeit as part of a global shake-up. In the seach for global capital, continental European countries are increasingly opening their capital bases.

Nor should the technology impact be under-rated. On some estimates, Europe's knowledge-based economy is at least two-thirds the size of that of the US. Europe might have been slow out of the stocks when it comes to e-commerce, but it is making an effort to catch up.The only snag, as in the US, is whether the huge investor appetite for internet-related stocks is based on a once-in-a-lifetime innovation-driven change in the economy or an all-too-familiar bubble. Technology or tulip - the jury is still out.

The euro has had an impact on the supply side reforms. The development of the euro-denominated bond market has helped finance some of the deals which are changing the corporate landscape.

If international investors start to accept the idea that the euro-zone's big economies are capable of producing sustainable growth on the back of supply side reform and fiscal easing (as the Maastricht effect unwinds) then the euro may recover.

The snag is the ECB. Its stance over the last 12 months can best be seen as a benign neglect of the euro. However helpful export orientated sectors may have found that, it will no longer do.

The US Federal Reserve will be raising interest rates again soon, maybe as soon as the coming week. British rates have hardly peaked. With growth picking up and much of Europe looking forward to tax cuts - 20bn euros in France in 2001-03, for example - the ECB should be looking very hard at raising rates.

The temptation will be to argue that growth should be given a chance. But some of Europe's smaller economies are already running with the wrong policy mix. International investors are hardly likely to make the euro the currency of choice if they see the entire eurozone with a mixture of strong growth and loose fiscal and monetary policy.

This week the ECB council meets in Frankfurt. It could do worse than to signal that its members have learnt a trick or two from the Bundesbank. Now, there was an institution with a hawk's eye for inflation.

fields.headline: Audio
fields.standfirst: A magnificent performance by Heathcote Williams in The Revelation of St John the Divine, plus Prunella Scales reads Elizabeth Gaskell's Cranford
fields.trailText: A magnificent performance by Heathcote Williams in The Revelation of St John the Divine, plus Prunella Scales reads Elizabeth Gaskell's Cranford
fields.body:
The Revelation of St John the Divine

(Naxos, £6.99, 83 mn)

"Alpha and Omega..stings in their tails . . . the sound of many waters . . . Babylon the great, the mother of harlots . . . and the sea gave up the dead . . ." So, this is where they come from, these rolling phrases that drench our language and culture. Heathcote Williams, who pulls off The Divine Comedy for the same label, deploys a subtle dryness of tone for the chilling bits, warming up for the redemptive. A magnificent performance.

Cranford, by Elizabeth Gaskell

(Cover To Cover, £18.99, 405 mn unabridged)

This celebrated patchwork of scenes from a Cheshire village dominated by women has enough sharp edges to prod it from sinking into rural idyll. Prunella Scales uses her crystal diction to point up the petty snobberies, and softening her tones for the moments of pathos that make this beguiling book so moving.

fields.headline: The List
fields.standfirst: Feeling drowsy? plus Supercollector, Leonardo and The Pound: A Biography
fields.trailText: Feeling drowsy? plus Supercollector, Leonardo and The Pound: A Biography
fields.body:
The Promise of Sleep
William C Dement and Christopher Vaughan
Macmillan, £16.99
Buy it at BOL

Slaving away through the night with goose quill and purple ink, as I do each week to bring you the List (driven only by caffeine, nicotine and a crusading flame of literary duty), actually constitutes terrible "sleep hygiene". Going to bed and getting up at regular times is one of the important components of healthy sleep.

Among other things, this useful pop-science survey shows what we duvet-lovers have been trying to convince the rest of the hard-eyed, psychotically wakeful world for years: most people really do need more sleep than they get, and are chronically fatigued as a result - indeed, major disasters like the Exxon Valdez spill and Chernobyl can be blamed on sleep deprivation. (This is not the first appearance of such a thesis; it was first widely publicised in Stanley Coren's 1998 The Sleep Thieves.)

The rather unfortunately named Dr Dement offers useful self-help tests to determine exactly how much longer you should stay in bed tomorrow, and also gives an overview of the surprisingly young field of sleep science - the physiology of sleep, its relationship with the immune system, and the heated arguments about REM sleep (Dement argues that it's a hangover from the womb, when the developing brain entertains itself in the absence of external stimuli), all in a readable, bedtime-story style. Odd, though, that such a fat book should lack an index. You could fall asleep before finding something specific. Oh, maybe that's the point.

Supercollector: A Critique of Charles Saatchi
Rita Hatton and John A Walker
Ellipsis, £12
Buy it at BOL

Bracing neo-Marxist screed against the man of whom art critic Matthew Collings has said: "nobody can ever quite sum up what the problem is". Our two authors have done it now: the anti-democratic nature of private patronage, by someone moreover who lacks good taste, is strictly a bad thing for the evolution of modern art. Beautifully designed and handily pocket-sized, so you can whip it out to impress attractive strangers at a gallery.

Leonardo: The First Scientist
Michael White
Little, Brown, £20
Buy it at BOL

The first scientist - that puts Aristotle, Pythagoras, Roger Bacon, etc, etc, in their place. May as well say he was the first human being. You have to admire White's phenomenal work-rate, but you certainly don't have to admire a claim like this: "I show how his thoughts were literally sealed off from society and tragically wasted". Okay, so his notebooks were out of circulation for a while, but his thoughts literally sealed off? No. Nor do you have to admire the low-rent psychobabble about da Vinci's study of bird flight coming "from some convoluted wish to escape", and other such lunatic guff.

There's lots of fluent prose in the middle about da Vinci's studies of optics and human anatomy, but in the former field he was not nearly as important as Alberti, and the latter enterprise, after gory nocturnal dissections, produced brilliant drawings and useful empirical observations, but little in the way of systematic physiological discovery. In such cases White likes to exaggerate glimpses of the artist's "prescience" and downplay his metaphysical noodlings, or the bits he just got plain wrong.

White has many passages throughout the book of clear and fine scientific explanation, but it cannot stand the weight of his perverse thesis. The author grandly claims that Leonardo da Vinci was his "childhood hero". My childhood hero was Spiderman. Who do you trust?

The Pound: A Biography
David Sinclair
Century, £12.99
Buy it at BOL

Euroscepticism by Trojan Horse: a light, colourful history of our currency used, eventually, to bash the euro. Because we're deeply culturally attached to the pound, you see. Be hopping mad to let the good old pound go. According to the subtitle, it's "lasted a thousand years".

Of course it hasn't, but the trick is to start counting about 400 years too early, with a pile of silver pennies. Fine, but I suspect that numismatists aside, anyone who really cares about the pound, instead of any other random symbol of "ability to buy beer", would be someone to avoid at a party. If you really want to know about money you should read James Buchan's Frozen Desire. And is it a joke that Century is charging £12.99 for this? You give them the last nice gold pound coin and get a dung-coloured penny in return. I fail to see how anyone who loved the pound enough to read this book could bear to agree to such a depressing exchange.

fields.headline: Non-fiction
fields.trailText: Accounts from a courtier in Memoirs of the Duc de Saint-Simon, plus, Death in England: An Illustrated History, and Eisenstaedt: Remembrances
fields.body:
Memoirs of the Duc de Saint-Simon, Volume 2
Le Duc de Saint-Simon ed. Lucy Norton
Prion, £10

The accounts of a courtier with all-areas access to the new Versailles palace of the Sun King, sumptuous blocks offering a standard of comfort well below a grot motel. To survive demanded career management and self-presentational abilities Microsoft or Disney studio execs would find cruel: crash and burn and you were sent into permanent exile among the mud and morons of your country estate. All of which is described without self-aggrandisement and with real respect for the few nobles whose charity and dignity were scarcely noticed among the hunts and levées. Still daily relevant to the ambitious: how much is being there where it all happens really worth? Your soul?

Death in England: An Illustrated History
edited by Peter Jupp and Clare Gittings
Manchester University Press, £19.99

As works which stare the skeleton straight in the eye-socket are wont to be, peculiarly comforting. With a sharpish tone, notably on that brief period, just three Tudor decades, in which the whole business (in the financial sense) of bereavement was changed by state intervention: Henry VIII nationalised burial and suddenly ended around 1,000 years of the consoling Catholic concepts of purgatory and prayerful chantry intercession for the dear departed. That must have have been an extraordinary shift in people's personal and social landscape, as if we banned advertising now - the removal of a hope of a constantly deferred better future for all.

Eisenstaedt: Remembrances
(Bulfinch Press, £22.50)

Eisie said he'd have on his tombstone that he photographed the sailor kissing the nurse in Times Square, V-J day, 1945, an expression of hard-fought-for joy which still thumps the breath out of you with its immediacy, time folded in and out like a bellows camera. But he was more than an eye-poet: his wet night in the Place Vendme in 1932 is a film noir in a single still; his Duce gesticulating from a Venetian balcony should have brought down Mussolini forthwith - an exposé as well as an exposure. Or try Basil Rathbone and Angela Lansbury in crown and dressing gown pickily attempting a Paramount commissary meal, 1953. It's acting, dear, it's a living.

fields.headline: Fiction
fields.trailText: A stunning debut novel about growing up in Primrose Hill, plus The Metaphysical Touch, Scrapiron Blues, The Crime of Olga Arbyelina, and Mothers And Daughters In The Twentieth Century
fields.body:
Primrose Hill

by Helen Falconer

(Faber, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Books about growing up are all too often written for nostalgic grown-ups or framed as a word from the wise by someone who's been there and got through. Falconer's first novel is something else: a book that makes you taste the frustrations of being a teenager. If it weren't for HIV, Si and Danny would be blood brothers. They spend a summer watching the smog over London from a patch of grass on Primrose Hill. They watch the girls and smoke draw until Danny asks Si to help him murder his mother's violent boyfriend. Then the beautiful, reckless Eleanor gets involved and dreams turn to action. Intense and funny, painful and humane, Primrose Hill is a stunning debut.

The Metaphysical Touch

by Sylvia Brownrigg

(Phoenix, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Emily Piper is on the West Coast, licking her wounds after a fire which has destroyed her home and her PhD thesis; JD is hiding out, mourning the death of his dog and writing a "Diery" which he posts on the internet. These two misfits get linked up through cyberspace and slowly find a connection. Despite its use of geeky technology, The Metaphysical Touch is no You've Got Mail. Brownrigg judiciously stops Emily from unpacking her modem until after 100 pages and is never in thrall to a gimmick. It's a sensitive and wonderfully serious novel with characters who are home with Richard Rorty and Hamlet, yet are engagingly human and intriguingly weird.

Scrapiron Blues

by Dambudzo Marechera

(African Writers Library, £8.99)

Buy it at BOL

Tony and Janet are the worst-behaved characters in fiction, but then as a writer Marechera is not above reproach. There's the moment when he dreams of sleeping with one of his heroines. Tony, Janet's husband, is none too happy with that, nor with being handed out a life as a hack copywriter. The story cycle "Tony Fights Tonight" is a stylish and brilliant introduction to this posthumous collection from Marechera, a Zimbabwean writer who died in 1987. This bitter-drunk's Harare has much more in common with Carver's America than any notion of post-colonial Africa. Marechera is impassioned, angry, funny and highly readable.

The Crime of Olga Arbyelina

by Andrei Makine

(Sceptre, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Makine, a Russian who lives in Paris and writes in French, has a truly original voice. His second novel deals with the strained, distorted world of the White Russian emigré community, and the parallels with Nabokov's The Gift are easy to see. Princess Arbyelina lives in quiet poverty, as unremarkable as her compatriots, until she is found on a riverbank next to a corpse. For a while she becomes an object of curiosity for the Russians and French alike. For want of evidence the charge of murder against her is dropped, but as her life is traced back and her relationship to her haemophiliac son is revealed, another crime more horrific than murder is disclosed.

Mothers And Daughters In The Twentieth Century

ed Heather Ingman

(Edinburgh University Press, £16.95)

Buy it at BOL

This anthology's primary purpose is academic, but for lay readers Ingman's selection is a neat way to pick through the best of women's writing from last century. I'm not sure that the excerpt from Jean Rhy's Wide Sargasso Sea really fits the remit except that the mother and daughter connection is absent. In contrast, Margaret Drabble's piece on the gut-wrenching, almost insane need of a mother to be with her daughter, and Tilly Olsen's description of a mother's failure towards her first-born, have the right effect - they make you want to search your shelves or nip out to the book shop for the whole novel.

fields.headline: Speculating on creation
fields.standfirst: Physicists used to model the universe; now they play the markets
fields.trailText: Physicists used to model the universe; now they play the markets
fields.body:
Strange Beauty: Murray Gell-Mann and the Revolution in Twentieth-Century Physics
George Johnson
Jonathan Cape, £18.99, 434pp

The Predictors: How a Band of Maverick Physicists Set Out to Beat Wall Street
Thomas A Bass
Allen Lane, £18.99, 309pp

Buy it at BOL

Many have dreamt of finding the hidden order at the heart of things. Physicists have a fair claim to be the best at actually doing it, at least if the search is for structure rather than meaning. But how far can they go?

Murray Gell-Mann was well placed to go as far as humanly possible. A boy genius, he came of age when post-war America was showering physicists with dollars in gratitude for building the bomb. By his late 20s, he was a full professor at CalTech, with a handsome salary and all the time in the world. And there was plenty for a gifted theoretician like Gell-Mann to ponder. Government largesse extended to building larger and larger machines to smash together the sub-atomic particles which seemed to hold the secrets of creation. The result? A veritable zoo of new particles: pions, mesons, kaons, X-particles. But no one knew how they all fitted together.

After Newton, Einstein and the quantum theory, theoreticians knew they must hunt for some pattern in this apparent chaos. In the mid-50s, Gell-Mann was recognised as a powerful talent at the mind-stretching work of spotting a bit of mathematics in reality, or maybe a bit of reality in mathematics. But would it be enough? The boy who grew up knowing all the right answers about everything had a few problems. He was working on questions to which no one knew the right answers. He was in a highly competitive intellectual game in which all the other players had been the smartest kid on the block, too. And he hated being wrong.

George Johnson, a fine science writer here trying his hand at biography, does a great job of showing how Gell-Mann's eventual success left him the most celebrated, but also least well-liked, physicist of his generation.

He made not just one but three startling proposals. The last of these, the existence of the new elementary particles he dubbed quarks, became the basis of the "standard model" of fundamental forces and particles, on which all subsequent physics is built. Yet each of Gell-Mann's ideas was also proposed independently by other scientists, and Gell-Mann's treatment of his colleagues' achievements ranged from grudging acknowledgement to outright denial.

This, combined with exasperating compulsions like showing off his linguistic skills by correcting new acquaintances' pronunciation of their own names, endeared him to few. Co-workers who had seen his mind at work at close quarters were often lost in admiration. Others saw someone undeniably impressive, but far from admirable.

This is conventional biographical spice. Johnson's best trick, though, is re-creating the sheer confusion of particle physics from the late 40s to the early 60s. He has to do this so you appreciate the magnitude of the theorists' achievement. But he has to do it without utterly confusing the reader. Competing proposals for fitting together particles, forces and fields - or maybe doing without fields altogether - come thick and fast, but the final quark model seems almost as satisfying as it must have done to Gell-Mann.

Even then, he hedged his bets. But their new venture, Prediction Company, is altogether more serious. They take as many psychic risks as Gell-Mann ever did, but they take financial risks as well. To divert even a tiny fraction of the capital sloshing around the globe so it comes your way, you have to trade many millions of dollars. Some days, however smart your computers, you lose the lot. Ask Nick Leeson and Barings. The "edge" Doyne and Farmer and all the computing hot-shots they recruit are looking for, if it exists, is a matter of averages, not sure-fire wins. It is a long game, needing deep pockets, steady nerves, and lots of confidence.

Confidence, of course, they have. They are physicists after all. In their heart of hearts they know there is order in the haphazard moves of the markets. And they know they can find it if their maths is clever enough, their data feeds fast enough.

Bass tells a gripping story of how they succeed. A bunch of intellectual riff-raff sitting in an ill-furnished box in Santa-Fe gradually turn themselves into a well-managed company delivering reliable software to Swiss Bank Corporation. The bank in turn is reinventing itself to become one of the most profitable players in the new markets, which don't involve anything as old-fashioned as investing in real enterprises. They are high-wire financial jugglers whose talk is of arbitraging, hedge funds, and derivatives, and more and more of computer modelling.

As Bass's story unfolds, it becomes clear it is part of a larger shift during the 90s, and Prediction Company is just one of many bands of physicists and mathematicians building black boxes for the bankers. Doyne and Farmer always believed they would eventually take a share of the cash and go back to theorising about the evolution of complex systems, free of academic obligations. But there is no sign that they have yet. Any new boy (or girl) genius who might outdo Gell-Mann in bringing order to future physics will have to deny temptations he never dreamed of.

fields.headline: Love in the Lab
fields.trailText:
One day

the technicians

touched souls
fields.body:
One day

the technicians

touched souls

as they exchanged

everyday noises

above the pipette.

Then they knew

that the state of molecules

was not humdrum.

The inscriptions

on the specimen jars

which lined the room in racks

took fire in their minds:

what were yesterday

mere hieroglyphs

from the periodic table

became today urgent proof

that even here -

laboratory life -

writing is mystical.

The jars glinted under their labels:

it had taken fifteen years

to collect and collate them.

Now the pair were of one mind.

Quietly, methodically

they removed the labels

from each of the thousands

of jars. It took all night.

At dawn, rows of bare glass

winked at their exhausted coupling

against the fume cupboard.

Using their white coats

as a disguise

they took their places at the bench

and waited for the morning shift.

 From Jo Shapcott's collection of poetry, Her Book, published by Faber (£8.99).

webTitle: After the droughts and the locusts

fields.headline: After the droughts and the locusts
fields.standfirst: André Brink tells Nicholas Roe how he keeps riding with the times
fields.trailText: André Brink tells Nicholas Roe how he keeps riding with the times
fields.body:
By 1958, when the Afrikaner writer André Brink was only 23, he had already published two novels and seen his first play produced. It was a highly promising start to a literary career but no real surprise to Brink. "I knew from the age of nine that whatever else I might become - a train driver or street sweeper or whatever - I would also be a writer," he recalls. "It was a compulsion."

His career was apparently mapped out when he set off for Paris for post-graduate study at the Sorbonne, but in France the course of that career was irrevocably changed. "The influence of the existentialist writers, Camus in particular, fundamentally altered my writing and the way I looked at writing," he says. "My early work suddenly seemed terribly sterile and naturalistic. And from 10,000 kilometres away, South Africa began to look like a startlingly different place."

Brink returned home a changed man. He became editor of Sestiger , an avant-garde literary journal that gave its name to a group of South African writers - Sestigers - who began in the 60s to challenge the stifling literary and social conventions of Afrikaner culture.

"You have to remember what Afrikaans fiction looked like at the time," he explains. "Novels were totally dominated by droughts and poor whites and locusts. We were the first generation of writers to challenge that and to try and write in an up-to-date way, influenced by the cultural cross-currents in Europe and elsewhere. Initially our challenge wasn't overtly political. It was more focused on the moral and the religious and the sexual. But over time it did begin to acquire a much more specific political thrust."

Brink's progression towards outright opposition to the Pretoria regime culminated in him being the first writer in Afrikaans to have his work banned. His 1974 novel, Looking on Darkness , had been acclaimed by fellow South African author Alan Paton, but its treatment of a sexual relationship between a black man and a white woman proved too much for the state censors.

"The experience was initially devastating. If you write in a small language not understood anywhere else in the world and you are banned, you become a non-person because you have no readers," he says. "So I started writing in English alongside Afrikaans. I thought it would ensure that even if I could not be read at home, at least I could survive temporarily abroad."

The strategy paid off. While his work continued to be suppressed in South Africa, overseas his reputation was steadily enhanced; he was twice shortlisted for the Booker Prize in the 70s for his novels An Instant in the Wind and Rumours of Rain . "It was a weird time, to say the least," he now says. "But in a curious way it was also very fulfilling. That is the advantage of working in a situation of oppression. Literature suddenly becomes the sort of thing that is reported on the front page of newspapers. You are involved in something larger than yourself and something, you hope, that will be worthwhile."

Brink's burgeoning use of English also provided an unexpected artistic spur. "Every language is better geared to saying some things and not others," he explains. He now writes the first drafts of his novels in a combination of English and Afrikaans before re-working - a more accurate description than translating -the text for publication.

"It's a terribly complex process and it's just as well that no reader has access to it," he laughs. "Sometimes I write virtually the whole thing in English. In my book On the Contrary I needed to think in terms of an 18th-century novel, and as there were no models in Afrikaans I fell back on Fielding and Sterne. But my last novel, Devil's Valley , is set in an archetypal Afrikaner village and the first draft was largely in Afrikaans. But there were 13 drafts in all, so the character of the book changed as it was formalised. The final Afrikaans and English versions are never identical."

As an award-winning translator of Spanish, German, English and French works into Afrikaans, Brink says that, when translating someone else's work, he is completely faithful to the original. "But when it's my book I don't give a damn about the original author."

For a novelist who, during the apartheid years, had explicitly set out to fulfil the role journalists were prevented from carrying out, the election of a majority government in 1994 could have been something of a double-edged sword. Did he ever feel like an author deprived of a subject?

"Perhaps for one moment there was a sense of, 'Oh my God. What can I write about now?' But then came this heady discovery of the spectrum widening so much, and there was infinitely more to write about than ever before."

Devil's Valley is part adventure yarn and part magical allegory: an investigative journalist goes in search of an isolated and ferociously close-knit religious community. There is little of the political directness of some of his anti-apartheid period books, but the distinctive strengths and, mostly, weaknesses, of the Boer mentality - in an admittedly extreme setting - are again perceptively probed and exhibited.

"South African literature in general has been assessing the new situation and trying to come to terms with it," Brink says. "And as yet there have been few spectacular new advances. But in terms of my own work, the elation has continued. If there is anything that frustrates me, it is that there are so many new things that I simply cannot write fast enough."

• Devil's Valley by Andr Brink is published by Vintage

fields.headline: Warts and all
fields.standfirst: Daniel McNeill's The Face leaves no spot unsqueezed
fields.trailText: Daniel McNeill's The Face leaves no spot unsqueezed
fields.body:
The Face
Daniel McNeill
Penguin, £7.99

Is it ever right to judge a book according to the facial comeliness of its author? Of course not, you'll say, how could you even think such a thing? But, in the case of a book about the face, one toys with such ideas; particularly if the author photograph on the back jacket reveals a pixie-ish, bearded face, hidden from above the eyebrows by a hat (why? To hide baldness? To look like a beatnik?), and generally looking more like the kind of doctor who plays in a jazz band than a proper, scholarly author.

"Ayn Rand placed a preposterously beautiful sketch of herself on book jackets," says McNeill, and adds later on that "the portrait of myself on the jacket of this book may not quite be me"; a footnote tells us that "it is". Which is a shame, as he could have had some fun with our expectations. "Can I infer my spirit from my physiognomy?" asked Wittgenstein, but I'm afraid I forget the answer, and McNeill doesn't put in the question.

Still, it's probable that you won't be able to think of anything else he's missed out. This is a pell-mell, fact-stuffed tour of the face, starting with a biological tour of its constituent parts; the face's first principles. Why do we have a face that looks the way it does? Why do our nostrils point downwards, unlike almost every other animal's? Why do we not have a muzzle?

Sure, you could have looked this up in Darwin, and indeed some of you may already done so, but this is the kind of popular-science book that supplies all these answers for us, along with a historical and cultural overview. McNeill has read widely, not just in his anthropology, advertising the interior mental furniture of the better-than-averagely cultivated person: Hardy, Eliots TS and G, Freud of course, Montaigne, and Pynchon. Well, if you've gone to the trouble of reading V, why not alert others to the fact? Look on it as a badge of honour, like the Melanesian tribesmen (unnamed here, sadly) who tattoo a mark on their faces for each warrior they have killed; one chieftain boasted 95 such.

Each page yields something you may raise an eyebrow at. Or fail to. "With sadness, distress, grief, and guilt, the inner eyebrows rise and wrinkle the center of the forehead. Fewer than 15 per cent of people can fake this gesture." The time lost in the accumulated darkness of each blink amounts, on average, to 23 minutes a day. A German expression "likens a smacking kiss to a cow pulling its hoof from a swamp". (It does not do to think about that last one too much. "Liebchen, kissing you is so delightful, it makes a sound like..." Eurgh.)

I was glad to learn from here the rudiments of applying make-up, particularly the tricks you can use to make your nose seem shorter, and give-aways that help you spot liars, although no one can invariably spot one. (The profession which tests highest for fraud-recognition is the Secret Service, significantly ahead of Federal polygraphers, or lie-detectors to you and me.) Americans and Jordanians are so out of tune with each others' facial codes that each can fib to the other until they're blue in the face - a phrase that McNeill misses, which is a shame, since he might have had something illuminating to say about it.

But not that illuminating: this is an overview, wide rather than deep. There is little deuxième degré or conceptual hurdling; but then if a book ever had a good excuse for being superficial, this is it.

fields.headline: Giant steps
fields.standfirst: Nicola Barker's new novel, Five Miles from Outer Hope, takes the staples of adolescent drama and transforms them into something quite unrecognisable.
fields.trailText: Nicola Barker's new novel, Five Miles from Outer Hope, takes the staples of adolescent drama and transforms them into something quite unrecognisable.
fields.body:
Five Miles from Outer Hope
Nicola Barker
Faber, £9.99, 191pp

Novels that strive to capture the agonising awkwardness and painful confusion of teenage life often provoke particular responses in their readers, many of them based on semi-appalled and semi-relieved retrospective empathy. Frequently, one might describe such writing as "bittersweet", "sensitive" or "knowing", or praise the author's ability to evoke a time of life that is, by definition, transitional, unstable, afflicted by virtually constant emotional and mental upheaval.

So it's a relief to note that there is very little of any of this about Nicola Barker's new novel, which takes the staples of adolescent drama (appearance anxiety, thwarted intellectual development, family squabbles and raging hormones) and transforms them, by a process of wildly excessive invention, into something quite unrecognisable.

The heroine of Five Miles from Outer Hope is 16 years old, and outlandishly tall: "six foot three in my crocheted stockings... with a tongue taut and twisted as a tent-hook and two tremendous hands like flat meat racquets." Not only is Medve tall - far, far taller than the rest of her tiny family - but unusually conspicuous, knock-kneed and rotten-toothed, clumsy and lumbering, frequently dressed in flip-flops, an embroidered kaftan and a fur-trimmed hide waistcoat.

It's lucky, then, that there are few people to see her as she passes a summer in the company of her equally unprepossessing family on a semi-detached island off the coast of South Devon, where they camp out in a derelict hotel and eke out a living painting novelty pottery (it's 1981, and Margaret Thatcher is a popular caricature).

Even Medve's family is temporarily incomplete, with her mother Mo off in the States promoting her new invention, an anal probe, to the prison service; her sister Poodle nowhere to be found after being ill-used by a local lad who named and shamed her for being flat-chested; and her brother Barge recuperating from a hideous tongue injury sustained while defending Poodle's dubious honour. Anyone musing on the peculiarity of Barker's character-naming will find their answer in the paterfamilias's fondness for Thurber.

The rump of the family - Big, their four-foot-nine daddy; an intellectually switched-on 12-year-old girl named Patch, the four-year-old Feely ("When he grows up he wants to be bulimic. He thinks it's a veterinarian who specialises in livestock"); and Medve herself - are living in a precarious state of quasi-harmony, inhabiting various wings of the hotel, living off ancient bar snacks and being unfeasibly vile to one another.

The last thing they need - particularly Medve, who, along with the problems that her physique presents, dreams that a serial killer is imprisoned inside her head eating cockroaches for protein - is a stranger coming along to disrupt the fragile eco-system of family life. Least of all when he is a bad-skinned, ginger-haired, balaclava-wearing oddball reeking of antiseptic.

Barker, it will already be apparent, is attracted to weirdness, and she is wonderfully able to sustain it over the length of a novel, albeit a relatively short, delightfully plotless and artfully baggy one. Any narrative coherence that can be detected derives from the guerrilla warfare between Medve and the stranger, La Roux, which is conducted with all the booby-traps, ambushes, conspiracies and lunatic skulduggery of a Shakespearean comic sub-plot. Their final skirmish, the end-game of a whole series of strikes and counter-strikes, involves a fake centipede and La Roux's morbid fear of the vagina. Enough said.

Far more impressive a literary creation, however, is Medve herself, who harangues us throughout (example: "No. Of course I don't know what I'm getting myself into. Lighten up a little. Weren't you ever sixteen?"), drenching us in a tidal wave of digressions of Tristram Shandy proportions, alternately cajoling and scolding, veering recklessly between showing off and beseeching. Her voice is witty, infuriating and unbelievable, her account of the summer's unfolding disasters at once gobsmackingly over-the-top and curiously evasive.

In short, despite the fact that she is unlike any 16-year-old you're ever likely to meet (unless you're very unlucky), she is also just like all of them: egotistical, insecure, over-confident, under-confident, shy, brash, whiny, demanding. This novel, which cleverly side-steps the traps of earnestness and seriousness, could well be read as a sort of literary tonic for enervation and grumpiness, the latest welcome despatch from Barker's determinedly perverse and ungovernable imagination.

fields.headline: Flesh for fantasy
fields.standfirst: Candida Clark's new novel, The Constant Eye, is misleadingly packaged as a slab of tasteful, aspirational erotica.
fields.trailText: Candida Clark's new novel, The Constant Eye, is misleadingly packaged as a slab of tasteful, aspirational erotica.
fields.body:
The Constant Eye by Candida Clark 200pp, Chatto, £10

Buy it at BOL

Candida Clark's new novel is misleadingly packaged as a slab of tasteful, aspirational erotica, conjuring up glossy-haired, aerobic adventure under stylish lighting conditions of midnight blue and suggestive mauve. But between the covers, sex is an apocalyptic, animal clash of meat and blood that takes place in Eurostar toilets, the "warm slide of cuntcock" that leads to madness and death. That, too, is a cliché, but Clark is a more original writer than her milieu might initially suggest.

This febrile tale is at first narrated by a male writer, an aficionado of locomotive seduction, who flirts and then copulates with the woman sitting opposite him on the train to Paris. He, the cynical literary roué, is baffled by unaccustomed feelings of helplessness, and when they get off he takes her to a hotel and then out to dinner, where she disappears. More than this it would be invidious to reveal, but the first part of the novel ends in a veritable cliffhanger.

Clark's tone is an idiosyncratic mix of icy elegance and stewed carnality. Sex here does not romantically transcend the physical; transcendence must be found in the bloody sinews of the meat or not at all. The bestial humping is muscular and laudably free of mimsy euphemism (though "my cock springs to attention" seems hydraulically imprecise). Emotional states, meanwhile, are incarnated in striking images of bodily tissue suffering violence. The writer's fantasy of escape from thinking, for instance, has him imagining hacking out his own brain: "I dream of the surreptitious cut and slice that would remove this thumping grey rubbish from my head."

Eyes are not windows of the soul but merely glistening, dumb pieces of meat. Clark's neo-gothic stylisation is signalled by the woman's unrealistic possession of "hot gold eyes", and the writer is repeatedly enraged because he cannot "make her see" with "the words that soar around me, screaming from my eyes". The writer's eye is not constant (he is unfaithful), and the woman lacks a constant I, as her personality grimly unravels. In the last of a series of titillating postmodern caresses, it is the single appearance of an authorial "I" that pins down the writer's savagery, in one story not of his own making.

Clark's prose teems with inventive imagery, such as a vision of rooks "like black hangman's hoods [...] shot down with arrows". Her tonal control can slip, however: that rook image is nearly spoiled by the superfluous characterisation of the rooks as "insane", and the reader is elsewhere bombarded with pathetic fallacy: visions of a "rotting sun" or trees on a riverbank like "a thousand sordid hands". The richly energetic melodrama of Clark's metaphors sometimes dissolves into the meaningless portent of a phrase like "midnight's fatal pulverisation".

The novel's characterisation is schematically Manichean: the writer is at once psychologically brutal and self-laceratingly conscious of his own brutality; the woman understands her lover perfectly, yet is in thrall to a doomed and senseless love. Clark is certainly a clever writer, and it is a sort of courage to risk absurdity in the search for emotional precision. But the splinters of grim psychological acuity are eventually overwhelmed by a crescendo of grand-guignol angst.

This is really a corset-ripping vampire story, with the writer as bloodsucking anti-hero. The writer swallows other people's lives and "pukes" them up in his work, while the woman's certainty that "In the beginning were no words" is eventually rewritten by the writer's smug solipsism: "In the beginning were his words." One smells a reheated thesis of phallogocentrism. The Constant Eye offers a perverse, unusual kind of fun, but in the end it's hard to meet its gaze and keep a straight face.

fields.headline: Beautiful falsehoods
fields.standfirst: Tim Radford  delights in Alice Carter's history of National Geographic artwork
fields.trailText: Tim Radford delights in Alice Carter's history of National Geographic artwork
fields.body:
The Art Of The National Geographic
Alice A Carter, foreword by Stephen Jay Gould
National Geographic, £25, 240pp
Buy it at BOL

The National Geographic once achieved the stunning feat of writing about the forthcoming fall of Singapore without actually mentioning what Singapore might fall to. In one year it visited Mussolini's Rome ("from ruins to radio"), phoney-war France and the Netherlands and Britain, and managed barely to mention that they were at war with each other. (My favourite memory is of a picture caption that said "The English countryside has not been overlooked by the Luftwaffe.")

The reason of course was that the US had yet to join the second world war, and the magazine had subscribers in Germany, Japan, Italy, France, the Netherlands and Britain. That was the secret of its success, and of the strange prism through which it viewed the planet. It was really the world's great international geographic magazine, a gift to the planet from a nation on whose behalf almost every tourist hotel in the world now has an en-suite toilet with a paper band round the seat saying "Sanitised for your convenience".

The cruel thing you could say about the National Geographic was that it presented a world sanitised for your consumption. The kind thing you could say was that it was committed to an America in which people worked hard, played fair and smiled most of the time, and it did the rest of the world the courtesy of assuming the same things happened there too. The warm thing you could say about it was that, like a Capra movie, it inhabited a wonderful world.

You see this most sharply in the paintings. In principle, the journal uses photographers, but there were none about when Robert E Lee surrendered to Ulysses S Grant at Appomattox, or when a Roman galley rammed a Carthaginian deck in 260 BC, or in 1934, when a US Army Air Corps balloon burst at 60,000 feet, dropping at a mile a minute. The last two men got out and opened their parachutes at 800 feet and 300 feet. In the painting, one of them has to stand on the gondola and kick the other in the stomach to help him scramble out against the pressure of the rushing air.

It probably happened like that. Artists were instructed to consider details very carefully. When commissioned to illustrate a piece on the mammals of North America, the bird painter Louis Agassiz Fuertes said: "I don't know anything about mammals." The great editor Gilbert Grosvenor told him "The National Geographic will finance you for a year if you will study the animals and then proceed to make the pictures." The result is a set of pictures that reflect patience and effort but not real life. How likely are you to see eight arctic hares on a snowfield in one narrow field of view? Why would an Alaskan brown bear bring a salmon that far from the river before even biting it?

That was in 1918, but the tradition continued. When in 1993, to recreate the moment when the Noatak river ice broke beneath Keith Nyitray as he crossed the Alaskan Brooks Range, the artist insisted on working out where the sun would have been at the moment of immersion, and told Nyitray: "Think about what it was like and then scream: make an actual sound." The emphasis may have been on accuracy (the scene at Appomattox included details such as the pattern on the rug), but the results were always rather reminiscent of socialist realist Russian paintings, or Boys' Own Paper illustrations: sublimely and wonderfully false, life as you would wish it to be.

The painting of Lee and Grant, admits Alice Carter, involves some artistic licence. "His emotional canvas exemplifies the rebirth of the nation from the ravages of war, and the wisdom of a surrender that was not defeat." To which all one can add is, you can bet it didn't feel like that to Lee at the time. John Gurche reports that he spent six months on a single illustration, consulting experts, making models. "You have to get the scientific end of it right," he tells Alice Carter. "Otherwise you are just creating a fantasy." So what does he produce? A worm's eye view of a Pachycephalosaurus "caught off balance in a crushing battle for dominance" as it "reels in the dusty air and seems to breathe in heaving gasps".

There are 175 paintings in this book and I loved every one of them. It really helps to have the world sanitised for your convenience. It does, it does. That way, you remember that it really is a wonderful world, but for some of the people in it.

fields.headline: Venus de lido
fields.standfirst: The Million-Dollar Mermaid, Esther Williams, was no pampered movie star
fields.trailText: The Million-Dollar Mermaid, Esther Williams, was no pampered movie star
fields.body:
The Million Dollar Mermaid
Esther Williams and Digby Diehl
Simon & Schuster, £17.99, 416pp
Buy it at BOL

In 1955, Esther Williams had her red, white and blue star dressing-room on MGM's Hollywood lot redecorated to wipe clean the slick of Nivea and Vaseline which had kept her skin unwrinkled and her hair sleek doing her daily work in chlorinated water. She packed her old bathing caps, pinned a welcome note on the door for Grace Kelly and drove out the studio gate. Fade out. Titles.

Esther was 33 and had been a MGM money-maker for over a decade, in daft films confected to showcase her strong grace as an Olympic-class swimmer; but she understood that fashions in absurdity change, and did not want to end up dead in the water like Joan Crawford, who was coming apart just down the corridor.

That is one vivid little scene from an autobiography that is full of them - few filmable under the pre-1966 Hollywood production code. There's under-16 Esther, raped repeatedly by a boy her parents took into their family as a substitute for their dead hero son, defying him at last when she realises the robustness she has gained in training. There's Esther, 17, in an aquacade show, dodging priapic, trunkless Johnny Weissmuller (the original Tarzan). There's Esther, 18, fending off for a while MGM's offer of a movie career, unfazed by Louis B Mayer's carpet-chomping rages or attempted seductions by executives who didn't come up to her handsome bosom, eventually to graduate from MGM's finishing school in an Andy Hardy film.

Now, I don't believe a word of the dialogue in these scenes (either Esther or her ghost has no ear for the speech of the period), but I don't care. They're horribly funny, like films of her era updated by directors from our lewder time.

In a sequence which dropped jaws on the book's US publication last year, Esther hopes to find in her lover, the ludicrously macho actor Jeff Chandler (a proto-Richard Gere hunk with white Brillo-pad haircut), a supportive third husband and father for her kids. She is in a sunsuit, cooking chicken cacciatore in his kitchen, when he summons her to his bedroom, posing for her approval in red wig, Gucci shoes, chiffon gown and too much slap. She sees Jeff off with the funny-sad line that he is too big for the polka dots he adores on his every expensive girly garment. It's Doris Day-Rock Hudson comedy, but remade by David Lynch.

That makes Esther sound as if she has the self-awareness, the paralyising investment in image now encountered in Vanity Fair interviews with, say, Sharon Stone. Not so. This isn't a movie life in which the star observes herself from far enough away to understand her own signals. In the decade after the second world war, Esther's all-over tan (actually a tinted grease) defined an American freedom for the rest of the word: one look at her white-water smile and everybody understood that the US of A was a rich land where suburban homes had swimming pools, swimming costumes were of new, sagless Lastex and no military debris rusted on beaches. If MGM could spend all that money building a permanent aqua-stage just so Esther could shoot up on fountain jets in flimsy films, the US sure had resources to spare for the Marshall Plan and H-bomb research.

But as actually lived, stardom before the old studios broke apart seems for women to have been an early version of the modern corporate life - the bulge of the babies Esther conceived with her second husband had to be hidden under draped seaweed and gardenias, no interrupting the filming schedule; once born they were publicity props while she had to get back in shape for the next idiocy onscreen.

Esther was her only asset, and she only had herself to tend that asset. The second husband was a profligate drone who drank, gambled and misinvested what money she banked from a studio skilled at constructively dismissing employees.

Her various directors knew far less than she had had to teach herself about dangerous stunts: she only rarely said no and told them who to hire as stand-in and for how much. Otherwise she jumped from helicopters and planes and learned to water-ski when pregnant, just saving herself and baby from being carved up by the propellors of Busby Berkeley's camera craft; she dived from trapezes, almost drowned in an underwater room constructed by a technician not part of her team, and nearly broke her back swan-diving from six storeys up wearing a inflexible metal crown.

At least as she relates it, she was far more alone than a Mel Gibson or a Kevin Costner, with their trainer, dietician, accountant, publicist, personal assistant and their stunt teams, let alone doubles. Onscreen she pretended to be a fun gal flippering along with Tom and Jerry or "swimming pretty" - meaning high in the water, demanding extreme upper-body strength - as Howard Keel serenaded. Off screen, she never knew how to use her strengths, possibly because she tried to behave in accord with the 1946 ruling that women ceased to be capable the day they were no longer economically needed to weld and rivet for the war effort. Joan Crawford's wide, war-years shoulders had been pads designed by Edith Head; Esther Williams's were muscle, not easily doffed.

When the career and the marital life fell apart, she still had the sea - "a good swimmer owns the water" is the best line in the book. The scene from Dangerous When Wet that I adored as a small girl had her swimming the Channel, encouraged by her screen lover (the gorgeous but narcissistic Fernando Lamas), who leaps into the surf to scoop her into his arms once she's crossed the finishing line. They were in the icy, choppy Pacific all day shooting it: every time he clutched her she slid through his grasp because she was coated in authentic goosegrease; finally, in the car back to Culver City, he grabbed her hand and kept it on his exceptional erection the whole way. A few years later, she married him and dwindled into a fat wife, faithful but abject, for over 20 years until his death. I'm glad I didn't know the reality when I used to act out the movie sequence, doing a length of the family tin bath in front of the kitchen fire on Friday nights.
