There's Esther, 17, in an aquacade show, dodging priapic, trunkless Johnny Weissmuller (the original Tarzan). There's Esther, 18, fending off for a while MGM's offer of a movie career, unfazed by Louis B Mayer's carpet-chomping rages or attempted seductions by executives who didn't come up to her handsome bosom, eventually to graduate from MGM's finishing school in an Andy Hardy film. Now, I don't believe a word of the dialogue in these scenes (either Esther or her ghost has no ear for the speech of the period), but I don't care. They're horribly funny, like films of her era updated by directors from our lewder time. In a sequence which dropped jaws on the book's US publication last year, Esther hopes to find in her lover, the ludicrously macho actor Jeff Chandler (a proto-Richard Gere hunk with white Brillo-pad haircut), a supportive third husband and father for her kids. She is in a sunsuit, cooking chicken cacciatore in his kitchen, when he summons her to his bedroom, posing for her approval in red wig, Gucci shoes, chiffon gown and too much slap. She sees Jeff off with the funny-sad line that he is too big for the polka dots he adores on his every expensive girly garment. It's Doris Day-Rock Hudson comedy, but remade by David Lynch. That makes Esther sound as if she has the self-awareness, the paralyising investment in image now encountered in Vanity Fair interviews with, say, Sharon Stone. Not so. This isn't a movie life in which the star observes herself from far enough away to understand her own signals. In the decade after the second world war, Esther's all-over tan (actually a tinted grease) defined an American freedom for the rest of the word: one look at her white-water smile and everybody understood that the US of A was a rich land where suburban homes had swimming pools, swimming costumes were of new, sagless Lastex and no military debris rusted on beaches. If MGM could spend all that money building a permanent aqua-stage just so Esther could shoot up on fountain jets in flimsy films, the US sure had resources to spare for the Marshall Plan and H-bomb research. But as actually lived, stardom before the old studios broke apart seems for women to have been an early version of the modern corporate life - the bulge of the babies Esther conceived with her second husband had to be hidden under draped seaweed and gardenias, no interrupting the filming schedule; once born they were publicity props while she had to get back in shape for the next idiocy onscreen. Esther was her only asset, and she only had herself to tend that asset. The second husband was a profligate drone who drank, gambled and misinvested what money she banked from a studio skilled at constructively dismissing employees. Her various directors knew far less than she had had to teach herself about dangerous stunts: she only rarely said no and told them who to hire as stand-in and for how much. Otherwise she jumped from helicopters and planes and learned to water-ski when pregnant, just saving herself and baby from being carved up by the propellors of Busby Berkeley's camera craft; she dived from trapezes, almost drowned in an underwater room constructed by a technician not part of her team, and nearly broke her back swan-diving from six storeys up wearing a inflexible metal crown. At least as she relates it, she was far more alone than a Mel Gibson or a Kevin Costner, with their trainer, dietician, accountant, publicist, personal assistant and their stunt teams, let alone doubles. Onscreen she pretended to be a fun gal flippering along with Tom and Jerry or "swimming pretty" - meaning high in the water, demanding extreme upper-body strength - as Howard Keel serenaded. Off screen, she never knew how to use her strengths, possibly because she tried to behave in accord with the 1946 ruling that women ceased to be capable the day they were no longer economically needed to weld and rivet for the war effort. Joan Crawford's wide, war-years shoulders had been pads designed by Edith Head; Esther Williams's were muscle, not easily doffed. When the career and the marital life fell apart, she still had the sea - "a good swimmer owns the water" is the best line in the book. The scene from Dangerous When Wet that I adored as a small girl had her swimming the Channel, encouraged by her screen lover (the gorgeous but narcissistic Fernando Lamas), who leaps into the surf to scoop her into his arms once she's crossed the finishing line. They were in the icy, choppy Pacific all day shooting it: every time he clutched her she slid through his grasp because she was coated in authentic goosegrease; finally, in the car back to Culver City, he grabbed her hand and kept it on his exceptional erection the whole way. A few years later, she married him and dwindled into a fat wife, faithful but abject, for over 20 years until his death. I'm glad I didn't know the reality when I used to act out the movie sequence, doing a length of the family tin bath in front of the kitchen fire on Friday nights.

fields.headline: Pocket books
fields.trailText: David Newnham goes for a ride, plus Take the Kids Travelling, Agatha Christie's England, Picasso's Paris, Russia from A to Z, Curious Chester, Great Places to Stay in Europe and Cheap Sleeps Europe
fields.body:
Abdul's Taxi to Kalighat
Joe Roberts

Profile Books, £15.99

Joe and Emma and baby Llewelyn were living in a flat in Bath when the nudists downstairs moved out. The nudists' upturned heating had warmed the entire building. So with winter approaching, it was time to head for Calcutta. And where better than the Fairlawn hotel?

Run by Violet and Ted Smith, the Fairlawn seemed a little bit of an England that never was. Fawlty Towers transported to the poorest city on earth? Sort of. Except that the Smiths and their guests begin where situation comedy leaves off, and Calcutta itself, while undeniably poor, has a lot more going for it than all those documentaries about Mother Theresa would have us believe. It is a living kaleidoscope - an ever-shifting pattern of buildings and people.

Take the Kids Travelling

Helen Truszkowski

Cadogan, £14.99

Friends warned the author of the previous book against taking baby Llewelyn to Calcutta. And when he developed a fever after a few days, they wished they had listened. Would the family have left Bath had they read this book?

Its determination to cover all eventualities ("Children can make themselves big and thus more visible by lying on the ground in a star shape if a searching helicopter flies over") could deter the faint-hearted.

On balance, though, Truszkowski's message is summed up by her subtitle, "Survive and enjoy". How do you tell if a prospective hotel is as child-friendly as the brochure claims? How can you be sure you are really getting a discount? Truszkowski has the answers. Her tips for single parents are especially useful. How many have been sent home because they lack written authorisation for the trip from their child's other parent? Star shapes won't save you then, junior.

Agatha Christie's England
Judith Hurdle
RDR Books, £13.99

"I prefer to travel like a local rather than like a tourist on holiday," writes Judith Hurdle, "and I have met such interesting people on public transportation." It takes neither a Poirot nor a Marple to work out that the locals are our good selves, Hurdle being an English teacher from Valparaiso, Indiana.

Actually, the fact that its author is American works in this book's favour. For it means that Christie fans, while following in the footsteps of their favourite fiction, can also gain innumerable insights into English life that a native might well have overlooked (why, for instance, in order to open the door in an older railway carriage, is it necessary first to open the window?)

The action flits between London, Oxfordshire and Devon, with an extraordinary interlude in Harrogate, where Christie turned up after an unexplained 11-day disappearance in 1926. What happened to her? Perhaps nobody told her about opening the train window.

Picasso's Paris

Ellen Williams

The Little Bookroom, £10

Any number of books currently work to this formula (see above), and Paris is uncommonly susceptible to such treatment. Indeed, Williams has herself produced a sister title, The Impressionists' Paris, and in this she is not alone. You know the formula. Follow in the artist's footsteps, locate some viewpoints, spot the difference, wring your hands at the ravages of time, then pop into this café (closed Mondays) for an authentic taste of old Montmartre. But the publishers have certainly gone to town. This is pocket-size, hardback and clothbound, neat and weighty, with illustrations that glint like gemstones. "Very nice objects," as they say. And for once, I'm happy to nod in agreement.

Russia from A to Z
Vladimir Reznichenko
Russian Information Agency Novosti, £7.95

A very interesting and comprehensive book on Russia. Says who? Says Boris Yeltsin, that's who. And, as a matter of fact, he's right.

It's a veritable mini-encyclopaedia, says Mr Y, presenting "the life of our country in all its myriad varieties and dynamics". All of them? "As it is well known," says the chapter on ethnic groups, "the nationalities question is a sticky one." The former president clearly approves of such candour. "We are not trying to hide contemporary problems," he says, "because we are sure that they will be overcome as soon as the reforms that we have launched are decisively and effectively introduced at all walks of life." Quite so.

Curious Chester
Gordon Emery
Gordon Emery, £11.99

Perhaps you didn't know that "Niyon anomhma mh monan oyin" - it means "I wash away my sins, not my face alone" - is the only Greek inscription that is a palindrome (try spelling it backwards after three glasses of ouzo). And perhaps you didn't know that Russian men were expected to pay a beard tax in 1698 - the ones with beards, that is. But you know it now.

The Greek palindrome is carved on the oak font canopy at St Peter's church in Chester. Small wonder, then, that it crops up in this "portrait of an English city over 2,000 years". But a Russian beard tax? The author was talking about hearth tax and window tax and thought he might as well drop it in. And why not? This is Emery's book - self-published and in his own handwriting. So anything goes.

And thanks to good design and a sense of humour, what might have been an undisciplined mishmash turns out to be a very nice book indeed. Dozens of photographs (by Mike Penney) and any number of old prints keep it going at a cracking pace. Like the Chester-Holyhead Mail that overturned in 1827, crushing the brother of the MP for Cheshire...

Great Places to Stay in Europe
Dorling Kindersley, £14.99

You know the look and feel of a DK book. The weight, the shine, the sheer volume of little colour pictures, glittering like jewels and surrounded by crisp, tiny icons on an endless number of pure white pages... You know, also, what a hotel looks like - a parador, a pousada, an inn, an auberge, a farmhouse, a pub, a villa, a cottage, a B&B in a converted windmill... Pour a couple of thousand of these into that DK format and you have this bright little thing to carry around in your briefcase and thumb through when you ought to be working.

Working? Oh yes. You'll need to work fairly hard if you want to turn some of these little fantasies into reality ("charming" and "distinctive" are words that crop up time and again, but I don't see the word "budget" too often). Of course, if you're happy just turning the pages and dreaming... Well, dream on.

Cheap Sleeps Europe
Katie Wood
Ebury Press, £12.99

The very title has been trimmed to the bone. No pictures and plenty of paper the colour of chipboard, yet it costs a mere £2 less than the plush tome described above. How's this? Well, it does have more than 10,000 entries. And as one reviewer pointed out, it could pay for itself in the first two nights.

Some of the addresses mentioned are not a million miles away from red-light districts, Wood points out. "But we have vetted the places listed, and if there is likely to be trouble or overt displays that your parents wouldn't like, they're not in."

Overt displays? Somehow, I don't think she's talking about dried flowers on the bedside table.

fields.headline: Fair in love and war
fields.standfirst: Michelene Wandor  follows women into battle with an anthology of women's writing on the First World War
fields.trailText: Michelene Wandor follows women into battle with an anthology of women's writing on the First World War
fields.body:
Women's Writing on the First World War

ed Agnes Cardinal, Dorothy Goldman and Judith Hattaway

Oxford, £25

Buy it at BOL

All anthologies are necessarily cheats. The rationale may be a category of writing, or a historical moment (as here), but the result - if the anthology is good - can be an expansion of horizons. In the case of this fascinating compilation from America, Britain and selected bits of Europe, we pivot round the horrors (not really the politics) of the first world war, and emerge with surprising, and welcome, insights.

The editors offer the book as "a complement to men's narratives . . . a perspective which corrects and reshapes our understanding of war writing as a whole". Certainly the first is true, with a series of notes on health by Sarah Macdonald, about coping with anxiety and the dangers of indigestion from warmed-up food; Lady Gregory writes about hardship in Ireland and having to reduce servants' rations.

Then there are familiar accounts of women working in munitions factories (Rebecca West on women working with cordite and its dangers), driving ambulances and nursing in France, including a page-long salvo from the Swiss Maria Napflin, a nurse who joins doctors in resorting to morphine to combat stress and exhaustion. Also familiar is the anguish at the loss of loved ones - Vera Brittain on her fiancé - and the day-to-day experiences of horror: Enid Bagnold on opera tions without anaesthetics, an extract from a novel by Polish Zofia Nalkowska, about a soldier screaming in agony for hours till he dies, and German exile Jo Miklahy's diary entry on a mysterious humming which turns out to be a bluebottle in a dead soldier's mouth.

More radical inclusions, despite the editors' exclusion of macro-politics, are pieces by women in Germany, exposing suspicion about "spies", helplessness in the face of official disinformation, and a description of the defence of Liege by women who poured boiling water on German soldiers. Although the editors say they have excluded material from the international women's peace movement of the 1920s, extracts such as these (and many other simply reported horrors) imply something of a concealed pacifist agenda. They also indirectly raise ethical questions about what might be justified tactics in war, particularly if you believe your cause is the just one. But, because this is an anthology, which works by accumulation and juxtaposition, these issues never surface explicitly.

The question of whether all is fair in love when it is part of war prompts some of the most exciting writing in the book. Long-out-of-print stories and completely new work dramatise relationships both in, and at, war. Radclyffe Hall is represented by two beautiful stories - "Fraulein Schwarz", a tragic fictional account of a German woman living in England, whose cat is poisoned, balances South African Olive Schreiner's real-life story of her difficulty in finding lodgings in London because of her German surname.

The book is neatly structured: a concerned note struck at the beginning by Sheila Kaye-Smith, wondering how the outbreak of war will affect writers, is bracketed by Sylvia Townsend Warner's ironic piece about her outspoken mother, who fought - and won - her own local battle about buttons versus cords on pyjama trousers for the soldiers. The editors' desire to reshape our understanding of war writing has real impact here, in its constant, surprising shifts of perspective.

It also does our understanding of literature a great service by bolstering the known - Brittain, West, Colette - with some unjustly neglected women writers. War may be a defining presence in this anthology, but the book is also a salutary celebration of distaff creativity in the first decades of the century.

fields.headline: Dazzling lunges of the flesh
fields.standfirst: Peter Robb's new life of Caravaggio has the purists fuming, but  Julian Bell  is fascinated
fields.trailText: Peter Robb's new life of Caravaggio has the purists fuming, but Julian Bell is fascinated
fields.body:
M

by Peter Robb
Bloomsbury, £25 567pp

Buy it at BOL

Anyone wondering how you might write in a partisan, pugnacious, useful way about the Old Masters - enlivening those Dead White European males in their gilt frames - could do much worse than read Peter Robb's M . Here we have a story about a painter who gives a culture that has gone numb a new throb of life; one who opens up previously unrepresented areas of feeling with a pictorial approach of revolutionary directness.

The main character in this narrative is a stirrer, a bag of trouble, a visual intelligence at odds with a deranged, but infinitely resourceful, big city. In the end, the city wins. This is a story that flatters painting, telling how the world can be changed by brushstrokes; it's also a tale about a killer and how he himself comes to be killed.

M (you will gather) is a hopelessly uncool, vulgarian performance by most art-historical lights, and will dismay all those who hope that, by now, the myth of the macho, self- willed genius might have been deconstructed out of court. But it's a great read: it grabs, it kicks, it lives.

The hero of this story may, or may not, be the same painter who last year was given a distinguished biographical treatment by the art historian Helen Langdon in her (far better produced) volume Caravaggio . "Caravaggio" was the north Italian home town of a painter who was known in the Rome of 1600 by many names: Peter Robb opts to shorten them all to a one-letter cipher. The manoeuvre - which goes with his adoption of a remorselessly punchy, street-talking style - leaves open the possibility that his "M" may not be the quantity known to art history at all. His "working hypothesis" may be no more than the figment of an imagination reading over-vigorously between the lines of the same 17th-century sources and paintings that Langdon treats with judicious scholarly prudence.

But what a driving, resourceful, shrewd imagination is at work here. Robb has gazed long in the galleries and dim-lit churches where the primary evidence for the painter's life remains; has then spread his writing desk with the earliest memoirs of Caravaggio and with a haul of four-century-old Roman police records brought to light by recent scholarship. He shuttles furiously between the images and the transcripts, stitching faces to names, weaving together a whole lost world of loves and hatreds and the jostly, shouty street-life of which Caravaggio's paintings are the still-astonishing trace.

The pretty boys mooching around behind the fruit-baskets of the 1590s, with their ripe-to-bursting sensual immediacy, are located among the retinue of Cardinal del Monte, the first patron to recognise the qualities of the young painter from the north. The labourers and toughs and whores who loom out of the dark from the turn of 1600, when Caravaggio's church work makes him the most talked-about painter in Rome, find their seats in the taverns abutting del Monte's palazzo, where drinking companions penned obscene satires on his artistic enemies. And the grim 1606 canvas of a sorrowing David holding the dripping, severed head of Goliath - Caravaggio's own likeness - is made to witness the predicament of a man who has killed an adversary in a street-fight and who will be on the run (through Naples, Malta and Sicily) for his four remaining years of life.

The sources Robb brings to bear on a life of run-ins with the law are a gift in one way. They open out a scruffy, smelly Italy jagged with drawn swords, hurled tiles and insults - the pages clang with "fucking pricks" and "dickheads"; they also give some savour of the intensely difficult, fiercely intelligent man at the heart of the action. But naturally people talking to the police (or writing memoirs of their rivals) are tight-fisted with the important truths; and here Robb, an Australian whose previous book, Midnight in Sicily , tangled with today's Mafia, makes it his business to nose out the conspiracies - including the one that he believes led to Caravaggio's death.

It's a strong story, and plausibly told, but the best reason to trust Robb is that he puts his chief trust in the paintings, writing them up with fervour. For their figures still lunge dazzlingly out of the dark of Counter-Reformation Rome, kicking against its oppressive orthodoxies and its slick and chilly art scene. Their hot, palpable, vulnerable flesh continues to stimulate and challenge today as it did in 17th-century Europe. As Robb says, the paintings seem "to have nothing to do with art at all. They seem to go straight to shocking and delightful life itself."

Which was Caravaggio's intent: "He did not take credit for even one brushstroke, but said that it was the work of nature," as an early source puts it. Seemingly painted straight onto the canvas without intermediary sketching, his Roman work breaks with Renaissance practices and paradigms to claim the status of photography - received fact, rather than constructed illusion. Robb notes how the pictorial "window" of, say, a Raphael gives way to the jut and swell of the paint surface in this new realism; he also traces Caravaggio's connections with the rise of science. Police records note an incident when he was found with a pair of compasses which were assumed to be offensive weapon; Robb takes them rather to be a trace of his connection with the world of Galileo, also working for del Monte, and with his innovative optics. You are put in context so as to feel the force of Caravaggio's cutting edge.

Is Robb, then, entirely to be trusted? I don't think so. He may have a fine ear for omerta - for the half-truths of suspects and memoirists - and a keen eye for artistic quality, but it doesn't feel as if he's ever actually held a paintbrush, let alone worked with models. To read him, you'd think that some elderly workman was being paid to lie upside-down with his arms outstretched and his head craning upwards, while his mate knelt down to hoist up the plank beneath him, until Caravaggio had finished painting "The Crucifixion of St Peter". More than three minutes of those poses and anyone would be done for - and no one could render things to this canvas's degree of finish that quickly. Caravaggio would have been working up the figures largely from a well-trained imagination, even if it suited his agenda to claim it was all straight from life. Maybe he burned his sketches. Don't trust what painters say, either.

Robb accepts that after his flight from Rome, Caravaggio worked mostly from imagination, and he's fascinating about the flashlit, visionary shorthand of the paintings left in obscure Sicilian churches in the fugitive's wake. His own efforts, you might say, amount to a bright flarelight of the imagination, whatever their factual status. One aspect, however, of the resulting book is inexcusable. Whoever decided that eight colour and 16 black-and-white plates would keep the readers happy through a detailed discussion of some 80 paintings short-changed them disgracefully. It amounts to a new suppression of evidence, especially when much of the argument is highly contentious. Bloomsbury should upgrade the format with the next printing. Right or wrong, the writing deserves it.

Here we have a story about a painter who gives a culture that has gone numb a new throb of life; one who opens up previously unrepresented areas of feeling with a pictorial approach of revolutionary directness. The main character in this narrative is a stirrer, a bag of trouble, a visual intelligence at odds with a deranged, but infinitely resourceful, big city. In the end, the city wins. This is a story that flatters painting, telling how the world can be changed by brushstrokes; it's also a tale about a killer and how he himself comes to be killed. M (you will gather) is a hopelessly uncool, vulgarian performance by most art-historical lights, and will dismay all those who hope that, by now, the myth of the macho, self- willed genius might have been deconstructed out of court. But it's a great read: it grabs, it kicks, it lives. The hero of this story may, or may not, be the same painter who last year was given a distinguished biographical treatment by the art historian Helen Langdon in her (far better produced) volume Caravaggio . "Caravaggio" was the north Italian home town of a painter who was known in the Rome of 1600 by many names: Peter Robb opts to shorten them all to a one-letter cipher. The manoeuvre - which goes with his adoption of a remorselessly punchy, street-talking style - leaves open the possibility that his "M" may not be the quantity known to art history at all. His "working hypothesis" may be no more than the figment of an imagination reading over-vigorously between the lines of the same 17th-century sources and paintings that Langdon treats with judicious scholarly prudence. But what a driving, resourceful, shrewd imagination is at work here. Robb has gazed long in the galleries and dim-lit churches where the primary evidence for the painter's life remains; has then spread his writing desk with the earliest memoirs of Caravaggio and with a haul of four-century-old Roman police records brought to light by recent scholarship. He shuttles furiously between the images and the transcripts, stitching faces to names, weaving together a whole lost world of loves and hatreds and the jostly, shouty street-life of which Caravaggio's paintings are the still-astonishing trace. The pretty boys mooching around behind the fruit-baskets of the 1590s, with their ripe-to-bursting sensual immediacy, are located among the retinue of Cardinal del Monte, the first patron to recognise the qualities of the young painter from the north. The labourers and toughs and whores who loom out of the dark from the turn of 1600, when Caravaggio's church work makes him the most talked-about painter in Rome, find their seats in the taverns abutting del Monte's palazzo, where drinking companions penned obscene satires on his artistic enemies. And the grim 1606 canvas of a sorrowing David holding the dripping, severed head of Goliath - Caravaggio's own likeness - is made to witness the predicament of a man who has killed an adversary in a street-fight and who will be on the run (through Naples, Malta and Sicily) for his four remaining years of life. The sources Robb brings to bear on a life of run-ins with the law are a gift in one way. They open out a scruffy, smelly Italy jagged with drawn swords, hurled tiles and insults - the pages clang with "fucking pricks" and "dickheads"; they also give some savour of the intensely difficult, fiercely intelligent man at the heart of the action. But naturally people talking to the police (or writing memoirs of their rivals) are tight-fisted with the important truths; and here Robb, an Australian whose previous book, Midnight in Sicily , tangled with today's Mafia, makes it his business to nose out the conspiracies - including the one that he believes led to Caravaggio's death. It's a strong story, and plausibly told, but the best reason to trust Robb is that he puts his chief trust in the paintings, writing them up with fervour. For their figures still lunge dazzlingly out of the dark of Counter-Reformation Rome, kicking against its oppressive orthodoxies and its slick and chilly art scene. Their hot, palpable, vulnerable flesh continues to stimulate and challenge today as it did in 17th-century Europe. As Robb says, the paintings seem "to have nothing to do with art at all. fields.headline: Faber triumphant
fields.trailText: But no show at the Whitbreads from JK Rowling, plus Charles Bukowski reissued and a firm hand on the wheel at Waterstone's
fields.body:
 Pity poor David Cairns, winner of the Whitbread Biography Award with the second volume of his study of Berlioz. Probably assuming that a 19th-century composer wouldn't triumph over a schoolboy wizard or a man-eating monster, he had consoled himself with the thought of meeting the ever more glamorous JK Rowling at the Awards ceremony. Cairns, like other Potter fans, was out of luck, as the children's author some expected to be the first to win the overall prize was tucked up in bed with the Sydney flu.

 For Faber, it was another jubilant night, as Seamus Heaney and his entourage slipped away for a quiet celebration drink at the Savoy. And an even better morning, with orders for 20,000 copies of Beowulf arriving first thing on Wednesday morning. All of which was comfort enough for Faber's Marketing Director Joanna Mackle, who suffered the indignity of being made to walk in and out of the Whitbread Brewery five times to be filmed in her elegant Philip Treacy hat - only to be nearly crushed by the stampede of photographers when Jerry Hall arrived a few minutes later.

 Fans of Roddy Doyle - and especially of Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha - will be surprised to learn of his unexpected links with legendary barfly and sometime Post Office worker Charles Bukowski. Inclined to think of himself as an unrecognised genius, Bukowski found time in between bouts of drinking, fighting and gambling to write much poetry and several novels, one of which, Ham on Rye, is being reissued later this year by Canongate's Rebel Inc. imprint. The new edition comes complete with an ecstatic introduction by Doyle, who was particularly struck by a description of its childhood hero under a table and its similarity to a passage in his own Booker Prize-winning novel.

 Waterstone's have appointed a new Marketing Director. We know little of the chap, but hear from a reliable source in the bookselling world that he's hotfooting it from the British School of Motoring. What? An organisation that attracts hapless and cowering customers and throws them into bewildering and potentially dangerous situations? On reflection, sounds perfect.

 The Loafer is grateful to The Bookseller magazine for drawing our attention to an amusing promotional mix-up, coincidentally in a branch of Waterstone's in Sauchiehall Street in Glasgow. Crowds flocked to hear Colin Bateman and Thora Hird read from their new novels, enticed by the prospect of two "outrageously shocking and devastatingly funny" writers, both of whom, apparently, have made an enormous impact on contemporary fiction. Thora Hird? Of Songs of Praise and Talking Heads fame? Alas, no: not Thora, but Laura Hird, author of Born Free, a gritty tale of Scottish family life. Tsk, tsk. Mistakes like this will certainly cost you points on your licence once the driving-school ethos kicks in.

webTitle: Become your own spin doctor and beat the scanners

fields.headline: Become your own spin doctor and beat the scanners
fields.trailText: Having difficulty navigating the CV maze? Pulling your hair out trying to figure out what kinds of information to include, how to format the document, what type of paper to print it on, and how to send it to employers? Well, if your "Finding A Job" folder is bulging with bookmarks on CV preparation, you had better check the dates on the material, because the rules have changed.
fields.body:
Having difficulty navigating the CV maze? Pulling your hair out trying to figure out what kinds of information to include, how to format the document, what type of paper to print it on, and how to send it to employers? Well, if your "Finding A Job" folder is bulging with bookmarks on CV preparation, you had better check the dates on the material, because the rules have changed.

Now, more and more companies are turning to CV scanning equipment and software to weed through their stacks of CVs. If you thought impressing finicky personnel people was difficult, wait until your CV passes under the eye of their computer counterparts.

These cold, calculating boxes of automated components pick through your carefully prepared qualifications like computerised cats, sifting out all the rubbish, and going right to the "meat."

So beating this system requires some cunning and quite a bit of in-depth research to match a recruiter's specific criteria for an available job.

Like any form of artificial intelligence, there are ways to beat the system. Because the scanning process is based on key words or phrases that the user asks the software to scan, candidates can try to guess the criteria for the job they're interested in, and pad out their CV with those terms.

If the job seeker's actual experience lacks relevant skills, they can rely on the "spin doctoring" approach used by politicians and their aides who are adept at being all things to all people.

For instance, using a CV subhead such as "Abilities" will allow you to list not only those things you've done, but also those things you're confident you can do based on education or other life experiences.

Use this strategy with caution, though. You'll obviously be expected to back up your claims in a personal interview.

They can't put you in prison for CV fraud before you're recruited but be warned: outright CV lies can come back to haunt you.

You should also consider document aesthetics. In their book, Electronic CV Revolution , J.L. Kennedy and T.J. Morrow offer the following "Tips for Writing a Scannable CV":

 Use simple fonts, such as Helvetica, Universe and Optima at point sizes of between 10 and 14.

 Avoid italics, script and underlining of words.

 Use bold face type sparingly.

 Use an ink jet or laser printer for better printing quality.

 Avoid abbreviations.

 Always use white paper.

 Don't fold your CV in order to send it. Use an A4 envelope.

Whether it's a grinning personnel manager or a stoic computer system suggesting you don't measure up, rejection can be painful.

But keep firing off those sincere, focused CVs to carefully targeted companies and you'll find someone or "something" that will recognise your ability and worth.

webTitle: Help: I'm obsessed with my work!

fields.headline: Help: I'm obsessed with my work!
fields.standfirst: I find myself thinking about work most of the time I'm not there - I even dream about it  (Kirsty M, press officer, Edinburgh)
fields.trailText: When the inability to switch off leaves you feeling like you're working double time for no extra money, consciously trying to disconnect can be counter-productive. You end up thinking about work even more and giving it greater importance than it deserves.
fields.body:
When the inability to switch off leaves you feeling like you're working double time for no extra money, consciously trying to disconnect can be counter-productive. You end up thinking about work even more and giving it greater importance than it deserves.

You have to dream about something and if work is a big part of your life it's not surprising it occasionally sneaks into your slumbers. Why not choose to see this as doing something useful whilst asleep - a way of sorting out the previous day or planning the next.

Perhaps you're not doing enough of that when conscious, leaving your mind so cluttered with unfinished business that it can't focus on anything else.

One approach is to replace the space worrying about work takes up with something more potent. You need to find what has the power to distract you and put the niggles of work into their proper perspective. Drastic solutions include discovering something even worse to worry about, like a life-threatening problem.

Much healthier is finding an interest which is absorbing enough to dislodge the dominance of employment-related thoughts and then indulging in it to the point of exhaustion. If you don't want work to infiltrate your dreams, concentrate on reducing its importance in your life.

Best of all, do more of whatever it is you'd like to be dreaming about.

webTitle: Don't march in without a plan

fields.headline: Don't march in without a plan
fields.standfirst: Map out your route before advancing
fields.trailText: Map out your route before advancing
fields.body:
Whether looking for their first or second position, most job hunters begin their search flooding employers with CVs. But since most openings go unadvertised, successful job seekers require more thoughtful approaches. Try the following suggestions for a more productive job search:

 Structure your days

Job hunting is a full-time occupation. Although it is tempting to exploit your free time, don't start going fishing mid-week or sleeping late. Get up at your usual hour, shower, eat breakfast and go to "work".

 Research first

Comprehensive research is your guide to success. It shows potential employers that you do your homework and keep ahead of the pack. Multiply your opportunities by researching numerous companies within your target industries and geographic region.

Analyse a target company's last three annual reports, promotional sales materials, trade publications and any relevant magazine articles to familiarise yourself with the overall industry, your target company's corporate culture and its key executives. Don't overlook the internet - search engines can be very helpful in compiling facts to use during interviews or in crafting CVs.

 Determine recruitment patterns

It is also crucial to determine if your target company expects to be downsizing, maintaining a stable workforce or recruiting soon. If, for example, you want to work in marketing find out that specific department's recruiting outlook. It's not uncommon for large companies to recruit in one department while downsizing others.

 Use your professional organisation

Professional associations are a great resource for job leads, mentoring and research. They can also keep you in the loop. Contact other professionals to tell them of your goals and to ask for guidance. You never know when one might say: "Call this person and say I referred you."

 Keep knocking

Follow up on a letter of introduction or an initial interview with a timely phone call. Keep it short and to the point. Ask if your letter was received and if any additional information is desired. If necessary, leave your message on their voice mail.

 Sell your talents

During your first meeting with an executive, avoid discussing specific positions. Initially, work on bonding with your interviewer by discussing your insights about the company and how your skills complement their corporate strategy.

Avoid the "I will do anything" trap. It sounds desperate. Instead, state specifically what positions best fit your qualifications. Employers want applicants to possess specific personal qualities, tangible professional credentials and well-articulated career objectives.

Be prepared with some penetrating questions. Executives like applicants who know the right questions to ask when problem solving or developing strategy. Ask specific questions regarding current projects, industry trends, employee turnover, ratio of managers to employees, dispute resolution processes, innovations, company reputation, business plans and goals, lines of authority and company expectations.

 Respect their time

If you asked for 20 minutes of an executive's time, under all circumstances respect that. Make sure the employer feels in control of the process, including the time involved. Be sensitive to when the employer seems to be getting fidgety.

When your time is up, sum up your meeting with an action item, such as bringing letters of recommendation or your CV by tomorrow morning. If the executive wants to talk with you longer, you will be invited to stay.

 Rewrite your CV

Under most circumstances do not bring your CV to your initial meeting. Carefully revise your CV based on the intelligence you gathered at your informational meeting. For easier revisions always maintain your CV on a PC.

 Remain upbeat

Looking for work is laden with emotionally draining rejections. Don't take rejection personally.

Share feelings with supportive people. Avoid getting too excited or too discouraged. Reward yourself with a special treat at each step in your job search. Apply for multiple jobs simultaneously and view interviews as opportunities to work on your interviewing skills, not as "do or die" situations.

webTitle: Banks face 30p limit on cashpoint charge

fields.headline: Banks face 30p limit on cashpoint charge
fields.standfirst: Disloyalty fee is too high but ATM costs can be covered, says Cruickshank
fields.trailText: Don Cruickshank, the head of the banking review team, has waded into the war over automatic teller machine charging, setting a 30p limit on the cost of withdrawing cash while supporting the principle of the controversial "surcharge" favoured by Barclays.
fields.body:
Don Cruickshank, the head of the banking review team, has waded into the war over automatic teller machine charging, setting a 30p limit on the cost of withdrawing cash while supporting the principle of the controversial "surcharge" favoured by Barclays.

His opinions, outlined in a private letter to the Link cash machine network, came just as the banks were starting to feel he was making more conciliatory noises about the outcome of his review into competition in the sector at the behest of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

His comments to Link, which is fighting for survival after a rebellion led by Nationwide Building Society over the Barclays approach, were made in time to influence a crucial vote of members at the end of next month.

Mr Cruickshank's intervention coincided with a reminder from the office of fair trading that it was scrutinising the situation closely.

John Bridgeman, the director general of the OFT, said: "It is disagreeable that some banks appear insensitive to the fact that fixed rate charges disproportionately penalise people who are less well-off".

The OFT has yet to start an inquiry while it awaits the outcome of the crucial Link vote in February.

If any investigation did find any evidence of anti-competitive behaviour the offenders could face penalties of 10% of their revenues under rules being introduced in March.

Mr Cruickshank, who refused to comment yesterday, told Link the owners of ATMs should charge for cash withdrawals, rather than the current account holder.

That was interpreted to mean he does not support the "disloyalty" fees some banks and building societies charge their customers.

It appears to back the route Barclays is trying to pioneer whereby it gives its own customers free access to any Link machine while charging its rivals' customers for using its Barclays-branded machines.

The comments also appear to clear the way for independent chains of ATMs to be set up, not necessarily owned by the banks or building societies, as they should be able to cover their running costs by levying the "surcharge".

However, by setting the limit for charges of between 15p and 30p, Mr Cruickshank poses problems for the banks and building societies, which charge as much as £1.50 in "disloyalty" fees. It also appears to make it difficult for Barclays to argue that it should charge £1 - a move fiercely opposed by Nationwide, which would have found it difficult to absorb that charge in such a way that it could continue to offer is customer free access to Link.

Nationwide, which yesterday insisted that it remained opposed to the surcharge, admitted that it was more likely to be able to absorb a 30p surcharge and so retain free access to the network.

It is unclear whether Mr Cruickshank made any comment on the "interchange" fee which the banks and building societies in the Link network pay to each other.

John Bridgeman, the director general of the OFT, said: "It is disagreeable that some banks appear insensitive to the fact that fixed rate charges disproportionately penalise people who are less well-off". The OFT has yet to start an inquiry while it awaits the outcome of the crucial Link vote in February. If any investigation did find any evidence of anti-competitive behaviour the offenders could face penalties of 10% of their revenues under rules being introduced in March. Mr Cruickshank, who refused to comment yesterday, told Link the owners of ATMs should charge for cash withdrawals, rather than the current account holder. That was interpreted to mean he does not support the "disloyalty" fees some banks and building societies charge their customers. It appears to back the route Barclays is trying to pioneer whereby it gives its own customers free access to any Link machine while charging its rivals' customers for using its Barclays-branded machines. The comments also appear to clear the way for independent chains of ATMs to be set up, not necessarily owned by the banks or building societies, as they should be able to cover their running costs by levying the "surcharge". However, by setting the limit for charges of between 15p and 30p, Mr Cruickshank poses problems for the banks and building societies, which charge as much as £1.50 in "disloyalty" fees. It also appears to make it difficult for Barclays to argue that it should charge £1 - a move fiercely opposed by Nationwide, which would have found it difficult to absorb that charge in such a way that it could continue to offer is customer free access to Link. Nationwide, which yesterday insisted that it remained opposed to the surcharge, admitted that it was more likely to be able to absorb a 30p surcharge and so retain free access to the network. It is unclear whether Mr Cruickshank made any comment on the "interchange" fee which the banks and building societies in the Link network pay to each other.

webTitle: An ABC guide to resisting the temptation of procrastination

fields.headline: An ABC guide to resisting the temptation of procrastination
fields.trailText: A. Brain drain
fields.body:
A. Brain drain

If you want to make a job harder and bigger, put it off for a bit. Whilst you divert energy to constructing excuses that don't convince anyone, the task on hold will grow in difficulty - along with the urge to leave it. The effort you put into procrastination is often greater than the effort it would take to get the job done. Convince yourself anything is preferable to what you know you need to do, and you're on a loser.

B. Take the plunge

The next time you detect an overwhelming desire to create a new filing system or sharpen all your pencils, fight it. Chances are there's something else you don't want to start on. Acknowledge that an unjustified fear of failure is what's holding you back is and break the curse by plunging right in. A huge, seemingly impossible chore becomes manageable if you break it up into small sections. Trick your brain into thinking this is a routine task by knocking off any bits you can do on auto pilot .

C. The mature approach

The sooner you get started the sooner you'll finish. Let yourself get immersed in what you're doing without being too concerned about the end result. The feeling that you're in control and making headway will give you the confidence to see the task through. Create enough momentum to get things going and you can leave your ideas to mature whilst rewarding yourself with a bit of light filing.

webTitle: Stay focused: Five mistakes that can kill your career

fields.headline: Stay focused: Five mistakes that can kill your career
fields.standfirst: But taking just a few simple steps will put you in the frame
fields.trailText: But taking just a few simple steps will put you in the frame
fields.body:
Mistakes in your CV can damage or even kill your career, because a sub-standard CV can prevent you from ever being called for a job interview. But don't worry - if your CV isn't perfect, you're not alone. Here are the five mistakes that ruin most CVs (and what you can do to prevent them):

Mistake No.1: No objective or summary

By not describing what job or field you want to work in, you start your CV off on the wrong foot. Why? You force the employer to read it all the way through to figure out what kind of job you're suited for. You create more work for your busy reader and this is the last thing you want to do.

If you know the exact job title you're applying for, say so! Start the CV something like this:

Summary

Management trainee, where strong people skills, relevant work experience and time spent travelling abroad will add value to operations.

What if you don't know the job title? Start your CV like this:

Summary

Seeking a position where strong people skills, relevant work experience and time spent travelling abroad will add value to operations.

By starting your CV with a clear objective or a focused summary, you tell the reader exactly what you want to do for him or her. This establishes a rapport and sets the stage for the CV, a simple step which will greatly improve your results.

Mistake No.2: Focusing on you and your needs

This is the worst mistake you can make. Unfortunately, it's also the most common. Remember, no employer wants to recruit you. In fact, employers hate recruiting. They only hire employees when they have problems to solve.

And no employer wants to spend a lot of time recruiting you, either, just as you wouldn't want to spend more time in a dentist's chair than you had to. So, your CV must answer quickly the one question that's on every employer's mind: "What can you do for me?"

Unfortunately, most CVs don't. Too many CVs start out like this: "Seeking a position where I can utilise my skills in an atmosphere with potential for career advancement."

This sounds fine and logical to the person writing the CV. But it completely alienates the person reading the CV.

Because this person - your potential employer - has his own problems. He couldn't care less about your career aspirations or desire to make more money.

Instead, tell the employer how you can add value to his/her operations, or contribute to efficiency. Take another look at our opening summary:

Summary

Seeking a position where strong people skills, relevant work experience and time spent travelling abroad will add value to operations.

Now, what employer wouldn't want to talk to someone like you, who's offered to add value to his operations? You could also say: "...will contribute to operations" or "...will add to profitability."

The exact words don't matter. What does matter is your focus on helping the employer meet his goals. If you do that, your career will advance too.

Mistake No.3: Focus on responsibilities instead of results

While it's important to tell the reader what you've done at each job or work placement you've completed, it's far more important to spend most of your time talking about what you accomplished and how you made yourself valuable to your previous employers. It's easy to do. Just think back on your daily duties. What good things happened when you did your job well? Write them down.

Focus on results. The more specific you can be, the better.

So, instead of writing "Responsibilities included implementation of departmental policies and procedures, interfacing with customers and correspondence duties", it's far better to write this:

Worked with customers to help increase sales by 23% in five months.

Mistake No.4: Too many big words

It's a shame how often a good CV is ruined when the author utilises a superabundance of polysyllabic terminology - or uses too many big words.

Don't hide behind your vocabulary. When your CV is not clear and to the point, the reader gets bored, time is wasted and your CV goes in the bin.

Keep it simple. Write as if you were talking to a class of GCSE students. So, instead of saying "implemented," try "adopted" or "set up," for example.

Never "utilise" what you can simply "use." Don't "interface" with people; "work" with them.

And try not to use "impact" as a verb - meteorites hitting the moon are about the only thing that should "impact".

Mistake No.5: Spelling/punctuation errors

Your spell-checker is not enough! You should read through your CV once for accuracy (check all the numbers, dates, names, etc.), once for missing or extra words, and once more for spelling.

Then, show your CV to several friends and ask them to read it out loud. Listen to where they pause; this could mean you've written something confusing or inaccurate.

After you get their feedback, revise the CV so that it's 100% error-free.

fields.headline: Supreme celebration
fields.standfirst:
London Symphony Orchestra/Pierre Boulez
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: Five years ago, to celebrate his 70th birthday, Pierre Boulez presented a major retrospective of his own music with the London Symphony Orchestra. Now Boulez 2000 will mark his 75th birthday with concerts in 11 cities around the world. The first programme on Thursday set a standard the rest of the series will do wonderfully well to match.
fields.body:
Five years ago, to celebrate his 70th birthday, Pierre Boulez presented a major retrospective of his own music with the London Symphony Orchestra. Now Boulez 2000 will mark his 75th birthday (which falls in March) with concerts in 11 cities around the world.

The programmes concentrate on the 20th-century scores he has championed throughout his career, alongside the premieres of specially commissioned orchestral works from Olga Neuwirth, George Benjamin, Peter Eotvos and Salvatore Sciarrino.

The first programme on Thursday set a standard the rest of the series will do wonderfully well to match. There is no composer that Boulez conducts better than Alban Berg, and there is no conductor who more completely understands Berg's unique combination of emotional power constrained by structural rigour or who realises it in performance with more shattering effect. It is impossible to imagine a more masterly or definitive performance of the Three Orchestral Pieces than the one Boulez unleashed here, with the LSO encouraged to produce playing of immense sinewy intensity and faultless virtuosity, with every layer of this teeming score utterly lucid and every climax faultlessly judged.

It was balanced by Mahler's Sixth Symphony at the opposite end of the programme. When conducting Mahler, Boulez is sometimes a little ruthless, pushing through lyrical passages (like the swooning second subject of the Sixth's opening movement, or the main theme of its Andante) without giving them quite enough room to breathe; but his ability to clarify texture is more than adequate compensation. The last movement is the most elaborately structured of all Mahler's finales and the hardest to bring off, but Boulez got it exactly right.

Between those towering Viennese masterpieces Olga Neuwirth's Clinamen/Nodus was never going to stand much of a chance, but as the first major score by this 31-year-old Austrian to be heard in Britain it would have been a disappointment in any circumstances - the wild, swirling textures, scored for a huge orchestra with copious percussion, are laced with Varèse-style sirens and the kind of "meta-music" effects made fashionable in the 80s.

At the Barbican on February 2 and 27, and March 2. Box office: 0171-638 8891

fields.headline: Look - no sounds
fields.standfirst:
London International Mime Festival
Cabot Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: Mini sagas are supposed to have gone out of fashion, but at the London International Mime Festival they are all the rage. It's Your Film, presented by Stan's Cafe, is an intriguing four-minute piece of theatre that looks and feels like a cross between a David Lynch movie and a piece of film noir but is in fact performed by live actors for an audience of one sitting in a viewing booth.
fields.body:
Mini sagas are supposed to have gone out of fashion, but at the London International Mime Festival they are all the rage. It's Your Film, presented by Stan's Cafe, is an intriguing four-minute piece of theatre that looks and feels like a cross between a David Lynch movie and a piece of film noir but is in fact performed by live actors for an audience of one sitting in a viewing booth.

Aberrations du Documentaliste, meanwhile, is a 45-minute tabletop miniature for an audience of just 35 in which an old man in a library (the distinguished French actor Jacques Fornier) tries to unravel the mysteries of the universe. Throughout, you hear the sound of dripping water, which acts like an eternal clock as tiny figures - some so amazingly lifelike that for a moment you wonder whether the creators have discovered how to shrink human beings - appear to demonstrate different theories about the creation of the world.

Both these performances are immensely assured and both create complete and engrossing worlds, particularly the latter, with its Borges-style, dreamlike atmosphere and metaphysical speculation. But they are also rather emotionally distant works, so bound up in the necessary technical skill that the content takes second place.

It's Your Film raises interesting questions about the relationship of audience and performer, particularly in the closing sequence when you feel that it is you rather than the cast who are in close-up. But it needs to be developed beyond its current timespan in order to create a truly satisfying narrative and explore this issue further.

Aberrations - which is performed in French and is stylistically peculiarly French - is strong on images but sometimes short on clarity. The puppetry is a marvel, but while the old man in the library appears to have some kind of revelation, I remained in the dark. Still, there is much to admire and enjoy if you just let it all wash over you.

Paolo Nani's The Letter was a big hit at last year's festival. I can't think why. I can only assume that this simple clowning show, in which a man writes a letter to his grandmother in a succession of different characterisations and styles, has gone through some changes since it was here in 1999. There is no doubting Nani's physical theatre skills, but the performance is so over-embellished and the audience participation so cringe-making that its natural comedy is all but suffocated. If he did rather less, Nani would make us laugh all the more.

Last performance tonight. Information: 0171-637 5661

webTitle: How to... sleep your way to the top

fields.headline: How to... sleep your way to the top
fields.standfirst: Nip off for a power-nap
fields.trailText: Nip off for a power-nap
fields.body:
President Clinton gets by on five or six hours of it a night. Rolling Stone Keith Richards is said to have gone for 13 days without any and Lady Thatcher made do with just four hours a night. Albert Einstein, on the other hand, insisted on a full 10 hours.

For most of us, seven to eight hours' sleep each night is about right, but increasingly sleep is perceived as a luxury rather than a necessity and to get everything done, many of us find ourselves stealing those hours from sleep. Some of us bring work home, further prolonging our work day. Others feel they have to work harder just to stay afloat and keep their jobs.

Linda B, a self-employed entrepreneur, has herself convinced that she needs only six hours of sleep a night. She gets up at 4:45am in order to have quiet time to herself and to prepare for the day. She works through the day and into the evening. This self-imposed schedule works fine for the first month, then she finds herself falling into bed at 8pm, napping through weekends, anything to get a couple of extra hours of sleep.

Samuel S, the young MD of an internet start-up, says that he gets by on four hours of sleep a night. He's successful and highly creative with ideas that come a mile a minute - but his stress level is soaring and he has become a prime candidate for career burnout.

In the United States, the National Sleep Foundation estimates that $150bn a year in direct and indirect costs are lost due to sleep deprivation: medical expenses, sick leave, errors in judgment, accidents and injuries. Such sleep deprivation has led to some spectacular accidents. The Challenger explosion, Exxon Valdez oil spill and Three Mile Island meltdown were all linked to errors made by sleep-deprived workers.

Denying your need for sleep only makes matters worse. A couple of years ago, a team from the Human Communication Research Centre at Edinburgh University decided to look at the effects of extreme fatigue on work output by asking six groups of six army reservists to go without sleep for 60 hours, performing a series of tasks in the windowless environment of a sleep laboratory. Those who tried to work alone and did not recognise their tiredness suffered most. Those who alternated between working partners frequently and admitted feeling terrible were the ones who maintained their ability to communicate or perform tasks best.

The researchers also found potential problems among a team who took stimulants to keep themselves alert - those taking drugs to maintain their performance tended to lose their natural safety consciousness and took risks.

In his book Sleep Thieves, James Maas, professor of psychology at Cornell University, New York claims that for every hour of sleep lost in a night, we effectively lose one IQ point the next day.

Professor Maas recommends power-napping through the day to increase alertness and reduce stress. He also claims it will reduce the likelihood of heart attacks. In the US, companies such as Kodak, IBM, Pizza Hut and PepsiCo now run courses in the art of the 15-minute kip, while Deloitte & Touche has installed a special napping room. In Spain, siesta shops offer jaded workers a bed for half an hour.

A similar trend is emerging here too. Advertising agency St Luke's has a chill-out room where staff can relax. Mail order company Freemans has four relaxation rooms for call-centre staff. Some have gentle background music and others have tanks of fish.

If you don't remember anything else, remember this...

Lack of sleep or problems sleeping may be an indication that your work/life balance is out of kilter. The most successful people are those who recognise that hard work is only one way we define our success. The best performers aren't those who get by with the least sleep; it's those who have the most peace.

fields.headline: High-profile internet companies cut jobs
fields.trailText: The high-profile internet retailer Boo.com, which sells designer clothes online, is understood to have cut 100 jobs in a signal that "e-tailers" are struggling to make headway against their high street rivals.
fields.byline: Anne Hyland  and  Jane Martison  in New York
fields.body:
The high-profile internet retailer Boo.com, which sells designer clothes online, is understood to have cut 100 jobs in a signal that "e-tailers" are struggling to make headway against their high street rivals.

The difficult situation faced by internet retailers was confirmed by Amazon.com, the world's largest online bookseller, which admitted yesterday it was cutting its workforce by 150.

Boo.com, which has been touted as the world's first global fashion and sports retailer, confirmed it had "let go a few people", but refused to confirm numbers.

According to several industry experts the job cuts indicate that some online companies have not lived up to their hype since the Christmas period. Many have not sold as much stock as anticipated, which has raised the issue of restructuring, staff reductions and advertising cutbacks. Other anlaysts said the cuts at Boo.com were peculiar to the company, which suffered a series of setbacks before its launch, which was delayed by five months.

The boom in internet share prices has fuelled a huge growth in stock market values around the world. Some observers, however, fear that the soaring values of companies which have yet to prove themselves as profit makers has falsely inflated stock markets.

Sources said Boo.com, which sells upmarket brands such as North Face, Paul Smith and Helly Hansen, was reducing its staff from 400 to 300.

The private company, which launched its site last November, announced earlier this week it would change its strategy and discount its merchandise by up to 40% to clear out goods from its autumn/winter 1999 range.

Boo.com has folded its online magazine, Boom, and has not revealed figures on its earnings performance.

Sources said it had more than $100,000 sales during the Christmas period. It is backed by investors such as LVMH, which owns the Louis Vuitton, Moet & Chandon and Christian Dior brands, as well as the Italian designer Benetton.

fields.headline: BA shoots down rival
fields.standfirst: Ayling intervention halts British Midland's plan for Heathrow flights to America
fields.trailText: British Airways last night used its powerful political influence with the government to scupper rival British Midland from obtaining four slots at Heathrow to start flying to the United States.
fields.body:
British Airways last night used its powerful political influence with the government to scupper rival British Midland from obtaining four slots at Heathrow to start flying to the United States.

Bob Ayling, BA's chief executive, used his contacts with the prime minister to warn Lord Macdonald, the transport minister, that the opening-up of Heathrow to other carriers could lead to a loss of jobs and threaten BA's position.

British Midland had been given the go-ahead by the Civil Aviation Authority to fly into New York, Washington, Miami and Boston and was hopeful that bilateral talks would confirm the agreement.

Mr Ayling's crucial intervention led to the collapse of talks between British and American government negotiators for a new "open skies" deal between the two countries.

The talks were due to continue over the weekend, but a brief statement from the department of the environment and transport said that there had been an impasse.

One of Mr Ayling's arguments was that there are too many airlines fighting for too many empty seats on the north Atlantic routes. Opening routes to more airlines could affect the four existing carriers - BA, Virgin Atlantic, United Airlines and American Airlines - which operate between Britain and the US from Heathrow.

The crisis between the two countries has lasted for three years, mainly because of BA's reluctance to give up its pivotal position at Heathrow.

It was suggested in Whitehall last night that the latest breakdown could lead to an attempt by Mr Blair and President Clinton to knock heads together. But a presidential election later this year makes a political initiative difficult.

British Midland reacted with disappointment to last night's news. It said that it had been campaigning for new competition on routes between Heathrow and the US for two years.

Sir Michael Bishop, the chairman, said: "We are ready, willing and able to bring new competition to these routes. If we could do so, we would create thousands of new jobs and would be able to invest in regional transatlantic services from our developing hub in Manchester."

Sir Michael said that the transatlantic routes were the largest intercontinental travel markets in the world. But travellers suffered from a lack of competition. "Business travellers pay far more than their European counterparts, whilst reductions in capacity being introduced by airlines will inevitably lead to increases in leisure fares."

The German carrier, Lufthansa, has acquired a 20% stake in BM in the hope that the British carrier would gain a footing in the US. It, too, was angry at yesterday's outcome.

American government officials were also furious. They said they had come to London thinking they had secured a deal, "but it blew up in our faces". They said that there would be a hostile reaction in Congress, but the Americans can do little because Heathrow is the key.

London is still the most popular capital for Americans and talk of moving flights from the US to other airports in Europe, such as Amsterdam or Frankfurt, would probably meet consumer resistance.

It is understood that the outline agreement would have allowed two other American carriers, Delta and Continental, landing rights at Heathrow. But BA sees that as the thin end of the wedge.

fields.headline: The next little thing
fields.standfirst:
Terris
Astoria, London
**
fields.trailText: It soon becomes clear that Terris currently represent a triumph of style over content. Their press invokes the spirit of Joy Division, yet at a push they could maybe give Reef a run for their money. No amount of arms-akimbo grandstanding from Goodwin can atone for their lack of a single diamond-hard tune to wrap around the memory.
fields.body:
Every year they come, wan-faced desperadoes who all too willingly pronounce themselves saviours of that raddled old nag we know as rock 'n' roll. A decade ago it was the Manic Street Preachers, and now another quartet of angry young men has emerged from the badlands of south Wales, bristling with righteous interview indignation at the hopelessness of "this coma of modern life", safe in the certainty that only they can restore the soul.

You can't fault Terris for their ambition, nor deny the Newport quartet's supreme competence for the job in hand. Singer Gavin Goodwin is the Exocet in their arsenal, a bleached-blond rag doll whose appropriation of Michael Stipe's semaphore dance acts as the visual conduit for his colleagues' taut bluster. That he sings like a cow in labour enthrals and appals in equal measure.

Underpinned by Neil Dougmore's busy analogue bass pulse, and with guitarist Alun Bound lashing out angular chops from his Fender, the effect is very much as if REM's synthetic folly Monster had been their first album and not the eighth: overwrought powerplay minus the leavening properties of irony.

Impressive, for sure, but it soon becomes clear that Terris currently represent a triumph of style over content. Their press invokes the spirit of Joy Division, yet at a push they could maybe give Reef a run for their money. No amount of arms-akimbo grandstanding from Goodwin can atone for their lack of a single diamond-hard tune to wrap around the memory.

Gauche and derivative they may have been, but at least the fledgling Manics came forearmed with a school satchel's worth of ready-made doomed-youth anthems. In comparison, Terris can offer only the drilling mayhem of Searching for the Switches, where Goodwin's theatrics are upstaged by the goggle-eyed savagery of Owen Matthews, an honours graduate from the Keith Moon school of mad drummers. And when the star of the show is the drummer, something is plainly amiss.

With the music industry desperate for young heroes to worship, Terris look like a champion youth club band, prematurely thrown into the fray and winging it gamely. Not so much the future of rock as an indictment of its present malaise.

webTitle: Euro doesn't figure in these sweet dreams

fields.headline: Euro doesn't figure in these sweet dreams
fields.standfirst:
Economic and Monetary Union: special report
KPMG's report
fields.trailText: A thousand days of Blair? That's nothing. It's 4,000 days since the pound was worth as many marks as it is today. Labour's plans for entry to the euro are as firm as a partially set jelly - probably just as well, because sterling seems set to strengthen further.
fields.body:
A thousand days of Blair? That's nothing. It's 4,000 days since the pound was worth as many marks as it is today. Labour's plans for entry to the euro are as firm as a partially set jelly - probably just as well, because sterling seems set to strengthen further.

Sterling's relentless rise can be explained from two perspectives: that of the UK and that of its counterparts. Nothing unusual in that - everything in the foreign exchange markets is a function of relativity.

The growth of the economy has long ceased to be a cause of wonder. Indeed, the chancellor, Gordon Brown, has been seduced by the apparently remorseless expansion and its accompanying low inflation into believing that the banishment of boom-bust cycles is within his grasp.

Mr Brown's ambitions are laudable. One hopes, however, that he recognises the odds are stacked against this dream. It was not so very long ago that Nigel Lawson espoused similar beliefs and allowed a boom to develop which could only end in bust.

The Lawson boom peaked at the close of the 1980s, just as the Berlin Wall came down and Germany embarked on the reunification programme that fuelled an economic bubble in Europe's heartland. Britain's slump and Germany's surge constituted a dramatic divergence - the craziest circumstances in which to tie sterling to the exchange rate mechanism.

The Tories never recovered from the beating their reputation took for economic competence during the ERM debacle. Britain's economy was more fortunate. Busts bring with them seeds of new growth in the form of lower interest rates. As the economy strengthened through the second half of the 1990s, so sterling recovered its poise.

Europe, meanwhile, had to cope with the aftermath of its own boom. The final years of preparation for the euro's launch were dogged by stagnation in the mainland's big economies and anxiety about the possible consequences of binding overheating smaller economies into policies primarily determined by German and French needs.

Now the euro is weighed down by dissatisfaction about the pace of expansion of Europe's larger economies and uncertainty about the sustainability of the euro venture. Both concerns are probably overblown but, with the United States and Britain offering apparently trouble-free growth, the rewards for backing the euro seem thin.

Europe's policymakers, fretting about possible inflation in peripheral economies and the dents to their reputations, have conceded that interest rates may need to be raised to bolster the euro. But interest rates are already higher and rising in the US and Britain. Nudging up euro interest rates will thus have only a limited impact.

Bitter experience shows economists to be of little help in anticipating exchange rate trends. Traders talk of currency markets being among the most efficient in the financial arena. Indeed many players in the forex markets rely heavily on technical analysis rather than the "fundamentals" economists espouse.

Traditional models show the pound to be substantially overvalued against its European counterparts - to the tune of around 30%, using a simple purchasing power parity model.

"So what?" is the best response, for the pound has been expensive on this model for three years without obeying its "rules".

Until the US or Britain show signs of generating a resurgence of inflation, or growth in the big European economies accelerates markedly, there is little prospect of the euro turning the tide against the dollar or the pound.

British inflation seems some way off. The latest data revealed the economy to be generating a 6% year-on-year improvement in labour productivity. Unit labour costs are actually falling. The rate of growth achievable without material inflation has clearly risen on the back of the technology revolution.

Sweet dreams for now, then, Mr Brown. But what a headache entry to the euro would cause him. Only a few months ago, with sterling around DM3, the debate was about how to massage the pound down 10% or more to facilitate entry at a rate that would allow exporters to remain competitive.

Meanwhile sterling has risen almost 10% further.

While the British public remains sceptical of Europe it clearly suits the government to push the issue of the euro as far beyond the next election as possible.

A couple of years is an eternity in the currency markets. If Labour prays hard enough for economic growth on the European mainland, it may just find it reaches the promised land - eventually.

Edmond Warner is the chief executive of Albert E Sharp Securities
